author: {'steamid': '76561197998690715', 'num_games_owned': 741, 'num_reviews': 133, 'playtime_forever': 747, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 295, 'playtime_at_review': 639, 'last_played': 1711732644}
review:
A great modern take on the classic shooter Descent.
The controls are excellent, it feels so smooth and easy flying your ship. Even in some of the more labyrinthian levels it rarely gets disorientating and the combat is frantic and fun.
The graphics style sits somewhere between retro and modern and explosions are really cool with sparks and particle effects flying everywhere. I think it looks great.

This is kind of a niche style of shooter but if you like this genre you will know exactly what you're looking for and Overload has it in spades.
Now i want HD remasters of Descent 1-3 because the ports we currently have on Steam will not do.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967573741', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 16059, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 3139, 'playtime_at_review': 12919, 'last_played': 1711603989}
review:
I'm gonna give a crappy review for two reasons:
- Horrible intuitive interaction with the world, unless you read discussion and guides (especially in the alien worlds)
- I should not have to start a level completely over from scratch if I die.

I know there's a "save game" but I just don't, and I don't die a lot, but sometimes it happens and starting all the way over is crap.

So, I guess I won't finish the game because I'll die before I do that level over again.  It wasn't that much fun the first time anyway.

*uninstall*

author: {'steamid': '76561198821622363', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 230, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 97, 'last_played': 1707403934}
review:
Fantastic game, basically exactly what I expected.

So I'm near 40 years old and grew up on Descent, it was basically all there was to play on PC for years back then. This is just Descent 4, there's no real way to put it.

It's a good game, but I'm only a couple hours in at this point. Obviously, if you're a Descent fan, there's no real reason not to buy Descent 4, since those first few games were legendary. And since this game was poorly marketed even I didn't know it existed until now.

Off the bat, one of my criticisms is that you can definitely feel that the developers are from a different generation. This primarily comes from an aesthetic and movement perspective. The aesthetic of this game feels like they took the old geometric approach to Descent's design and just updated it with modern graphics engines and slightly overdid it with the lighting and effects. It's not a bad thing, but hopefully as they explore further iterations of this game, they can work on the atmosphere a bit to feel a little more organic. Turning off lens flare and decreasing some of the shinyness actually makes the game look better.

Desecrators is a more recent roguelike game that is basically Descent 4 as well, but as better movement and more intuitive, streamlined QOL in terms of how it plays. Graphically, however, Overload is better.

I like the game a lot. It's a huge amount of fun because it's just Descent. Descent will be fun no matter what.

author: {'steamid': '76561198137757483', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 178, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 46, 'last_played': 1705042189}
review: It's 1995. I'm a kid standing in line at Comp USA looking at the new VR Tech. The guy behind the counter was raving about it and was demonstrating a game called Descent. I was captivated, but not with the poor VR tech that was 25 years too early, but with the game Descent. I begged my parents to buy the game, went home and installed it on my powerhouse Pentium 2 450 Mhz PC. I was in gaming heaven. Fast forward 28 years and somehow I stumble across this gem in Steam. It brought me back. Barely dove in, but the nostalgia hit is damn fine and I enjoyed the first 2 missions so far. Has the classic Descent/Quake era vibes with mission structure and everything feels on point. Looking forward to diving in more. Fun!

author: {'steamid': '76561198063311798', 'num_games_owned': 178, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2187, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1567, 'last_played': 1704079655}
review:
[h1][i]Overload[/i][/h1]
[i]Overload[/i] is a decently enjoyable, though occasionally frustrating, game. My review is focused on the general gameplay and the campaign, played once using a joystick controller and then keyboard and mouse. I have not played multiplayer, so this review does not address it. Overall, I would give it a high 7/10. The gameplay is excellent. Yet, some maps lean more towards tedious rather than difficult. This detracts from the overall experience.

[h2]Overview[/h2]
[i]Overload[/i] is a 6 degrees of freedom (6DOF) game, where you pilot a spaceship in a "zero-G" environment. The ship is armed with a variety of energy or ammo based primary weapons and secondary missiles. The player dogfights with drones in a maze of tight corridors, finding keycards to progress through the level, and destroying a base reactor. The player is confined within tunnels and rooms, where are no open-air locations unlike other dogfighting games. Various pickups, from health to special powerups like invulnerability, enhance the player ship. There are also upgrade orbs, which can be collected to upgrade the ship between levels. For those familiar with [i]Descent[/i], the gameplay is fairly the similar; for those who are not, think of a shooter like [i]Doom[/i] with the addition of vertical movement. 

The campaign is short, with a total of 16 campaign levels and no secret levels. Depending on your playstyle, you may range between 4-10 hours for your first campaign playthrough. There are five levels of difficulty, in which higher difficulties increase enemy projectile speeds and reduce the effectiveness of health/ammo pickups. A player can save at any point and the game only autosaves at the start of a level.

[h2]Gameplay and Design Review[/h2]
Map design is the main aspect that makes or breaks the experience of [i]Overload[/i]. When done well, a map allows the gameplay to shine. Large hallways and rooms allow for greater maneuverability, which makes dogfighting far more enjoyable. Some levels have good enemy placement, in which the player is neither overwhelmed nor unchallenged. A good level can also be completed without a reliance on powerups. However, there are some frustrating maps by virtue of poor design (I say "poor" because it relies less on skill and more on foreknowledge). Certain enemy types are unavoidable if placed in short corridors. There are also cases in which particularly deadly enemies are hidden around corners or behind doors. Sometimes, this results in unavoidable damage (especially when no invulnerability power-ups or homing missiles are available). As such, this will necessitate save-scumming and cheesing enemies by knowing their location. This is especially true for higher difficulties, in which enemy projectiles move faster and health pickups are reduced. I found the final four levels to be the most frustrating because due to the combination of enemies with tight halls and blind corners. Expect frequent deaths and make liberal use of saving.

There is a decent enemy variety. Most drones are fairly simple and pursue the player, while some hang back and attack from a distance. Enemies seem to attempt to dodge player attacks, though not to an extreme degree. Weapons are a mix of slow and quick projectiles, with some enemies firing a whole barrage. Fortunately, nothing has hitscan weapons (no Class 1 driller-like enemies). So, everything is technically dodgeable. That said, there are occasions where a barrage of fast moving projectiles is essentially unavoidable. Some enemies fire homing projectiles, which can also be dodged provided that the player has room to do so (which, depending on map design, is not really possible). One criticism about enemy variety is the underwhelming variety of unique functions (consider the spider drones from [i]Descent 1[/i], which split into smaller drones when defeated). Most enemies in [i]Overload[/i] simply attack and are destroyed, which may get stale without more varied behaviors and functionality.

Regarding the player controls, [i]Overload[/i] has a nice variety of weapons and movement is smooth. The ship's maneuverability is very good, allowing for effective dodging and dogfighting (map permitting). There is a nice variety of primary weapons, which I believe are viable. Each has a unique function, rather than simply being a variation of the same basic attack. The missile variety is mostly useful, each distinct from others. Some are best saved for particular situations, based on map and enemy types. The player also has a "smash" attack (charging into enemies). While some weapons have fast projectiles, most energy weapons and all missiles have a slower travel time. This will require decent predictive aim, but the most enemies in the campaign do not usually dodge rapidly (multiplayer will doubtlessly be different). Some weapons have or can be upgraded to have tracking, which reduces the aim requirement. I found that aiming with a mouse is far better than with a controller, as the quantity of enemies in some levels requires fast and steady aiming. Playing with a mouse also allows for more reckless (therefore, fun) combat. That said, a controller is still viable to complete the campaign.

[h2]Closing Thoughts[/h2]
In conclusion, [i]Overload[/i] is a decent modern 6DOF game. The enjoyability relies primarily on the map design, in which the campaign levels are hit or miss. Beyond map design, the gameplay is smooth. I have no complaints regarding the movement or gunplay itself, beyond what is possible given the level design. Mouse and keyboard is preferable to controller, but it is playable with either. If you are looking for a more open-air dogfighting game, [i]Overload[/i] may not be your cup of tea. For those who do enjoy the 6DOF genre, I can recommend this in addition to classic titles (though, given its length and price you might hold off for a sale).

[i]Overload[/i] also works well on the Steam Deck with about 3 hours without charging (that
said, I experienced occasional stuttering).

author: {'steamid': '76561197967625604', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 12751, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3733, 'last_played': 1709892190}
review: As a massive fan of the old Descent games, I was so happy to learn that the original team that made Descent had made a successor game to them. This game is fantastic! It's even more fun than the classics! The levels are fun, the secrets are fun to hunt for, the harder difficulty levels offer a real challenge and multiply the replay value. The challenge mode is a great addition to the story mode as well. This is already one of my favorite games in my library. I only wish I had heard about it when it first came out. I love this game and you will too!

author: {'steamid': '76561198026145317', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 2593, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2237, 'last_played': 1705084229}
review:
This game provides seemingly endless amounts of enjoyment. Everything is so well made, the settings menu, the profiles, the music, a ton of challenge levels, so many secret areas in each level, huge and long levels, secret levels, nice weapons upgrades... 

I play this game since 2 years or so and playing it 30-40 minutes is enough food for one evening, because it is also very fast and dense of content. It is so time efficient!

Also, just for this game I bought a 3D mouse (space mouse), and it was totally worth it because it is 100% supported. Ah, and VR is supported too,... of course! ...and ultra wide screen as well...

This is a game that happened because experienced game devs came back and made a sequel to their 20 year old game. The EXP of the devs really shows in this game.

Play this with mouse, gamepad is not really a good option.

review:
3/5
Sparatutto con movimento libero a tre dimensioni e rotazioni, ispirato al vecchio Descent degli anni '90 (che ebbe infatti gli stessi sviluppatori). Il gioco fa il suo dovere esattamente per quello che √®, con musiche orecchiabili e un'azione dinamica. Purtroppo non brilla per il resto.
I livelli (a parte gli ultimi) sono tutti uguali rendendo ad esempio indistinguibile quella che dovrebbe essere una raffineria da un porto spaziale o da un laboratorio, che sia su uno o sull'altro dei vari satelliti di Saturno che si esplorano. Anche i nemici sono pressoch√© indistinguibili se non fosse per le diverse armi che hanno, mentre le armi forse anche troppe perch√© di 8 armi principali se useranno in genere solo 2 o 3.
Comunque consigliato, anche se alla lunga tende ad essere ripetitivo.

author: {'steamid': '76561199196172701', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 186, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 119, 'last_played': 1691875964}
review:
I think I can sum up my whole review in one question: How on earth did I miss this one??

I'm only 2 hours in and already I'm hooked. Overload is a blast and represents a piece of gaming that's been lost to us for so long and I am HERE for it. This is what I've been waiting for decades to have again and if it wasn't for the imminent release of From software's return to the Armoured Core series later this month I would be spending every gaming second playing the bejeezus out of this little gem.

For the uninitiated, Overload is a "6 degrees of freedom" (6DOF) shooter. If you like FPS games, imagine doom, but where you are essentially floating all the time and can go up and down at will as well as left, right forward back and the usual strafing movements. While it sounds like it can be confusing, it quickly becomes intuitive to move around as the controls are basically standard FPS controls with the ability to 'fly' wherever you want by pushing forward to move wherever your camera is pointing, even if that's straight up. This lends a measure of verticality to the level designs that makes your environments more immersive and combats more strategic and more intense than your average FPS. 

Overload lays on the atmosphere thick, borrowing every cue it can from it's spiritual predecessor, Descent. The sound cues, colour palette, level atmosphere, gameplay loop and even the 'corporate doing bad things' story  are taken almost wholesale from Descent so you'll feel right at home if you've come from the any of the Descent series. If what you were looking for in a game was "Descent, but modern" and somehow you missed this, stop reading my review and but this right now - you will not be disappointed at all.   If you don't know what descent is, read on and I'll tell you why this may appeal to you.

Imagine flying through a starbase or the innards of a moon in a space hovercraft armed to the teeth where every robot worker you meet wants you dead. As you work your way through the environment uncovering tunnels, rescuing colonists in cryosleep, you're looking for a reactor to detonate the facility and wipe out all the robots and whatever naughty things the bad corporate types were up to in one fell swoop. You set off the reactor's meltdown sequence and then realise, " I can't teleport out!" so now you have to dash back through the facility looking for an emergency exit before you explode with the facility....
It's a rush and a far more atmospheric and tactical experience than 90% of traditional FPS games. If the passage above piques your interest or makes you think "That could be fun" then Overload is for you. Go get it. 

If you are still on the fence, 6DOF style games bridge a gap between space combat sims like colony wars, X-wing/Squadrons or Wing Commander and traditional FPS games like Doom, Rise of the Triad, Duke Nukem, or Serious Sam. I draw the Doom comparison more due to the themes (moonbases where bad stuff happens and what was once good now becomes bad). People who like the idea of Space Combat but who typical can't get along with target tracking or flight controls will find 6DOF style games better suited to them as a 6DOF game doesn't have the typical flight control issues, target tracking or constant moving. If you stop, you hover. So, if you are worried about tracking targets or getting lost, don't worry. this game feels like playing Doom but where you have wings. 

While Overload seems to have been written for people missing Descent (like me!), the devs have made this a very friendly experience for people new to the genre. Multiple difficulty modes, an excellent automap, a little drone to help you find your way around if you get lost, a clean UI, accessibility tools, fully remappable controls and controller support with a well thought out default control scheme help a newbie get involved at their pace easily. There's also a great training mode and plenty of things to find that isn't just "shoot the bad guy and panic" so the gameplay loop doesn't feel stale as you learn. Getting started is easy and if you are used to FPS games rather than flight sim games you can even invert your Y axis to act more like you'd be used to in a traditional FPS game. 

For the vets of 6DOF games all the options you'd expect are here: Multiple weapons to discover, upgrade paths for your arsenal, plenty of secrets to find, story bites through discoverable audio logs, mouse and keyboard or flight yoke support, a plethora of graphics and audio options, VR support, online multiplayer. There's a lot to like here for the newcomer or the veteran.  

In play, the game is smooth and the textures work well. Lighting is nice and the flares/headlamps work very well to light darker spaces. Control is smooth, whatever methods you choose, and audio cues for waiting robot foes are present so you can be clued in on imminent ambushes or hidden doorways. The map is so much better than the old Descent map and reminds me a lot of Sublevel Zero's map system. Audio in combat is meaty and the weapons feel varied with some thought put in to how to make the various missiles look and feel different from one another both is visuals and effect.

As far as drawbacks are concerned there is one I've encountered - interactables in the environment aren't always super clear. The first you come across is a big red button. When you see it for the first time you may dismiss it as a light or a grill but once you know what it is you'll be looking for more. It's, admittedly, a minor gripe in an otherwise excellent game.

If you are looking for a 6DOF or your next Descent-style fix, or if you want something different from your usual FPS or space combat games, Overload has what you want. Get it, get lost in it's winding tunnels, let the story carry you away and try not to call yourself Material Defender while you're scrapping robots.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973207635', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1215, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 763, 'last_played': 1697988380}
review:
I used to be an avid Descent player back when I was a child. It really was the gateway game for me that brought me into PC gaming. Sadly, with the implosion of Parallax Studios and Interplay, what remained of Descent also imploded in the early 2000s.

That being said, I have not found a game quite like it, that plays and handles the same way since then, until I played Overload. I actually gave it a shot, and after some enjoyable game time, and some follow up research, I found that it was a group of the original Descent crew that put this project together. The music has the same grunge sound. The ship handling and level atmosphere are, for being a different engine, identical, in my opinion. I put on my VR headset with this a few times, and it was so realistic that I was getting dizzy. 

I honestly wish my little brother hadn't passed away because he was my wingman in Descent when we were teens. I believe he would have enjoyed this just as much if he could get his hands on a pair of x-52's.

If I had to give this game a rating, it would be Descent/10 with a different name. I love it. If you liked Descent, you'll like this.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987016608', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 308, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 308, 'last_played': 1689291903}
review:
It's a throwback to old 6 degrees of freedom games, like Descent, but it suffers from most the same problems and has a few new ones.

It plays almost exactly like Descent. Given how easy it is to die you'll either be saving a lot or relaying stages a lot. Games back then weren't known to be fair and this game is no different. The difficulty curve is also all over the place, going from super easy to super hard back to easy in the span on seconds. If you're fine with that you might enjoy this.

My big complaints are the environments are very samey and so are the enemies. It makes the whole experience kind of blend together. Rooms often look very similar. Given how labyrinthane these games are, samey environments make navigation a chore. The navigation drone is almost required and feels like a crutch for this.

I also wish they'd done more to modernize the game, making it more fair, while keeping the challenge. It really needed something to make it stand out from Descent. It seems the only real big addition here is the upgrade system which feels under baked.

I'd only recommend this to die hard fans of the genre but even then there's far better titles in it. Even the original Descent (which has aged like milk) had more interesting enemies and environments.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074788581', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 87, 'playtime_forever': 649, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 649, 'last_played': 1688178382}
review:
Descent is back! Overload revives the long forgotten original 6DOF FPS design. Alongside the Tribes games, Descent was one of the most unique shooters ever made. It was innovative, complex, addictive, and damn hard. With the current boomer shooter revival, it was time for Descent to make a comeback and here it is. Overload executes Descent's unique mechanics perfectly and arguably better. You once again have 6 degrees of force, labyrinthine levels full of secrets, secret levels, multiplayer that takes serious skill, and a hard-as-nails campaign. Seriously, there's a reason only 2.1% of players have beaten this game...ON MEDIUM.

The 16 missions featured here are huge and confusing to navigate. You'll be checking your automap often. Navigation is something that people have complained about for being unclear and nauseating. I can't speak for how it'll make your head or stomach feel flipping around constantly. I played Project Wingman in VR, so it's hard to really make me nauseous. By the way, this game has a VR mode and it's awesome. Regarding the confusing design, you can always check your extremely detailed map or just use the hologuide which will literally show you exactly where you need to go in real time. It'll even come back to guide you if you get separated. I'll agree with the complaint that levels aren't visually distinct much. Every few levels take place in a unique location, but they look similar until the final levels where the game goes from challenging, but fair, to cheap enemy spawns and SPAM. As a Descent fan, this game is much easier than those games. Much of the difficulty is mitigated by an easy mode (Rookie) for newcomers, upgrades between missions and the quicksave feature that can be used almost anywhere any time. No shame in spamming the F8 key.

This is as much a skill-based shooter as Quake or Unreal. You gotta move constantly and be as accurate as possible. Spatial awareness is king here. The enemy AI is just as smart as it once was in Descent. They will wait until you enter their room, dodge your shots and surround you. The enemy variety is excellent. You gotta learn their quirks to optimize. There are a ton of primary and secondary weapons each with their own strengths/weaknesses. My favorite is the Driller which kicks like a mule and drops enemies from afar. The game sounds incredible with great punch and variation to each weapons' shots. Combine that with an amazing atmospheric electronic soundtrack and it's a feast for the ears. Game doesn't look bad either. Levels are colorful and enemy designs are really distinct and memorable. There is a story here and it's well told. You'll find numerous audio logs from the personnel working in these overrun facilities fleshing out the background lore that explains what went wrong. It's also fully voice acted which is a nice touch. The story is nothing mindblowing, but it provides context. Too many boomer shooters coming out with literally no plot whatsoever which is fine, but nonetheless, a missed opportunity.

Overload is the total package. It's got everything you could possibly want in an old school shooter or Descent game. Once you've finished the campaign, you can always go back to find the secret levels, play on a higher difficulty, play the Challenge mode, play some of the user made levels or engage in deathmatch online. There are multiple endings by the way, but I won't say how to unlock them. I believe this game is worth the price. There aren't really any major gripes I have here. Maybe I'm biased since I'm a Descent fan already, but I'm feeling a 10/10. Now would someone please bring back Freespace?

author: {'steamid': '76561198185339605', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 6952, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4470, 'last_played': 1685839485}
review: It wasn't lack of marketing that killed this game; it was poor gameplay decisions made by development.  The secret levels are not exciting, only enraging.  Everything after Enceladus was a sadistic joke; targets that teleport away from danger, "ultimate" weapons that don't do anything "ultimate," every switch and ammo pod becomes a trap, and not enough smart missiles to clear every corner, targets that shoot before they have line of sight.  It became predictable, repetitive, and tedious, not engaging, and the storytelling became an overdramatic slog.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040005010', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 491, 'playtime_forever': 310, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 253, 'last_played': 1682146397}
review:
Es similar al Descent, y se nota que es un succesor espiritual:
 Tenemos la tipica, autodestruccion. Para que, al finalizar el level, tenemos que correr a contra reloj, por que activamos el dicho boton, y hay que speedrunnear todo (al estilo Warioware).
 Zonas laberinticas bajo cero. 
Podes voltear y disparar a 360 de forma libre. 
 Explosiones por donde quier, y buena banda sonora.
 Pero, las pantallas de carga(super largas para mi), sumado a que NO reapareces en el nivel, con contador de vidas. Para anular tanta pantallita de carga. Como que, le quita su escencia. 
 Sumado a la mala optimizacion. Como que, causa algo de rechazo.

 8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198006804970', 'num_games_owned': 675, 'num_reviews': 98, 'playtime_forever': 3193, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3193, 'last_played': 1679619824}
review:
A pseudo-remake of the Descent titles from the 90's - which if you haven't played those titles I highly recommend it. You can pick them up on Steam or GOG, and use a source port like "Descent Rebirth" to get better functionality than DOSBox. But back to this review.

The game plays exactly like the "originals" (for those not familiar, they play mostly like a first person shooter, but in 3 dimensions), with slick 6dof combat in enclosed levels.
Weapons feel balanced (none of that godawful plinking away at 10,000 hp grunts that you sometimes see), movement is response, and the visuals are fine. No performance issues either.

My only complaints are that the explosions are a bit too detailed; obscuring whats behind them for too long, and the map sucks. (The 2nd to last level is also a nightmare to navigate).

In short, worth a play (definitely on sale, probably at full price if you're a fan of this style of game).

author: {'steamid': '76561197993312995', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 217, 'playtime_forever': 8, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8, 'last_played': 1610304499}
review:
I am a 52 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing Overload. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son found this game at Christmas, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game world and started playing but I was stuck on what you were supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he helped me. Loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.
Thank you <3

Overload has tasteless graphics, boring level design, and forgettable music, but still it's really fun to play and I'm happy it exists.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968570137', 'num_games_owned': 370, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 4044, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3028, 'last_played': 1675734457}
review:
I grew up on the original Descent games, and was very disappointed by Descent 3. Luckily Overload does not have the same problems that D3 did. It stays very true to the original D1 and D2 formulas of "clear the mine, find the exit, memorize the escape route, blow up the reactor, get out before the mine explodes." This time your ship has a more interesting selection of weapons, and an upgrade system that you'll probably never max out, even in a New Game +.  In short, it's as faithful of a throwback to Descent as you can get. It's basically Descent remastered, with the gameplay polished to a mirror shine.

Short version: If you liked Descent, you need to get this game. If you've never played a 6DOF FPS before, this is the game to get because Overload does the best job executing on the idea. Highly recommend.

Does Overload do anything wrong?

One thing I wished they did was to have a better tutorial. There's a few new features that can be easily missed or misunderstood. For example, better explaining what those red circles found in the levels are, how to spot secret doors, the fact that holding down the flare button will launch a sticky flare, and the smash attack which seems to really only be useful for speedrunners, but apparently gives you back shield energy? See, it's not clearly explained in the game. Players have to consult FAQs and guides understand what the ship can do.

The level design is routinely dark, relying on headlights and flares for visibility. I'm always playing with my headlights on. Apparently flares do alert enemies (again, needs a clearer tutorial). And most of the exist require little to no planning to get to when the reactor explodes. Your map only lets you drop one marker, and sticky flares is not mentioned in-game (that I can remember). So if they tuned that part of the game we would have had some more exciting races to the exit.

All in all, the game is great. Played the game twice and I'm now going through the challenge modes. I may even buy the two community packs for the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982788610', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 692, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 553, 'last_played': 1676162057}
review:
If you were a fan of the original Descent games, or are a dad who grew up playing these games hoping for your kids to have similar adventures I cannot recommend this game highly enough.  Awesome fun, and hits all the right notes for a spiritual successor of Descent.  This is a love letter to the fans and I for one dearly appreciate it!

I had to tone down the difficulty for my first play-through as I haven't played a solid 6-DOF space shooter since Descent III released.

author: {'steamid': '76561198301669039', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 226, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 226, 'last_played': 1673825278}

author: {'steamid': '76561197971072603', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1879, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 238, 'last_played': 1704062623}
review:
Descent, the game which Overload is intentionally the spiritual successor to, is one of my favorite games of all time.  Overload delivers on that intent.  Let me take a step back to show you my history with Descent, and with other nostalgic re-releases, so I can truly tell you how much I appreciate Overload.

It was the first game I really got into as a kid.  I couldn't beat the boss on the 7th level, so I played the first 7 levels (up until I got to the boss room) over and over again.  I got to the point I literally beat the first three levels with my eyes closed.  Not just beat, but 100% - picked up the hostages, hit all the secrets, killed all the enemies, blew the reactor, and escaped in the time limit.  It was on the easiest difficulty, but hey, I was like 7 years old.

Flash forward to remakes of games.  I've played many expansions and sequels to games I've loved, and come away with a bitter taste in my mouth.  Nostalgia plays a huge part in my interest of a game, but not in my enjoyment of it.  In order for a game to be enjoyable, it has to be a good game.  It has to take what I've loved and retain it, and take what could be improved and made better.  A prime example of this is the Star Wars: Battlefront remake.  I loved the original Battlefront 1 and 2.  I hated the remake of Battlefront 1, and did not even bother with Battlefront 2.

Now, let's actually talk about this game.  It is close to perfect as a spiritual successor to Descent.  One thing it does, that very few games nowadays do, is it doesn't have a pricing plan that's designed to milk players for all they're worth.  But that's not the half of it.  Overload maintains the high-octane action and 6D freedom that Descent had.  

The main campaign is much improved, with the addition of voice acting and and upgrade system, as well as some missions that aren't just "kill reactor and leave".  You actually get a benefit for rescuing the hostages (er...collecting the cryo-chambers) instead of just getting points.  The addition of the challenge mode is very welcome.

However, there are a few things I think could be improved.  For one, the lighting contrast is so stark, that sometimes it's hard to see what's going on.  I think it was easier in Descent to tell enemies apart, because enemies had a distinct shape and color that you could clearly see.  In Overload, the eyes glow so bright you can't really see much of the robots.  The textures in the map don't do a good job of orienting you which way is up.

The secrets in the maps are sometimes very arbitrary.  Some doors are locked, and it's not very clear how to unlock them.  Sometimes there's a button you can destroy to unlock or open a door.  Often times I'll destroy one and then not even know what it did or what it opened.  I think this was also a problem sometimes in Descent II.

It would help in the campaign if there was a way to keep track of how many upgrade points you've found so far in a level, as well as if you knew how many there were.  That way I know if I want to keep searching or make my way to the reactor.  Similarly, an option to replay the level if you didn't get everything.

And, while Overload does have some game modes that Descent didn't (or didn't invest as heavily into), one thing that Descent had that Overload doesn't is a cooperative mode.

Overall, the game hits the nostalgia button just right.  It feels like Descent in all the right ways, and improved in just the right places.  Is it perfect?  No.  But it's a million times better than most reboots.

author: {'steamid': '76561198347095877', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 7421, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1478, 'last_played': 1702172108}

author: {'steamid': '76561197979931562', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 218, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 218, 'last_played': 1640956039}
review: As it was promising a return to retro-style action, I was excited to play this game, as I was raised on 90's shooters. Sadly, this does not build on the foundations of the original to create something new and interesting the way Doom did, but rather, it's a return to repetitive level design, samey enemies and simple gameplay that doesn't engage the way it used to, now that there are so many better games to choose from. In addition, the game has an annoying habit of making you search through every nook and cranny for upgrades - or you're irrevocably handicapped for the rest of the game. This kills the flow as you might find yourself alt-tabbing to a wiki rather than sniffing through the entire map after you've already cleared it. Between the unimproved gameplay, lack of any compelling story, the frustrating hunt for secrets and the repetitive design, there isn't enough to earn a recommendation.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972318629', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 6135, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5713, 'last_played': 1681202138}

review:
Overload really does feel like a modern sequel to Descent series. The level interiors, weapons, enemies, and the level design that makes you think how to maneuver your ship in all 3 axes to get the best out of situations, are all there, with just better looks.

For multiplayer, I am glad the option is there, but you know very well that nobody plays games like this except you and me.

review: I bought this game for the multiplayer.  I had to download a mod for multiplayer to work and my friends had to guide me through getting it setup.  But once I got it working it was a lot of fun versing my friends in cramped maps and action everywhere.  The weapons were fun to use and took skill to aim.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976026714', 'num_games_owned': 1717, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 792, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 792, 'last_played': 1670778116}
review:
A great throwback to a legendary game.  Really hearkens back to what I liked about the orginal Descent games that I played in the 90s.  It has a nice level of polish on top of that, but doesn't dramatically change the formula.

The exception to that is the upgrades system.  I don't know how I feel about that system, it doesn't take a lot away from the game: as a casual player I was able to upgrade my favorite weapons without wasting a ton of time looking for upgrades or resorting to a walkthrough.  But at the same time, there's nothing exciting about finding secrets.

After completing this game I went back and played the first few levels in a source port of the original Descent.  This game does elevate the genre from a gameplay perspective but, surprisingly, the plot of the source game was better - even though the new game has voice acting.

review: Decent fans rejoice, this game is awesome.   The game as-is runs smooth as butter at high resolutions and frame rates. It looks REALLY good in VR.  My only wish is that they added more enemies and boss levels (maybe this is in here but I just have not played far enough).  As someone who grew up with Decent and other similar flying games this really hit home in VR for me. My kids also loved it since they could fly around in the easy mode without any damage from running into walls.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080799811', 'num_games_owned': 169, 'num_reviews': 96, 'playtime_forever': 1588, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1585, 'last_played': 1669978121}
review:
TLDR: Get Aquanox 1 instead

It's not a bad game, this is a great game, technically speaking. It's well put together, the overall format, the gameplay loop, the basic good things.
I just can't recommend it.

There's a story of some sort, but I ignored it because the premise is bad.
80% of the game just has you as an anonymous pilot destroying miner robots due to reasons.
In the final 20%, there's alien levels, where the pilot actually gets a name and is related to the characters, and is actually cool on the face of it, but is too little too late.

It's a fun game, sure, but it's hard to say if it ever felt like it was supposed to feel.
A lot of the game was spent finnicking the controls to get them just right.
It's most fun to rotate around the enemies "trichording", but there isn't much space for that.
It's a step down from Aquanox in many ways, story and sound among them, of course.

On sound, some of the guns sound good while others sound really bad, and some of them are just really not worth using.
The default gun Impulse sounds good, but isn't so great to use, while the Cyclone is great to use, but sounds like a flimsy laser. 
Driller sounds great, but is very weak. There's a shotgun equivalent (not Flak), and it sounds great, but it's semi-auto fire. 
I have a most hated gun, Reflex, simply because it sounds so bad. It does not sound like something that would hurt a person, nevermind metal.
The worst gun is Thunderbolt, it just really is not worth it. It's a charge shot, semi-auto, you hold then release the mouse to shoot. You have to charge every shot for it to be useful. So sluggish.
There's the Lancer weapon, but there's little ammo for it. It's an endgame weapon, and by that point you can't upgrade anything anymore.
It really doesn't meaningfully differentiate itself from Impulse, besides charging the puzzle locks in the last levels (like the Thunderbolt).

I forgot, the levels. They are fairly lengthy, which is nice, but some of them are symmetric, and I'm like, what's the point, are you kidding me? The environments already look similar to one another, having symmetry makes it worse, and it's plainly uninteresting.
Another reviewer said the levels are just abstract things put together, and he is right, I noticed this right away. The story says the robots are miners, and so the levels are mining structures, but that is bullshit, it obviously isn't the case, visually.

The part I hated the most was the visual design.
1. It's unclear which objects are interactable and which aren't, and they share designs. For example, there's two glowing red lights, one is a circle, another a triangle. The circle one activates doors around the level, the triangle does nothing. If the circle was interactable, maybe it should glow green instead? Basic things like that.
2. Enemies, when exploding, cause too much visual noise even at lowest particle settings.

I also hated the fact the sticky flare glows less than the ordinary flare.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015812595', 'num_games_owned': 438, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1019, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 590, 'last_played': 1675109436}
review:
This is basically a Descent game in everything but name. Also made by ex-Parallax Software people, from what I understand. So it's actually quite authentic. Great action, great controls, great dynamics, awesome music (very reminiscent of Descent 1 and 2, but even better imho). Looks and plays excellent and generally a fun game for old-schoolers and modern gamers alike.
One advice: Don't forget to save often. This game is not a cakewalk by any stretch of imagination and it doesn't autosave for you every minute like a lot of modern games do. So you need to keep this in mind.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971905856', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1710, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1669, 'last_played': 1700192029}

author: {'steamid': '76561198106354220', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 940, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 940, 'last_played': 1533417941}
review:
This is an exceptional remake of Parallax's classic, Descent; A fully 3D, use a joystick, epic shooter.

Consider this game the Quake of space. You fly a cool ship with cool guns and you run around blowing up clever robots who hunt you and have the same weapons you do. Add to that, that each mission is essentially a maze where you need to rescue hostages and find and make it to the exit after blowing the reactor and starting the self destruct timer.

If you played the original Descent games, you'll feel right at home. 
If you didn't, you need to try this.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981795202', 'num_games_owned': 220, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 972, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 631, 'last_played': 1700940233}
review:
This game is great, and I highly suggest you give it a try.  If you were a fan of Decent back in the day, then you will love this one.  Runs great on Steam Deck.  If you want cloud sync to work with a windows desktop, be sure to install the Windows version of Overload on the Steam Deck, by default it loads the Linux version of Overload. The Linux version still cloud syncs and the save game files are interchangeable between the two, but Value is keeping them separated in the cloud.

Note for Steam OS users: If you run Multiple controllers, you might find the controller has stopped responding in the menu.  Go to "Reorder Controllers" and set the preferred controller to #1.  The in-game menu offers the ability to change the controller but I find Steam OS controller position swapping easier.

Valve this game deserves a "Playable" status. At the time of writing this review it is listed as "Unknown"

author: {'steamid': '76561198002732574', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 3233, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 681, 'last_played': 1698201379}
review:
This game is fantastic, for someone who likes 3D movements, navigating tunnels, and finding secrets.

When I played Descent for the first time in the 90's, it blew my mind - 6 degrees of freedom, 10+ weapons!  Even more stuff than Doom!

Now, decades later, I played the updated Doom, and I wondered if there was an updated Descent as well.  Yes, it's this game (not Descent Underground, which is not great).

Everything about this game gives me flash backs of my childhood -- zipping around the mines, destroying robots in tight corridors.  Being older now, I have more patience looking for secrets and exploring, and this game delivers on that too.  Everything about this game just screams fun, and I could not put it down.  My biggest complaint about Descent as a kid -- navigating the maze, has been helpfully solved with a guide bot that leads you through (but doesn't reveal secrets).  Unlike Descent 3, there aren't any obtuse puzzles that require you to visit a Wiki.  

The game is all about zooming down tunnels and blasting robots.  With a side helping of exploration and secrets finding.

My complaints about the game are minor -- 2nd tier upgrades can't be undone (unlike new Doom games, where you can swap on the fly).  The orientation of my ship in automap can be tricky to discern.  And finally, the hud turns off by itself sometimes and doesn't come back unless I reload an earlier save (I'm mostly playing on Steam Deck, if that matters).  

Someone did mention that if you don't find secrets in a level, and progress on, you just missed out on them for the rest of the run.  That's correct.  The upgrades are mostly discoverable if you look at the minimap, as they tend to be either in side paths, or in a bulging box that sticks out from the of an area.  There are also excellent Steam guides and Jbode's videos revealing them, though I do understand that tracking these down may not be for everyone.

In short, I missed Descent, and if you are tired of playing the same FPS over and over again, this might be something to look forward to too.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970187929', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 1049, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1049, 'last_played': 1668068367}
review:
I played the game in VR only.
I was not familiar with the original Descent games that this is based on.
I played the campaign only.
This is a good 6DOF shooter with a minimal story.
The graphics are good / music is awesome and (in VR) this is definitely an intense experience.
I found the difficulty pretty high at the start (probably because I was not using the right tactics) but eventually I got quite comfortable with the mechanics.
I would imagine this would be quite challenging in VR for new players but I did not experience any issues with motion sickness myself.

author: {'steamid': '76561197962437715', 'num_games_owned': 288, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 563, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 176, 'last_played': 1666917642}
review:
It's a lot of old-school fun, and looks great too! 

Sometimes I feel a bit overwhelmed with navigation and getting lost. Usually this is short-lived - I just try to pay attention and notice the hints the level designers gave (arrows, colours, etc.). Trusting that they did their best to test what your experience might be and planned accordingly to help you have a good time bears fruit in this game. e: eventually I learned there was a holo tourguide available at the push of a button

I play this without VR, though I have a headset. It's good both ways, but I'll probably stick to non-VR.

After playing for a bit more, the level variety is a bit lacking. I'd love to have some different levels that feel different. I guess they are all space stations and mining stations so how much variety can we have but i dunno; maybe it would be cool to be in one of those big spinny habital rings? going through the vents or something? would be nicer to see something a different colour at least.

e: finished the game; the level design changes eventually, though IMO it should have happened sooner! the later levels can be confusing. lots of flying around after you've killed everything to try to find the thing you obviously missed, and you can't use your holo thingy anymore.

overall i would recommend the game, but it needed a bit more polish

author: {'steamid': '76561197993924705', 'num_games_owned': 319, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 679, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 661, 'last_played': 1664825358}
review:
Let's start by saying that I've never played a Descent game in my life, so my views are in no way affected by nostalgia.

Six degrees of freedom is, from a design standpoint, both really cool and a very fertile ground for new experiences. But also, because of how uncommon these types of games are, it's a dangerous gamble. The rules are different, the dynamics are different, and the player has to get used to a lot of new concepts, so you can't use the same tools as if you were making a traditional FPS.

I really want to say that Overload nails it. It gets a lot of things right, with really fun combat and visuals, movement feels very nice with a lot of customization options, a compelling, well acted story and loads of content.

But the reality is that it gets more wrong than it gets right. There's a lot to discuss regarding outdated design decisions and problems with the control scheme, but the main issues, for me, reside in the level design.

The navigational issues present in 6DOF games are not helped at all by abstract, Classic Doom-like level design. With such a developed story and lore, you'd think that the levels would be constructed as recognizable bases, science labs, mine shafts, etc. But this is almost never the case. Only late game are some environments used to communicate a place, but still with the same labyrinthine level design, made even worse by the fact that certain very important guiding systems are disabled. In general, nothing identifies what is up, down, left or right, and areas do not flow logically. So, you get lost. A lot. Adding to this the abundance and importance of secrets, most of the game is spent floating around being unsure of where you're going.

There are many other things wrong. The weapon selection system is truly terrible, the default control scheme is weird, and the game kind of overstays its welcome. But most of these thing could be forgiven if the levels were designed with easy navigation in mind. It saddens me, because Revival didn't deserve to go under, and a sequel could have fixed all these issues and made a truly amazing game. And what's here is a fun and unique experience.

I can't sincerely recommend it, unless you're ready for a particular kind of experience. The kind that Descent fans would enjoy. This definitely feels like a game made for the fans, but sometimes, relying on nostalgia ends up working against you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037605810', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 600, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 233, 'last_played': 1695494883}
review:
Only 2 levels in and I'm loving the game so far.

I used to play the original Descent in the 90s and it was a great game with a fairly unique story, a very creepy atmosphere and a lot of fun.

Overload captures all of that, for the experienced Descent player, the more you play overload the more you remember features from Descent.

The gameplay is a lot of fun, the effects are beautiful there is nice original music. The single player and campaign story are highly appreciated in today's world of multi-player only games.

I have tried Descent: Underground in the past but it was always too buggy to play for long so I cannot really compare the gameplay.
Overload is what I've been waiting for as a Descent fan, a great game resurrected.

There's a nice mix of sci-fi, secret hunting exploration and obviously a lot of combat.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054542558', 'num_games_owned': 480, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 1550, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 112, 'last_played': 1664367743}
review:
Before buying this, I snagged and played:
Descent 1, 2, & 3 (Grew up with these because I'm old now) as well as Sublevel Zero Redux.

The first few minutes in Overload made me think,
"ahh, yess... they've done it"
Modern Descent with all the benefits of history.  Feels almost perfect out of the box with a controller.  

Combat, compared to aforementioned games, is phenomenal enough to warrant Challenge Modes (aka horde arenas).  Everything else is Descent... SPOT-ON.

Congratulations team, you nailed it and made a small dream come true.  This is the shyt.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960957941', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 619, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 619, 'last_played': 1661905871}
review:
Play, but on a deep discount.  Fun but gets a little long in the tooth at the end.  

Zoomer trivia: Long in the tooth is an olde timey expression meaning something gets old after awhile.

For example: "Isn't the TikTok trend of [insert current TikTok trend here] getting a bit long in the tooth at this point?"

Use this to impress your non existent internet friends for .25 seconds!

author: {'steamid': '76561198022300365', 'num_games_owned': 345, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 739, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 263, 'last_played': 1703452999}
review: This is rather a fun game.  The plot is mostly to be ignored, its really about exploring the levels and enjoying the visual and sound design.  It also runs really smooth which helps with the prior things.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970394230', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 474, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 414, 'last_played': 1661657541}
review: Six degrees of freedom games are rare, and this is one of the most fun I have found. It is the spiritual sequel to the spiritual successor to the Descent games from the 90:s. I just tried this with two Thrustmaster T16000M to get analogue sticks in all 6 degrees of freedom and that was more interesting than just having 5 degrees of freedom as you do with a normal gamepad. The optimal game of this kind would probably be skirmishes in space with huge battlecruisers that you fight from the inside while fighting small fighters, Star Wars style as opposed to this exploration of mining shafts but this game is good at what it does and enjoyable in its own right. One good enhancement over the original Descent is the quest arrow or hologram guide, because I am mostly here for the fighting and not the 3D-puzzling.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965066413', 'num_games_owned': 671, 'num_reviews': 684, 'playtime_forever': 174, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 107, 'last_played': 1661820074}

author: {'steamid': '76561197960999276', 'num_games_owned': 997, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 359, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 131, 'last_played': 1664009836}
review:
Holy ****!!!  
This is [strike]Descent 4[/strike]....  I mean "Overload".

I am an old school Descent fan, having played all the games back on their original release in the 1990's.  Even bought a Voodoo FX 3000 card just to play Descent 3 on back in the day of the Pentium 2 processors.  I have been playing Descent 1 ~ 3 recently (using the Rebirth Mod) and having a blast.  So I was searching Steam trying to find an updated Descent clone to play and I stumbled across Overload.  I was reading about it and found that it was made by the original Descent Team.  Instant buy for me.  I have been playing the game and it is great.  Great graphics, great sound, great enemies, great 6D maps with tons of hidden paths and items.  I was stoked <3.

Then I was reading in the forums about how the Dev Team had to shut down in 2019 since sales were poor and my heart broke  </3.  These guys did a hell of a job on this game and they should have been met with fanfare.... 

I really hope [strike]Interplay[/strike]....  I mean Revival Productions get another chance to make more great games like this.  
This Dev Team is legendary and it shows.

author: {'steamid': '76561199094095550', 'num_games_owned': 51, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 1656, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1397, 'last_played': 1678219884}
review:
Highly recommended. It is 2018 version of descent with every aspect better than original. Looks great, sounds fantastic. Fully playable on steam deck and I was able to finish full campaign using following setup:
left stick for sliding,
right for quick turning,
gyro used for precise targetting,
triggers for forward and backward
back buttons for firing and weapons switching 

With that said, it still plays best with mouse and keyboard on higher difficulty levels.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077765902', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 3438, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2245, 'last_played': 1692555601}
review: A lot like the DESCENT series which was made by the same people 24 years earlier. I liked the variety of weapons (though not as large as Descent 2 or 3 but more than Descent 1). My main complaints are about the upgrades - I couldn't find enough in my first play-through (though this is now solvable because the community post has all locations), and also the fact that the two versions of fully upgraded weapons are mutually exclusive (otherwise there would be more variety than Descent 2 and 3). The level editor was something I really immersed myself in in 2018 and made a few levels using some I had made for Descent 1 or 2 in 2006 (as well as Titan Core and an Overload version of Tethys Mine, which by the way is possible on Insane but just extremely hard to avoid getting blown up at the very beginning - I have done it). I had ideas for a six-level campaign which I hope to complete sometime - currently the first 2 levels are complete and the third is somewhat done and accessible if you can find where people upload campaigns (I remade the Silph Co 3D maze at the start and put a few things in). There is still some material from 2006 to use but I came across the fact that too many cubes were still needed in Level 4 and somehow lost my motivation, but hey, maybe it will come back in 2030 as it took 12 years last time. Also I am very bad at Multiplayer but maybe it was because I had not found how to enable trichording at the time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022649244', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1247, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 795, 'last_played': 1659394116}
review: I love the freedom of 6DOF. I loved Descent and now I love Overload.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007145952', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 103, 'playtime_forever': 826, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 265, 'last_played': 1659492648}
review:
Descent 2.5, Descent 2 brought to modern standards, Descent 2-2, whatever ya wanna call it. The OG Descent devs got together to make a spiritual successor to a classic, but forgotten FPS series, And boy what a ride it is!

For those of you who are unfamiliar a bit of a history lesson. Descent was released in 1995 by Parralax Software, it was a First person shooter that used an honest-to-goodness 3D engine and instead of being locked on the floor and running around as an infantryman, like in every other FPS game before and most since, you are in a Zero-G environment and pilot a vehicle thats more akin to an Attack helicopter with an array of energy weapons and missiles, only you can freely rotate, and strafe in any Axis. You thought circle strafing in quake or unreal was nuts, Add a vertical element to it! And there you have Descent! You fought Mining and security robots gone hayware from a computer virus in all the games, rarely killing actual people (Mostly accidentally in 3, completley on purpose in 3 Mercs). I completely missed out on underground but I've heard it ended up being and unfinished buggy multiplayer-focused mess that was canned by a shady publisher who screwed the developers over in the end.

As A kid I played a LOT of Descent 1 and 3, never quite beating them (1 had limited lives and very long levels, 3 was buggy and I could not progress due to a crash bug on the moon mission, I did play and beat the uneven Mercenaries expansion however), only picking up 2 when it became available for GOG, 2 Ended up being my favorite of the three for its incredible pacing, UX improvements, and Soundtrack (nevermind some VERY satisfying weaponry). 

1 was innovative and a technical marvel at the time but could be a slog and had cheap enemies. 2 Ironed out a lot of 1's rough edges, by introducing an optional guide bot that was locked behind a cage at the start of each mission that would lead you to each key and eventually to the reactor or boss, passing up secrets as a drawback (it would come back annoy you like Navi or Fi in the Legend of Zelda games if you deviated from the path). and 3 (and it's expansion Mercenaries) was structured a little more like Goldeneye over DOOM, being more objective focused rather than "Get all the keys and kill the reactior and escape" adding in puzzle elements to the mix, while it helped vary up the level design, the implementation was hit-or-miss.

The reason why I went on this history lesson is because Overload Faithfully preserves everything good about D 1-2 (and some elements of 3, like being able to spawn your guidebot anywhere and some weapons) and then improves on nearly everything it brings back. Really writing the history of the descent games will explain 80% of what overload is

Descent's weapons did feel kind of samey but in Overload, They all have different tactical applications and gimmicks. There's even an upgrade system that allows you to fine tune your playstyle and encourages exploration more! Audio logs flesh out the story, SPAWNERS CAN FINALLY BE DESTROYED, and modern options can even help alleviate some of the motion sickness the series is famous for inducing (FOV Sliders reportedly, I never had this issue but I know its been a hard sell when I try and hype it up to my friends)

And if you want it Has VR!

author: {'steamid': '76561197972494162', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 149, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 106, 'last_played': 1658519653}
review: Descent is one of my all time favorite games and it's amazing to play that style of game again with better graphics and especially in VR!

author: {'steamid': '76561198843698309', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 103, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 82, 'last_played': 1673421873}
review:
Descent in VR.  

A game of it's time.  Not sure if able to recommend when compared to what other space shooters in VR may look and play like.   Other space shooters may be more realistic or more open world, this is not those things, even though lighting and many effects are beautiful, graphics pretty crisp and nice, think of levels having a very old school basic Doom levels type layout.  Start at one point, find some keys, kill some bad ships, exit isn't too far, on to the next one.    As of this writing this review have less than 2 hours total game time, but I assure you, enjoyed every single minute of it and will go back at some point when this itch needs a scratch, but very hard to make a general recommendation as you can read in every other review, this game is in essence Descent in VR, so if you want that, it is here and pretty damn perfect.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062196842', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1514, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1117, 'last_played': 1691352604}
review: This game is everything I could have asked for as a Descent fan. The gameplay is perfect. The movement is smooth and the controls are precise. The weapons and tools you have come to rely on from Descent are all there in updated, lovely flavors due to the fantastic upgrade system that offers a lot of replayability. I could not have asked for a more faithful revival of a series and genre that I love so dearly. Invest in getting your controls how you like them before you start and it'll pay off a thousand times over as you experience a freedom of movement other games don't really reach.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970739339', 'num_games_owned': 676, 'num_reviews': 564, 'playtime_forever': 924, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 924, 'last_played': 1657488723}
review:
I first played Overload a few years back when it was in Twitch Prime's offerings. Given that service's slow, corruptive sublimation by Amazon and the fact that Overload is on its own merits a very good game, I had absolutely no issues repurchasing it here on Steam, especially given that I didn't have the DLCs or a VR headset the first time around.

Overload is a newer title from many of the people who worked on the classic Descent series, including the co-founders of Parallax Software and composers from all three Descent games, and plays very much like those games with a variety of quality-of-life improvements, as well as VR support. The game is fully playable in VR but the limited FOV coupled with the intense lighting effects made it less comfortable then playing it standard.

For those unfamiliar, Overload, like its spiritual predecessors, is a "6DOF" FPS, meaning "Six degrees of freedom". As you are in a spacecraft within a zero-gravity environment, you can move, look, and fire in any direction, and so can your enemies. If this sounds like it would cause you to become nauseated or disoriented, it very well might, so beware. It also has harsh, tron-esque lighting effects that can readily cause eye strain on some monitor setups or if you have sensitive eyes to begin with, like myself.

Here's the setup: It is the year 2118. You are a gunship pilot stationed aboard the service vessel Iberia, bound for the moons of Saturn, to which you have been sent by mining corporation Juno Offworld in response to a distress call from their subsidiary of Cronus Frontier. Their complement of "autonomous operators"; a fleet of curiously aggressive-looking mining robots, have seemingly gone violently haywire. Assisted by the Iberia's AI, Mara, you will have to enter Cronus' various mining and support bases, battle the auto-ops, retrieve the cryopods of any survivors you might find, and then, destroy the reactor and beat a hasty retreat before the facility collapses in on you.

Overload's campaign plays out over a series of increasingly complex and mazelike levels littered with enemies, equipment and secret areas. You have a full 3D map screen upon which you can place markers for navigation, as well as a "hologuide", a construct similar to the Guidebot of the Descent series, but this time completely invulnerable. The hologuide by default will lead you to the next sequential objective to proceed through the mine, and can be instructed at any time to instead lead you to supplies, enemies, or cryotubes. Sometimes it can find secrets in this way, but for most you will be at the mercy of your own wits for those- or at least, a number of very helpful steam guides.

You begin Overload's campaign with a simple "Impulse" dual laser cannon and dumbfire "Falcon" missiles, but you can find a range of new primary and secondary weapons. There are both energy-based primaries that draw from your ship's energy supply, shared with your lights, afterburner, flares and hologuide, and ballistic ones that draw from a seperate ammo pool: My personal favorites are the Cyclone, a rapid triple-shot energy cannon, and the Crusher, a nasty dual shotgun that imparts considerable impact force on enemies, often screwing up their aim. Secondaries include various missile types and a few outliers: Rapid-firing Swarmers, seeking Hunters, mine-like Creepers and more. In genre tradition, Overload trickles in new weapons and enemies one or two at at time per level over the course of the campaign, and the weapons can often be obtained one level earlier then they are formally introduced in the pre-level briefing screen if you find them in secret areas.

New to Overload versus Descent is a persistent upgrade system. Scattered throughout the levels, both in the open and in secret areas, are green glowing Upgrade Points, as well as purple Super Upgrade points. Every weapon has an upgrade track with a linear upgrade for the first level, bought with the regular points, and then a choice of two final upgrades, purchased with the super points. Passive upgrades are linear and include, but are not limited to, more damage reduction, reduced self-damage from explosions, more movement and boosters speed, and removing the energy cost from boosting, flares and headlights.
It is possible to fully upgrade everything, though not in a single run. There is however a new game plus feature.

Overload also follows in the footsteps of Descent 3 in particular, with a greater emphasis on plot, character and worldbuilding. Each mission is prefaced by a briefing from Mara, who also periodically contacts you in-mission with updates about the evolving situation in the Saturn system. Along with scattered audiologs, all of these are fully voiced, telling the story of a mysterious plot by Cronus head honcho Gabriel Kantor to "prepare humanity for the future," and the events leading up to the auto-ops' sudden attack.

At the time of this writing I have not sampled the multiplayer mode or the two DLC campaigns, comprised of community-made levels made official, with half of proceeds from such going to the level creators.

Overload is of course a treat for returning Descent veterans, but I urge anyone interested in old-school first person action to give it a try. It's not typically mentioned in the context of the retro-FPS revival but I believe it  deserves to be counted alongside games like DUSK, HROT and Supplice.

review:
The original crew that created Descent made this game. It truly is an homage to the Descent series, and is beloved by Descent fans and new players alike. The engine used and the quality and polish put into the programming, netcode, enemy algorithms, graphics, textures, shadows, and lighting are all fantastic. I highly recommend.

[spoiler]There are a lot of hitscan enemies, but that's my only complaint.[/spoiler]

Plays very enjoyably as a modern version of Descent - i.e. a first-person shooter with strong emphasis on 3D spacial movement. Also, thanks for the hologuide!

author: {'steamid': '76561198004053899', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 154, 'playtime_forever': 1599, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 634, 'last_played': 1656115531}
review:
It's basically Descent, but done better, with more QoL and with new maps and game modes. Plus it has branching upgrades, New Game+ and several difficulty levels, so there's lots of replay value.

Some of the near-endgame levels are a bit annoying to get through but overall it's a solid 6DOF game and definitely recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079469175', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 629, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 629, 'last_played': 1640918254}
review:
I don't understand how this game doesn't have "Overwhelming" positive reviews. Anyone giving this a negative review is either WAY too nitpicky or isn't a fan of this type of game. I was always a big fan of the Descent games (all of them). I'd always wished they would make a new version of the original with today's graphics. This game does exactly that. It's a slightly different story, different name, but same ideas and most of the same cool weapons and features. But, who really plays a game like this for the story? I just love gliding around blasting stuff and figuring out the little puzzles (which amounts to finding key cards and hidden switches).

I like everything about Overload. The music, sound effects, the story, and of course the graphics. Most of all, I enjoy trying to find all the secrets, power-ups, and captives in each level. I love it when you enter an area, the exits all get blocked and alarms go off. There's going to be a fight. This is classic FPS beautifully rendered and perfect control. The controls by the way can be completely setup your way.

Do I recommend this game? Absolutely. If you're an old-school DOS/WIN95 FPS game fan from the early 90's, you need this one. 10/10 for me. I would love to see more from this team, especially a sequel to this one, perhaps something akin to Descent: Freespace (another old favorite - a starfighter game you can actually play that doesn't have 40,000 buttons to remember).

author: {'steamid': '76561197993169377', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 665, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 650, 'last_played': 1654311848}
review:
Worthwhile whether or not you played the original Descent for the low low price of $27 USD. As someone who played the original Descent all the way back in 1996 as a child, this game was and is very much a big nostalgia trip. Indeed, it was made by many of the members of the same dev team who worked on the original game at Parallax studios back in the day. 

If you enjoy shooters and dungeon crawlers, don't pass this game up.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981983657', 'num_games_owned': 61, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 111, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 111, 'last_played': 1650848331}
review: This game makes great use of full movement and maneuverability that you expect from a space combat sim. In practice, you can't make full use of it because every zone you go into are narrow corridors that don't allow you to make use of said movements, especially when you have enemies to deal with! And it's even worse when not only do you have both your weapons and thrusters tied to the same energy bar, but these enemies also appear from out of nowhere and in blindspots where you can't really dodge when you need to. It certainly doesn't help when the available upgrades seem paltry compared to the amount you actually need. Maybe this is where the Strike Suit Infinity series comes to play in this genre...

author: {'steamid': '76561198090118360', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 480, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 480, 'last_played': 1616307699}
review:
Playing this game with twin  HOTAS and flight pedals turns it into an action shoot em up.
But the first person view makes it look like there is plenty of room to maneuver your craft
When in fact there is little to no room for your craft outside of your view as the ship is large compared to the environment.
Could of been good but the large ship turns it into a crash feast that ruins the action.

Forsaken does not have this problem.
But Forsaken does not look this good.
Ever space also does not have this oversized ship to view ratio problem.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019319751', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 336, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 182, 'last_played': 1652495295}
review:
Anyone who grew up loving Interplay's Descent in the 90s absolutely MUST get this game. It's basically a perfect replica on a modern game engine, with a slightly different skin. The gameplay is amazing, the story is intriguing--at least as much as I've seen so far--and it provides a great nostalgia hit every time I run it. I bought it as soon as I saw a video of the gameplay, and I haven't regretted that snap decision for one second.

The Challenge mode is a neat addition, and I'm excited to try some online multiplayer one of these days. The only thing I wish they included that the original Descent had is cooperative multiplayer, where more than one person can go through a whole campaign. My brothers and I used to do that all the time as kids on our home network. But alas, we probably wouldn't be able to coordinate our schedules across three busy families to pull that off these days anyway...
