author: {'steamid': '76561197996505295', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 70482, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5540, 'last_played': 1709884073}
review: Descent 2 was one of my favorite games.  This game DOES NOT live up to my expectations.  3 out of 5 stars.  Disappointed. There are so many things missing in this game. No wonder the makers called it a prequel.  There is no PIP (picture in picture) so you don't have a rear view mirror view screen. No guided missiles. No camera pods.  Also the weapons preferences don't let you set your own.  You can't jettison weapons. This was a fun way to hide mines and fake death in multiplayer. You can't even shoot your own mines to release homing plasma.  This game is way dumbed down.  It should be named Descent .8 beta with tons of eye candy.  I want game play not lipstick on a pig.  Also you have to grind grind grind to get enough XP to unlock weapons like a RPG.  The multiplayer doesn't work without downloading another app.  The main mission is too short and the puzzles aren't even close to the originals complexity and imagination.  Oh yeah, and there are fewer weapons.  In a nutshell, just less of everything that made the original Descent series so amazing.  My advice is if you have a VR headset wait till it goes on sale.  At least 50% off. or better yet, find an old copy of the original series (D2 was my favorite) and play through that.  It will be far more enjoyable.

review:
Improved Descent, I love this game.  It's hard but very fun to play, I loved Descent when I was a kid and I have totally enjoyed this so far.  I like the upgrade system, and a lot of the weapons are fun to play with.  The enemy's are sneaky and dodge well, so far been playing on Hotshot.
The only issue I do have so far is it does not have a co-op, I would really enjoy teaming up with a buddy with a co-op of this like old times.  
Was totally worth the buy.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999481653', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1142, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 889, 'last_played': 1645494520}
review:
This is one of my favorite games to jump into pretty much any time. I was a fan of D1 and D2, not so much of D3, and this just hit all the perfect sweet spots for me. The controls are razor sharp, music perfect, overall presentation just nails it. It's clear the original talent is back, and I hope to see more from them.

Did you enjoy the heck out of Descent 1/2? Still play with modern ports? Then you can't really go wrong here. You can line up the controls pretty close between d1x-rebirth and Overload to keep your muscle memory true.

Oh, this is also a polite reminder to take asperin for your back.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026070169', 'num_games_owned': 340, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 268, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 181, 'last_played': 1693741661}
review:
Absolutely yes! Many have written this before me but this is basically the true Descent 4. Everything you loved about the original Descents, the developer here transplanted into a modern day engine and it works (with a bit more plot exposure). Is it an innovative and ground-breaking 6DoF shooter? Definitely not. However, this is good old Descent and that's exactly what I was looking for.
(buying the OST cause it's awesome!)

author: {'steamid': '76561198010857621', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 6557, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4430, 'last_played': 1662192982}
review:
This game is probably the best 6DOF game out there when this review is being written. I get lost a lot, but that's mostly on me, and the game has a good readable 3d-map, might would have been helped by a gyro style compass though.

The controls are amazing, and the feel of flying the ship is great whether  you use a joystick or the mouse. I have more fun with a joystick but if you don't own one don't sweat, this 6DOF game has the best mouse controls I have ever played with in any game of this kind. 

I love this game and have played through it multiple times.
There are also community levels you can download and play, some which are very creative. There is no Workshop integration though, the easiest way to find the community content is probably through the Overload Discord.

The only gripe I have is that even though the game has a native Linux build the level editor doesn't, and I couldn't get it to work on Linux at all, even when I tried using Proton. But that's probably not relevant for most of you. I really wanted to make my own custom levels though, with statues of sexy aliens and abandoned alien underground cities to explore.

But don't take my word for it, the game has a free demo that represents the full game very, very well.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979091641', 'num_games_owned': 948, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 989, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 989, 'last_played': 1642215738}
review:
[quote]I review for fun and on my own schedule. Open this review in full-screen to see better formatting. Click SUBSCRIBE to smudge your monitor. Respect to all the review clubs out there.[/quote]

[h1]Overview[/h1]
Overload is a first-person spaceship shooter set indoors with an emphasis on freedom of movement, secret finding, and combat. 

[b]The Good[/b]
[list]
[*] Secrets
[*] Soundtrack
[*] Challenge modes
[*] Weapon and ship upgrades
[*] Pathing guidance
[/list]
[b]The Bad[/b]
[list]
[*] Difficulty
[*] Forced weapon swapping
[*] Secrets in timed level sections
[*] Powerup locations
[*] Blocked upgrading
[/list]
[b]Buy or Try[/b]
[list]
[*] Buy on sale or seek an alternative
[/list]
[b]Stability[/b]
[list]
[*] No crashes, graphical anomalies, or sound issues
[*] Frame rate drops encountered noticeably in later areas
[*] My System: Windows 10, i7-7700 @ 3.60GHz, 16GB ram, 1060 3GB, played at 1920 x 1080
[/list]

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
In Overload you control a spacecraft within mining facilities on Saturn's moons. You'll fight your way to rescue captives, destroy reactors, and then escape before they explode. The game's 16 levels are labyrinthine interior environments full of cramped spaces and variable lighting. Navigation is aided by a hologram wayfinder, automap, flares, and headlights. These tools will prove useful as you'll need to explore thoroughly for weapons, energy, armour pickups, audio logs, security keys, and upgrade points used to buff your weapons and ship between missions. Rescuing captives is optional though provides rewards and impacts the game's ending. 

Your 16 weapons are split evenly into two groups. Primary weapons are your main guns ranging from gattling lasers to flak cannons. Secondary weapons are explosives ranging from missile launchers to time-slowing bombs. Separate weapon wheels for each group makes for convenient swapping. All weapons have two tiers of upgrades, the second of which is a choice between two options. For instance, you could opt to improve your missiles' homing ability or instead go for a straight damage boost. Enemies vary in their own weapons and maneuverability posing ever-greater threats. In addition to standard foes are three boss battles spread evenly across the campaign. 

Story is delivered between missions and during play with additional details found within collectible audio logs. The game provides quicksaving and manual saving, with no in-level autosaving (that I'm aware of). Overload includes a campaign, newgame+, multiplayer (not reviewed), and two challenge modes. Challenge mode is a series of 12 separate maps to destroy as many enemies as possible either within a 5 minute window or as long as you can survive. XP earned from killing foes in all single-player offerings go towards permanent ship upgrades in challenge mode. Weapons in challenge mode are levelled up from scratch each time you play a round. 

An uptempo soundtrack complements the action. Overload includes 50 Steam Achievements with the majority attained by less than 1% of players. In a little over 16 hours I beat the campaign on the 3rd of 5 difficulty options as well tried most of the challenge mode maps.

[h1]Critique[/h1]
Midway through the campaign I was having a blast but upon beating it was left underwhelmed and disappointed. A good first impression made me willing to overlook a misstep or two. But the further I got the more problems arose to the extent they could no longer be ignored. The freedom of movement, the combat, and the majority of the level design was well executed. Hunting for secrets was just as fun as winning battles with both offered in equal measure. Though I amassed a series of minor gripes what killed my enjoyment was a lack of consistency and, more glaring, an unfairly balanced difficulty.

Upgrade points are mainly found in secret areas, a design I've hated since 1997's Jedi Knight forced secret hunting to improve Force powers. That said Overload is a lesser offender, for though it's doubtful you'll locate every secret you'll still find enough to upgrade all the things you'll actually use. During my run I was able to upgrade my mainstay weapon to maximum, all of my ship upgrades, as well as most of my preferred secondary weapons. Annoyingly, around mission 9 you'll lose your ability to upgrade entirely, despite the fact you'll still be acquiring new weapons. 

Like in the campaign, when you level up your weapons in challenge mode you are granted a choice between two options. Unfortuntaely the options aren't described, instead referred to with generic names like Missiles XL. Lacking a Codex to review upgrade options you won't have a clue what you are choosing. Since enemy and weapon descriptions are often provided before campaign levels I found the lack of a Codex strangely absent.

All of your secondary weapons have their own ammo counts and you'll use them all. Primary weapons don't have ammo that is collected, but rather that is pulled from one of two of your HUD's status bars. This was confusing, something I only figured out for myself after beating the campaign, reading the manual, then going back to play around some more. Some weapons use energy while others use "ammo" represented by the white bar. You won't need to swap primary weapons since enemies don't have particular weaknesses and most fights will be fought in a confined space. Because of this, slow firing weapons are terrible. My preferred weapon was energy based and energy is in great supply. Frankly I feel the white status bar could have been removed.

Secondary weapons are the most inventive yet some are lackluster with others downright annoying. The Vortex is one of the last acquired yet barely deals any damage. The Time Bomb is the worst offender as it literally slows things to a crawl. Three time-limited powerups can also be found consisting of a weapon boost, invulnerability, and cloak. These work fine but not when placed in a secret area you'll never locate when beset upon by enemies when entering a new location.

Overload's biggest issue is that it is less about skill and more about managing saves. Without autosaves you'll rely on quicksaving, and should you not make additional manual saves at high health, you can find yourself in unwinnable situations. Certain level sections make avoiding damage impossible, such as when you are locked or teleported into a small room surrounded by enemies. These moments are made worse by the fact that found health pickups are finite. I'd often quicksave with less than 100 armour expecting to find a boost later on, only to instead be thrust into a confined space where enemies would destroy me in seconds before I could get my bearings.

Enemy spawn stations and wall turrets that can't be destroyed, secrets tied to time-limited escapes, and forced weapon swapping to open doors can all be attributed to poor design choices in what I initially thought was a really good game. And don't get me started on the story. Oh, a virus has turned autonomous machines against the crew of an expensive mining outpost? Rather than just save the crew and destroy the machines, blow the station up too. That makes perfect sense.  

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
The level design is good. The soundtrack is apt. And the challenge modes make for quick and fun combat. In light of its problems I can only recommend it on sale. Should you buy it, take my advice. Set the difficulty to Rookie, don't obssess over every secret, find a weapon that works for you, and make manual saves too. EVERSPACE and Sublevel Zero Redux offer similar combat with more consistent design and can often be found at a discount. I would have been happier had Overload been outright bad. It nails some of the hardest things to do right. I'm saddened by how little it would have taken to transform my frustration into complete and utter delight. 

[b]In A Word[/b]
[list]
[*] "Decent" - instead of "Descent," get it?
[/list]

review: Plays great in VR, just don't go crazy with the graphics or it's likely to crash. At 120 HZ and everything on mid level it was borderline using a 3080, 90+% GPU usage but butter smooth, until it crashed when I tried also capturing. And I get the feeling it ignores the display setting for resolution and uses the pc's desktop res if you use fullscreen, so I suggest low and windowed, 800x600 maybe, and it doesn't impact the HMD display at all.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044081373', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 205, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 76, 'last_played': 1703185885}
review:
Overload is a modernized Descent. The bulk of my playtime with Overload has been the Linux version from gog.com, so my Steam stats don't tell the whole tale.
Six degrees of movement and zero gravity effect the mechanics in some interesting ways.
Enemy AI is sharp enough to be challenging.
Stage layouts are complex enough to justify the in-game map.
Hidden goodies to upgrade your ship with and reveal more of the story.
Online multiplayer across platforms and OSes. But be warned! Descent vets will pummel you!
Challenge modes add some pretty fun wave based bot battles.

author: {'steamid': '76561198356284356', 'num_games_owned': 757, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 205, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 154, 'last_played': 1659818823}

author: {'steamid': '76561197969699062', 'num_games_owned': 130, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 362, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 168, 'last_played': 1688829732}
review: This is the best entry into the 6dof space since Descent 3 - and this game looks to have the community backing that the original descent has. There is a plethora of community content available and the official discord is friendly.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043325072', 'num_games_owned': 505, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 287, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 139, 'last_played': 1642926982}
review:
Just a really nice new take on the essence of Descent. The enemies are more varied, the placement more sneaky and the attack possibilities are versatile from mob and player POV. 

Unity can be ticklish. I got a single crash, but I like to shift-tab and alt-tab a lot so it's not limited to Overload as far as stability is concerned. It's very responsive given the guts involved in a game like this. Rustiness must wear off before I can rank this but I already know it's at least as good as Freespace, and Freespace is possibly my favorite take on the genre this series invented. If you like Descent / D2 / Freespace this is clearly for you.

tl;dr  This game definitely emphasizes automap usage. You could get by in D1 without but D2 made it pretty necessary to use the map. Definitely of benefit here too. Flight mechanics and enemy movements are reminiscent of the classics. Being a huge fan of the originals I'll just say it's instantly intuitive. A quality production. Doesn't hurt the fact the principals behind the first games are the devs!

author: {'steamid': '76561198067180365', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 2329, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 473, 'last_played': 1645449262}

author: {'steamid': '76561198029646510', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 179, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 59, 'last_played': 1701368751}
review:
Sadly I have to confirm the eye hurting flickering when looking in direction of lights at a wall when playing in VR. Its really annoying. I mean you dont have these lights in front of you constantly. But its definitly something which have to be fixed. (Valve Index on AMD XFX 5700xt graphics card and latest non-beta drivers.)

Besides that its absolutly amazing! The real Descent feeling. Das ich Das noch erleben darf! 
I had tears in my eyes when I heard of this game and instantly bought it. To play this in VR is so good.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987204139', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 335, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 276, 'last_played': 1680054041}
review: This is more Descent 3. If you like Descent 3 you'll like this one too

author: {'steamid': '76561198018683143', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 162, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 91, 'last_played': 1681715942}
review:
Awesome controls and movement and shooting. 
I've never seen a Unity Engine game run this smooth!

I feel like they could have done more with combat, e.g. there's not much reason to choose any particular weapons against any type of encounter because they are all fun and effective. But it is exactly what you'd except from a descent game, so it's great fun either way.

Definitely the best out of all of the Descent clones.




The levels could be less maze like imo, and I feel like they were a little more creative in Descent 2. 

I just had a lot of fun zipping around and blowing things up in all directions!

author: {'steamid': '76561197970496513', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 100, 'playtime_forever': 1049, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 245, 'last_played': 1695173276}
review:
Use a flight stick combined with WASD or gamepad left analog like you would for FPS.  Then, on the flight stick use the up/down hat buttons for ascend/descend.

Refreshing gameplay mechanics and a satisfying learning curve really makes Overload worth it.  If you've got a flight stick, don't miss out on this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970482231', 'num_games_owned': 625, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 79, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 79, 'last_played': 1639691480}
review: If you are looking for the TRUE sequel to Descent 2 . . . this is it!  Original devs, musicians, and yes even the guide-bot (now a ghost for some reason IDK I killed him too many times in D2 maybe?)  Warning for VR: turn off Ambient Occlusion and Lens Flares, they are both not stereoscopically correct.  Have Fun!

author: {'steamid': '76561198041157067', 'num_games_owned': 325, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 407, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 407, 'last_played': 1639719414}
review: Good spiritual successor to Descent and related titles. Grew up playing the first three games with my dad on a Windows 98 machine. He never beat them but I did! :) Thanks for a great game!

author: {'steamid': '76561197970329732', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 196, 'playtime_forever': 265, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 179, 'last_played': 1640388749}
review:
The game is finally playable, and that's thanks to the brute force of the RTX 3090. Maxing out all graphics settings, I get close to solid 90 fps in VR using Valve Index res 150%. Granted this game should be able to do res 400%, but I fear devs more or less gave VR players the raw 2D version x 2...

In big battles I can't do 90 fps, but 95% of the game is solid 90 fps.

I've waited years for this moment - and the game really is awesome.

I have to concede that keyboard+mouse seems to be a much more precise and responsive control method than a good HOTAS, especially for something as fast-paced as this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089979881', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1412, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 11, 'playtime_at_review': 1401, 'last_played': 1712351243}
review:
If you're old enough to remember the classic game Descent, just go buy this game now. Its everything you loved, updated for modern PC's.

If you haven't played Descent, then hang on, this is a 360, bot hunting FPS. In VR, it's even more insane, as down can suddenly become ip, and the hole in the floor can become a dark hallway leading a 1,000 feet straight down.

Stealth and weapon management are key to your own play style, especially in multiplayer. 

Strap in and enjoy the ride!

author: {'steamid': '76561198152592550', 'num_games_owned': 446, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 305, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 115, 'last_played': 1635308743}

author: {'steamid': '76561198064850410', 'num_games_owned': 770, 'num_reviews': 374, 'playtime_forever': 845, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 845, 'last_played': 1634661198}
review:
[h1]'Descent' into Ymir, Titan, Enceladus and beyond.[/h1]
[u][b]Premise:[/b][/u] In 2118, you'll operate a multi-purpose service vessel (MPSV) donned the ‚ÄúIberia‚Äù registered to the Cronus Frontier which is a subsidiary of Juno Offworld Automation.

You, the ostensibly [i]unnamed[/i] pilot, will awaken and be contacted by an AI named ‚ÄúMara‚Äù onboard the Iberia. Mara informs the pilot that an outpost on Ymir, a moon of Saturn, has had its operators ‚Äî what are mining and security drones in the facility ‚Äî  malfunction and become hostile. During the mission, the pilot learns more about the tumultuous relationship between Juno Offworld Automation and the Cronus Frontier CEO, Gabriel Kantor.

The story is exclusively told through preamble voiced text before each mission as well as audio logs found throughout the levels. The voice acting is quite good. Anecdotally, Overload feels a bit like System Shock, Red Faction and Perfect Dark 64 if they were all combined and re-imagined as a 6DOF game. Of course, this game actually made by the same devs as ‚ÄúDescent‚Äù under a different banner ‚Äî appropriately named ‚ÄúRevival Productions‚Äù. Chiefly, Matt Toschlog, Mike Kulas of Parallax Software (now called Deep Silver Volition) and Luke Schneider of Radian Games.

[h3]Gameplay[/h3]
[i]Most[/i] level objectives are straightforward and.... unchanging. Typically revolving around very light exploration to find security keys, then going through the subsequent security door and destroying the main reactor. That or destroying a boss ‚Äî then escaping. On occasion, you'll run into lockdown sectors that you need to destroy the subsequent security in order to leave , other objectives might include destroying a smaller reactor to de-power a security gate. Nearing the end however, this slightly changes. For narrative reasons, you need to pass through portals after supplying them with enough power. All without the aid of your holo-guide.

The game does not take place in ‚Äúouter space‚Äù so much as it's inside of outposts and facilities around the moons of Saturn. A sort of ‚Äútunnel shooter‚Äù.

If you're unfamiliar with what ‚Äú6DOF‚Äù means, it essentially means you've got full control of pitch, yaw and roll movements of the ship. ‚Äú6 degrees of freedom‚Äù. A number of movement aids are available if you're easily disoriented, such as auto-roll ‚Äî this can be augmented to the degree of which it is active with both strafing and mouse movement adjustments. 

6DOF games require a bit more spatial awareness than a traditional shooter. For instance the sight-lines are different, were this Call of Duty or Battlefield, you'd be able to reasonably predict where an enemy may appear around of the corner ‚Äî being filled with ground-faring creatures. Even in something like CoD: Advanced Warfare or Titanfall, you can make a reasonable prediction that enemies' center of mass will appear just above the ground but not so high that your aim is perpendicular to the to the ground. Otherwise, a rough estimate can be made where a player could reasonably be wall running. In Overload/Descent, or in any 6DOF game for that matter, anything could be anywhere.

However, if you get lost, you can assign the holo-guide to track specific things on the map. Need more power? Tell it to guide you to an energy center. You can't overcharge there, but it can get you out of a bind. Have no idea where to go next? Tell to it to guide you to the next security key/gate. This of course only works in facilities assigned to Cronus Frontier.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2631696831

There are enemies in which their first parameter for attack is simply ramming into you ‚Äî occasionally they will attempt this in a relatively furtive way. You'll be exploring for secrets, power-ups or what have you and all of a sudden this big metal beast will smack you on the side knocking you around.   With the clank of your metallic hull combined with the antagonistic engine sounds and the operators make, this surreptitious ramming can make you feel rather vulnerable ‚Äî especially if you already feel uncomfortable with ideas like there not really being an up or down.

[h3]Misc[/h3]
Operators break up nicely. You can see them ignite from the inside and become inactive, ultimately sending them careening to their demise. Recognizing when they go inactive can save you a fair amount of ammo.

You can find upgrade points throughout stage. Used to increase stats like maximum ammo or damage from specific weapons.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2631686786

There's a challenge mode with its own separate unlocks and progression. But there is an NG+ after the campaign is completed.

Headlights draw small amount of power, which is acts as health underneath the shields. So it behooves one to use flares instead. They can also help reveal clocked operator positions ‚Äî plus they look really cool.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2631686770

There's also cross-platform multiplayer, though I would not suspect it's very active.

Weapon variety is pretty decent. Everything from standard lasers and missiles to time bombs ‚Äî and I don't mean a bomb with a timer, I mean a bomb that slows down time itself. There's also chain guns like the Cyclone that increase its rate of fire the longer the trigger is held, creeper mines that slowly seek out operators among many others.

[h3]The Gist[/h3]
It's a very fun, fast-paced and challenging shooter ‚Äî especially on higher difficulties. There's not a lot of variation in the level design or mission objectives, which can be a real bummer. The story is actually pretty intricate and compelling, that is, if you actually pay attention to the mission briefs. Personally, I would wait for a sale, as I don't think what is here will satisfy people that are not actively seeking out a modern replacement for Descent.

[quote]If you've read this far, consider following my curation  ‚Äî [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/28295405/]Station Argus[/url][/quote]

author: {'steamid': '76561198233271140', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 47, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 47, 'last_played': 1633031140}
review:
It has a lot of problems...
1.) My top savegame will randomly be replaced by a several months old "ymir save".
...Not only the top ones, other are starting to get replaced too, and they are OLD savegames, like im not sure all of them are actually mine... they could be from other players too...
2.) At one of the later levels in the game, as soon as there are more than 2-3 enemies, it will drop fps to maybe 10... Which would be explainable on older hardware... But this is a 5600X, RTX 3060, 16gb 3600mhz Ram... I have a gigabit internet connection, and the game is being run of a ssd...
I can¬¥t find ANY solution online, or here on steam...
3.) The Holo-Guide is located on "Z" which i have never used, but accidently hit, while playing...
There litteraly is NO possibility of turning it off! 
-BUT it gets worse! -It can open doors, all by it self! -Which it ofcourse did! -Which made every enemy close to the doors on the other side react, and ofcourse follow it, to attack ME... It kept doing that for 15 minutes or so, while i had to fend enemies of, because there was a couple of "Auto Fabricators" which ofcourse kept producing more and more...
In the end, i had to remap the Holo-Guide, to the farthest key on my keyboard, so i wouldent accidently hit it again!
Also the button layout for weapon change, are 2-3 keys per weapon... and you just have to keep on pressing, hoping to get the one you need...

** DLC **

The DLC is actually WORSE!
I know, i know, it¬¥s made by other players... and they are not experts... and what not... But hey, i¬¥m still paying for it.. it¬¥s still money, for something that¬¥s less than okay... i mean the maps for instance, are almost useless! -Doors are showen as "normal doors" but are either security doors, or "event activated doors" ... meining you have to look thru all the other rooms, to try and figure it out! -For instance: i was flying from room to room, looking for secret doors, panels ...whatever that would open a door... turned out to be a pack of Vortex missiles i had to pick up... which didn¬¥t auto-trigger when i flew thru it, because my Vortex ammo was filled up!?!!??
...And the logs you pick up, are ALL text! ...you cant pause to read them, and enemies are chasing you, sooo you wont see any of them!
The levels are mishmash of all the different stages from the base game, and all taken out of context... even the enemies are randomized... so enemies from alien worlds are mixed with lava robots, and levels are mixed lava, ice, alien worlds, coal mines, and industrial complexes, all mixed int o one... 
This is BAD! DLC is not worth it! Even if it was free... it got so monotinous, that i just hurried thru them to get it over with!


...as long as theese problems exist, the game is not recommendable...
...I have played more than 30 hours, and steam shows less than 0?...

author: {'steamid': '76561198073525556', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 10426, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7413, 'last_played': 1704762779}
review:
I'm grateful this game exists, for an old genre that just doesn't have the attention I'd like. After 2+ years, it still impresses me how well these devs nailed the gameplay/combat. The game overall feels a bit bare-bones, but clearly they spent their resources wisely. Technically It looks good (particularly in combat), though at times there is some stuttering (Unity) which I have been able to minimize with various methods. Believe me I hate stuttering but it's not enough to ruin the game. It's satisfying to play, has a good story and some great voicework, and surprisingly good music. It's honestly better than it should have been, and deserves any attention it gets.

P.S. Though Overload takes the cake for me, Sublevel Zero is also very good and quite different; you should get both if you're into this genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052575335', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 2519, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1533, 'last_played': 1710772750}
review:
If you grew up on descent. This is the one for you.

My understanding is the team behind Overload were from Parallax Software of Descent 1 and 2 fame (under Interplay).

Anyway, onto the game details:

Pros:

Plays like Descent. Same freedom of movement, enemy types, weapons- all great graphics. And since this is a VR compatible experience, Its even more incredible with my headset on. 

Cons:

The enemies could be a little more interesting-looking. I mean, compared to Descent, they didn't seem to have as much character. However, I may need to play a bit more. The protagonist's ship is somewhat bland as well. 

In all though, its the best Descent we've gotten in decades. A stark contrast to what the official franchise has become these days.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969527004', 'num_games_owned': 867, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 304, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 189, 'last_played': 1693927886}
review:
Hells yes! This is the closest we'll ever get to Descent 4 IMO. Overload is very much a modernised Descent with awesome graphics, a pumping soundtrack, and even VR support. 

The devs, many of whom worked on the old games, did a fantastic job of recreating the Descent feel. The levels I've seen so far are a little more sterile than the older games' levels, though, and I have found myself lost once or twice (the 3D map they included is a nice addition for those times), but neither of those things are deal-breakers.

If you had a good time with Descent back in the day, I'm sure you'll love this. I have yet to try the multiplayer, though, but at least it's there!

author: {'steamid': '76561199115911740', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1440, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 746, 'last_played': 1662233321}
review: This would be a perfect game if the multi-player options worked. However, unless I'm missing something, they do not work without having go through complicated modding. I still have not figured out how to play multi-player in VR. Not many things are more annoying than finding out after the refund period expires that something does not work seamlessly or as advertised. If you can't just play multi-player, or whatever, without hassle, don't advertise that you can. Someone please tell me if I am wrong. I love this game except for that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198449831129', 'num_games_owned': 110, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 4147, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3145, 'last_played': 1699590491}
review:
I played Descent 4: Overload in VR, blind (Holo-guide notwithstanding (I only ever used it about eight times)), and 52 hours hours later, I've completed the base game, which I very much so enjoyed!

Much love to all the people at Revival Productions for letting me re-live my favourite game in modern tech!

author: {'steamid': '76561198000695382', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 1460, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 336, 'last_played': 1676528713}
review:
Whether or not you played this games 90's predecessors, "Descent", this game is a must-have for any fan of arcade shooters. This game retains all the feel of what it was like to be a game in the golden age of gaming, the 90's. It's complete on launch, it's fully polished and launched only when it's DONE - Before launch, there was even a freeware demo! Not a word you've heard in a while, huh?

It's got a bangin' soundtrack, six degrees of freedom in a zippy, responsive gunship in twisting and turning vertigo-inducing levels with 8 unique primary weapons and 8 unique secondary weapons, levels full of secret doorways and triggers, 5 difficulty levels 

AND

Free, online community level packs and play.

This is what it was alllll about.

author: {'steamid': '76561198106011053', 'num_games_owned': 452, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 72, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 56, 'last_played': 1627877812}
review:
It's literally Descent 4 and it's awesome.

If you like Descent, or 6DOF games like Forsaken, it's just about everything I could ask for.  It very much feels like a DOS era game with better graphics and modern controller support.  There's nothing really new or innovative, and I'm fine with that.  You fly a ship, blow sh*t up, and go the wrong way a lot because you're disoriented and confused, and tell yourself that you don't need that stupid navigation bot.

Playing with a controller is a decent Descent, like with the originals you'll have to rewire your brain a bit.  Joystick options too, but I haven't tried them yet.  The story is you don't care, just blow up stuff.  Graphics are minimalist, but it works well here, making everything look suitably science fiction-y without being too busy so as to confuse your eyeballs.  Robots blow up good, too.  Attention to detail, like being able to blow up the monitors on the wall brought a smile to my crusty old face.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963852644', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1005, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 150, 'last_played': 1653868258}
review:
It's somewhere around 1995 and my friend down the street had bible thumpin' parents. Many video games were a no-no, but Descent was a-Okay for them. His dad showed it to me and let me play it. My own father eventually got it and we both spent many hours on it. Then the series disappeared. I had completely forgotten about it. 

Fast-forward to 2021. I'm going through a plane flying game phase and stumbled across the "Take Control" bundle on Humble. This was included. The idea peaked my interest, but it wasn't the first game of the bundle that I played... and that's too bad, cause this kicks ass. 

Non-stop action, bots flying out of every corner and crevice, sneaking up on your ass (I'm playing on Hotshot). Hit 'em with a double-whammy of continuous lasers and rockets while moving in anyway you want to avoid their shots. 

I lack a joystick, so I'm playing on mouse and keyboard. It plays like an intense modern-day Doom-esque shooter when you're on a straight plane, but you also have entirely different directions you can go. Up, down, spin. For those unfamiliar with Descent, think of a hovering spacecraft crawling through a confusing FPS map. It takes a bit to master the controls for this, but once you do, it's incredible. 

Speaking of confusing FPS maps - A huge pro for this kind of game is the navigation bot. I had not paid close attention to the opening hints and found myself lost on the first level, until I was reminded that I just need to hit 'Z' and a bot will guide my way. I vaguely remember getting myself lost in the old Descent games and found myself so lost in the first level, so it's great that they included this. 

Some downsides - I'm not incredibly far yet, but the mod options seem rather bare minimum. Ammunition for the various weapons has to be picked up while you're on a mission and nothing carries over to the next level, aside from a few upgrade points. The upgrade points allow you to make power upgrades before starting a mission. The missions themselves are more arcade like and do not feel like a proper campaign/story. I understand why they may have took a classic approach on these things, but including some modern mechanics, especially around modding and ship customization, would have been a huge improvement for this game.   

It also does not play well with a controller (tested on Xbox One controller). The buttons have to be manually assigned and the calibration refuses to work. I can get it functional with my controller, but it's just not right. There may be workarounds for controller use, but this seems to be a bit of a weakness for a game released in 2018. 

However, overall, this game is what I needed. And despite it's pedigree, it feels like an entirely new and unique experience. It's easy to jump into, looks amazing, and runs extremely smooth - never dropping below 60 fps in 4k on my upper-mid-end PC.  The action is intense and relentless. It's incredibly challenging, but rewarding. Would recommend.

Edit: I went back and played with the controller settings some more. It is definitely playable with the controller. My preference remains mouse and keyboard, however. BUY THIS GAME.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993326992', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 98, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 37, 'last_played': 1627268663}
review:
Are you the developers of Descent and Descent 2? Are you looking back on your creation, one of the genre defining shooters of 90s PC gaming, with love and awe? Do you want to remake it in such a way that you take exactly all the good parts of those games and mix it with modern graphics, VR, and so many particle effects that you'll give your players Cataracts?

Well, it's too late, these people did it... and it's fucking great.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030817835', 'num_games_owned': 287, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1576, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1164, 'last_played': 1627197988}
review: Actual successor to the original Descent games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055429610', 'num_games_owned': 314, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 921, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 810, 'last_played': 1635124929}
review:
I've never played a game like Descent before, but I walked in thinking I was going to get a bit nauseous playing this compared to games like TF2 or Quake. I was wrong -- rather, I adjusted to the controls and the ride was very enjoyable.

The movement in Overload is SUPER smooth, and the combat destroying those pesky robots is incredibly satisfying. I haven't played through the multiplayer or DLC levels yet, but the campaign and challenges are more than enough to enjoy what Overload has to offer. The soundtrack in this also has its moments -- Tetrahedron in particular is amazing.

I can't wait for more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018333173', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 506, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 506, 'last_played': 1624550358}
review:
Hm. I wish reviews would allow a 1 to 5 Star Rating. I'd give this a solid 2 - 3 Stars. This is great for fans of the genre but if you're just like shooters in general and look for something generally well made and entertaining, this is most probably not it. And not worth more than $15.

It was great fun when I was still motivated to play because I wanted to see and experience all the levels and the upgraded weapons. But it felt really boring and slow and long... more like work... so I stopped playing for half a year.

Now after the pause I tried picking it up again and the flaws became really obvious and I stopped playing after a couple of minutes because of a bore-out:

My main point of critique:

- The levels are extremely generic and lack any form of sense, reason and structure. 

I guess this could be seen as "staying true to it's descent roots"... but it just feels boring and uninspired after a while. 

There's generic space corridors, generic engine rooms, ice caves and lava caves. That's it. 

Nothing stands out as very tight, very spaceous, good looking, well structured, impressive - just architecture that has an obvious purpose - a level that has a certain logical structure. 
It all feels like endless generic space-corridor boringness. Any oldschool computer could have generated these levels without the help of any human brain.

And this also leads to the next point:

- The fights are always the same - because the environments are always the same.
Enemies appear. You shoot them... most of the time you do no have much space for moving around or really using the level to your advantage because the enemies always follow in the same way - or by flying around you "wake" up more enemies.


So I wish there would be some sort of logical story... and then some sort of progression that you can see in the world... maybe starting in generic corridors but then also entering different planets. Frozen, Lava, Jungle, Desert, Metal, Water... Structures that are huge, strctures that are tight, outdoor parts, new scifi levels, old rusty dirty scifi levels, then destroyed or wrecked space ships (inside and outside), dangrous environments, friendly environments, old green-houses with plants taking over, sunken cities, old ruins, just anything but only corridors... 

Then every environment would create it's own playstyle and different strategies. 
But I guess time and resources were not there... which would be fair for a $10 game. But $25 is just too much.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026828397', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 274, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 128, 'last_played': 1650422750}
review:
This game is really good so far but when I bought it a few years ago I only had a Mac. Don't bother buying this game if you plan on using a Mac. I was never able to get the game to run.

author: {'steamid': '76561199050479748', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 730, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 284, 'last_played': 1659723055}
review:
It's stays true to the old Descent game. The gameplay does hold up with time. The enemies is not to fast and shoot projectiles possible to move away from so in a sense it's a little bit more like a 3D bullet hell game than modern shooters like CS.
There is difficulty options with abig spread so it should fit players with all skill levels.
I don't like the new Doom game the monsters was to fast and the levels to cluttered so my old brain couldn't handle it and it was tedious and difficult to find the way and figure out what to do. Overload haven't changed the gameplay that made the original game succesfull and it is so fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198188664927', 'num_games_owned': 1605, 'num_reviews': 386, 'playtime_forever': 258, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 258, 'last_played': 1621109385}
review:
[quote]A review copy was provided by the developer.[/quote]
[quote]Follow my Curator page, [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/41363546-Fruit-N-Doggie-Reviews/]Fruit N Doggie Reviews,[/url] so you can be updated whenever I post a new review.[/quote]
[h1]Overall Rating - Seriously Flawed ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ‚òÜ‚òÜ[/h1]

[h1]First Impressions[/h1]
Not since Star Fox 64 back in 1997 have I played many SHMUPs where you don't just look at a small ship from overhead, as piloting a ship in a 3-dimensional manner doesn't seem to arise very often. The only exceptions I'm generally aware of come from jet fighter sims. Regardless, looking at Overload (OL), I was excited for the opportunity to play such a game again. With such positive reviews, I was all too happy to take a key from someone who didn't need it.


[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
As already mentioned, this is a first-person perspective SHMUP style game, and true to form you face off against an enemy count that greatly outnumbers you. Your progress carries over from stage to stage, including ammo and energy reserves. At least, I think so, due to the otherwise arbitrary amounts of items you start a stage with, since you don't start off maxed out. Additionally, you're able to upgrade various stats of your ship, such as the power of your weapon systems, speed of the ship, durability, etc. Doing so requires you to find upgrades scattered about each stage, in contrast to gaining XP by killing bad guys. There are also secrets, some of which require careful navigation to find.

Each stage includes progressing objectives. These essentially involve finding keycards to access secured areas, before blowing something of importance to pieces, such as a reactor or boss. Completing the last objective triggers a short count-down before the entire station you're at self-destructs. If you don't escape in time and haven't manually saved during the stage, you would have to start at the very beginning again. You're also able to rescue hibernating people before the base explodes, but more often than not, I can't find where they are and let them die.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2487989336
[h1]Controls[/h1]
Flying a spaceship is surprisingly complicated, but that's because of how much control you have over it. Since you're freely navigating stages in a three dimensional space, you need ways to adjust your trajectory, height, and direction. The controls are fairly intuitive as you get used to them, and give all the tools necessary to fly where you want to go. It takes time to get used to, and it can feel floaty, but the controls work pretty well overall. You also have tools that can be toggled, such as a guide and which weapons system you want to use.


[h1]Story[/h1]
I can't say the story is that interesting, primarily because of how it's delivered. Although it does include voice-overs, you listen to the voice acting while staring at neon green text on a black screen. There aren't cutscenes or images of the people involved to give the events some context, as the only time you'll see the visage of a person is when rescuing people in stasis. Even then it's nothing more than a photo ID. A story is nothing without characters, and the events taking place come across like some paranoid businessman getting ticked off because others won't support his research.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2488112691
[h1]Visuals[/h1]
The locations you fly your ship through exclusively consist of research facilities set in outer space, and excavated tunnels, which doesn't make for the most exciting or diverse environments. For all intents and purposes, it could all be taking place on Earth. In spite of the sterile location, the visuals still look smooth and crisp. Kind of like the environment, enemy ships and the projectiles fired aren't that distinct, but that wasn't what drew my attention to OL in the first place. With my original concerns about the visuals, I'm glad that my orientation in the environment didn't feel obtuse or hard to discern. 


[h1]Sound Design[/h1]
I wouldn't say the music strikes me as spacey, even though the synthetic sounds may have tried to impart that effect, as this is taken over by the consistent style of grungy rock. Some songs slow the tempo down so it's not as aggressive, but I could see all of these songs fitting together on the same CD. It fits the game well enough, though I don't find it to be memorable music either. I didn't mind the voice acting, as infrequent as it might be. Similarly, the sound effects of missiles blowing enemies up, and the other weaponry, sounded as I'd expect from a game.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2488112031
[h1]Pros[/h1]
üåü I didn't notice a lot of difference in the primary weapons, but I could see the distinction more clearly in the secondary ones. This variety helps address different enemy types and situations.
üåü If you like exploring, there's plenty of secrets hidden in each stage. I doubt you'd find most of them without a guide though.


[h1]Cons[/h1]
‚ùå The environments aren't broad or open in any sense. You're always flying through tight, compact locations. It somewhat defeats the point of flying a spaceship, because you have no freedom or room to take advantage of your range of flight. 
‚ùå For whatever reason, I found myself playing the game a mission at a time, not really feeling like playing more of it right away.
‚ùå Enemies get bullet-spongey quick, so you'll almost have to spend upgrade points on your weapons.


[h1]Tips[/h1]
üîç With the ammo and other pick-ups available in each stage, you'll want to use your secondary weaponry evenly so that you don't have a slot that still has full ammo and no need for that refill, but are completely empty on something else. Since your weaponry isn't unlimited though, make your shots count.
üîç Enemies can be tucked away in dead-ends and around blind corners, so you can't be too careful while going into unexplored areas. With how enemies suddenly show up, some won't spawn until you trigger a spawn point.
üîç Explore the level by yourself for a while before turning on the guide. When I play levels without guidance the whole time, I tend to find more upgrades.


[h1]Final Thoughts[/h1]
What I enjoyed most while playing OL was the sense of movement as I flew around, and even though some angles might disorient me, it always felt pretty smooth. However, the game itself didn't give me as much satisfaction as I hoped for. The stage design worked against what these controls could have allowed for, putting you into a concise box with almost as little visual interest. With an emphasis on needing to explore for upgrades and secrets, it reminded me of Nintendo 64 games. I remember games from that era hiding power-ups in out of the way locations, and your time in any given stage increased significantly in spite of not accomplishing anything. 

I think the reason why the game gets such good reviews is because it initially feels good. However, the achievements for getting very far into the game aren't earned by many people, with only 15% of people beating the first 3 stages (not including the tutorial). I might recommend OL if I thought more people would even beat it, and since that seems unlikely, I'd suggest skipping it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052200738', 'num_games_owned': 122, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 157, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 157, 'last_played': 1618577028}
review:
Installed Descent, ended up here! What a great modern version of a game I played as a kid! Playing in VR is definitely the way to play it, environments are superb and combat feels real and almost scary at times with scorpions jumping out at you from hiding places to grind you in the face! 
Upgrade point system is good, it's got a use but I did like the way weapons were upgraded in the original Descent better, finding active upgrades rather than ticking boxes feels more organic personally. 
Only real annoyance is the lack of controller input in menus. Having to lift my VR to find enter or navigate the upgrade menu is junk, it's not a huge let down considering my xbox controller works 100% in game but it would be smart to have it work in a future update.
Honestly can't recommend it enough if you played the Descent games!

TL;DR
Whats good
- Graphics
- combat
- movement
- environments
- puzzles
- enemies
- weapon choice

Whats in the middle
- Sounds
- upgrade points
- story

What needs work
- Controller support when in VR

author: {'steamid': '76561198261041384', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 11063, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8011, 'last_played': 1692936699}
review:
I played Descent I or II (shareware edition, so basically first 2 or 3 levels with the boss in the end) back in the 90s, and I sucked at it. Got the Overload a few months ago and enjoyed it thoroughly. Visuals are awesome (esp last 3 levels), levels are complex (though eventually it gets easier to navigate), bots are scary and somewhat intelligent, weapons are cool and there's a variety (though there's 2 or 3 that are completely useless and probably were added just to beef up the numbers). The upgrade system works well and you really notice the difference when you upgrade shields/weapons/speed etc. Story is engaging; in fact, this is the 1st game EVER I went from the beginning to the end, simply because I wanted to know how the story ends (and was not disappointed). I also don't suck nearly as bad as I did 20 years ago, probably due to better hardware (PC with Ryzen 5, GTX 1660Super, and 16Gb RAM, and I get good FPS on maxed out settings).
Judging by the reviews, most players played original Descent which seems to suggest they were targeted by the marketing (and rightfully so), but I think this game is so unique and well made so that it could be enjoyed by this generation as well. Getting new levels and looking forward to wasting a few more hours in new single-player campaigns.

author: {'steamid': '76561198412378568', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 345, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 345, 'last_played': 1618339469}
review:
The community is nice.

The movement is good.

The weapons are crap. Everything is a barrage of missiles, or plasma bolts, or shotgun pellets. Every fight is a horrible clusterf..k of rockets and chunks of glowing death flying everywhere. I mean, if you enjoy that, feel free to buy the game, but personally i prefer to be able to count the bullets on the screen and address each of them meaningfully. There is a weapon, Thunderbolt, which actually takes skill to use and does not fill the battlefield with 1000 pellets, but good luck getting everybody to stick to it.

But the biggest issue is the glow. You get hit, the screen glows. It flashes white, it flashes orange. I should sue the devs for harming my eyes for whatever 30-ish minutes of multiplayer fighting i experienced. No, there's no way to turn it down. No, it has not been addressed since the game came out. Conveniently i've been told the next update will address it, and that should come out in a couple of weeks... but for some reason i don't really trust that.

I wish i could refund it, but Steam's refund policy is ass. The 5 hours i played were me trying to figure out how to play the game by fighting bots, while waiting for the multiplayer match. Only when i finally joined the latter, did i realize: no, this game is not for me. $15 wasted for 5 hours of boring shooting of dumb bots.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999363101', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 6118, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1972, 'last_played': 1695237658}
review:
Honestly, if you ever so much as looked at Descent, this game is worth your while, and at full price, too. Great enemy design, great level design, good weapon variety and the same angry noises coming out of your mouth after a robot sniped you from around a corner on Insane difficulty. 
The only gripe I have with it is the upgrade system, which does feel very forced. Some tier-2 upgrades are pretty nonsensical and only exist to justify having an upgrade system. If you choose the upgrades that *do* make sense, though, there's a neat sense of progression giving you the firepower you need to survive the brutal, brutal endgame levels. Of course you can also play through the game without upgrading anything - there even is an achievement for that - but you'll have a pretty hard time near the end. The actual feature they wanted here was weapon configurability, which can be done through other means; no upgrade system required.

Looking past this, though, the actual gameplay of Overload is exactly what it should be; it's classic Descent action alternating between slow sniper-type battles and frantic enemy ambushes - sometimes in Lockdown-events where you can't escape from the combat area - that force you to make good use of your arsenal or perish. Like the Descents, Overload expects you to play these levels multiple times, gradually learning where each enemy is, where the secret doors that give you upgrade points and ammunition are, and all the while increasing the difficulty level. There's also a NG+ mode with an even more vicious "Insane+" difficulty available - even with the full endgame weapon arsenals and a ton of upgrades, Level 2 on Insane+ already murders your life if you're not careful. The replay value of Overload stems almost entirely from your own skill improving, which is exactly how it should be in a good action game.

Also worth mentioning, the soundtrack is really good; it's made by several composers who did work on the original Descent series and it really gets into your head after a while - the soundtrack from the endgame alien levels in particular is a great experience when you first get there. And I think I even recognized some motifs from Descent 1 somewhere around the Titan Collider level. Honestly, great stuff.

I'd say buy this game, then buy it for all your friends, then even buy it for people you hate. Just give Revival a reason to get back together and make a sequel! ;-)

review:
This is the the cleanest and sharpest 6DOF shooter I've ever played and mechanically really good. I still think Forsaken has the cooler guns and better soundtrack, but this one is my close second + the first 6DOF I ever completed, because it has a Holo Guide that shows you the way. author: {'steamid': '76561198041924801', 'num_games_owned': 435, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 129, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 129, 'last_played': 1612485308}
review:
I love this game.... Maybe its just the Nostalgia of playing Descent as a child, but this is 100% exactly the same game-play, by the same developers. 

An arcade shooter, where you're put into a complex... complex... Every level takes place inside a moon, planet, etc, and its your job to navigate the labyrinth of corridors, and hallways to complete the missions, find the secrets, and get out.

While this game does take away some of the difficulty the older games had in the form of a drone which will guide you out, and guide you to things you need. (The old games didn't have that). You can simply not use it. Or abuse it. 

You'll find weapons scattered around which you use on the fly to eliminate the enemies in the level, and after each mission you can upgrade your "character" or, rather the ship you fly. 

It's a fun little arcade-esque shout out to the old 1995 Descent games, that you can sink many hours in.

author: {'steamid': '76561198272450593', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 4658, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1274, 'last_played': 1702932362}
review: This game is a  fantastic modern interpretation of the "360 degrees of freedom" gameplay and feel that was introduced with the classic Descent & Descent II from 1995/96.  If you're a fan of those games you'll love Overload.  Highly reccomend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198145206696', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 235, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 119, 'last_played': 1613098144}
review:
It's Descent again. Get it.

0 gravity combat in sort of tight spaces with all directions of movement.

The sound and music are also very good, which is also important since you have all directions of combat.

author: {'steamid': '76561198134617046', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1263, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 370, 'last_played': 1675823752}

author: {'steamid': '76561198012216265', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 585, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 190, 'last_played': 1612333363}
review: Plays fast, really is a modern day Descent

author: {'steamid': '76561197972355522', 'num_games_owned': 1811, 'num_reviews': 163, 'playtime_forever': 196, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 196, 'last_played': 1532577768}
review:
Overload is a retread, in this case of Descent and Descent 2 (1994 and 1996, respectively). And it turns out that‚Äôs 100% okay, because Descent was the path not followed; in the 19 years since Descent 3 was released, almost no games have tackled the ‚Äúsix degrees of freedom‚Äù shooter, with mainstream shooters having moved in the opposite direction. The few that did were either underbaked or something substantially different (namely, the roguelike shenanigans of Sublevel Zero).

Overload is fast & frenetic, combining subterranean maze navigation, twitching shooting, fancy piloting, and secret hunting into an adrenaline-filled package that‚Äôs smooth as butter. The levels are big enough to allow for real exploration but small enough to prevent you from being totally lost, and new enemies and weapons are introduced at a rapid clip. There‚Äôs a handy, retro 3D automap, and the ‚Äúguidebot‚Äù from Descent 2 returns to provide a more naturalistic way to hunt down enemies, power-ups and objectives than the giant floating HUD markers favored by modern open-world games.

It‚Äôs not entirely without its faults‚ÄìRPS forumite Godwhacker summarized them well when he noted that ‚Äúa) there‚Äôs only one enemy AI behaviour, which is the classic ‚Äòfloat forwards shooting‚Äô and b) they‚Äôd put secrets in every level but implemented them Wolfenstein 3D style, with the only way of finding them being shooting every wall.‚Äù But neither of these significantly reduced the fun I had digging out my HOTAS and blowing up robots while spinning in circles likely to make onlookers nauseous.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007646122', 'num_games_owned': 1583, 'num_reviews': 125, 'playtime_forever': 49, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 49, 'last_played': 1611253196}
review:
Does exactly what it promises. Beautiful smooth movement, guns destroy things you shoot at, difficult levels suit all skill ranges. This is a proper old-school shooter and entirely unashamed of it. 

The levels are quick to complete without feeling constrained and there are plenty of secrets and upgrades to find. There is story, but that's not why you play a game like this. Swivel, rotate, slide and shoot your way through an enjoyable time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023909421', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 235, 'playtime_forever': 1455, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 541, 'last_played': 1612176902}
review: inkook

author: {'steamid': '76561198023263037', 'num_games_owned': 130, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 216, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 123, 'last_played': 1611178586}
review: If you liked descent 1-2 this is quit fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198202795398', 'num_games_owned': 371, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 517, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 434, 'last_played': 1610883258}
review:
Overload is a 6D shooter similar to games like Descent 1 and 2. This is the first time I have played a 6D shooter so I hope this review helps newcomers like me.
Presentation-
The game looks great. The environments are greatly textured and the lighting is very well done to create a pretty sweet atmosphere. The music is a banger as well appropriately adding to the the ambience. There is a story told through large paragraphs before missions. There are also audio logs scattered throughout missions which are decently voiced. I personally didn't care for the story mostly because the paragraphs at the start crawled so slowly onto the screen that I got bored and skipped it.
Gameplay-
Now this is the best part about the game. The controls in this game are very tight and responsive which is great. Levels are mostly open areas where you fly around shooting enemy Operators. The operators themselves are very smart. There is a wide variety of enemies each with different weapons and they move around alot and flank you with their numbers. Hopefully you have some pretty sick weapons too divided into primaries and secondaries. Primaries include a stuff like a Machine gun,Flak Canon and Lasers whereas Secondary includes Missiles,Bombs and other various explosives. Level design in this game is really complex and its easy to get lost ,luckily there is a holo guide and an easily readible map to guide you in case you're stuck.
Overview-
I had alot of fun with Overload considering it is my first 6D shooter. Level design can get confusing at times and there are a few difficulty spikes like stuffing you in a small corridor with tons of operators but all these are not major deal breakers. The core gameplay loop is solid and never gets old as the game keeps rewarding you with new toys to play with. Highly recommend it

author: {'steamid': '76561198070139600', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 17654, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 3, 'playtime_at_review': 797, 'last_played': 1711487377}
review: Greatest fps made in a long time!

author: {'steamid': '76561198021982372', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 3235, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2538, 'last_played': 1692572186}
review:
So I wanted a game like Descent in the modern era.  This isn't a game like Descent.  This IS Descent.
Allister Brimble and the rest come back to make it sound like Descent.  It moves like Descent.  Everything from the bot sound effects, to the music, to the weapon sounds, are prettymuch Descent.  The visuals are stunning, like Descent in its final form.

This is Descent, and God bless it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077869887', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 3111, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 256, 'last_played': 1613260544}
review:
This game is awesome! I can't believe it took me this long to play it after buying it. Exploration is tense and ammo management pays off when you can pour all of it into your enemies as you make your daring escape! Eye-candy effects complement shooting mechanics done right. The upgrade system seems good too. My only gripe is that the secrets might be a little *too* secret. I'm pretty obsessive about covering every inch of a level but I still seem to miss the majority of secrets and those can contain super-upgrade points and whatnot.

But yea, overall my first play session was a blast (4 hrs) and I have no doubt I'll finish this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067458221', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 559, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 106, 'last_played': 1693701053}

author: {'steamid': '76561198039034725', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 907, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 689, 'last_played': 1609986433}
review:
Why I put off picking this up for 2 years is beyond me.  This is the successor to the old Descent series.  It is 6 DOF gaming at its finest.  I have not touched multiplayer yet, but the campaign has been engaging, even if the story involves a lot of tropes.

The weapons feel good, and there are some similarities to past weapons from the series.  The only complaint I have is the config is a little limiting.  I was hoping to put my sliding thrust on the mouse stick of my throttle, but I have not figured out how to do so.  I have implemented a work around using other buttons, but it is not as smooth as it could be.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005991503', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 1548, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1698868465}
review:
This is for all the gamers that think the best shooter of the 90s was neither Doom nor Quake but Descent 2.

It's Descent 4 in all but name with an added sensible ship upgrade system that is actually fun. 

Prepare for descent!

author: {'steamid': '76561197975454531', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 677, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 550, 'last_played': 1609678332}

author: {'steamid': '76561197976091020', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 124, 'playtime_forever': 612, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 565, 'last_played': 1642099104}
review:
Been a bit since I played this, but thought that it deserves a thumbs up at least.
Give the free playable teaser demo a go if you need some convincing, it's very good and you can customize a lot of options.

The combat is very punchy, hectic and just fun, robots are pushed around, the explosions and effects are gorgeous, the lighting contributes well into the fights in dark asteroid tunnels and facilities. The controls are intuitive and smooth. The music is absolutely stellar and I still listen to it from time to time in the background.
Sadly the performance was always an issue for me, Unity engine doesn't quite like old potato laptops, and some of the single player campaign levels are large elaborate mazes. 
Most of my meager playtime came from jumping into skirmish because those levels were mostly small, and I just was drawn to that moment-to-moment combat.
Remember that exclusive fullscreen is hidden behind a launch command with Unity engine games:
"-window-mode exclusive"
Borderless is always blurrier, less responsive and more performance intense for older hardware.

Would like to return one day to play through the campaign and DLC, it seemed high quality enough for an indie title, even had voice acting that was decent.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993743199', 'num_games_owned': 448, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 58, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 55, 'last_played': 1623903119}
review: Great fun.  I've only played a bit of the single player campaign but the controls are nicely done and the I got that feeling of playing Descent back when 3dfx was a thing.  Thanks for making it guys!

author: {'steamid': '76561198027905280', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 25, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25, 'last_played': 1607716216}
review:
This feels like it would be the coolest game of my childhood. It moves like a noclip first person shooter instead of a game where you control a vehicle, and has that pleasing nostalgic simplicity of the early 1990s. The weapons are distinct, fun, and each serve a different role. Weapons and your ship can be upgraded between missions, so you can focus on the gear you like to use.

I do struggle with navigation, but the provided guide makes it easy to follow to your objective and the mini-map is wonderfully detailed and precise. I would have found it helpful if there were more decals, details, or difference in textures to serve as visual landmarks.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061233467', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2559, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 837, 'last_played': 1679544028}
review:

I know some people said the vr is not great, but honestly, I don't know what they are talking about. If you don't suffer from motion sickness, no other game I have played gives you such freedom of motion. Even if you don't have vr, this game is great!

author: {'steamid': '76561198854130442', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 1504, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1417, 'last_played': 1654080944}
review: This game is an action adrenaline pumper. I've never played Descent in the past so my review is limited to this game. I enjoyed it. This game, whilst a 3DOF shooter, actually has a certain artistic feel to it, with the music choice and the artwork. It's unlike any other game which I have played in that regard.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992339432', 'num_games_owned': 100, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 798, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 54, 'last_played': 1674429480}
review:
This really is from the creators of decent and freespace. You get massive vibes from just the first few levels. Screw doom nostalgia. How about real pulse pounding space ship nostalgia! Sound track really sets you in to the game and gives off the old school sound effect that you always wanted but never got. The game play is exactly replicated from decent. 

With the minor negative is of the secrets. Where instead of being delayed a special weapon in decent, you have to find it in overload. Not a fan of because that means i have to look up a guide instead of just paying the game. 

I have to say the mouse and keyboard work just fine, but i borrowed a friends ps3 controller for the exact feel of decent and believe me it is PERFECT. You owe it to yourself to get this game if you were a fan of decent and freespace back in the day.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961100560', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 7, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7, 'last_played': 1606446735}
review:
I was really excited to play this game on my new Valve Index, as I was a massive fan of the original Descent back in the day. However, this game has some of the worst performance in VR I have ever seen. I get a consistent 45 fps during gameplay, with 40-50% reprojection, which just makes it ugly as hell and absolutely unplayable. Adjusting settings did nothing to increase performance. Looking around online, it's clear that my system isn't the problem, as many people with systems both better and worse than mine described the exact same performance issues.

I ended up refunding because I bought this game to play in VR, which isn't possible.

System Specs:
i7 8700
16gb RAM
GTX 1070
