author: {'steamid': '76561197970790497', 'num_games_owned': 262, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 571, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 571, 'last_played': 1604975821}
review:
Overload is a spiritual successor to the Descent series. It was made by many of the same people who worked on the original games and it shows. In terms of gameplay it is most similar to Descent 2, barring some modern additions such as the ability to upgrade your ship and weapons. It has a real "just one more level" feel to it and it is an absolute blast to play. I also like that you can deploy a level guide to assist you any time you like, just like it worked in Descent 3.

However, I have to say that the final couple of levels are a disappointment. Not only do they feel rushed to a point where everything looks very samey but they are also a pain to navigate. The portals in one level in particular are a serious nuisance and should have been ommitted.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971569035', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 362, 'playtime_forever': 362, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18, 'last_played': 1605880778}
review: Un onesto clone di Descent, non urla al miracolo ma √® ben fatto.

author: {'steamid': '76561199099721919', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 5627, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 361, 'last_played': 1689035462}
review:
Descent 1 and 2 back in the 90s were my favorite computer games as a kid.  So much fun to have a modern rendition of them!  I agree with some of the reviews that the levels get a little repetitive, but to me destroying bots in battle  is so much fun, I've put about 10 hours in and am not anywhere near being bored with it.  The gameplay is better than the originals, and the graphics are great!  It has such an "old but new" feel.  If you like the old ones, you will love this one.  I really wish there were more games like this and not all just first person shooter that play on one plane of movement.  In my view, Descent is harder, and much more fun to me once mastered than most first person shooters.       

Note:  I didn't previously have a joystick for this, so I took a gamble and purchased the Logitech Extreme 3d Pro Joystick for this and it is perfect!  I couldn't find any recommended controls online, so hopefully this helps somebody:  the Joystick is with my right hand for turning and looking, firing primary and secondary weapons, cycling primary and secondary weapons and melee attack.   Then with my left hand  I use ASD and W on the keyboard to move up and down, E and Q for rotating (flips the craft upside down), Space bar for forward, shift for backward, and Z, caps, F, Q and tab for other miscellanous things like headlights, flare, guide bot, and map.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996519701', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 12, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1602182729}
review:
It is like the good old Descent games but in VR!
I played seated with an Xbox controller and it works great.
The game controls could be improved for VR like the No Man's Sky starship controls to improve immersion even further but the Xbox controller works great for me. However, I have to take a break after each mission due to motion sickness. It is getting better gradually though.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960852791', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 117, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 117, 'last_played': 1531637776}
review:
If you loved playing Co-op Descent with your friends.... then this is not for you. :( 
The developers said they were open to co-op later. Well, It's later... and no co-op. 

Would have been nice. 

If you're into a fun single player experience that feels a lot like Descent, then this game is for you. The mechanics and gameplay make you feel like you're playing a nice remastered descent. 

To me, the lack of coop or really much multiplayer means I can not recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972590051', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 962, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 714, 'last_played': 1702560077}
review:
This is an ABSOLUTELY *AWESOME* Revival of  one of THE **GREATEST** Games of ALL TIME: "DESCENT"!!!!! When I first saw this in Beta Testing, my Jaw DROPPED To The Friggin' Floor!! I was like, "OM*G!!!!! THEY DID IT!!!!! IT'S *REALLY* *BACK*!!!!!"       8v) )

Ever since then, I have set aside Only Special Sessions with this game where I have Plenty Of Time to Soak It All In in a "Total Immersion" type of game play to make the UTMOST of Each Session. After all, this IS Descent Reborn ANEW in a TRULY *FABULOUS* FORM that has me coming back For More And More And MORE!!!!   :)

BIG TIME DOUBLE THUMBS-UP For This One!!!!! The Music for it is *SUPERB* as well!! All in all, a Well Rounded Resuscitation of the Original DESCENT game series!! *VERY* *IMPRESSIVE* 360 Degree Action Shooter if EVER there was one!!!! And with the V.R. interfacing built into the game, It's Even WILDER!!!!!  8v) )

Check This One Out If You LOVE Action Shooters cause This One is SURE TO IMPRESS!!!!! *SUPER* *FUN*!!!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198018965521', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 139, 'playtime_forever': 47, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22, 'last_played': 1606855730}
review:
Remember the sci-fi simulator Descent? Overload is the same!

Descent is one of those games that players in their thirties remember with a nostalgic tear in their eyes. While the younger ones probably have no idea what Descent is. Now all generations of players can experience what flying in narrow tunnels is like. Or in closed rooms, where swarms of robotic enemies are pouring in on you from all sides.

Overload is basically the same as the original DESCENT. Anyone who has ever played Descent will immediately know that these two games have the same genetic basis.

Your opponents fall into four categories. The most numerous group are those who are trying to pierce you with beam weapons. Then there are those who shoot you with rockets from a distance, at best with unguided ones. The third group is represented by robotic drones who want to share it with you up close. And the last category is kamikaze robots that rush to you and detonate. Enemies often understandably attack in mixed groups.

You can gradually hang up to sixteen different weapons on your battleship. There are either cannons (energy or projectile) or a wide range of missiles:

In addition to the story campaign, Overload also offers multiplayer competitions and an endless mode where you can test your reflexes and accuracy. That is, provided that all those turns, turns and quick movements do not make you sick.

     Graphically, the game looks decent, the sound and music are ok. Overload is well optimized and does not require disk space. I would recommend it especially to those who still remember Descent and want to relive the challenge of a tunnel shooter.

     And I secretly hope to see a remake of Descent: Freespace, which in its time offered experiences comparable to the Star Wars space battles. Even without claustrophobic levels, with giant enemy cruisers.


!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! DESCENT !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198103308794', 'num_games_owned': 928, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 1220, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 575, 'last_played': 1669585520}
review:
Hatte das Spiel im Humble Choice und es erinnerte mich an Forsaken was ich auf der Ps1 √∂fters gespielt habe bis ich dann merkte das es genauso ist! Super Geil! Ist zwar von den Descent Machern und ich habe das noch nicht gespielt aber Forsaken ist genauso. Und nur durch dieses Game habe ich rausgefunden das es ein Forsaken Remastered gibt auf Steam was ich mir instant gekauft habe! 

Also wer Bock hat auf einen 90s 360 Grad Shooter in mega H√ºbsch sollte sich das holen! Der Singleplayer ist echt lang hat 15 Level und ich bin nach 9 Stunden erst ca im 7ten da die Level ziemlich gro√ü sind! Und der √úberlebensmodus ist auch cool gemacht und macht viel Spa√ü! Finde es nur sehr schade das der Multiplayer anscheinend Tot ist jedenfalls habe ich nie jemanden gefunden also sollte man das eher mit Freunden spielen.

Klare Kaufempfehlung! Super Geiles Spiel!

author: {'steamid': '76561197963366484', 'num_games_owned': 777, 'num_reviews': 210, 'playtime_forever': 23, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23, 'last_played': 1598746057}

author: {'steamid': '76561198847675807', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 15918, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 29, 'playtime_at_review': 4775, 'last_played': 1711792046}
review: A very fine upgrade to a classic game we all knew as DESCENT and DESCENT II back in the 1990's wherein the player really needs a very powerful computer to play.  Times have changed and so have the look and feel as well as the technology yet here we are enjoying a brilliant six axis of freedom game once again. I do miss the guided missiles however. That was a wonderful feature for a missile that we fire and then aim in much the same way as modern systems. That was present in the old DESCENT but seems to be missing. There are a ton of features here and one item that can be a tad annoying is the puzzle nature of hidden secrets.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075412886', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 337, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1, 'playtime_at_review': 108, 'last_played': 1711875365}
review:
To put this simply, if you liked Descent, You will LOVE Overload! Never played the Descent games? This is a twitchy 360 degree space combat sim. BUT ... it all takes place in a maze of halls, corridors and caves. Did I mention that the locations are crawling with murder bots?

Your ship is quite agile and easy to navigate. The weapons and upgrades are distinct. Pick-ups plentiful. Overload is just crazy fun! I am soooooooo glad that this was made. Currently my favorite game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198018293698', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 137, 'playtime_forever': 461, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 461, 'last_played': 1597874559}
review:
Despite being a pretty big fan of Freespace, I've never tried any of the Descent games‚ÄîDescent is basically only connected to Freespace 1 by a colon in the title, so they just never really crossed my radar. I probably should've played them a long time ago, though, because their spiritual successor Overload is pretty damn awesome.

Developed by many former Descent devs and poaching most of the main gameplay mechanics, Overload is a generally fantastic game. Working as a kind of 360 degree Doom, you traverse claustrophobic bases in a very agile ship, strafing and flipping in any direction as needed to navigate. It's a huge shift from what I've come to expect in the more traditional space sim, which was a pleasant surprise! Overload combines all the freedom of movement I love in space dogfights with the twitchy paranoia of corridors filled with things that want to kill you. 

It all culminates in a thrilling rush to the exit after blowing a generator, twisting, boosting and manoeuvring quick as you can through the squadrons spawned to get in the way. It's a gimmick lifted completely from Descent, but I can see why because it's easily the best part of any level, desperately trying to stay oriented and keep your bearings while your screen visually assaults you will explosions. 

Even the story is a lot better than the average 90s shooter. When I first picked up Overload I played usually one or two levels a day before moving on to whatever bigger game I was working on. But by the midpoint or so, I was getting pretty interested in what would come next, both in terms of plot and level design. By the end, I beat the last five levels in one sitting‚Äîthoroughly hooked, if you couldn't tell.

Being unfamiliar with Overload's main inspiration I'm sure I missed a bunch of other shout-outs and design refinements, but the point is that Overload is super fun even without the nostalgia‚Äîthe best of both worlds that every Kickstarter retro revival should try to hit. It's a criminally underrated game‚Äîlikely done in by the cult space sim audience and impossible to Google name‚Äîand well worth picking up as a sleek, modern entry point to the spaceflight genre.

Ending Question Corner: [spoiler]I noticed I got an achievement for the Beale ending. I've scoured as best I can but can't find anything other than the mention of a Trinidad ending on achievement sites. Anyone else have a clue what causes the split? I'm assuming it's cause I saved all crew members, but would love a confirmation.[/spoiler]

review: The core mechanic is fine (flying) but I don't want to look around for keys and be lost without the auto tracking. As a throwback to Descent it is fine but there is a bit of disconnect - the levels are so simple they are almost low poly but the fights are in contrast very visually busy and confusing. It is not terrible but the game does not really have a consistent artstyle. I hoped to get some fun out of multiplayer but I was not able to join any games so I can't really tell... It is obvious a lot of work went into this game but it just did not reach my expectations.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985453888', 'num_games_owned': 970, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 67, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 67, 'last_played': 1595904248}
review:
So.  It's Descent, but with one of the major issues I used to have with descent fixed:  Collision with wall damage.  With that gone, you can speed through levels, blasting baddies in full 3d with 6 axis of movement and dance through beautiful chaotic fight scenes to get your adrenaline pumping!

Then stop.  And rub up against every single wall panel to find that one hidden door with the upgrade point so you can still handle the baddies further along in the game.  Slowly.  Because at full speed, you might go right past the door.  True, there are sometimes visual cues that there's a hidden door.  But sometimes there's not.  And sometimes the visual cue is a lie.  And sometimes it's a locked door that's part of an area later on.  It would be one thing if the secret doors just had a bit of extra energy, armor, ammo, whatever.  But it has these godforsaken upgrade points.   Or worse, sometimes the hidden doors are actually the next location on the map.

And you need dozens and dozens of these points to upgrade your ship.  Tons of upgrades, only a few every level.  Balls.  A fantastic fun game ruined by "searching for secret doors".  If I wanted that, I'd play D&D.  I don't know if I'll bother finishing it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005130329', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 3617, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2897, 'last_played': 1598113648}
review:
If like me, you are frickin old... and remember the 90's Games Descent and Descent 2... plus the expansions... then prepare your butthole for some nostalgic feels.

To put it simply, this is basically a clone of the originals... and developed by people who actually worked on them.

It's a simple premise, fly into underground bases and complete your missions... Stop the infected autobots... blow reactors and shut down/destroy the outposts.

It's simple shoot up fun and mayhem... the learning curve is good, the levels get harder and the DLC offers plenty of extras... and there's at least 50 or more muiltiplayer maps and challenges. Skiill levels range from Trainee to INSANE... Leaderboards are there to see how you rank against others, but only from Rookie level upwards.... Put it this way... On Rookie, I'm doing ok and in the top 10-20% on most of the challange levels I've played so far.... next level up... My ranking drops drastically.

I'm old you see... in my 40's now and my reflexes aren't what they used to be.

But this game is fun, and I'm put around 50hrs into it so far and have completed the game and the DLC and am halfway through challenges on the first 3 levels. So there's plenty to keep you going and it's well worth the ¬£10 I paid for it.

So grab your popcorn, sit back and remember the good old days when you were actually a gaming god. instead of the podgy middle aged dude you are now. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198067273360', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2962, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2691, 'last_played': 1678400513}
review:
Very similar to the first two Descent series games, and takes more than a few cues from them too.  If you haven't seen or played them, I would suggest checking them out, Descent was the first 360 ship shooter in existence, and there are still those who keep the games working, even after over twenty five years.

Moving on, you start out with a pair of laser cannons and dumbfire rockets.  As you advance, you'll find more advanced weapons that can be used differently, or just do the same thing the previous one did with a slightly different twist.  Those who have played Descent will recognize the weapons, as many of them are almost identical in function to the ones from Descent, with a few that are similar to ones from the third installment (remember the seeker mines?  Powerful but only if they catch the bot.)

The objective in most mission is seek and destroy; Find the core and destroy it.  This will cause the entire facility to be destroyed, so make sure you know where the emergency exit hatch is.

Throughout the missions you can find hostages, a must for advancing quickly, kept in cryotubes.  Just make sure you retrieve them before you blow the core.  Among the levels there are also communications from current and former employees, collect them for a little more lore on the story.


Also as you advance, you encounter more and more powerful enemy robots, each with a different brand of death waiting to serve you.  At the end of every sector, you'll encounter a boss, who will be equipped with unique weaponry that will hurt a lot if it hits you.  Take the boss bot down to advance to the next sector.

Overload uses a lot of what Descent had back in the day, improving on the parts from the originals that...just weren't quite there yet, especially from the third installment (Although lets be honest, there were a lot of things from number 3 that needed improvement.)  If you enjoyed Descent, you'll probably enjoy Overload too.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993621237', 'num_games_owned': 744, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 345, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 343, 'last_played': 1666566035}
review:
While it may not officially carry the Descent name, Overload was developed by many of the same people behind the original Descent franchise, and it shows!  It feels exactly like a new and modernized addition to the Descent series and I couldn't be happier with it - especially since the official Descent Underground title is beleaguered by legal troubles and may never even see the light of day.  I commend the Revival Productions team, who raised half as much money as Descendent Studios to develop their new game, and delivered this rock solid title just over two years later.  By comparison, two years after Descendent Studios' Kickstarter we instead saw Descent Underground removed from Steam Early Access, and nearly three years after that we are still left waiting for any meaningful progress.

+ Modern features
VR support, Tobii eye tracking support, and surround sound audio really take the immersion to the next level - provided you can afford all those accessories and peripherals.

+ Great controls
I love games that let me take full advantage of my Steam controller, and gyro controls really shine with this title.  6DOF games do come with a somewhat steep learning curve, it can take some time to get the hang of navigating and aiming accurately, but using a Steam controller made this less difficult.  You can easily map any other gamepad or joystick you have instead if you prefer.  It is definitely more challenging to play with just a keyboard and mouse however.

+ That Descent feel
The story, the level design and lighting, the models of the enemy robots, the weapons, the sound effects, the music - all of it will bring back that Descent nostalgia by being just similar enough to the original series.  As a fan who played countless hours of the original trilogy of Descent games, I loved every moment of this game.

Other thoughts...

* This game is hard.
I've seen a number of reviews complaining about the difficulty of this game, from the hoards of robots you face during later levels to how hard it can be to locate all of the secrets within the maps.  These are not negatives but positives in my opinion.  I'm honestly tired of how most modern games hold your hand too much and don't present you with a real challenge.  There will be none of that here with Overload.

* Multiplayer, but not enough players
There's maybe at best 30 players online at one time, so while the game supports multiplayer, unless you bring your own friends to play with you there sadly isn't in reality much multiplayer action to be had.  Unfortunately 6DOF games don't have a very big player base to begin with.

* Built on Unity?!
Usually I can tell right away that I am playing a game built on Unity by the obvious lack of quality.  It is very easy for a developer to build a mediocre game on Unity, it is much harder to build a good game on Unity that doesn't immediately look and feel like a Unity game.  Further testament to the skills of the Revival Productions dev team for managing to make such a quality title on this second rate game engine.

review:
Entretenido shooter de naves con 6 grados de libertad. Dificultad endiablada (al menos en Alta) y laber√≠nticos escenarios, afortunadamente la Hologu√≠a nos indica con claridad el camino a seguir (aunque sigue siendo recomendable buscar secretos para mejorar la nave).

En los ultimos niveles (que afortunadamente son un poco m√°s f√°ciles), la hologu√≠a no estar√° disponible, pero son un poco menos laber√≠nticos para compensar.

Sin bugs notables, aunque en algunas partes con muchos disparos de rayo se notaban tironcillos (en una RTX 2080!), y se agradecer√≠a una opci√≥n de VSync a 144Hz, ya que s√≥lo ofrece 30, 60, o sin l√≠mite, que calienta la gr√°fica cosa fina.

En resumen, un juego entretenido de un g√©nero poco habitual, quiz√°s demasiado retro para su propio bien, pero bien acabado.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970472778', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 905, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 699, 'last_played': 1709776991}

author: {'steamid': '76561198170380285', 'num_games_owned': 149, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 260, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 217, 'last_played': 1608849361}
review:
This game is a lot more fun than I originally thought it was going to be. It looked pretty simple and repetitive at first. So I got it on sale and I loved it. It's really fun dodging ships and turning to avoid fire. It looks great and is really satisfying to play. When you kill a ship it starts to drift off until it hits something and explodes. And I just love those effects. 

There's multiple primary and secondary weapons to collect and use. There's secrets found within maps that you find by back tracking and exploring the areas. I usually don't like back tracking in games, but I don't find it as tedious in this game. I don't usually get every secret, but it's still worth it to upgrade my ship. In other reviews I heard it being said that the different stages feel too similar. But I don't agree so far. They use some of the same map elements in different maps, but it doesn't feel too same-y to me.

There is a story, but I have trouble following. I get pieces but I only partly understand. It's partially because i'm busy trying to get hit while also trying to pay attention to some of the story being played at the same time. Of course that only applies to the while playing story bits. Not the pre-game bits. But, I still really enjoy this game. Definitely recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009732307', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 501, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 304, 'last_played': 1693157333}

author: {'steamid': '76561198008717578', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 55, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 55, 'last_played': 1594319182}
review:
They should give you a medal for playing this in VR. Be warned if that's what you're buying it for; I don't get motion sick and I've had 600+ hours in VR now, so you could say I've got my "Sea Legs" but after 10 mins of this game I'm ready to chunder everywhere.

Still if you've got an iron stomach the graphics are sharp and the music is good and it controls well with a gamepad.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971398029', 'num_games_owned': 229, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 847, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 795, 'last_played': 1614573437}
review:
As a spiritual successor to Descent, Overload polishes and improves upon virtually every aspect cribbed from that franchise, but it doesn't quite do enough to [i]evolve[/i] the Descent formula, leaving it feeling perhaps a little too familiar by the time the campaign wraps up.

The 'cutscenes' that are in the campaign (including the one you see every time you escape at the end of a level) don't appear to have sound, so they all feel a little unfinished, especially if -- for whatever reason -- you decide to play without the music on. Since the game also ends with a cutscene, the lack of sound (as well as the lack of bombast with which the cutscene plays out) felt a bit anti-climactic, but this is maybe the only area in the campaign where the polish wasn't up to the high standard set by everything else.

On the music, all the tracks are great, but I none of them instantly stuck in my head like some of the tracks from the original Descent did, though they all did a great job at laying an atmospheric bed for each of the levels.

In my opinion, there are a few too many guns available, and the intended role of many weapons is either unclear, or undermined by other weapons. As such, I rarely felt the need to switch away from the Crusher (essentially a rapid-fire shotgun). If I could make any changes in this respect, I would have made the weapon roster both more streamlined and more specialised in their purpose.

A major downside for anyone interested in multiplayer is that the servers are virtually dead, and setting up a multiplayer game isn't very straightforward, with the server browser only being available though a third-party executable. Further, one of the biggest draws from Descent (as with many other shooters from the era) was the ability to play the campaign cooperatively; a feature that Overload is sorely lacking.

It has its shortcomings, but it's otherwise very solid and -- on sale -- is worth the asking price for the campaign alone.

[h1]Overall: 7/10[/h1]

review:
Really cool game. I've wanted to get into a space shooter of some type but haven't really found too much for me in the few I've checked out. I think even in the small bit of play time I've had I can say that this definitely appeals to me. The controls are really tight whether using KB&M or a Controller (I opted for the former after trying out the controller a  bit) and the shooting feels responsive and satisfying. 

I look forward to digging into the more substantial missions that await now that I've gotten a feel for things.

author: {'steamid': '76561198102801112', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 538, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 466, 'last_played': 1605369076}
review:
This is a Descent clone, made by a lot of the people behind the original Descent series. If you haven't played the original Descent series it was both the first FPS with true 3d graphics and the first shooter in a zero gravity environment. Descent has very sprawling maze-like levels with plenty of Doom-like secret doorways and hidden goodies and that's all present in Overload as well.

+ Controls have been modernised, it's easy to drop in and play I didn't rebind any keys, didn't even feel the need to change mouse sensitivity. Your ship has weight to it and is very easy to control.
+ Lockdown sections (especially the optional ones) explore how different enemies act and work together and put you in an isolated arena suited to those enemies strengths. These sections really stood out in the overall level design.
+ Hidden goodies are easier to find, thanks to better graphical fidelity you can see the seams where wall panels might slide away to reveal a hidden room or cubby.
+ Enemy AI employs a range of tactics. Some enemies are just dumb and sit in place shooting at you. Some will fire off a salvo and run away behind a corner to surprise you later, others will aim to ram into you and if they miss will continue to attack you from behind, others will actively set up flanks and others still will attack head on in a pack and dart away to pull your attention in 3 different directions.
+ Thanks to enemy AI being at the level it is, it's very satisfying to trash them. It actually does sometimes feel like you're outsmarting them.
+ On that note, horde mode! Trash as many bots as you can without dying and make it on to the leaderboards.
+ Weapons are all made to fill a niche and can be upgraded and specialised.
+ No hit-scan weapons, weighty turn speed. You can avoid most shots and you can exploit some enemies slow turning speed to get yourself into their blindspots if you're quick enough.
+ Multiple difficulty settings to offer a nice consistent challenge.

+/- Maze like map design

- Grey rock tunnels look the same in both directions. Overload takes a realistic approach to decorating levels as opposed to Descent with its purple cave walls and running water (on an asteroid) on the floor (in zero-G). Everything looks a lot better but reorienting yourself without those hints is more of a challenge. It's a tradeoff, luckily the minimap is very good.
- There are two pairs of "model twins" among enemies, Goblins and Ogres share the same profile as do Gorgons and Krakens. It's not a mistake you'll make after a couple of hours in game but it's an exceedingly painful mistake for those couple of hours because in both cases one twin is mostly harmless and the other will happily burst you down at medium range. I can't help but compare to Descent once again, not only did each enemy design have its own unique garish paint job but they were also all radically different shapes so none of their targeting profiles blurred together. This is again a tradeoff with graphical fidelity, thanks to all the pretty lighting and reflections it's hard to tell what kind of paintjob a particular bot has at a glance.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968892172', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 4403, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1529, 'last_played': 1699327207}
review: If you're looking to scratch the Descent itch, look no further. Having to rely on your memory and mini-map - not a GPS - with level design that forces your brain to re-calibrate away from modern games, just felt awesome. And almost exactly like the original games. Awesome neon effects, metallic reflections, hi-res textures and silky frame rate makes the entire experience better. The upgrade system is fun to progress  thru - and seems well-mapped to the increased difficulty of the levels and bad guys. Playing in Hotshot, the firefights are challenging without being frustrating. There is an abstract, spatial quality to the action that requires one dust off their old kinetic skillset to succeed. The game allows you to cautiously work your way thru the level, almost at the pace of a survival shooter - except during the Lockdown sequences, boss fights and generator hunts, so if you'd like, a mix of frantic and slow. Music sounds right at home. If you liked the originals, there's just no way you won't enjoy this.

review: I purchased this hoping for a glimmer of fond childhood memories of a beloved game. Instead what I got was a tunnel through time to a summer spent deep in PTMC mines against a horde of hostile robots. This game is classic Descent with a fresh coat of paint. Everything about it feels and plays like the original games and I've spent the last few nights staying up later than intended, just to finish one more level.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973616858', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 588, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 166, 'last_played': 1594026890}
review: So to start, I absolutely LOVE this game so far. It is one of my favorite VR games, it's very easy to jump into, and surprisingly doesn't give me a lot of nausea like I thought it might. I grew up playing the original Descent with my Dad, I'd sit on his lap, he would steer using the keyboard and I would shoot using a joystick. One of my fondest gaming memories ever. I haven't played much since then, but apparently there's been quite a few iterations since then. But I hadn't had much interest until I saw this was in VR. Plays perfectly with keyboard & mouse...now for the downside, and I'm only a few levels in so bear with me. I originally started in hotshot, and I did pretty good to start. Third level in, and there's too many enemies at once in a tight corridor in my opinion. It seems like they tried to make it "more exciting" but at some points it was just ridiculous. Fun, but 20 enemies all at once firing in all directions? Forget it. I'll continue to play, but for those of you just starting out, the difficulty goes from 0 to 1000 real quick. Received through humble bundle.

review:
This is a pretty cool experience, never played Descent myself (was more of a simulation nerd). Pick up powerups, armor, energy and access keys while you go through the levels, like a regular FPS game, but in 3D with some inertia. Flightsimmers won't have any problems playing this.

My only gripe is that the flashing stuff (access keys) should be removed from the game. There is no need to make your customers suffer from an epileptic episode while playing the game. Other than that, awesome game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068661196', 'num_games_owned': 1072, 'num_reviews': 141, 'playtime_forever': 450, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 3, 'playtime_at_review': 442, 'last_played': 1711686261}
review:
Overload is an exceptional tribute to the Descent series. It keeps everything you hold dear from the classic series, but also introduces enhancements and adds extras such as collectibles, challenge mode, and achievements. The Cronus Frontier (campaign mode) features 16 levels and three bosses, while Challenge Mode allows you to choose between 12 different levels. Speaking for myself, I like the level design and enemy diversity.

In other words, Overload is one of the best choices if you're looking for a modern and contentful Descent-like/6DOF game. Its developers are the creators of Descent themselves, and it's unlikely it will disappoint you, especially if you like mazes, challenging shooters, sci-fi, or already know what to expect.

author: {'steamid': '76561198110249346', 'num_games_owned': 937, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 33, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 33, 'last_played': 1592890786}
review:
I've always _wanted_ to like ship based shooters, but never have I played one I could enjoy. Overload manages to break this incredibly long streak for me. It manages to not be overly punishing by not causing damage when bumping into walls etc, and the controls are easy and intuitive.

What's more, this game somehow manages to bring back the charm of games years gone by that seems to have all but disappeared in the recent titles. Games these days have become a bit like websites - they all follow a certain theme and template, too scared to break out of that mold. Overload manages to break free of that and pull it off quite well. I will admit, it's been a while since I've attempted any ship shooter style game, so it's possible that there are lots of games like this out before it and I may be unaware.

I will have to continue playing in order to get a better understanding of how much I enjoy the game, but so far it's managed to impress me beyond the highest bound I expected of this style game

author: {'steamid': '76561198040370585', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 157, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 91, 'last_played': 1598528335}
review: Plays great. A lot of fun if you're looking for a shooter with a high skill ceiling. The way the narrative is presented reminds me of Armored Core, which I happen to like a lot. I strongly recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075765278', 'num_games_owned': 301, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 824, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 786, 'last_played': 1593142702}
review:
Overall I liked Overload better than I was expecting (given the free demos). I thought the gameplay was very good, the different weapons all felt unique and there were situations for most of them. The biggest problem is that upgrade progression is tied to finding secrets in the world (to find upgrade points). These points are rather hard to find, and are simply just finding "the out of place tile" or looking on the map which is really annoying (as opposed to figuring it out through context which I really like). Because these points are progression you basically have to find them or the game will be really difficult. Finding these secrets is also tied to destroying control panels, but it's not at all clear which panel is linked to which doors, which is a huge problem. Towards the end the enemies didn't keep up with upgrades so they became a little bullet-spongey which was disappointing.

I thought the level design was really good, for the first 80% or so of the game I could never really be sure I was "safe" - things kept jumping on me all the time, which I really liked. I figured out most of the patterns by the end and it wore off though. 

I thought the story was going to just be an excuse for asteroid levels but it turned out to be deeper than that and had some gameplay consequences which was pretty neat. A lot of the findable logs told the story but it was missable so they basically caught you up in-between levels which was pretty cheap. Every log seemed to be directly related to the story, there's no "world building" logs. 

If you're interested in 6dof shooters this is almost the best "pure shooter" I've played - everspace has much better world building, a more interesting story, and better progression, but for pure gameplay overload is better. I still prefer everspace myself though by far because I like the former qualities better. I personally think UT99 is still better than Overload (better weapons, levels, aesthetic) but that's a high bar.

One caveat - steam cloud sync does not work, so make sure to back up your saves if you want to keep them.

6/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197995240388', 'num_games_owned': 1757, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 482, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 482, 'last_played': 1592521115}
review:
Very fun game if you like blasting space robots for a few hours. Offers a dizzying level set that properly takes into account the 6 degrees of freedom mechanic. Has a great assortment of classic video game features such  20+ weapons, secret doors, fast pace movement, and a ton of enemies - which all flow together in a great harmony. Robot explosions are well crafted, weapon firing mechanics work how you would expect, and the flying mechanic defaults to an easy method for noobs out of the box. Everything can be taken to more extreme levels with VR support, eye tracking, joysticks, or advanced flying mechanics so that fans of the genres can really get everything they want. 
The campaign was fun but only varied slightly towards the end. It was mostly the same level design but in different layouts. There is a new game+ and challenge modes to really flush out the capabilities of this game.

I only played the main campaign because that is all that interested me but there is definitely a lot of content for those that like blasting robots and want a challenge.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005430003', 'num_games_owned': 359, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 464, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26, 'last_played': 1632006105}
review:
It's basically a modern version of Descent in VR and it's awesome!
If you're a fan of Descent, you'll love this. Playing it brings back so many good memories.
The music is even similar and so is the plot.
You're also in a mining colony.
The gameplay is solid and fun.

The VR is great, it feels like you're on a motion simulator ride. It does not support the Oculus controllers, so I had to use an Xbox controller. It's not a big deal though because you're just piloting a ship.
I would give a heads up though, this is a game that will definitely give you motion sickness, so only play in brief spurts and make sure to take breaks.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999443165', 'num_games_owned': 1839, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 805, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 187, 'last_played': 1624735339}

author: {'steamid': '76561198040811698', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 429, 'playtime_forever': 283, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 193, 'last_played': 1592179163}
review:
Recommended for fans of first-person and degree-of-freedom shooters. It definitely felt like one of the better 6DOFs in recent years.

+Visuals and music
+Weapon and enemy variety
+Levels and secrets
+Difficulty options
+Scout ghost ensures you are never really lost
+Voiced story

-Repetitive, missions feel very similar
-Story is not very cohesive
-Unlimited enemies in some areas

author: {'steamid': '76561198008755524', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 121, 'playtime_forever': 155, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 103, 'last_played': 1643272101}
review:
Wayy back in the late 90's I played Descent with a friend on our school computer (that was the rule) and one would control movement whilst the other, weapons. A few months ago while browsing VR games I came across Overload and learned that it was a successor to Descent. I was so happy to come across the game again and FINALLY KNOW WHAT THE OG WAS CALLED. Picked this up in the Humble Choice recently. 

It's addictive it's really great to play. "Nostalgia" revised modern. I don't think you should expecct anything too fancy in terms of story or whatnot. It's more of an arcaadey shoot-em-up and fun game to enjoy; and in that it EXCELS. 

Simple, fun, oh and this time you get upgrades. 

I might still get Descent again for old times...

author: {'steamid': '76561197970761123', 'num_games_owned': 2960, 'num_reviews': 904, 'playtime_forever': 928, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 928, 'last_played': 1591481528}
review:
Disclosure: 

I backed this game on Kickstarter because many of the people who created this game gave me my start in the game industry.  I‚Äôve worked closely with some of the people on the team. I didn‚Äôt even give this game a score when I looked at it previously because I am biased. 

After the first hour:

Overload is a return to the era of Descent.  I think Descent was the first 6 Degrees of Freedom game where the player flies around a mine to blow up the reactor and escape.  Overload is essentially the same game though made a couple of decades later.

Much of Overload is exploring large environments and trying to find keycards, stranded civilians, and the reactor, all while dealing with modified mining drones that will attack you on sight.  This isn‚Äôt the stand and shoot type of game, but more focused on constantly moving and dodging attacks while shooting the enemies as well.  It‚Äôs very different from anything that is currently out there in the video game market.

A big piece here is that 6 degrees of freedom.  What that means is the game allows you to move and rotate your ship in any direction, similar to how planes would operate, but without the force of gravity it creates a very strange experience with trying to move through the large bases you‚Äôre on. 

I would recommend this to anyone who remembers Descent or anyone who wants a very different style of gameplay.  Overload is made to replicate the original game so if you‚Äôre not interested in a game like Descent, this might not be for you. There is also a slight chance of motion sickness because you can move in all six directions but I didn‚Äôt experience that myself. 

There is also a VR mode for the game so if you like VR, you could check that out but I would also caution on that because I find that VR mode hard to play and it‚Äôs a bit sick inducing. 


Related Video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VkVbu6KqWcM&t=959s

author: {'steamid': '76561197972040704', 'num_games_owned': 1844, 'num_reviews': 725, 'playtime_forever': 84, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 84, 'last_played': 1591844879}
review:
Descent, Descent 2, and Descent 3 were games I was quite into back in the '90s. Such freedom of movement, in regard to not only sliding in various directions, but turning and traveling in various directions as well. It was wild at the time, and as a bit sci-fi fan, I was sold. The music was neat at the time, the gameplay was cool, and there weren't really any other games I played that compared with it. Secrets were fun little temptations to get the next cool weapon one mission before the game practically bounced it off your windshield later on, and it worked. This was essentially the same tactic games like Doom and Doom 2 used in the '90s as well. Great stuff.

Overload is mostly a love letter to Descent in that it feels almost exactly like playing a Descent game with far better graphics, high-quality sound, and even better music than before! The gameplay is slicker/smoother, the new "guide-bot" (or whatever this game calls it) is nice for helping you find enemies, exits, reactors, etc. like in the original, if not better than before, and just...so much is here to love!

However, the way this game handles secrets deviates from the way the original handled them - and by proxy - the way Doom and Doom 2 handled them. Instead, it uses an approach more akin to how Doom 2016 handles secrets. So instead of  just being delayed on obtaining something, you permanently lose it and are gimped the rest of the game. How so? Well, Overload has upgrade spheres hidden around the levels. A few are plain as day, and others are so hidden that I scoured the first mission and only found half of them. There are a limited number of these, and based on the number appearing in each mission, and the number of upgrade points one can spend, if you miss some of these, you will never get all of the upgrades. This is not in line with the premise of the original Descent games, and I find it to be to Overload's detriment.

While I love persistent upgrades, having missable upgrades in a game where you can literally fly in any direction through sprawling maps with hidden doors is counter-intuitive to the exciting pace the original games had. Flying around in Descent 1-3 was exciting and didn't have terrible slow-down. However, if you're having to search everything or get permanently gimped on upgrades, then the pacing is drawn to a screeching halt. Although I overall enjoyed Doom 2016, the '90s Doom games handled pacing far better with their secrets, whereas Doom 2016 had missable persistent upgrades. It was annoying in Doom 2016, but with the additional freedom of movement afforded by Overload, finding all of the persistent upgrades becomes an even more aggravating chore detracting from my enjoyment of the game.

As someone often against games over-relying on nostalgia, I find it surprising to be stating that I would have vastly preferred the original Descent games' approach to secrets and new goodies be used than the Doom 2016 model. I believe that the original way of handling secrets was wholly superior to how Overload handles them.

However, if you just don't care about being permanently gimped as you go through games, or you have fun pausing, looking up a walkthrough for a secret, unpausing, rinse, wash, repeat, until you've found all the upgrades in every mission lest you miss them, then this won't matter to you. =p

author: {'steamid': '76561197970674841', 'num_games_owned': 2103, 'num_reviews': 231, 'playtime_forever': 886, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 886, 'last_played': 1591763737}
review:
(9/10)

True modern game in the "Descent" 6 degree of freedom design.  You get all of the crazy mind bending maze tunnel gameplay, modern graphics, real upgrade paths, a ridiculous number of secrets, other challenge modes to play through, and a few modern nice touches like a really useful auto mapping system and navigation probe to help lead you around to things you want to get to.

Difficulty scales pretty reasonably on the lower levels, but you can easily crush your soul with absolutely insane difficulties if you really want to.  There is even a pretty decent story that plays out as you work your way through the levels.

Absolutely a must-purchase for anyone who loved the original Descent games, but beware, a good sense of direction and a solid sense of strafing shooter tactics are critical to really enjoying things here.

author: {'steamid': '76561198242342814', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 745, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 745, 'last_played': 1590666705}
review:
-CONCLUSION-
The game looks dull all the time, the levels are the same and unmemorable, the story is boring and uninspired, it's so dark so you will be throwing flares everywhere, the weapons are underwhelming (except for 3 i guess), and the sound effects are similar (pew pew). BUT, the AI and core gameplay is remarkable, the music is above average, movement is on point.

Overall, i had very good moments with this game, but i just can't recommend it to anyone because there are so many bad moments i had with being stuck in a dark tunnel, throwing flares everywhere, and interpreting where i was in the automap. COMPASS PLEASE!

The one below the line goes to the specifics
=================================================
------------------( AESTHETICS )------------------
The aesthetics and colors are so dull i just can't enjoy it, I've never had this kind of problem until now.

If you played the first level then you've seen it all. All of the levels are just grey rock or grey metal with some neon lights slapped in the corners. I didn't have a sense of progressing because all of the levels look the same. 

         FOR EXAMPLE, what do you think a mining facility should have to mine? Drills, shovels, and something to haul the resources? Guess what, none of these appear in the levels were you're supposedly in a 'mining facility'.

The enemies aren't any better either. The silhouettes and colors are all similar in appearance which makes them hard to differentiate which enemy is which. None of the enemies are memorable visually; i can only think of one, but only because it makes a certain sound.

But the main problem is with the DARKNESS. There is only a few light sources that actually does something, and that makes everything more eye squinting. Going to tunnels that splits everywhere while not knowing where you are or what you're looking at is so nauseating.

Which brings me to

----------------------( LEVEL DESIGN )-------------------------
The level design is best described as a bunch of tubes interconnecting each other. I don't mind this kind of level design at all but if ALL of the levels are like this, then it will feel repetitive. And that's exactly what the level design of this game is, a jumble of tubes everywhere.

There are many unnecessary walls, and secrets are scattered randomly. So when you want to 100% it it will be a massive chore with you constantly looking at the automap and wandering around like a zombie

-------------------------( GAMEPLAY )----------------------------
This is a challenging game, you'll probably die a lot. I don't mind that, but there's a super fancy death sequence every time you die that get's very annoying. And there's no "load latest-save" option, so you have to manually load the last save. All of this amounts to a very time consuming death which you will see A LOT.

Weapons are boring and uninspired, 80% use the exact same projectile but with a different color on it. One is a basic pew pew weapon, the other one is a basic pew pew weapon but it bounces! That is how the weapons are like in this game, with only an exception of 3 weapons. The missiles are a different story though, they are actually great!

Codec dialogues are everywhere, and there's nothing you can do about it when you accidentally collect one and have to hear an essay about the evil mcbusiness doing evil stuff.

Flares? really? Yes, i know the Descent games were the same. But with a game as dark as this, and a futuristic world with space colonies, you would expect a flashlight in your ship. Instead you constantly press the f key to see where you're going.

The movement is actually great! It feels responsive and you can rebind the controls when it doesn't feel right.

The AI is one of the BEST i have ever seen! They flank you from behind, some snipe you and quickly hide away. They all have individual personalities and i love it! They know what they're doing if it comes to programming.


----------------------( Other )--------------------------------
Here's some other ones I like and also don't like but i don't know where to put it

- music is good
- challenging
- the story is terrible, but that isn't exactly the big selling point of the game
- The cockpit view is hilariously unfinished
- cheaply spawns an enemy behind you once you collect some secrets

author: {'steamid': '76561198053131972', 'num_games_owned': 547, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 293, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 129, 'last_played': 1668637952}
review:
So first i wanted to say that ive never heard about this game, i got it from Humble Bundle Choice June 2020.

I was really surprised how unique and fun this game is. At first i was getting really motion sick, even without playing it in VR (that must be some other level of gameplay), there is no up or down, well there kind of is, but isnt at the same time :D so i had to take pauses after each level.

Once you understand the mechanic and start using the map, uncover some secrets, it gets really addicting, at least for me, when you just want to explore all the secrets and finish the level on 100%

I really recommend it for anyone who is looking for some new exciting ways to train his aim and shooting skills.
There are many weapons & upgrades to unlock, and the levels get more complex the further you are.
Im playing it on the medium difficulty, and even there, things sometimes get tough, when you are surrounded by many enemies, you dont have much energy and ammo and you just dont know what to do first :D I can only imagine how hardcore the game would be on the hardest difficulty.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980785450', 'num_games_owned': 2605, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 755, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 147, 'last_played': 1592614807}
review:
[b][url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/448850/]Overload[/url][/b] is an awesome modern replacement for the [url=https://store.steampowered.com/bundle/5605/]The Descent Classic Collection[/url]!  I didn't even know this game existed until I saw it was part of the June 2020 [url=https://www.humblebundle.com/subscription]Humble Bundle Choice[/url].  This is what the now-dead [url=https://steamcommunity.com/app/360950/]Descent: Underground[/url] could have been.  

The first thing that struck me was the perspective-curved menu, which was fresh and modern.  I enjoyed working my way through the levels, trying to find the security keys, finding secrets and secret levels, destroying enemies in spectacular explosions, and trying to stay alive to accomplish the missions.  There's a ship upgrade system to help your ship to overcome stronger enemies, or more difficult levels, requiring you to discover upgrade tokens hidden through the levels in order to take advantage of.  The game itself looks and plays great, being quite sharp and highly polished.  It has trading cards, lots of achievements, a free [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/884970/]Overload Level Editor[/url], built-in cross-platform multiplayer modes, and also mod support.

It's easy to become disoriented while playing, due to the [i]six-degree-of-freedom (6DoF)[/i] nature of the game, just like the original [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/273570/]Descent[/url]. To offset this, you're provided with a 3D level-map to help you find your way if you're lost, which can also be used to help you find secrets.  In addition to this, you have flares and headlights built into your ship to help you navigate darker sections of a level, and a holographic guide-bot to lead you to where you want to go.

On the downside, the Internet multiplayer aspect of it could have been improved, because you need to find the IP address of a server to join using a web browser, and I felt an in-game server listing would have helped immensely.

Aside from that, I highly recommend this game if you're even slightly a fan of any games in [url=https://store.steampowered.com/bundle/5605/]The Descent Classic Collection[/url], because [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/448850/]Overload[/url] is clearly the spiritual successor of them all!  If you are interested in the genre, or want to give 6DoF a try, you don't want to miss this game!

[h1]9/10[/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198011817913', 'num_games_owned': 2361, 'num_reviews': 178, 'playtime_forever': 377, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 99, 'last_played': 1591654296}
review:
Are you too dang old for these modern Battle Royale games, Call of Duty clones and Multiplayer online battle what'sits? Do you have fond memories of the 90s? Did you like Descent 2?

If you answered yes to all of these questions (or maybe just the last one) then I have great news for you: This is a modern Descent 2. Just with an added upgrade system (which is actually pretty cool and strongly encourages level exploration), the guidebot from Descent 3 (yep I'm okay with this, 6DOF shooters are always a battle against disorientation more than anything else), and fancy modern graphics (it's an older version of Unity but it gets the job done). Absolutely nails what it's trying to do.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064958776', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 324, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 301, 'last_played': 1591500325}
review:
I loved Descent 1 and 2 when i was a kid. When the reboot of the series ran into legal trouble and pretty much disappeared off the face of the planet, gotta say i was pretty bummed. However apparently this existed this whole time and I just now learned about it because of this months Humble Choice, and gotta say, this game is exactly what I'd expect from a Descent 4. If you enjoyed the original Descent games then you will enjoy this. In almost every way this game is Descent, just without the name. 

A few notes:

Mouse and keyboard support is good in this game! If you tried playing the original Descents with M+K you know how unwieldy it is. fortunately not the case with this game.

I haven't tried multiplayer, but with how it is set up, I imagine that it is something that you would want to try to set up with friends rather then randoms. (I'll add and edit if I ever get to try it out)

author: {'steamid': '76561197971773177', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 44, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 44, 'last_played': 1574093209}

author: {'steamid': '76561197967429573', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 129, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 65, 'last_played': 1671620445}
review:
This is a VR (Oculus Rift S) Review:

I just got the game on the humble bundle, which was a very nice surprise, since I've been wanting this game for quite a while now, but wasn't sure if I would like it.

I played Descent 2 alot as a kid with my original Microsoft Sidewinder Joystick back in the day. I always loved the fast paced action and the great soundtrack. I would have never thought that I would be playing the successor in VR some day, but they absolutely nailed it. The action is faster and more frantic than ever, the soundtrack still rocks (and is similar in style) and the controls with the xbox controller is super fast and precise (after getting used to it). This is just great fun in VR, I really love it. Only thing I noticed is that the performance sometimes drops with many enemies and explosions on screen. Granted, I have every setting on high (no super sampling though), but I'm also rocking a 3900X with a RTX 2080 Ti.

Overall I would definitely recommend this game to VR users and old school Descent fans!

author: {'steamid': '76561198001399556', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 133, 'playtime_forever': 79, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21, 'last_played': 1625922666}
review:
This game guys! If you are old enough to remember the old "Descent" DOS games, then this game will melt your heart. If you liked them though. My god! The controls and atmosphere are so tight, that you are going to get ported straight back to 1994. Playing this without VR is no problem. 

It is really really good with the right nostalgia feel. I would say, even though you arent familiar with the Descent franchise, this game could tickle your fancy. Go get it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198318042253', 'num_games_owned': 54, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 817, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 214, 'last_played': 1692461653}
review:
Une tr√®s bonne reprise des tireurs √† 6DOF, ce jeu est pour ceux qui ont tout simplement envie d'encha√Æner des kills sans poser de questions. Mais attention, ce n'est pas une ballade dans le parc. Il m'a fallu du temps pour bien comprendre le mouvement du vaisseau dans l'espace tridimensionnel. Sans compter les multiples fois ou un ennemi embusqu√© m'a tir√© dans le dos, petit c√¥t√© Valve. Le tout dans des maps labyrinthiques qui donnent du fil √† retordre! 
Clavi√©ristes s'abstenir, une manette ou multiples joysticks sont s√ªrement n√©cessaire pour jouer √† ce jeu. Pour ma part, j'utilise une manette Xbox 360. L'int√©gration est bonne, voire excellente compar√© √† bien des jeux, mais la manette manque s√©rieusement un sixi√®me axe, qui m'aurait √©t√© bien utile dans plusieurs contextes.

Finalement les graphiques. Ce sont pour moi le point fort de ce jeu. J'ai toujours aim√© les jeux 6DOF, mais Descent ne permet pas aux cartes graphiques modernes de s'illustrer pleinement (normal pour un jeu qui a pr√®s de 30 ans). Le design d'overload est excellent et il est agr√©able de voir un excellent gameplay modernis√©.

Petit point n√©gatif: Je trouve ce jeu un peu redondant. Entre les niveaux qui ont des objectifs semblable au d√©but, cela me procure g√©n√©ralement une heure de plaisir √† la fois. Avec un mal de t√™te! J'ai toutefois toujours h√¢te d'y revenir apr√®s une petite pause!

Est ce que ce jeu s'adresse √† tout le monde? Non. Beaucoup de gens n'aimeront pas la complexit√© d'un jeu 6DOF. Est ce qu'il remplit une niche? Pour ceux qui aiment les d√©fis, absolument!
En somme: 4.5/5

author: {'steamid': '76561197960320897', 'num_games_owned': 408, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 291, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 33, 'last_played': 1690716338}
review:
This game has started out badly in early access. I have regretted spending my money on this spiritual successor of descent/forsaken. 

BUT: things have changed. Given a little time, handling feels smoother and much more interesting, orienation is working flawlessly even for new players and looks (as well as performance!) are stellar. The voice messages telling the story add a nice touch, the atmosphere is great. I will now go finish the game!

author: {'steamid': '76561197998094126', 'num_games_owned': 1682, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 687, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 687, 'last_played': 1590813550}
review:
Great 6DOF game.  Had very few issues, and great technical support on discord when I did have an issue that turned out to be related to a separate program I had installed.  

The diversity of weapons is decent and the levels are well made, if a little confusing.  Thankfully the map is available and pretty decent.  I wish I didn't have a search every nook and cranny to get a decent number of upgrade points, but other than that I have no complaints.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972140284', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 10681, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5769, 'last_played': 1700961066}
review:
A successor to "DESCENT", with fairly solid VR support.

Been falling in love with it ever since Valve added World-Scale settings to SteamVR‚Ä¶(60% FTW).

Has story/campaign mode, and a highly-replayable Challenge mode (good quality/quantity of arenas, spawns, etc‚Ä¶be sure to check it out);

///\\\
\\\///

Regarding World-Scale and VR:

1.
100% scale is unnaturally large on the Valve Index...(a cockpit sized for a giant; robot-monstrosities; etc)...I highly recommend reducing scale by at least 20% ( I prefer 60%).

(SteamVR -> Settings -> Video -> Per Application -> Overload).

2.
If you've already lost your ability to experience discomfort in VR, try disabling the cockpit...it improves both gameplay and performance.

3.
Nearly all in-game Graphical settings can be reduced to minimum without fundamentally altering image quality.

‚Ä¶just keep the following settings one step above the lowest tier:

"Shadows"

"Effects Lighting"

"Texture Resolution"

"Post-Processing"

*Anisotropic Filtering (negligible performance cost)

*Screen Space Reflections (negligible performance cost)

**Reduced Shaders**
Enemy cloaking causes a spontaneous performance drop in some Arenas...the reduced shader setting appears to prevent this by disabling the effect on some maps, but it also reduces the quality of dynamic lighting for sparks/explosions.

4.
Weak CPUs may choke in specific sections of a map due to the to the aggressive/sloppy automatic culling used in the game. Just keep that in mind and/or stay a certain distance away from certain fans, etc.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991804060', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 8998, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8426, 'last_played': 1612342123}
review:
As someone who's played the Descent series since I was practically a toddler, I feel like my recommendation of this game should carry some weight. Overload satisfied my craving for both a reimagining of the Descent experience and a 6DOF game in VR, even with my skepticism about its capability to do so. I had a blast initially playing through Overload a number of times, and even revisiting its campaign a few years later. I feel like I'd be doing a disservice to anyone who might appreciate a wonderful 6DOF experience by not recommending this game, but by the same token I feel obliged to temper that recommendation with some of the major flaws of Overload.

My biggest issue with Overload is the level layout. I never quite felt [i]lost[/i] in any of the levels like I did in Descent. That's probably because most of the levels are obnoxiously linear. The Titan and [spoiler]first two alien[/spoiler] levels, in particular, are horrible offenders on this front, which is particularly unfortunate considering they constitute the bulk of the game. The two Phoebe levels are significantly less linear than the rest of the game, but still don't manage to be quite as exciting to traverse as any of the original Descent levels. In almost all the levels, the exit is located very close to the reactor, so you'll never have to fear getting lost in the mines as they're about to implode around you like you would in Descent, which definitely detracts from the excitement of actually overloading the reactors.

The soundtrack was also a bit of a letdown. I've been listening to the Descent I soundtrack almost as long as I've been playing the game, and its music has always been a personal reference point for what video game music [i]should[/i] be. Perhaps the flaw here comes from Overload attempting to emulate Descent II's music, but the soundtrack almost always seemed to be unnoticeable or trying too hard. There were a few exceptions, namely Titan Workshop, Titan Harbor and [spoiler]Cygnusoria[/spoiler]'s music, which all felt like they added to the immersion of their respective levels. On review, I found a further few tracks to be notably good, but still didn't feel they quite fit their levels.

I've also found the netcode for this game to perform poorly. In my experience with online play, I found that I was practically unable to connect shots with opponents without leading tremendously, far in excess of what one would expect from the velocity of the target. On top of that, there's no cooperative play for the campaign mode - a disappointing omission given that Descent included such a feature far ahead of its time.

Also, the Kodachi gunship and most of the operator designs look dorky. It's a minor complaint, but still disappointing to me, especially when I imagine the Kodachi next to the Pyro or most of the operators next to their Descent counterparts. Perhaps another minor complaint - the upgrade system is something I enjoyed, but at the same time frustrates me in that it effectively prevents any true "cold starts" of individual campaign levels.

Aside from those complaints, the game is solid. It has a terse but compelling story which is nicely accentuated by the log file powerups you'll find throughout and begins its climax with [spoiler]Cygnusoria, complete with its awesome musical intro and confrontation with Kantor[/spoiler]. It has beautiful environments that feel like an appropriate modernization of Descent's visuals. It has a nice variety of weapons, some better and some worse than their Descent counterparts (don't get your hopes up for the Plasma-equivalent), though not every Overload weapon has a Descent counterpart and vice-versa. It has a fantastic challenge mode which, albeit a sorry replacement for secret levels, stands strong in its own right. It has a weapon select menu that slows time when open, which is a subtle addition that makes combat feel drastically more fluid and satisfying. Oh, yeah, it also has GREAT 6DOF COMBAT, and that alone is enough for a fun game.

Overload met my expectations, but did not exceed them. Given that my expectations have been set by the high bar of the Descent series, however, I think it's impressive that Overload has simply met them.

author: {'steamid': '76561198351698577', 'num_games_owned': 216, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1597, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1559, 'last_played': 1608708550}
review:
I played "Descent" (the 1995 Parallax software DOS game) like it was a part time job - this is an amazing return to that feeling, and the addition of VR is wonderful.  
The game is fun and challenging, the controls are responsive, it looks amazing; the levels are well-designed, and navigating the sprawling 3D levels is immersive.  Plus it maintains a nice sense of style.

However, there's a lot of little elements of the VR experience that make it seemed tacked on as an afterthought.  For example:
I wish more of the HUD was on the surfaces inside the ship, rather than hovering, or attached to the player's view; I think that'd help 'ground' the player more into the cockpit, which may help with the little bit of motion sickness I'm getting (which I never got from the old games).  Also the way the weapons magically appear & disappear kinda takes me outta the moment.
It'd also be nice if debris bounced off the windshield, rather than floating magically into where my legs should be.
Being able to change difficulty levels mid-game I'd also welcome; I'm on HotShot, and it's a bit too easy, but I'm too deep in and I've spent too many upgrade points to want to re-start now.

review:
Yes, yes, yes, yes, YES!
As a big fan of Descent 1 & 2 (haven't played the 3rd one), I cannot believe I missed the release of this game.
But this big mistake is fixed now!

This is Descent. Period.

My only concern is for the VR mode. It's badly optimized and there is a lot of stuttering, even with all the graphics settings to low.  (and there is really not much to display...)
Hope to see a fix someday.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970807880', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 182, 'playtime_forever': 526, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 277, 'last_played': 1585952992}
review: Decent is one of my favorite games of all time and I thought for sure I would have liked Overload. But there were no players found by the online matchmaking, and multiplayer was one of my favorite parts of Decent. I also didn't like how enemies spawn behind you, especially not the infinite respawn zones. Maybe that was in the original Decent too but I don't remember it bothering me if so. In this game it just feels unfair, many times I go around a corner enemies are in my face and I take damage I didn't really have much of a way to avoid. I also don't like the heavy secret aspect, I feel like I'm forced to search every nook and cranny and punished when I beat the level and only got 1 / 7 upgrade points.

author: {'steamid': '76561198833804175', 'num_games_owned': 106, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1231, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 919, 'last_played': 1592567416}
review:
No-brainer if you were ever a fan of Descent 1 -- 3, and for the uninitiated, a wicked introduction to the 6DOF style.
Hard to believe this genre has basically been hibernating for two decades!
Awesome music and sound design, simple yet appealing graphical style, occasionally mind-bending level design -- it's all so good.

Fair warning that the challenge curve ramps up pretty hard towards the campaign's end (I played through on 'Hotshot' difficulty, not sure how others compare) -- either way the difficulty never trumped my enjoyment, it just puts your skills to the test (not unlike the old days)

Very very well done!

author: {'steamid': '76561197994325928', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 362, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 63, 'last_played': 1652290965}

author: {'steamid': '76561198166071579', 'num_games_owned': 28, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1520, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1377, 'last_played': 1679518793}
review: If you like the Descent trilogy of the 90's and early 2000's you will love this one. Fast paced combat, stomach agility and great graphics.  The only downfall is that there aren't many chances of PVP. But it will improve your shoot them up skill by a lot. So take your motion sickness pills strap in and get shooting. Welcome to Overload.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077348744', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 1981, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1629, 'last_played': 1585433310}
review:
This is the game Decent fans have been waiting for. It feels exactly like Descent, just brought into modern times. It's an incredibly fun, fast-paced game. Wether you're a fan of the genre, or you've never heard of it before, there's little to no chance you're not gonna enjoy it.
Definitely recommending this game.

Pros:
+ Fun, fast paced action
+ Excellent controls
+ Single player campaign with good story
+ Fun Multiplayer
+ Awesome music
+ It is what Descent Underground failed to be

Cons (most of these are complaining on a high comfort level):
- Lacks the variety of mission goals of Descent 3 (it's back to blowing up reactors)
- No outside (it's back to tunnels only)
- Only one ship (in Descent 3 you had 3)
- Most weapons are pointless. Once I got the Crusher, it was all I needed, with the Impulse as fallback)
- Campaign story ends just when it gets interesting

author: {'steamid': '76561197970610256', 'num_games_owned': 428, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 277, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 246, 'last_played': 1659294426}
review:
"Descent is a first-person shooter (FPS) game developed by Parallax Software and released by Interplay Productions in 1995 for MS-DOS, and later for Macintosh, PlayStation, and Acorn Archimedes. It popularized a subgenre of FPS games employing six degrees of freedom and was the first FPS to feature entirely true-3D graphics."

Only played it in VR but it blew my mind.

OVERELOAD is the definitive Descent clone for 2020, and my god has to be one of the best. 

Total VR bad ass action, groovy music and great FX.

Not a lot needs to be said just that if you want tunnel 360 action with lasers, guns, missiles and robot ships then this is it..

author: {'steamid': '76561197973154898', 'num_games_owned': 1689, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 774, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 770, 'last_played': 1595106483}
review: Really awesome game for fans of Descent or Forsaken. Old-school fast-paced shooter with modern graphics. Works well on Linux too. Had a lot of fun with this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198090296929', 'num_games_owned': 40, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2437, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2091, 'last_played': 1583534609}
review:
The best 6DOF Shooter since Descent II. 
Fun weapons, super smooth gameplay, interesting enemies, complex levels, challenging gamemodes. This is the true Descent successor.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996847436', 'num_games_owned': 72, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2808, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1129, 'last_played': 1705070754}
review: Logical Successor to the decent games of the 90's, simular game play elements and more
