author: {'steamid': '76561197974933037', 'num_games_owned': 429, 'num_reviews': 203, 'playtime_forever': 1847, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1820, 'last_played': 1590617142}
review:
[h1]IL VERO DESCENT 4?[/h1]
Sono sempre stato un grande appassionato di Descent, il gioco del '95 dei Parallax. All'uscita del 2, l'anno dopo, non stavo pi√π nella pelle e le aspettative furono ampiamente ripagate con novit√† di tutto rispetto (SVGA!!!) e una maggiore diversificazione dei "mondi" che si andavano a visitare.
Questo Overload √® sicuramente il degno successore dei sopracitati titoli: c'√® lo stesso vibe di allora, con un controllo fenomenale da joypad (imprescindibile, direi), un bel feed nell'uso delle armi e mostri vintage in giro per le miniere.
Cercare segreti √® intrigante, cos√¨ come capire, leggendo la mappa in 3D, se sia pi√π conveniente una data strada piuttosto che un'altra. Azzeccato il tocco di potenziare la nave/armi grazie ai power-up (RPG style) e, pi√π in generale, GRANDE sfoggio di Unity da parte dei Revival Production.

[h1]MA...[/h1]
Nonostante le mappe siano ben costruite e la navigazione per i corridoi sia un piacere, si sente la monotonia che gi√† si leggeva nel primo Descent, con una certa frustrazione negli ultimi livelli, dovuta allo sleale posizionamento dei nemici e alla loro estrema potenza (cosa che spinge verso la vile modalit√† quicksave/quickload).
La storia √® esposta prima di ogni livello dal computer di bordo e supportata da registrazioni audio durante la partita: un metodo davvero poco efficace (e lento) se si vuol catturare l'attenzione del giocatore annoiato.
Visivamente non c'√® grande variet√† nelle location e i mostri sono tutti uguali a distanza d'ingaggio (tranne un paio). Ci√≤ spegne l'esaltazione mano a mano che il gioco procede (almeno nel mio caso).
Personalmente, dei 16 livelli di cui si compone il single player, me ne sono divorati una decina in due o tre giorni, per poi rallentare inesorabilmente e finire gli ultimi a fatica e NON per la difficolt√†, seppur elevata&scorretta, ma per noia.
Un co-op con qualche amico avrebbe indorato la pillola, ma il multiplayer si limita al solito PvP, senza alcun tipo di PvE, esattamente come vent'anni fa. [b]:-([/b]
Pelo nell'uovo: ho trovato fastidiosa la scarsa "intelligenza" della guida olografica, che su carta ci dovrebbe aiutare a trovare armi e munizioni senza impazzire con la mappa, ma che spesso ci porta a quelle di cui siamo gi√† pieni. Non penso ci volesse molto a limare un po' questa sua brutta abitudine.

Quindi 'sto Overload vale la pena o no? Dipende. Se siete fan dei vecchi Descent e dei giochi spaziali in cui il sotto diventa sopra in un istante, non lasciatevi intimorire dalle lamentele e compratelo: vi divertirete (soprattutto all'inizio). Se per√≤ siete nuovi al genere provate prima il [url= https://store.steampowered.com/app/450220/Overload_Playable_Teaser_30/ ]demo[/url].
Io ci vedo pi√π pregi che difetti, ma √® innegabile che la pessima abitudine di creare gli ultimi livelli con nemici che ti arrivano addosso dal nulla (dicasi "aumento di difficolt√† con mancanza di idee"), abbia un po' rotto il ca**o (scusate il francese).

author: {'steamid': '76561197962786553', 'num_games_owned': 791, 'num_reviews': 155, 'playtime_forever': 621, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 621, 'last_played': 1550119305}
review:
I grew up with the original Descent series on PC, in fact, it was the first PC game I /ever/ played growing up and was the jumping off point for me into many different series, Freespace and Mechwarrior just to mention a couple.

This game is the spiritual sequel to Descent in every capacity, with;

An outstanding OST.
Great graphics and more importantly, good performance in a game of this nature.
And lastly, and most importantly, gameplay that embodies the soul of Descent. (That controls really well with a mouse/keyboard by the way.)

This is a masterpiece of the genre. Bravo. If you're a fan of Descent, Freespace or any game remotely akin the series, you owe it to yourself to check this out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198907769110', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 8790, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 933, 'last_played': 1674881975}
review:
I used to love playing Descent. I was looking for it and found this game. I am delighted with it, especially that it is now available for the Mac platform.

I would suggest adding the marker buoys like in the old Descent.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971187212', 'num_games_owned': 494, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 1869, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1154, 'last_played': 1604440280}
review: A gently modernised Descent, and really rather good. Fast, vicious and genuinely hard at higher difficulty.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034242557', 'num_games_owned': 198, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 262, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 240, 'last_played': 1550634542}
review:
I never played Descent - only watched my mom play as a kid - and I've always gravitated towards shooters with absolute mouse aiming, so I was a little worried I wouldn't be able to pick up the 6DOF movement or the mouse-accelerates-ship aiming.

On the contrary, even with no experience with these types of controls I settled into them quickly and had a lot of fun. The physics that go into movement and aiming are clearly tuned to a fine point, and it shows.

The number of collectibles is reasonable and a good number of them are in open areas, so I feel rewarded for exploring levels but don't feel bogged down with a laundry list of items to go find after killing everything.

Very fun and very polished.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072827877', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 4581, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1448, 'last_played': 1635326748}
review:
A new interpretation of a video game classic.
An homage made with much love and attention to detail.
A worthy successor with a modern polish.

Prepare to overload!

author: {'steamid': '76561197985566664', 'num_games_owned': 662, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1044, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1025, 'last_played': 1674254383}
review:
Overload picks up where Descent left off and improves on it all around.

If you're interested in 6DOF Shooters at all, Overload is a must have as it might as well be a summary of what is awesome about the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041276905', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 238, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 222, 'last_played': 1591917962}
review:
Flabbergasted.  This is such a faithful re-invention of Descent, to be sure.  And yet, it's unthinkable, and almost unforgivable, that there isn't a Cooperative player mode for missions and campaigns.

One of the things the game's description says, to quote verbatim:

"Intense Multiplayer action with up to 8 players."

Sure.  But it's entirely PvP.

One of the more charming aspects of Descent was the ability to play with friends over LAN, or even via direct modem connection, PvE (vs AI, really).  So why does this not exist in this version?

I can't recommend this game until that issue is addressed.  And I wish, wholeheartedly, that it is.  It's such a glaring omission that it's this game's "elephant in the room."

author: {'steamid': '76561198028586079', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1004, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 959, 'last_played': 1647116502}
review:
And then it was 3am . . . oops . . . again.

I'm impressed with the scaling of the game, meaning that it ranges from working fine on my old computer, yet scales up to high end VR machines.  The story is about what I expected, easy to ignore as long as you keep smashing bad operators.

I enjoy it.

Room for improvement :  

I think that a co op campaign would expand the fun to be had in this game by a long shot.  Having maps that require 2 or 4 or more players would allow an enormous amount of complexity, puzzle solving, and ambush tactics.  I would love to get in on a game like that.

I think that instead of having all of the custom maps on discord, opening up the steam workshop for the community to pick over would be a boon to the company.  There are plenty of weapons and such in the game, but messing around with different versions wouldn't hurt.

Still worth every penny.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970615349', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 1534, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 669, 'last_played': 1692781833}

author: {'steamid': '76561197970359498', 'num_games_owned': 1696, 'num_reviews': 241, 'playtime_forever': 419, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 419, 'last_played': 1547367955}
review:
One of the very first PC games I played, before even owning a PC, was Descent.  I had no idea how to play, I was a little kid doing everything wrong.  I thought shooting flares was my gun.  I achieved nothing except wonderment at the idea of a 3D game where you fly around and fight robots.  Now 20-some years later I got to try my hand at the spiritual successor, Overload, and this time‚Ä¶ I know how to shoot. 

[h1] A Brief History [/h1]

Overload was kickstarter funded in March of 2016 and went into development under Revival Productions, a team with members of the original Descent team.  It was released just over two years later in May of 2018.  The whole event snuck under my radar.  Probably because I had my gaze focused on another Descent spiritual successor, Descent: Underground.  A game also successfully crowdfunded with some former Star Citizen developers.  However, unlike Overload, it had a much more rocky release and is currently back in development for a single player campaign.

[h1] On to the Actual Game [/h1]

I have to start by saying this game is definitively representative of Descent as my nostalgia-riddled mind can remember it.  It really feels as close to the original game in all of the core aspects.  I know most people aren‚Äôt familiar with games well over two decades old, but luckily you can still buy and play all of the original series on Steam.  Nice, right?  Yet, if you don‚Äôt want to jump back in time, Overload brings back a much of the gameplay, but with a wonderful rendition of modern graphics.    

What sets Overload apart from the modern resurgence of space dogfighting games is how it squeezes you in to tight spaces and down narrow maze-like hallways.  I‚Äôm not using ‚Äúmaze-like‚Äù loosely here, with the nature of your ability to fly in any direction and roll 360 degrees without much defining what is up or down, it‚Äôs incredibly easy to get lost in this game.  Navigation, of course, is used as one of the main components in the challenge of the gameplay.  The level design has you traveling into random corners and through hidden doorways to both find secret bonus items and upgrades as well as progress through the game itself.  It can easily be overwhelming, especially early on, as you desperately dip in and out of the massive 3D rendered map looking for some hallway or doorway you missed.  To combat this, Overload includes a ‚Äòhologuide‚Äô that you can pop up at any time that will lead you to the next objective, whether that‚Äôs the end of the level or just another key to unlock a door.   

[h1] Fight the Power [/h1]

As you progress through the relatively short story and it‚Äôs 15 levels, your biggest hurdle outside of figuring out where the hell to go is shooting your many different weapons at a decently diverse set of enemies.  You end up with eight standard weapons that pull from two pools, energy and ammo , as well as eight secondary weapons in the form of various missiles, rockets, and mines that have a wider variety of functionality, but a much smaller pool of ammo.  While on the relatively low difficulty that I played, ammo was more than abundant, it is important to make sure you use weapons efficiently and swap regularly for what best fits the situation.  You can (and should) spend time exploring levels to find upgrade points that you can use to make weapons do more damage, fire faster, or in some way increase their effectiveness.  In addition to this, you have to split the limited points with upgrading other portions of your ship like its health and speed, which can be just as important when things are getting out of hand.  

It may not seem like it at first, but things will get chaotic as enemies can be generated from spawners (that you can destroy) and some are particularly good making things hectic by charging right at your face for massive damage or filing the screen with explosives.   Overload‚Äôs level design is specifically tailored to allow these enemy robots appear out of hidden doors and from around corners to be extra effective with their attacks.  The oddly Jurassic way they often roar when they attack from that hiding spot makes for tense moments as well.  Yet it doesn‚Äôt really step into the realm of the tension you‚Äôd feel in a survival horror game since you‚Äôre armed to the teeth with robot shredding weaponry.

[h1] Cherry Picking the Past [/h1]

Overload gets a lot of things right.  It has plenty of action, tons of secrets and exploration for the people who are willing to dive into that insanity, and even a decent story that gets moving as the game progresses.  The soundtrack is a little hit or miss, but is very prominent throughout, so that could be a strong point for some as well.  If you look at the campaign alone it is a bit short, but if you‚Äôre a completionist, you enjoy challenge levels, or you manage to find some people online to play the multiplayer with, you can sink many more hours into the game.  It could probably also benefit from a little more visual design variety since nearly every level features the same gray walls and industrial assets with rock caves thrown in randomly.  It also wouldn‚Äôt hurt to see a little more variety in the objective types for each level, where the vast majority are simply destroying a reactor.  Yet, even with those issues it‚Äôs not hard to see that this is a great spiritual successor and fun to play.  However, at this point seven months after release, it‚Äôs probably safe to say you should be looking for it a good bit less than the base $30 price tag.

I think we have the privilege these days of a nice combination of accessible game development tools and a huge history of great games that can be revisited to entertain old fans and make new ones.  Overload took a classic franchise of the past and built a game that not only appeals to the old farts that enjoyed it back then, but can also be appreciated by people who weren‚Äôt even alive when Descent was in stores (on shelves, you had to go pick up a giant box, it was cool).  That quality is sometimes forgotten in modern remakes and spiritual successors, and I‚Äôm always happy to see a one that has a potential for broad spectrum appeal.  

[quote] If you'd like to see more of my reviews, check out my curator page here: http://store.steampowered.com/curator/28346672-Endyo-Gaming/ and https://www.thegamemessiah.com[/quote]

author: {'steamid': '76561198018533429', 'num_games_owned': 484, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1749, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1120, 'last_played': 1587326961}
review: This is the only game in 20 years that comes close to the gameplay of Desent I/II.  On top of that, it is a beautiful game.  The explosions, the autobots, the environments.  The game lights my whole office up.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991581811', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 232, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 147, 'last_played': 1549133765}
review:
I admit I was a huge Descent fan and had the full series with expansions back in the day. Imagine my joy upon discovering that not all good things have to end - THE DEF TOTES AMAZE-BALLSNESS CONTINUES!

So erm while I'm still playing the campaign through I already want to know - When does the expansion or awesome DLC come out? I can haz moar happy fun time? :D

author: {'steamid': '76561198022370609', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 132, 'playtime_forever': 400, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 364, 'last_played': 1548968193}
review:
I got really excited by the Overload demo, and told a few Steam friends about it. (I suggested, 'try the demo'.)

Then I bought it for ¬£20, which is a lot for me for a game. Since then I have been bored stupid with it. Everything is the same. All the levels are just sort of variations. Game-play is the same. You get different rockets and weapons etc as you progress, but you see that in the demo. 

There really is nothing for me beyond the demo. It's taken me weeks to play three hours, and I am bored with it. I so hope none of my Steam friends bought it on my recommendation, when I was excited by the demo. I will keep trying to play it though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026275953', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 2093, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2092, 'last_played': 1548018941}
review:
This is a very fun game.

I was expecting something much more lowbudget since 6degree shooters are not super popular; but while this is certainly not an AAA game, it doesn't have a low budget feel either. A lot of time, care, and polish was put into it. It runs really smoothly.

The best way to describe this game would be, think Doom, but more 3D and with robot spaceships.

Like Doom, you level up by finding secrets (in the main campaign), but my beleif is, that this is the biggest downside of the game. This is just my personal opinion, and I know many will disagree, but I think in a [i]shooter[/i], leveling up should be earned by [i]shooting[/i] things. For example, kill two enemies with one shoot, get double the upgrade points, ect.

There are a few other nitpicks, like not having quite enough ammo to use the best secondary for the area, or super sampling not working, but nothing that should stop you from buying this awsome game... if you have good enough hand-eye-coordination ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561198057499487', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 7488, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2546, 'last_played': 1689996590}
review: Extraordinary! If you played Descent games in the past, this is the real deal. I'm not a gamer by any stretch, but I spent hours as a kid playing the original Descent. Now, well into adulthood, this brings back the original spirit and then some. Not to mention it looks & plays flawlessly in 4k (with a 1080 Ti). I've not had this much fun playing a game in years. If you're at all interested in space, or 6D flying, this is a must have.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970750409', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 116, 'playtime_forever': 969, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 969, 'last_played': 1546619717}
review: Good game, definitely scratches that Descent itch that I've had for a long time.  Here's hoping that enough people buy this to fund an even bigger and better Overload 2.

author: {'steamid': '76561198330811359', 'num_games_owned': 220, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 88, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 74, 'last_played': 1582209600}
review: Graphics, music , sound effects and gameplay amazing ! Totally worth it :D

author: {'steamid': '76561197998590072', 'num_games_owned': 45, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1060, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 898, 'last_played': 1548098459}
review: This is not a reboot, restart, homage or anything to Descent, this IS Descent.  If the sound of screaching, Vulkan armed robots was (terrifying) music to your ears 20 years ago, this is a must.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023154791', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 2682, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 912, 'last_played': 1710372708}
review:
A glorious return to form by the kings of 6DoF shooters. It is impossible to overstate how much they nailed every detail, from movement (ship inertia, mouse acceleration), to level design, enemy variety, gunplay, and perhaps most of all, THE Füî•üî•üî•ING SOUNDTRACK.

Plays flawlessly on the Steam Deck.

author: {'steamid': '76561198335501062', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 935, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 935, 'last_played': 1546721453}
review: Just because it is a worthy successor of the Descent series, it does not make it a good game. It is good, but even in hotshot difficulty it is unfairly hard sometimes as the enemies unavoidably damage you when they see you. Not to mention that the maps are just way too similar.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990841244', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 823, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 761, 'last_played': 1546507570}
review:
Finished game. It's definitely what it claims to be: Descent 4, in all but name.
It plays well, the AI is good, there's fun variety in the weapons, it looks good, performance is good... it's good if what you want is a 6DOF shooter that will separate the men from the boys as far as navigational skills go.

Individual caveat: The game crashed a lot for me. Between every mission it would crash. never IN a level, though.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971321269', 'num_games_owned': 227, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 624, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 71, 'last_played': 1672535527}
review: All I can say is WOW!! Descent is back and amazing. This is a must. Thanks for bringing back the descent I playing as my first computer game on the 486 computer in 1995. It was an emotional gameplay. Love you guys.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968451616', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 40, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 40, 'last_played': 1546360124}
review:
Overload is essentially the Descent series remade in its gritty, unforgiving, stomach-wrenching 6DOF glory made for the new generations of players. I have spent hundreds of hours on the classic games, and I have to say this game captures that feeling very well. The music fits, the gameplay is spot-on (it couldn't be otherwise since this is essentially made by the same people who worked on the original Descent games).

What I can't understand is however, why the bland maps? I believe that the levels are plain uninteresting to visit, too many flat surfaces and no "decoration" or styling, like there is no differentiation between one level and the next. There is no excuse for this as today we have hardware that can handle complex scenery. And what staggers me even more is that I can't handle this game in full detail on a Radeon RX 580 @ 60 FPS or more given the graphical simplicity.

For these reasons I can't recommend this game unless it is deeply discounted. If you look for a stylish 6DOF shooter, I recommend you SubLevel Zero instead.

author: {'steamid': '76561198142973299', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1554, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1503, 'last_played': 1587883087}
review:
Are you a freedom lover? 

This game offers 6 degrees of freedom. No game offers more.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966482898', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 2945, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 756, 'last_played': 1673656878}
review: This game is to Descent what Doom (2016) was for.. erm.. Doom (1994).  It resurrects the spirit of the franchise while eliminating the less favorable aspects from the original.  It also adds new gameplay features, very similar to the same way that Doom (2016) did.  Upgrade points are available to spend that improve your ship and weapons from mission-to-mission.  There are legions of secrets and time-challenges to discover.  The soundtrack is superb.  Levels are mazes to race through, blasting enemies with an ever-expanding arsenal of destructive weaponry.  I was a huge Descent 3 fan back in the day and it is so gratifying to see this sub-genre come back with such polish.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995793933', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 804, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 488, 'last_played': 1550005515}
review:
Wer fr√ºher schon Descent 1 oder 2 gespielt hat wird dieses Spiel lieben.
Da werden Erinnerungen an lange LAN-Party wach an denen viel Descent 2 gezockt wurde.
Super Titel um mit mehreren Spielern Online oder auch im LAN zu zocken und Spa√ü zu haben.
Auch im Singleplayer auf tolles Spiel. Hat mich motiviert immer noch eine neue Runde anzufangen.
Sch√∂ne Grafik mit tollen Soundeffekten (mit viel RUMMS dahinter).
Bei entsprechender Soundanlage lohnt es sich mal aufzudrehen.  
L√§uft super gut auf aktuellen Systemen. Habe min. 100fps auf FullHD (GTX1080).
Mit einer VR-Brille zocken ist bestimmt megageil!

Absolut weiter zu empfehlen!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198041985869', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 898, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 251, 'last_played': 1547952973}
review:
I've waited over 20 years for a worthy successor to Descent II.  To say it was worth the wait would be the understatement of 2018.  My expectations for this game have been completely shattered.  I grew up playing Descent and Descent II, but I didn't like the third installment.  This game is everything the first two games were and much more.  I still crap my pants when I round a corner and find a cluster of hulks ready to pound me back to Phoebe. I cannot wait to finish my first playthrough, but I have a feeling I'm going to leave wanting more.  

If you loved Descent and/or Descent II, buy this game.  If you like 6DOF games in general, buy this game.  If you like flying around shooting combat robots with an arsenal of destruction, buy this game.  

Buy this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198085792193', 'num_games_owned': 327, 'num_reviews': 122, 'playtime_forever': 682, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 534, 'last_played': 1701452078}
review:
Nice. Realy nice. A true successor to Descent and a very good 6 degrees of freedom game. Graphics are sharp, xplosions are mind blowing, gameplay is comfortable, supports vr and there is a level editor :)

Long review:

Overload is a 6 degree of freedom space shooting game against robots. Aaahhh, even this reminds me of my childhood with descent :) You are gonna clearing levels, actually moons of saturn, jupiter and etc.., from robots. The story is sort of figthing against rebel robots. I think this game is a good successor to Descent and i also hope they release Descent Underground too. I have already paid for that game :D

Gameplay:
You are usualy clearing closed levels, there is no open environments is this game. You will be exploring a map and there is a guide bot that can help you find a securty key or reactor or a power up or robots. The levels are confusing just the right amount :) You are gonna be operating a spaceship from inside. You have primary and secondary weapons. Secondary ones are missiles and explosives. Primary ones are lazers and plasma kind of things.

The weapons are not the most interesting thing about this game. The action and thrill in the game is top notch. Robots are smart and they will track or hunt you down :D In the campaign mode, every mission begins with a breifing and the game informs you about the robots you will face with. The levels have 3 levels of security and those doors need clearance. I would prefer blue, yellow and red keys :( At the end of each level, there is a reactor or a boss robot.

You will find upgrade points in the game and you can upgrade your weapons and ship. Super upgrade points are harder to find and rarer but they will upgrade the ship and weapons beyond the max. The game has 5 different difficutiy settings. I would like to enjoy the game without getting blown up, so i play on trainee difficulty :) Rookie, hotshot, ace, insane are more difficult obviously.

After you complete the campaign without cheating, you will be able to start a new game+. Which is amazing. The game supports vr, i don't have one but it would be super awesome. Controller support is also cool. I play with keyboard and mouse and the customization of controls are plenty.

There are challenge levels where you can select weapons from the get go. I haven't tried the challenges yet but you will be unlocking new ones as you progress. There is amultiplayer but i haven't found anyone :S You can play head to head with a player, choose anrchy mode as free for all or team anarchy agains a team. I don't know if there is an option for coop campaign. That would be cool.

Audio, Visuals
The game has a pretty suited soundtrack. I usualy silence the music in games and listen to my own :D But this one enhances the feeling in the action. Descent 1 is better then this game but that game is legendary. The robots and explosions are making clear noies. You can detect and identify every single chattering. Which is requeired while all sorts of mayhem going around.

Visuals are impressive and optimized. Except from screen space reflections (tooo heavy) and post processing, my i5 2500 and r9 380 rig is able to handle the game at almost 60 solid. The lighting is important in this kind of game and it is done perfectly. The explosions are gonna spread tons of pieces, which is a visual festival for me :)

Cons:
I can't think of any cons actually :D I don't know why but i couldn't find any online matches.

Overall:
If you like space shooting games, this one is good. If you liked Descent, actually there is no possibility of disliking the Descent, if you have played Descent, you will like this. Overload is a thrilling, amazing and a little bit dizzying experince =)

author: {'steamid': '76561198001484058', 'num_games_owned': 297, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 812, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 662, 'last_played': 1599457053}

author: {'steamid': '76561198034855456', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1305, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 164, 'last_played': 1586177231}
review:
My very first modern game in the 90's was Descent. I had the Anniversary Edition in the boxed set (and I still do!). I play without any auto-leveling mashing at strafe, yaw turn, descend/ascend almost all at the same time and while playing this game, I'm happy to find out muscle memory is real because I've spent countless hours in the previous iterations. Descent to me was revolutionary in my eyes because I was still playing Wolfenstein and Doom back then. Overload was able to capture EVERYTHING and provide even more! I kept feeling this was the Descent every fan deserves. Finding out that the original creators were involved in Overload had given me goosebumps and I didn't care whether or not the game was on sale. I had to have it. The graphics is definitely a huge step up and it really felt more immersive with the modern light ambience and spectacular explosion. The music had an obvious retro sound to it but it perfectly matches the intensity of the gaming experience. I love the new ship and weapons upgrade choices between levels because it does make you spend more time looking for those power-ups. My only con is the ship design haha. It's so utilitarian looking. I thought the original design of the ship in Descent was seriously cool. I made so many play-doh versions of it. I hope there's a DLC that will allow you to use the original ship design.

This game is HIGHLY recommended. If vertigo causes you to lose your lunch, I'd recommend fasting for a day before playing because it's worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055976209', 'num_games_owned': 135, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 1259, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1225, 'last_played': 1688383561}

author: {'steamid': '76561197971568340', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 449, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 420, 'last_played': 1653493483}
review: Did you like Descent back in the day? This is literally modern remake of Descent. Excellent, silky smooth gameplay combined with fast paced action. This game also includes VR-mode and more fleshed out story than what original Descend had, but story isn't the reason to play this. The reason is the intense action and freedom of movement.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963353056', 'num_games_owned': 426, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 329, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 152, 'last_played': 1546310224}

author: {'steamid': '76561197960938249', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 430, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 177, 'last_played': 1661369446}
review:
This brings back the feeling I had playing Descent 1 + 2 back in the days. It's a good example of how it is possible to polish established gameplay without all this modern "open world", "procedural generation", "pay to win"-stuff which all games seem to include these days. Combat is smooth, fast-paced and at times daunting. In the old Descent I used to be able to retreat to other parts of the level to restock, here you need to actually get into the thick of it, especially if there are fabricators around.

The upgrade and experience system gives players an incentive to give replay the single player campaign and discover all the secrets. It's a cleverly featured role-playing element.

The graphics are superb, however the colour palette seems to have little variation and also the operators look rather similar.  I could identify the robots easier in the old Descent games. Here, you need to wait for shots fired, to realize what you're up against. Also the explosions, while rather impressive, seem to clutter everything up.

Sound and music however seem very punchy, something I liked in the prequels as well. There is plenty of bass to listen to, when you fire your weapons and blow things up.

Enough reviewing, I'm going back to more gaming. Looks like this will keep me satisfied for a long time :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198027667796', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 372, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 233, 'last_played': 1672636986}

author: {'steamid': '76561198087610673', 'num_games_owned': 2873, 'num_reviews': 115, 'playtime_forever': 6264, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1046, 'last_played': 1701254605}
review:
Overload is the ultimate 3DOF FPS experience, It is fast, tense and tough as nails. tight mazes full of action with free movement and a lot of secrets, It is a true successor to the Descend series.

Welcome to the moons of Saturn, Mining robots are malfunctioning and started attacking the humans working in the factories, It is up to you to destroy the miners. There is a whole story behind it, But honestly that is not what the game is about, I adore the backstory and the insane amount of details, but for me this game is all about the action, blowing up Operators in zero gravity.

These Operators come in many forms, Some come in swarms, some rush in on you and some have nukes with your name on it. They all have the element of suprise, They are placed tightly around corners and will always catch you off guard. It will take some solid strategy and a clear head to clear out the rooms and the tight hallways.

The game is tough as nails, Beating this game on the hardest difficulity is next to impossible. There are also lots of secrets to discover, Collectables, but also hidden weapons and powerups which you can use to upgrade your ship. You can upgrade every weapon, but also your speed, armor, shield, among other things.

Next to the campaign there is a challenge mode for some quick games of carnage. Sadly there is no Offline multiplayer or co op, But it makes up for it with Online PVP. You can go Head 2 Head in a 1 vs 1 deathmatch. You can also play Free for All with 3 to 6 players and Team Deathmatch with 4 to 8 players

The graphics are great, I think it is among the better looking Unity games, It is a very dark and metallic atmosphere, It almost feels like an horror game, But they are just autonomous operators wanting to destroy you, Nothing creepy about that right?

Just learning to control the ship is a pain, It is practically a FPS but just add up down and roll into the controls, But having the freedom to go in every direction really makes for an unique challenge. I think it plays best with 2 combat flight sticks But a Controller works just fine.

The game is non stop action, full of secrets and impossible to clear on the highest difficulity level. It is a must have for anyone who loves a challenge and especially any fan of the 6DOF genre I have to give it a solid 9 It truly is an example for the genre

author: {'steamid': '76561197984141450', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 3433, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2156, 'last_played': 1698799383}
review:
Very creative use of game assets. The sort of ingenuity that you can only find in an indy environment. With a relatively low amount of game content the developers at Revival Productions pushed what assets they do have to the limit with clever reveals and clever a.i. The result is a an explosively thrilling ride you will want to play again and again.

9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198000819630', 'num_games_owned': 310, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 6951, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5234, 'last_played': 1694980062}
review:
Revival of a game without the name.

This is the 6dof FPS successor to nineties Descent, made by the original developers. They are back with all the action packed gameplay fans were waiting for so long down to the iconic music of the first titles. Sure, the enemies look different and the Kodachi ship the player flies cannot replace the beloved Pyro and the PTMC is just a side note in the singleplayer storyline. But make no mistake, this is giving you the original Descent vibe in any way: destroy lights and signs while you explore twisted levels without gravity, fighting off loads of robotic drones and reach the reactor to blow up the whole mine. Along the line you pick up hostages in cryo tubes and tiered access cards replace the good old colored keys. And there are lots of secrets to find and switches to be shot, sometimes giving the players quite a puzzle to solve. If you get lost, summon your holo guide to find what you are looking for.

And this time you really get to know what made the robots turn hostile.

Apart from the campaign there is also a challenge mode, where you navigate a small level and fight against auto-ops that spawn endlessly and to compete on the online leaderboard for highscores. There is a tactical element as well, as you will be able to upgrade your weaponry as you progress and kill bots, each weapon offers a binary choice like either more damage or higher rate of fire. The single player mode has these as well, but upgrades are more varied in the campaign and only availabe to tinker with in between missions.

Some of the challenge maps are part of the campaign as well, available as secret levels. But this time the secret levels do not end your current map and warp you to the next one after you finish them. Instead they teleport you back to the place in the campaign map where you entered them and the secret levels are all running against the clock.

Of course there is a multiplayer mode as well. And while it is really good deathmatch fun, this is where the game does not meet the high standard of its predecessors. There is just Anarchy and Team Deathmatch, no zero gravity game of football and sadly no co-op mode to fight through the main storyline with your friends. It also shows that though this game is a true gem, it is also part of a smal niche: there are only a small number of people playing this online. And most of them know the ins and outs of this genre by heart. But don't be afraid to enter the matches as a newbie, the small community is very friendly to newcomers.

The game also features a wide range of all kinds of options to customize your experience and has fantastic support for gaming peripherals. There is even support for multiple joysticks and gamepads at the same time for a player, so you will be able to play with two flightsticks for example, which do not even need to be the same type. 

Another thing to note is the levels are still built with hollow cubes, just like the first to Descent titles. But this time there are  lots of decals to be tacked on the walls like pipes, lights, wiring, plating, signs and so on and the cubes can be deformed in ways the Descent games were not able to 20 years ago, so the result will not look blocky at all. Even better: the caves really bring the mines those games are staged in to live like never before.

And you can build your own levels as well, the editor the team used to make the game is available for free. The DLC for this game is a curated and polished set of levels created by the community.

Highly recommended, although the genre will probably never be loved by the masses. A lovely fan service.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048930542', 'num_games_owned': 567, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 6824, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4237, 'last_played': 1605790990}
review:
Truly the next chapter in the Descent Family. I love everything about this game. Built with love by the team that brought you the classix 6DofF. The community is dedicated and committed, and the Dev team is constantly working on updates and maintaining a close connection with its community on their Discord channel [https://discord.gg/Ke2UVe]

I was surprised by the extent of the single player campain. It felt polished and engaging, considering the story isn't the driving force, I'm always ready to start the next mission. It certainly has that 90s game feel, which I personally think games are missing these days. Truly a fast paced rush of adrenaline. 

There's a lot of games out there that has fantastic semi realistic graphics, and while this game doesn't match up with that level of detail, once you start playing, you wont even notice or care. The graphics are well enough that it Nothing to complain about, it does its job!

As for Multiplayer, it works too, but given the size of the Dev team and how much they put into this game, it's easy to say that some things are lacking, but you can totally forgive them for it. The best way to get into a match is to get onto the discord and say "Hey! who wants to play?" and the community will be there to log in with you! But since the community is still small, if you don't request a group to play and you just randomly try to search for a match, you could be waiting white a while in Que. 

While some may want to use their Joystick, I personally recommend this as a mouse and keyboard game. As a Joystick player, I eventually converted back to the mouse, and the controls are smooth and polished and it feels absolutely seamless and fantastic to fly. The sound when making a kill is thrilling and satisfying! and if you turn up the difficulty and make it to the end of a mission, you will certainly feel like you have truly accomplished something! 

Good Luck Pilot...

author: {'steamid': '76561197970401592', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1899, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1011, 'last_played': 1545762533}
review:
F√ºr Kenner: Wer damals mit Descent und Descent 2 seinen Spa√ü hatte, kommt hier voll auf seine Kosten. Spielmechanik, Steuerung, Gegner wie beim Original, nun aber mit richtig netter Grafik (nein, nicht ultra-realistisch - aber trotzdem super und farbenfroh). Auch das Verbesserungs-System mittels Upgrade-Punkten macht Freude und spornt an, alle Verstecke zu finden. PC-Anforderungen sind moderat.
[b]Macher von Overload sind die des damaligen Descents[/b], und es ist ihnen ein wirklich spassiges Remake gelungen.
Klare Empfehlung. Nat√ºrlich muss man 6DoF m√∂gen und abk√∂nnen, aber so isses nun mal: Nur die Harten kommen in den Garten. Over and out.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988807411', 'num_games_owned': 3494, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1610, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1598, 'last_played': 1644658754}
review: Fluid combat, powerful weaponry, exquisite level design, brilliant particle effects and a fantastic soundtrack combine to show that not only did the Descent developers know what they were doing in the 90s, but that they haven't lost any of their skill in the intervening 20 years.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999384699', 'num_games_owned': 402, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 1588, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1588, 'last_played': 1531553906}
review:
It's Descent in all but the name.

Not only that, it's a really, really, really [b]good[/b] Descent game. It has that full 6 degrees of freedom feel, it makes you constantly re-orient yourself because everything is everywhere, shooting is snappy, secondary weapons feel powerful, enemies are devious, it's all here!

If I had to criticize something it's the IMO needless inclusion of multiplayer, but I know others like it a lot even with a community too small to support non-hardcore players and hence rather exclusive. 

But even given that, this is [b]well[/b] worth the money just for the campaign + challenge mode if you either a) used to love Descent back in the days, b) used to love Forsaken or c) the idea of a fully weightless and hence all-directions-are-equal shooter with strafing and turning in all directions at the same time intrigues you. 6 degrees of thumbs, all up!

author: {'steamid': '76561197999253284', 'num_games_owned': 262, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 413, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 168, 'last_played': 1694147154}
review: The creators of Descent have brought Decent into modern times. The controls are pretty intuitive even for those new to the 6DOF genre who are familiar with FPS. Combat is gritty and intense, and the weapons feel satisfying to use. Multiplayer matchmaking includes a ranking system but tends to be light on players so I would recommend joining the official Overload Discord server to coordinate with other pilots.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993925625', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1173, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 747, 'last_played': 1658275535}
review: Just feels silky and right. Very satisfying.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960759468', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1267, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1039, 'last_played': 1702238162}
review:
what a trip! Descent was one of the first pc games that REALLY got me going: very immersive experience,
3d freedom in an age of 2d games, can still remember my neck aching from all the compensating in the beginning
feeling the anxiety of entering a dark corridor and sensing it was filled with hostile bots, greet 8bit soundtrack, ...
Now it's back with polished modern graphics (and sound) true to the original feel and atmosphere.. 
topped with an even better handling mechanism, mouse keyboard works like a dream..
kuddo's to the dev team!

author: {'steamid': '76561198074188496', 'num_games_owned': 1105, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 883, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 806, 'last_played': 1667766722}
review: Rock solid gameplay. I was worried it'd be geared too much toward online play, but the campaign is a fun personal experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961148207', 'num_games_owned': 181, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 868, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 829, 'last_played': 1708738567}
review:
If you played and enjoyed the original Descent, you will love this game. If you're new to the game then expect 360 degrees of freedom with a decent story line. Definitely a great flight sim game!

Once you beat the game, look to the challenges to see if you can get a high score. They have some interested survival modes, definitely worth checking out if you'd like to test your skill!

author: {'steamid': '76561198000167056', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 156, 'playtime_forever': 523, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 275, 'last_played': 1542521612}
review:
100% 90s era design, right down to the fast-paced movement and shooting, labyrinthine level design, and electric guitars. It's literally a modern Descent.

And it's amazing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019219795', 'num_games_owned': 277, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1441, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 677, 'last_played': 1690061521}
review:
When I played Descent back in the day I had a hard time finding fault with it. It was Doom in a spaceship... whats not to love? When I heard they were bringing it back as Overload my main concern was that they would ruin the game-play of a product that really didn't need much more than a bit of polishing for modern systems. I have to say that they did a great job. Its just as engaging as the original. The graphics are improved but not to the point of looking overdone. The feel of Decent is 100% there. 

The most notable improvement in my opinion is the mouse control feel. I normally play with a joystick but on the few occasions I had to use my mouse to play it was smooth and not at all motion sickness inducing, unlike past experiences with flying games (orig Descent included). 

As for cons I haven't found any deal breakers yet. I have tried to get into multiplayer a few times without success. Not sure if that's just player count or server issues but I will keep trying.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062813911', 'num_games_owned': 1958, 'num_reviews': 2050, 'playtime_forever': 203, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 121, 'last_played': 1541596878}
review:
[h1] DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review [/h1]

Overload is a game developed and published by Revival Productions, LLC. and is a sort of 'reboot' of the classic DESCENT series

The game offers some pleasant graphics and really vibrant colours, although some ugly glitches here and there, it is pleasant all the same

The game is hard especially in single player mode but a fun game nontheless especially with friends which sadly I don't have

Overload overall, however, is a fun game to play in short bursts!

[h1] RECOMMENDED :) [/h1]

[b] REVIEW SOURCES: [/b]
[list]
[*] None

author: {'steamid': '76561198051476651', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 17, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17, 'last_played': 1540816933}
review:
Tried playing it in VR with  vive pro .... I almoust vomited my whole stomack content ... I dont undestand how anyone can play this in VR ...motion sickness is extremly high ...  Pavlov had same effect on me .. I dont think this gliding locomotion works well in VR ... you have to have a strong motion sicknesss tolerance

I cant coment the other aspects  because I am unable to last more then a 30 seconds before feeling exteemly sick.
 to people who want to enjoy VR Games but suffer from motion sickness ...
I recomend Fallout and Moss..
 I manage playing them without  getting sick at all ... Fallout 4 ( thanks to clever teleport movement) and Moss
which is in reality static 3d platformer absulutly  beautifull to look at and very imersive ...

author: {'steamid': '76561197996955509', 'num_games_owned': 957, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 393, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 249, 'last_played': 1550954009}
review:
A nostalgic reimagination of the absent 6dof shooter genre, Controls are spot on, level designs are awesome with tons of explorations and secrets as well as secret levels.

Music is gritty dark and electronic very appealingly combined with Robotic noises from the Occupants in the mineshafts.

Sound design fullfilling, using missiles and hear the explosions afterwards has never been so impactful they did a masterful job... The enemy robots all have their own distinguished sounds which gives each entry personality and invokes fear.

Game is for people that love 6DOF and Descent franchise. If you liked those games don't even second guess here just get it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198138829235', 'num_games_owned': 373, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 1511, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1417, 'last_played': 1654552309}
review:
For all practical purposes, this is Descent 4. If you loved the Descent series, this is a must. It's quite good, though perhaps a bit too faithful to the first two games in the series.

Pros:
- Gameplay is exciting and quite polished. The robots show more intelligence and character than in Descent 1/2 and are fun to hunt down.
- EXCELLENT sounds and music.
- The story is not bad. Was surprised to see that there IS a coherent story, certainly compared to Descent 1/2.

Cons:
- The graphics and level design are the biggest letdown. Visually, everything is clean, sterile and boring. The environments are mostly uninspiring. Descent 3 levels were much more atmoshperic, interesting and grand.
- The ending is not well handled. As is the norm nowadays, writers tried to be clever, and the product suffered.

author: {'steamid': '76561198852404530', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 36230, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 266, 'last_played': 1587236164}
review: The game is a great reminder of the Descent games. I do find it exceedingly frustrating when developers put rediculously difficult puzzles in a game like this, such as the double doors in the Lyyranicus level. Rather than continue to enjoy the game, I'm hopelessly stuck trying to get past this one assenine door timing issue.

author: {'steamid': '76561198371987867', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 3378, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2426, 'last_played': 1562318822}
review:
Review Edit, "I really hope the Overload team reconsider starting up the oceana server."

This is an incredible game, graphically immersive and very challenging mission wise depending on what difficulty you choose i love the missions but i love MP more.  Like many games that have not long come out of early access it has its fair share of bugs which is understandable and they will be sorted in time.

Where i am torn is the lack of server support in the Oceana region, so i am dependent on servers in the states which i do not mind. In saying that the best server for me "Oregon" is a good 100ms ping slower than a North American server that is much further away in another 6Dof game where i can actually compete on a more equal footing with my stateside friends.

Overall I love the game period!

Pros:
Graphically Impressive!
The campaign/missions are fantastic and the story line is rich.
The Control and feel of the game is excellent.

Note: The ability to choose a server would be a nice addition

Cons: There is only 1  
No Server support in the Oceana region for MP which makes for a dreadful experience in MP. Yes i have tried the whole VPN thing and it does not work for me. Us server support is abysmal with the best US server giving me pings in the 280+ range while i can get pings of 160ms+ from the North American server of another 6Dof game which confounds me.

Of Special Note: I have gifted this game to 2 friends one in Germany and one in New Zealand and plan to gift it to another so it has my support and it is a fantastic game.

Finally i can not recommend the Multiplayer aspect of this game for players based in the Oceana region because of the frustrating and very weak server support from the states when i get incredible server support in a similar game. ie approximates 280ms+ as opposed to 160ms+ < this being from a server that is much further. 

This review is open to change should there be an improvement in server support.

I have enabled comments ( your right of reply ) so please be civil and constructive.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015212916', 'num_games_owned': 693, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 88, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 78, 'last_played': 1567131308}
review:
Prepare for Descent. 

Really enjoying this one. Definitely the best 6DOF game I've played since the old days of Descent, and this takes me right back there. It's easy to just consider this to be Descent 4, as the feel of the gameplay and universe fit right in. Unfortunatley matchmaking hasn't found me any opponents, so I hope they switch to a lobby system. But the single player and challenge modes alone are enough to have a great time with this. 

Highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998427189', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1175, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1076, 'last_played': 1540831251}
review: Best shooter of the last ten years, hands down. If you're tired of health regeneration, linear levels, limited guns, arenas, slow pacing, low difficulty and overdone cutscenes, look no further.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064257257', 'num_games_owned': 407, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 1014, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1014, 'last_played': 1539510718}
review:
If you want to relive the glory days of Descent but with far better graphics then get this. It's from the original team and compared to the other six degrees of freedom shooters out there it's the only one to really nail the feel/mechanics/look of the original Descent series.There's a few fun nods to Descent in there as well, even though it can't technically be part of the same series they allude that it's in the same "world" by some names that are meantioned. 

It's a fun game, excellent gameplay and some levels get fairly complex. The story is a bit slow but gets interesting. Still pretty limited though. It's more about the experience in my opinion.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999602379', 'num_games_owned': 81, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2821, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2247, 'last_played': 1667063272}
review:
Overload is a great game. Great controls, great gameplay. So why would I downvote? Good question.

The campaign is very short. Multiplayer is very sparsely populated. Those two things mean you probably wont come back and replay the short campaign unless you want to try harder difficulty levels or do the achievements. Now there is the issue with DLC. Community maps being sold as DLC reminds me of the Bethesda Paid Mods scandal. New maps developed by the community being sold by the devs? The original Descent games came with multiple episodes. First one was shareware and then came others if you wanted more of the game. Now we pay full price, which is fine, but devs are charging you money for the hard work of the community. They create tools to make maps so that they dont have to but still charge you money for the content created by the community. That is not okay. Developing their own episodes and charging as DLC would be fine, but this seems wrong.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018149384', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 881, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 881, 'last_played': 1553666060}

review: This is Descent, plane and simply, brought into 2018. It has good graphics, (energy) weapons, fantastic controls and ship feel. It just feels like Descent all over again. Bosses are actually fightable in this one. Sadly, no coop (yet).

author: {'steamid': '76561198217327255', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 6090, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 151, 'last_played': 1704850728}
review:
Overloadingly amazing! Done by the original Descent trilogy teams, this is the unofficial Descent 4 you've been waiting for. If you're a hardcore fan of the Descent series, then this is well worth the cash, plus it's available on Linux.

The visuals and soundtrack are awesome, and playability/controls are just what you'd expect from a game with six degrees of freedom.

My only complain about this game is the plot and setting are very close to the original trilogy: you're a pilot who flies through mines on various moons, destroying virus-infected robots, and ultimately blowing up a reactor to escape just in the nick of time. I would've liked to see an added twist on this, and I wish they would've kept Descent 3's formula of going outside to the moons' surfaces at times, rather than just flying through a complex of corridors.

If any of the team reads this, kudos to also keeping the original trilogy's difficulty level names. Nice touch. :)

Bottom line: get this game; you won't be disappointed. I can only imagine how amazing this would be if I had a VR headset while playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960561328', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1196, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 891, 'last_played': 1708316354}
review:
TL DR.  Buy this game now.  Its well made and has a lot of a replay value.  

to skip backstory skip to second paragraph...

I had a computer as a child. Since 286s were a thing.  I really started paying attention when the Descent series started to come out.   Descent 2, especially, was a huge thing for me when I was really young.  I can't really say much about the later installments in the series, I played them a little but it wasn't the same.  I did play the Freespace series and did like it but thats another story.  

Overload feels like a great return to form for the series, even if it is only a spiritual succesor.  The way the ship pilots and how the weapons feel really remind me of Descent 2.  Definitely very eerie getting that same feeling from the combat over 20 years later.

The AI is not as sneaky or scary (as Descent 2) but I have only played up to hotshot difficulty so I am not sure if they become that way in hgiher settings.  That being said, in Descent, the higher difficulties just meant FASTER reacting enemies, not necessarily smarter or sneakier.  This aside, I do still like the AI, its just different.

The Graphics are good but not overkill good.  Just enough to make it still feel "gamey", which I like.  Game plays very smoothly, framerate wise,even in big fights. I like the level design AND the bot design.  ALMOST as much as Descent 2. 
 Very polished so far.  One thing I did notice is the lack of large interiors for huge fights.  Maybe that changes later on. Maybe its a conscious decision by the developer to keep battles less reliant on kiting.

The Sounds are ok.  Descent 2 had better sound and better music, more on that further on.  I really miss the more unique sounding "barks" of bots that were so recognizable in the Descent series.   I remember being TERRIFIED upon hearing the crys of late game bots travelling near by yet still unaware of my prescence.  Especially the ones that shot nukes.  Back then the game ran on a life system so retrying was a lot less of an option.  It did add to the adrenaline and stress but I feel that leaving it out, as Overload has, was ulitimately a good decision.  It makes the game easier to just hop in and start playing, rather than having to get your mind set up and get warmed up.

I haven't played (and don't plan to play) multiplayer.  Its not really my thing for this type of game.

And now for the reason I'm writing this review.  The music... And it won't be what you think I'm going to say...

I credit in game music as starting my passion for music in general as a child.   I can trace my influences back to such composers as Frank Klepacki and Yasunari Mitsuda.  Music is now my livelyhood and it is a very important part of my life.  When I play a game, I pay SPECIAL attention to the music and see if it fits the game's moments well.  Most of the time , recently, I'd have to say no... I am a huge opponent of cookie cutter orchestral scores in ANY game, no matter how intellectual and grand their creation is.  Most games tend to have this now a days but back in the magical era of the 90s and very early 2000s, video game music for action titles was techno, metal and rock.  It  was GREAT time for game music, in my opinion.

Overload tries to straddle the feel of the old Descents with some more EDMish (maybe somewhat industrial if i squint my ears) sounding music which ACTUALLY wasn't half bad.  I actually liked it.  I didn't expect to AT ALL but wanted to give it a chance, as per my habit.  But this brings me to the crux here...

I had planned already to get this game on sale.  I knew EXACTLY what I was going to do when I bought it.  I waited so long for it to drop in price because I had been hurt by sooo many remakes in the past.  When I finally got it I executed my plan.

Acquire a copy of the ORIGINAL RED BOOK AUDIO from Descent 2.  Turn off in game music.  Turn on Descent 2 music.  Turn up volume.  Set difficulty to hard.  

My god it was a glorious experience and still is!  Instant adrenaline upon entering combat.  Somehow the music STILL does this magical thing that predicts the ebb and flow, the tension and release, of the room to room battles.  EVEN IN A DIFFERENT GAME! HOW!

It fits the game WAY better than the original overload music, even though it is good in its OWN right.  It just had no chance.

Its like this style of game was made for that sound 

If you've read this far then you atleast value opinion to a degree.  Take my advice,  buy this game, GET THE MUSIC.  Take some of the crappier tracks out and voila.  Perfect no grav mining tunnel mayhem experience.  Only made far greater if you have the nostalgia to boot.

Excellent game so far!

author: {'steamid': '76561197970735464', 'num_games_owned': 2915, 'num_reviews': 176, 'playtime_forever': 430, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 297, 'last_played': 1539360593}
review:
Oh boy am I happy I decided to pull the trigger on this game! I played Descent 1 and 2 when they were current and absolutely loved them. They had tight gameplay mechanics, a fresh style of gameplay (6 degrees of freedom), excellent atmosphere, and great music. 

Everything present in those games that wowed me are here in Overload with as much polish, style, and great gameplay mechanics as the original Descent games. Plus, there is multiplayer, challenge mode with leader boards and a really easy to use level editor so you can have endless fun! It is so great to see some devs get back and revive their genre in the truest form to their old games as possible while being completely modern. The icing on the cake is playing it in VR! With an HP WMR HMD + Xbox One S controller I am LOVING this experience. 

I highly recommend this game if you were into the descent games and want something that lives up to them whether you are playing in pancake or VR mode this game is awesome - you will not regret it. 

8.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198079025399', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 244, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 235, 'last_played': 1540033693}

author: {'steamid': '76561198067349241', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 545, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 382, 'last_played': 1579461260}
review: This is a great game.  The visuals are stunning and the gameplay is a wonderful reminder of why Descent was such a great game to play.  If you're a Descent fan this is a must have.  If you never got the chance to play Descent then get this game and see what you missed.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990704157', 'num_games_owned': 1170, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 218, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 112, 'last_played': 1558128990}
review:
I usually like 6 DoF games, and I thoroughly enjoyed the recent "EVERSPACE". My prefered method of control for these types of games is a mouse for aiming, my Logitech G13 keypad which has a little thumb joystick for Lateral and Vertical thrust, and using W and S to move forwards and backwards. 

I have been unable to enjoy overload because I can't use my G13 due to whatever input wrapper thing the devs are using for this game. It just can't handle it for some silly reason. They told all three of us G13 users that they'd contact the devs of the input wrapper thingy and get back to us. No word yet, and it's going on 5 or 6 months now. 

I really want to play this game. I don't want to have to bind my joystick to arrow keys and lose all my analog functionality, ugh. 

plz gib G13 support.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071483433', 'num_games_owned': 1047, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 3255, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2440, 'last_played': 1680535123}

author: {'steamid': '76561198035132614', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 701, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 701, 'last_played': 1537587706}
review:
Overreliance on old-school tropes ruins the game. Sure, we want to experience the original Descent look and feel. But there are several aspects to the UI that make the game feel frustrating and outdated. 

1. Absolutely horrendous weapon slection and cycling UI. You can only cycle forward with the mouse wheel (unchangeable, I have a mouse with 2 wheels and I can't use the second one effectively), and weapons and missiles are doubled up for each selection key. So there is no way to map 1 weapon or missile per key (also unchangeable). This makes changing weapons in combat error-prone and unintuitive.
2. In the upgrade screen, there is no tech tree allowing you to see upcoming upgrades, so it's hard to tell if a weapon is worth investing in.
3. The save and load game screens have to indication as to which game was saved last, and no quick way to resume the last save.
4. Unskippable death animations without a quick way to reload the last save, but provide an option to restart the level (sure, how many people would like to restart a level from the beginning because they died?)
5. Last few levels don't provide access to upgrades, and you are not warned about that
6. Speed upgrades are week, and afterburner much slower than Descent, making movement feel sluggish

And a bunch more.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964368970', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 12174, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6861, 'last_played': 1672296659}
review:
Bring back the old school 6DOF gaming with a twist of modern touch. This is as close to Descent as it gets! In many ways it feels like a combination of descent1,2,3 and what even would have been 4. I backed this and descent Underground on kickstarter. this is an example of not only a good game remade, but a kickstarted game that delivered as promised and was actually released.!



I haven't played much multiplayer yet, as i was super big on multiplayer descent all the way back to modem to modem days. This however has kept me busy with the challenge mode scoreboards. I am slowly getting old players back into the mix so maybe some multiplayer will be on soon!

If you ever played and enjoyed any 6DOF games like Descent, Foresaken, Descent underground and others you will like this one!

author: {'steamid': '76561198861965289', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 641, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 223, 'last_played': 1557002904}
review:
The ONLY thrust vectored realistic spaceflight series I've ever found. 
Spend some time really dialing in your control mapping and axis settings until it feels as easy as walking.  Two analog sticks req'd Joystick or Controller will do.
PRO-TIP: Try an extra keyboard on the floor for bank left/right.
***** Rated: Five Starfighters

author: {'steamid': '76561197998642227', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 2867, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1478, 'last_played': 1687897735}
review:
Never played a 6 DOF game before but always wanted to, so I tried this out... and it's awesome! 
No really, if you're a fan of old school fps, I bet you will like this.

Might be a bit confusing to navigate at first but the levels in the beginning are simple enough to get the hang of it.
There are many different weapons and missiles which you get to upgrade, all of them are usefull even in late game.
The music! it kicks ass, I even bought the ost later.
Story is interesting enough.
Level design is great, good variation between big spaces and small tunnels.
Enemies are fun to fight, boss battles are engaging.

Anyway, give it a try, I'm sure you will not be disappointed if you like to shoot stuff with awesome weapons.

author: {'steamid': '76561198097195208', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 17, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17, 'last_played': 1537765458}

review:
Pros: Solid AI, complex maps that aren't complete mazes, lots of weapon and enemy diversity, solid controls that feel good when you upgrade your movement speed a little. 

Cons: Infinite enemy spawning sections that can suck a cock, upgrades and weapons lack some balance.

Overall: Breddy good.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971698529', 'num_games_owned': 163, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 228, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 201, 'last_played': 1539268857}

author: {'steamid': '76561197971158398', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 12157, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5058, 'last_played': 1643601020}
review:
Well after that Arne  made OL Proxy and made it possible to host dedicated servers, it doesn't matter where you are located, this is a big deal !

And a major game changer. so even if you live in the Oceana area you can host your own dedicated server so peopel can join you that are from your region no matter where you are located, this fixes and changes everything for that part.

but many cons still remain such as the following which Descent 2 a game from 1996 still has the advaantage over Overload:

[b]No Co-Op
No Hoard
No Flag
Ships that die near players don't damage other players
No Rear view camera with picture in picture method as in HUD.
youc an fire weapons when using after burners
no  netgames server lsit where player can shoose whats erver to join
Unable to join gaqmes thatare already running
Host can't choose was server to host from
Dedicated servers work via OlProxy 0.2.0 only hereby needing 3rd party software to get you server running
Community m,aps need a seperate folder in the Overload DLC folder
Many community maps suffer ligting bugs that is caused by Overload's Unity Engine.
CryEngine 4.0 or Unreal Engine with Vulkan API would of been far superior
No Survival mode[/b]


And I know there was a limited budget, even I know some of these things could of been added Co-Op & Flag mode for example, would of given Overload a much better content.

From what I have een Open Source devs do for much less money and have far more  game modes, I question this a lot.

But thanks to the fun I am having with the Overload Teams League I do recommend this game for those that love competative game play, so all besides the cons I actually start loving Overload  when I played with the OTL and just other Overload players in general, it doesn't have to be perfect to be fun to play in the end.

You can find more info about the OTL Here:
http://otl.gg/

Join their discord for more information, their discord link is placed at the bottom right corner of their OTL website's main page.

author: {'steamid': '76561198118181630', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 1394, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1170, 'last_played': 1700863172}
review:
ive never heard of descent. but i like overload. it challenges your perception in futuristic space facilities with tense battles. there is no up and down really, left becomes up or the ceiling becomes the floor, however you desire. in some later levels it can become tough stealth action where you have to plan out your attacks and you feel like some kind of spider sneaking up on dangerous prey, walking on the ceiling, hiding in cracks on the wall, hunting robots and slowly working your way through the levels that branch in all directions like an underground nest. you learn the characteristic behaviours of the different robots, some even sneak up on you.
rookie difficulty was too easy and just a fly through, which made me miss out on a lot of what makes the game. start with hotshot difficulty at least. i now restarted my first playthrough on ace difficulty and have to plan my ammunition and constantly save and load because it is that challenging in later levels, but it is fun. play with mouse and keyboard, it's more like an ego-shooter and you wont hit much with a gamepad. the sound design is notable, you get different songs in different levels, sometimes horror-game like background sounds in different areas and some of the coolest weapon sounds ive ever heard. oh, and the enemy sounds are like a horde of demons coming down on you. well done.
the graphics are ok if distance light fading is on. unfortunately, that option costs about 30fps, so i had to buy a new card. but i am not complaining - it runs natively on a free os without issue. one of my favorite games now.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970721984', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 5075, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2905, 'last_played': 1677552549}
