author: {'steamid': '76561198418549470', 'num_games_owned': 1157, 'num_reviews': 654, 'playtime_forever': 431, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 41, 'last_played': 1630103116}
review:
This game.. such a good successor to the old Descent game. They got the enemy AI perfect, which was so important. Graphics, music, and sound are just all perfect. I thought the map design was also excellent. I am just really, really happy with my purchase of the game, and I highly recommend it to anyone interested in first-person shooters, who is also looking for a new type of experience. You will need a gamepad or a joystick with throttle for best experience. Works perfectly on ubuntu linux with radeon mesa drivers.

Update: I think it is great that this game continues to get new maps from developers and users as Steam DLCs. There is a lot of quality entertainment here that keeps on giving!

author: {'steamid': '76561198001047882', 'num_games_owned': 235, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 1908, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 108, 'last_played': 1675571619}
review:
Few peopel will have the patients for this game.  Think back to the mid 90's when FPS games started ripping threw the shelves and us old people as you kids like to call Grandpa's have no Idea.  This isn't your everyday COD BS gameok.  You will not just jump into this game and do well at all.  Online the people playing this game have been playing it since it wore the name Descent.  This is a Descent series game and is everything Descent stood for back in the 90's.  Even today these Same people still play Descent of the 90's and rave about this follow up that is now 20 later.  20 years of tweaking and MOD's that lead to what it is now.  

Jump into this gmae give it some time, your entertainment depends on it.  

So, Do you think that you are a Hardcaore gamer?  If you are you will love this game.  If you are not, you will just leave it sitting in your list pissed off about it for life becuase your not the hardcore gamer you though you were. 

"DO NOT COME INTO THIS GAME LIKE COD, you will fail getting the skill set required to play this game before you even buy it!"

author: {'steamid': '76561197970638435', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 974, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 423, 'last_played': 1545847787}
review: The real sequel to Descent 2. Feels like home.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976277709', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 2653, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1753, 'last_played': 1707330246}
review: Being in my late 30s this was a massive hit to me. I loved Descent, Freespace, and Forsaken. This feels and plays like a sequel to where Descent 3 left off. It isn't perfect, but man it is good. I wish more developers would release games like this based on older original game play. We don't need 20 different things going on in one game. There are not as many older players as new, but we are here and we love games that bring us back to the 90s and early 2000s. Most of the games I play these days are indie games because they are the only ones willing to make games like this. I beat the game and downloaded several community map packs and it has been a great experience. Hopefully they will make another game, but we can only wish.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021987353', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 972, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 839, 'last_played': 1653964125}
review: I thoroughly enjoyed playing this game.  I was always a fan of the Descent series and I have been waiting for a game to come along that scratched that same itch and Overload completely succeeded.  The controls were flawless and it felt much more fluid and easier to control compared with other titles (even the Descent titles).  I only ran into one bug the entire game and I honestly believe it was a bug in Steam's game sync system as it was after I loaded a save game none of the robots would attack for the level I was working on; this obviously made the rest of the level a little too easy.  My really only complaint is that some of the weapons were just not very useful in the campaign as I found that I rarely ever used the flak cannon or the vortex missle.  Overall if you like 6DOF game I would say purchase this game without a second though; I really hope they continue working on this game and release another one in the future.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055712441', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 83, 'playtime_forever': 520, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 520, 'last_played': 1532019861}
review:
Overload ist ein recht guter FPS. Diesmal steuert man nicht eine Person sondern ein kleines Shuttle mit reichlich Feuerkraft!

Die Grafik ist ziemlich gut und an dieser Stelle ein riesiges Lob an die Entwickler. Die Texturen, die liebe zur Detail echt gut geworden!

Das Gameplay erinnert aus meiner Sicht ziemlich an Descent (sind ja auch die selben Entwickler haha) und auch an Aquanox oder Forsaken. Ein kleines Shuttle, ausgestattet mit verschiedene Waffen muss andere Shuttles abschie√üen und muss ins n√§chste Level abschnitt kommen. Soviel dazu, klingt simpel ist es auch ja aber macht jede Menge Spa√ü!

Alles in allem finde ich wie oben genannt, Overload einen sehr gute FPS. Im Sale ein Muss f√ºr jeden der Forsaken oder Descent gespielt hat.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970762131', 'num_games_owned': 545, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 401, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 401, 'last_played': 1542855526}
review:
A fun, fast, and solid 6DOF shooter. The controls are flawless, the levels sharp, and your weapons and enemies both deliver a punch. The sound is fantastic as well, with a decent soundtrack and SFX that both sound satisfying while harkening back to the original. Lighting is excellent; shadows will have you cautiously checking out blind corners or making you wonder what's behind you. This *is* Descent, remade for the moden era, and it's fantastically polished at that. If there is one flaw in this game, is might be that it's *too* much like Descent, right down to the elements of it's level design and enemy placement. It's perfect in execution, and its as if the decades between Descent II and Overload wern't there. But it's 2018 now, and while it feels wonderful to play Descent again, it also reminds me of how far the art has progressed since.

Edit 11/21/2018 - It's encouraging to see just how active the community is around this game and how well it's being supported post-launch given it's seemingly "sleeper" status. If you haven't given this a spin yet, do so.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019924727', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 13999, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9728, 'last_played': 1702742154}
review:
I failed the 2nd year of my Engineering Degree due to Descent 2 (true), so having it reborn as Overload is amazing!
It's been very well done, absolutely faithful to D2, with amazing graphics and it perfectly progresses from the usual robots in mineshaft to something different as you work thru the single player levels.  
The Challenge Mode is great fun, simple 'rooms' with more and more and more autoops coming at you, it's intense!  
And then Multiplayer.  Enormous fun. Absoute carnage! lol.  Sadly i'm usually connected with a huge ping/lag so get annihilated.

Really hoping that it might one day gain Co-Op in story mode. Being in a team of 4, battling more random plasced, AI driven autoops thru the mines would be addictive as hell!  I'm still playing L4D2 to this day because Co-Op is so fun.  This will ensure OL will stay popular for years too!

author: {'steamid': '76561198041819348', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 674, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 606, 'last_played': 1536259867}
review:
Vorab: Ganz klar eine Empfehlung!

F√ºr alle Fans von Descent (90er Jahre) ein absolutes MUSS!
Preiswert - aber jeden Cent wert! Die Geschichte ist nat√ºrlich genauso "interessant" wie in den Originalteilen, aber das St√∂rt nicht. Die Vertonung ist bis auf ganz wenige L√§ngen sehr gut gemacht. Die Sprecher interessant.
Das Leveldesign ist typisch - nichts weltbewegendes. Aber es gibt nichts zu meckern.

Die Steuerung ist hervorragend - egal ob mit Pad oder Maus/Tastatur. Intiutiv, direkt. Nicht zu verbessern.
Die Grafik ist ok (man k√∂nnte mehr rausholen oder mehr Details einbauen... aber mal ehrlich: Wer achtet denn auf Bl√ºmchen in den Texturen, wenn man umherfliegt und auf alles schie√üt, was sich bewegt!?)

Die oberen Schwierigkeitsgrade sind etwas hart, aber machbar. 

Manko? - keins. Die Missionen werden auch beim 2.-3. Durchspielen nicht langweilig. Der Multiplayer macht irre Laune.

Gef√§llt Dir das Video? Magst Du Descent? Einen sehr guten Soundtrack?

Dann: Dein Spiel!

author: {'steamid': '76561198141904953', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 90040, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4895, 'last_played': 1706237595}
review:
Get this game. You really need it. You want to fly in ANY direction? Thats what 6 degrees of freedom is. On top of that you are a fighter pilot hunter on seek and destroy missions often becoming the hunted. You are an explorer seeking out useful  secrets. You are a humanitarian rescuing survivers. You will participate in heart pounding action packed battles. You will fight hard, fight furiously and when at last you manage to OVERLOAD the reactor and make your escape in the nick of time you will punch the air knowing you thoroughly deserved that monumental victory. All of this happens whilst being accompanied by a soundtrack that is perfect for this fantastic game.
 And that, my friends, is only level one of single player mode.
Look. . . do yourself a favour, stop reading this review and go and order this game. You won't regret it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992256380', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 4303, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 458, 'last_played': 1690747121}
review:
I rarely ever really write a review however, on this occasion I must praise the developer and team behind this game, it is so rare to find a team to be able to re-hash and modernise a game without losing that original feel, concept and experience. Well Done Guys!!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561197963470524', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1389, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 643, 'last_played': 1557882760}
review:
If you loved Descent in the 90's, then Overload is a must for you.  It accurately captures that crazy abstract level design that was so characteristic of games in its era -- and nicely explains it in the plot as well.  The storytelling is very non-intrusive and can be avoided entirely if you just want to shoot some robots.  The gameplay is a very faithful update of classic Descent mechanics.  And, it's a blast to play in VR too!

TL;DR: Overload is a callback to a better time in gaming, before microtransactions and everything had to be an e-sport.  Worth picking up.  No game will ever recreate that feeling you had playing Descent when you were a kid, but Overload comes pretty close.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982285648', 'num_games_owned': 2699, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 216, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 204, 'last_played': 1593123051}

I hope in future Revival Productions will release expansions, single player DLCs or a sequel. This genre must come back again like the 90's!

Not sure about multiplayer yet. Will update.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995164564', 'num_games_owned': 687, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1610, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1094, 'last_played': 1674409648}
review:
This is Descent IV without the name.
The development time was outstanding. This is a stable, optimized, solid running piece of software.
Linux is support. Such a huge thank you to the development team for this.
This game has made me have a whole new love and appreciation for the Steam Controller.

The control handle just as the previous Descent games did. The game plays just like the previous Descent games did. The maps are bloody mazes just like before that will leave you lost and relying heavily on your map. The guide bot isn't annoying <3. 

There are a few things I do miss from Descent II that this is lacking, no rear view PIP window, the key bindings are a little limited, I'd like to be able to map key bindings to just the weapons I prefer/enjoy using for easier and faster switching, instead of having to press the key twice to toggle A or B, also set the individual Guide Bot functions mapped to keys, I like to use find powerup to sweep the level before I clear it, great way to find hidden areas.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968672190', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 165, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23, 'last_played': 1694067916}
review: Nostalgia overload. :) Absolutely love it. Great job to the team for making something so true to the roots of this genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005734969', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 3407, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2095, 'last_played': 1707888917}
review:
Singleplayer: Thumbs up. Great. The gameplay is excellent. Could probably use more variation in the level design, but the campaign was fun. 

Challenge mode: Two thumbs up. Excellent gameplay, excellent pacing, excellent variety, love the leadboard system on it. I didn't know I needed this in my life.

Multiplayer: Thumbs down. It's pretty fun, but mostly is lacking. The maps are very small, there's no element of map control because everyone spawns with whatever loadout they want. The biggest deciding factor for who wins matches is where the server is located. It's basically got the netcode of a typical 1990's game. Also the only mode is deathmatch and the weapons are not very balanced for PVP. 

Overall: Thumbs up. If you like Descent this game is worth 30$. If it's something that you havent experienced before, it's probably worth 10 since it's a toss up between feeling badass or feeling too claustrophobic and difficult.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960783768', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 846, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 846, 'last_played': 1533702657}
review: What an awesome modern successor to the Descent series. I grew up on Descent 1 and 2 and have to say, I pretty much played through the entire Overload campaign with a giant grin on my face. If you were a Descent fan and haven't picked this up then I really don't know what to tell you. And if you're new to the whole 6DOF shooter thing, I can't recommend a better starting place.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970631771', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1345, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1322, 'last_played': 1609015261}
review:
A fantastic update of Descent that manages to combine all the best aspects of the original series with some modern twists. Everything about this game is clearly a labour of love, made by a small dedicated team that manage to deliver an excillerating shooter. It makes most 3D shooters feel 2D; the extra dimension adds immensurably to the fun. It's fast, frantic, mindblowing and is backed up by some of the best retro-music I've heard in a game. The soundtrack is amazing.

If you like Descent, just buy it, it delivers. If you've never played Descent, just buy it, you're in for a treat.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070016284', 'num_games_owned': 309, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2140, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1833, 'last_played': 1695566930}
review:
The other reviews are impeccable at describing this game. The single word: Descent. Those familiar with that game will feel at home with this one. If you want to feel the controls to feel more like the originals for the mouse, turn a lot of the optional mouse settings off and it'll play like the legend. It's not a 1 to 1 remake, but it doesn't have to be.

Majority of the changes between this and Descent are positive, and I'm not only talking about aesthetics. Sound effects have the right amount of crunch to them. Enemies are easy to spot and the improved graphics aren't intrusive to the experience. The physics of the ship are as tight as the spiritual predecessor and the weapons...the WEAPONS!

The weapons really show off the innovation of what could be done in a repetitive shooter market. Many of these weapons draw inspiration (or are blatant rips) from Luke's previous 2D Dual Stick shooter, Inferno (which is great in its own right). Many weapons are ingenious and extremely useful, like the Creepers and the Reflex (especially when fully upgraded). Others are clearly taken directly from Descent in form and function, like the Thunderbolt (Fusion) and the Impulse (Laser). There are weapons for different playstyles. Enjoy close quarters? Use the Crusher or Cyclone. Prefer to play it safe from a distance or aren‚Äôt too accurate with your shots? Use the Reflex, Missile Pods, or Hunters. Are you actually accurate with your shots? Use Falcons and the Driller. Another added layer is the upgrade system. It is a welcome addition and definitely good at empowering your weapons. It takes a little time to get used to, but once you do, you‚Äôll be scouring maps for precious upgrade points to upgrade your favorite weapons. Want old fashions Quad Lasers? Done. Gauss or Vulcan Cannon? You‚Äôre set. Every weapon feels like it fits into a different niche and has its own purpose except maybe the Time Bomb (except when fully upgraded) and the Flak Cannon‚Ä¶which to be fair, I haven‚Äôt given enough time to try.

The level design is phenomenal. You‚Äôll find yourself crawling through levels that twist and turn in every direction that even the auto-map gets confusing. Every inch of each map is teeming with encounters. The only critique I have here is that a lot of the areas have a samey feel. Maybe it‚Äôs just the nostalgia goggles, but I miss the elemental themed levels (as clich√© as they might be) from the classic games. While comparing a game like this really isn‚Äôt fair, it still doesn‚Äôt help that I can‚Äôt visually tell if I was in Titan Collider or Phoebe. Of course, the ending levels are very far placed from the rest of the game so you get a good amount of variance there.  Additionally, in this game, I feel that enemies can be a bit repetitive so that you‚Äôre used to the same Harpies, Gorgons, Wyverns‚Ä¶and the darn Golem/Reavers. Other than that, the ship design looks like a flying toaster and customization is fairly simple. I also wish that pressing Esc would fast forward so you can see all the text for cutscenes instead of skipping the cutscene altogether.

And that‚Äôs it. Those 4 minor gripes are the only things that bother me about this game. Just about everything else is amazing. This game fits like a glove when you get the controls right, the difficulty is great, the level design is great, and the weapons are the best. Definitely recommend this for anyone interested in skill based combat in an old-new genre of shooter. 9/10 in my book :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197982210314', 'num_games_owned': 836, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 404, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 381, 'last_played': 1533262272}
review:
Overload is to Descent what Doom 2016 is for the Doom Franchise. A solid 6DOF shooter with an excellent soundtrack and level design, it also features a pretty interesting story that actually got me hooked on the last section of the game just to see how it ended. 

If you enjoy Descent and is currently looking for the real spiritual successor, look no further, Overload is as close to a Descent 4 as it gets.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970314107', 'num_games_owned': 2304, 'num_reviews': 917, 'playtime_forever': 569, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 569, 'last_played': 1533270006}
review:
[b][i]Review copy provided by developer[/i][/b]

Descent has always been something of the odd man out in the pantheon of FPS classics. Despite innovating on the basic first-person formula with its six-degrees-of-freedom free-flight combat, it never took off or spawned the slew of imitators its peers did. It did get two sequels and a brilliant spin-off space sim series, though, and now after far too long it has returned. Only now it‚Äôs called Overload, and all the names are different. The head-spinning combat and ravenous robots and flashy weapons and explosive escapes are all back, along with a few new tricks learned in the intervening decade. But in some ways, Overload might be a little too tethered to its ancestors to really rise to its occasion.

Space mining corp Juno Offworld has pushed out to the moons of Saturn with their Cronus Frontier initiative, a network of bases manned by skeleton crews and worked by robotic autonomous operators. Something has gone drastically wrong though, and the auto-ops have begun taking their mining lasers and rock crushers to the humans instead of the minerals. Your ship, the Iberia, just happens to be in the right place to intervene and happens to have a smart little gunship for you to pilot on search and destroy missions. To root out whatever madness is afoot you‚Äôll need to battle back the auto-ops and destroy the reactors of the fallen facilities, hopefully escaping the blast in the process.

The formula is very much the same as in the first two Descents, but new to Overload is a fairly involved story. The pre-mission briefings drop tons of tidbits about what‚Äôs going on in Saturn‚Äôs orbit as you gear for your next assault, and each mission has a bunch of concise audio logs that detail the strange machinations that led to the robot rebellion. Eventually the many plot threads weave together to explain the whole mess and point you to a final showdown that‚Ä¶ honestly only resolves a small piece of the story. I‚Äôll forgive them a weak ending for keeping the narrative running just through text and logs, because there‚Äôs a surprising amount going on that you only really hear about.

Your concern is going to be getting in, blowing everything up, and getting back in one piece, and that won‚Äôt be a simple task. Being a six-degrees-of-freedom game, you have the ability to fully traverse the cavernous chambers and winding passages of each facility. These places are packed with deadly robots, with smarter and fiercer ones appearing the further into the adventure you get. Battles are hectic, with you dodging lasers and missiles from every angle and returning fire with your own impressive arsenal. As you progress you‚Äôll unlock gatling lasers, flak cannons, homing missiles, room-clearing warheads, and even exotic tools like time-dilating bombs and vortex-generating missiles.

Finding secrets earns you upgrade points to improve your arms, and this part of the game deserves special note. Overload is absolutely THICK with secrets, tucking away literally dozens per mission. They can be as simple as a floor panel that slides open when you bump it, or a button hidden behind a grating that drops the forcefield around a reactor that powers another forcefield that leads to a maze of tunnels loaded with enemies and items. The upgrade points you find are split into two types, normal and super, used to upgrade each weapon twice. The normal upgrade usually gives a single bonus like more damage or a new feature like enemy tracking, while the super upgrade lets you pick one of two powerful suites of improvements. Even if you‚Äôre not dogged in your search for secrets you‚Äôll be able to upgrade your favorite weapons, but if you‚Äôre the obsessive type you‚Äôll come out with a devastating arsenal.

And you kinda need it, because Overload can get pretty brutal. I say this fully acknowledging there are five difficulty levels and you can switch at any time, but I was determined to beat the third and while I did, it wasn‚Äôt always a pleasant experience. The early levels ease you into fighting dangerous auto-ops and big swarms, and the middle levels ramp this up to a thrilling challenge. By mission 11 it was getting a little ridiculous, as new enemies could pound my armor down to nothing in an instant if I ever failed to dodge or juke a salvo. There are no checkpoints either, so I resorted to saving regularly once missions got to be 40 minutes long and the risk of failing an escape at the very end became real. It‚Äôs also worth mentioning that the last four missions of the game have a significant change of pace that I found more frustrating than anything.

Overload fits right in with the recent wave of aggressively-retro FPSes, and not just for its old-school sensibilities about challenge. The sixteen sprawling levels you‚Äôll blast your way through feature dizzying networks of shafts and chambers that make the most of your free-flight movement, just as the original Descent and its sequel did. But modern level design has been making places look like actual places for decades now, and Overload‚Äôs levels‚Ä¶ don‚Äôt. As detailed as the auto-ops are and as luscious as the particle effects get, the rooms your battles rage in tend to be extremely plain. They never look like real, functional locales, just tunnels for you to hunt keys and secrets and robots in. Don‚Äôt get me wrong, they serve their purpose in their layout and complexity, but I have no doubt that a talented environment artist could have added details like catwalks and airlocks to make the levels feel lived-in and real.

Despite these missteps, Overload‚Äôs gameplay is some of the most hectic and gratifying you‚Äôll get in the genre. Your weapons feel powerful and impressive as they shove auto-ops around and shatter them against the walls. Sparks, fire, and metal bits cascade through rooms with every robot you smash, making huge battles veritable typhoons of destruction. And for the explorers in the audience, you‚Äôll have hundreds of secrets to turn up across the seven or eight hours it takes to blast through the campaign. There‚Äôs a challenge mode, New Game+, and even multiplayer that you probably shouldn‚Äôt count on being populated but hey, it‚Äôs there. Overload is the Descent revival we didn‚Äôt know we wanted, still a little stuck in the past but flashy and fun enough to make a solid shooter.



Did you enjoy this review? I certainly hope so, and I certainly hope you'll check out more of them at https://goldplatedgames.com/ or on my [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/11322459/]curation page[/url]!

author: {'steamid': '76561197971316390', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 97, 'playtime_forever': 1919, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1919, 'last_played': 1531606521}
review:
Retro games are a curious thing. You can have amazing games with retro graphics and sound and people will love it. But why? What do they have in common? Let's take two recent success stories with Sonia Mania and Shovel Knight.

Sonic Mania - "Exciting level design, a stellar soundtrack, and cool expansions on the original formula"
Sonic Mania - "A breakneck platformer that uses classic Sonic as a foundation for something fresh and exciting. "
Shovel Knight - "Shovel Knight is a modern classic that takes the 2-D platforming genre and modernizes it. "
Shovel Knight - "Old and new in almost the best ways."

What is the common factor here? Both have retro graphics and sound but their gameplay is modern. So what happens when you have a game with modern graphics and retro gameplay? A very mediocre game, thats what. And that is Overload.

When you look at the reviews, you can see that there is a great deal of gushing about how much this is like the old Decent games. The way the ship handles, the enemies, weapons and environments. And they are very, very right. It's like the developers have been locked in hypersleep for the last 20 years and then woke up and decided to make a game. But this isn't what actually happened, they've simply rejected what progress designers have made on how to make games as fun as possible over the years, In their own words, they wanted to bring back what is missing in modern games. Things such as enemies appearing right next to you when you push a button. Remember that from the old days? Opening a doorway with an enemy facing you on the otherside for a free hit. Ahh, that old acorn! Running along face-grinding walls and shooting random surfaces to open hidden stashes of weapons and powerups. Oh, the fun! Enemies that stand perfectly still and silent only to attack without warning as soon as you turn a corner. Every level having the exact same goals with no variety. I won't carry on. Put simply, everything which drags a game down and everything which has been tossed away as refuge by modern games is back! This folks is the Mighty No 9 of 2018 - the wrong kind of retro.

The level design and balance is equally as poor, with you frequently being fired upon down narrow corridors where you have no room to dodge and you need to back up to the nearest corner to play peek-a-boo. Whole rooms cleared because you went in, backed out and then just shot the bots as they came through the narrow doorway one by one making the whole affair a tedious chore. Enemies dropping health like candy because the developers haven't got the hang of enemy placement and map layout so in order to keep you alive they have to keep throwing health at you. Powerups, like invulnerability, hidden in secret compartments well away from the action so when you do get them they're utterly useless. There is also the questionable fact that it is impossible for them to carefully design levels to be fair for the player when their difficulty system increases the projectile speed of enemies. So if you're in a room with a bot at the other end and you can just narrowly avoid incoming fire on the lowest setting, it then becomes impossible on the high settings. Same room, same bot placement but with a completely different result. Suddenly you need cover but none is provided.

But it's not all doom and gloom. The music is nice and the graphics are decent. But Overload is simply the wrong way to do retro games. It tugs on the nostalgia by including hi-scores and Decent-like gameplay but it ends up being mediocre because it revived all of the great things about the series along with all the bad game design habits that should stay in the past. Not recommended at all.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968307413', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1245, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1226, 'last_played': 1688584466}
review:
Six Degrees of Awesome:

1) Gameplay is rock solid, old-school 90s 6DOF goodness, dripping with nuance.
2) Aesthetics dripping from every vertex, awash in an aura of industrial foreboding.
3) Rockin' music which serves to amplify the atmosphere presented and the tempo that Overload demands
4) A difficulty curve that eases you into the 6-Degrees of Freedom, but then thoroughly challenges you once you've mastered the basics.
5) A narrative with a sympathetic villain and an equivalently morally ambiguous organization giving you mandates creates a sense of crossed loyalties; is it worth this sacrifice to build a new world? No, it's much more than that, and you'll keep second guessing your own actions as well as those of others until it's explained at the crescendo.
6) Altogether, the single player experience is one that any fan of 90s shooters would be loathe to miss. Also, there's multiplayer!

**** out of 5.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977433175', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 109, 'playtime_forever': 1427, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 986, 'last_played': 1610070585}
review: This is one of the best quality games I've played in a very long time.  It reminds me of the good old days when games were actually fully tested and debugged before put in the hands of players.  As soon as you start playing this game you'll realize how much effort the developers went to make it a very satisfying and fun gaming experience.  Everything about the game is polished from the beautiful graphics to the perfect combat mechanics and controls.  I never played descent but the six-degree-of-freedom movement reminds me of classic DOS shooters like X-Wing and Tie Fighter -- and I'm extremely reluctant to compare any modern game to legendary titles like that but Overload absolutely makes the cut.  In terms of value for money I guarantee you won't be disappointed buying this game.  Now that I've played I can say it's worth way more than they're charging for it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002854407', 'num_games_owned': 268, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 50619, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11301, 'last_played': 1677132660}
review:
The crew from the classic Descent games returns for a modern incarnation of the 6-degrees-of-freedom games we all know and love. There are three primary game modes available:

[h1]Single Player Campaign[/h1]
Much like the old-school shooters it draws influence from, the biggest draw in this game is easily the single player campaign. The Cronus Frontier campaign is no-nonsense, fast-paced action. While a little bit shorter compared to the classics of old, the overall level design and difficulty balance is much more polished. With five selectable difficulty levels, both directionally-challenged newbies and challenge-seeking veterans should be able to find some enjoyment here. The upgrade system offers a nice bit of flexibility to your playstyle and nicely rewards those with a keen eye for secrets. My only criticisms are that I found most of the boss fights to be somewhat underwhelming, and that some players might find the lack of mission variety to grow a bit repetitive by the end.

[h1]Challenge Mode[/h1]
Challenge Mode pits you into an arena with endlessly spawning bots, with two seperate sub-modes: Countdown (Get as many kills as possible in a 5-minute time limit) and Infinite (Survive as long as possible, getting as many kills as you can before being taken down). The item and enemy spawns are randomized on every playthrough to ensure that no two plays are the exact same. While this does keep the mode from getting stale, it is a bit of a double-edged sword for anyone looking to place high on the in-game leaderboards. Ranking up in that regard can often feel somewhat dependent upon randomly rolling a favorable intersection of high-value targets and strong powerup pickups. If you're not too worried about chasing leaderboards, though (or even if you are!), there's still quite a lot of fun to be had here once you've finished up the campaign.

[h1]Multiplayer[/h1]
Multiplayer is, much like the single player campaign, all about straightforward, no-nonsense action. Rules are simple - blow up the other guys, but don't get blown up yourself. First, the bad news - the multiplayer experience is currently considerably restrictive and laden with flaws. Long wait times, finnicky ranking system, squirelly lag compensation, lack of a server browser, and very limited number of servers all mean that getting a balanced match without frustrating hit-registration problems is unfortunately not something you can expect to get consistently. There's also a distinct lack of multiplayer co-op options available for the campaign and challenge modes.

The good news, though, is that the developers have stated that they are aware of these issues, and are looking to make improvements here one of their next focuses once the console versions are completed. Here's hoping we see improvements in the future.



Overload is absolutely worth picking up if you're a fan of shooters, especially 6dof shooters like the classic Descent - but only if you're looking for a solid single player experience. If you're looking for a good multiplayer experience, I'd probably recommend holding out for a bit until after the console versions release.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980052428', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3213, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2375, 'last_played': 1689886320}
review:
This is an outstanding title and a worthy successor to Descent in every way. It is honestly my favourite game to come out for a very long time. I say this as an incredibly long-standing fan and veteran of Descent; probably my favourite game series of all time. This game is 100% worth buying if you are a fan of Descent, 6DOF, good shooters, or even just video games in general!

As a whole, the game is incredibly well designed. It looks and feels incredibly satisfying to play. The ship handles most similarly to the Descent 3 ships, in that it moves fast and has a fast turn rate, but I actually think this suits the more modern style and the Unity engine the game runs on. The graphics are simply lovely. The levels themselves are fairly minimalistic but they look gorgeous, leaving very little to be desired in the graphics department. Particularly impressive is the attention to detail with lighting; the dynamic lighting from weapons and effects is simply wonderful and the game makes heavy usage of dynamic lighting from the map's own lights, which also do a great job of looking pretty while guiding the player and serving their utility purpose. Perhaps my only criticism of the base game as a whole is that I think performance is a little poorer than one might expect, but that may just be an unavoidable byproduct of the many high-resolution textures and intense usage of dynamic lighting. The game also has a great UI and the options menu has all the settings and features you'd expect from a proper PC title. I had no complaints.

The singleplayer is an all around excellent product. It achieves a perfect blend of that satisfying old school core gameplay loop of: kill bots, find keys, rescue hostages, kill reactor, escape via exit exit, with some more modern shooter elements, such as: weapon upgrades, audio logs, story snippets, etc. Because of this it feels fresh, while also familiar and fun. The story is immersive and enticing and unfolds at a perfect pace; but it is also entirely ignorable if that sort of thing is not your cup of tea. The weapons are well balanced, numerous, and satisfying to use and experiment with. The levels are very well designed and nicely varied - I never really felt fatigue or repetition while playing it. The bots have a lot of personality and are varied, reasonably intelligent, and fun to fight. I've played through the singleplayer campaign 3 times now and I still enjoy it, finding new things every time. There's an excellent New Game+ mode too, as well as speedrunning and % completion options too, so there's something for every level of player.

The multiplayer is also great, but leaves a fair bit to be desired. I'm a veteran of Descent 1 and 2 multiplayer, having played them over Kali for more than 10 years now. I think the core gameplay loop of Overload's multiplayer is solid: the weapons are mostly well balanced and the ships feel responsive and fast, and the game plays like Descent really should. It's a more modern Descent. I think some of the weapons may have some balancing issues; in particular I think the Driller and Flak are a little too overpowered for what their purposes are intended to be, but it isn't anything that couldn't be solved in a quick patch. I quite like the loadout, perks and XP progression system that is in play; again, it's a nice little modern element that doesn't carry too much weight. It entices you to play a bit more and unlock stuff but none of it is massively impactful so you never feel like you are at a huge disadvantage if you don't have the higher level stuff. The level selection is also pretty great; I don't feel like many of the maps are instant classics like everyone's favourite MP maps from Descents 1 and 2, but what's there at the moment certainly does the job well. There are no maps that I dislike or felt bad to play.

The areas in multiplayer that I feel are slightly lacking are the features. Multiplayer was never intended to be included with the base game, so while it's a lovely bonus for players that is still totally worth playing, it still shows that it was somewhat of an afterthought. There's no variety in gametypes (deathmatch only), searching for matches can be a bit of a crapshoot (the MP population is somewhat hidden so you never know if there are actually others playing or not), the ranking system is neat but rather obfuscated, and there's no option to easily play with friends outside of a private server. I think there's a lot that Revival can do to beef up the multiplayer and make it a really solid part of the game, and I hope they will do so in a future update. I know the passion and the desire to improve the game is there, so here's hoping!

Overall, Overload is a fantastic game and a worthy successor to Descent. This is an old school game revived and done right. You should play it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198039312993', 'num_games_owned': 233, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 28, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28, 'last_played': 1532374293}
review:
- VR Only Review -
It is what you expect to be, but there is a huge issue for me while playing this game. I don't know why, but it seems like that the movement with VR is at 90 Hz, but if I thrust or spin my ship the world around me move with ~ 30 Hz. This is not a graphic card problem, and it won't affect the gameplay. It only makes me as dizzy as no VR game before. If you feel some locomotion issues in some other VR games then I would not recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068217248', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1578, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1570, 'last_played': 1533786273}
review:
I never played Descent, never even heard of it until I looked at this game. So my review is from the perspective of a newcomer to the series and to the 6 Degrees of Freedom (6DOF) gameplay. Overload is a zero-gravitry, bullet-hell, close quarters FPS that feels like classic DOOM, but with space ships and modern graphics. It's fun, challenging, well-priced, and I will say it again: DOOM IN SPACESHIPS!

In fact, the call back to classic games is done better here than in modern DOOM. Levels are confusing nonlinear complexes with A LOT of secrets hidden in each level. There are no meaningless collectables, just powerups, weapons, story logs, and upgrade points to spend between levels. This encourages and rewards exploration.
You can save anytime you want but there are no checkpoints. Difficulty can quickly range from easy to nigh impossible. And the overall music and aesthetics harken to Reto Arcades. Some critics say that because of these things the game feels dated, but I prefer the term: Authentic.

Multiplayers! You either become good at this game or get destroyed by 6DOF Veterens. Also, as of writing this review the game is sadly under appriciated and has not gotten enough attention, so the player base is small. Challenge Mode is just that, fun survival or timed challenge levels that you can use to compete with freinds or Steam Leaderboards.

In short, this game is a wonderful FPS gem that newcommers can get into and enjoy without even knowing what Descent or 6DOF is. More people should be playing this game, and praisng the developers for a solid job well done! Bang for your buck, best $30 I've spent in a while.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968546348', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 69972, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5289, 'last_played': 1636595228}
review:
[h] Overload - Not Just a Modernized Descent Game [\h]

Overload brings back the six degrees of movement tunnel games like Descent 1/2/3 and Forsaken. However, the development team went far beyond just the nostalgia of the past, they created a game that represents a near perfect 6DOF game. Through out the development, the dev team listened closely to the community and kickstarter donaters to create a game that shows how much passion the dev team has for this game. I believe you will be hard pressed to find another title that has this much direct support and community. While many dev teams disappear after release, you can still find the dev team actively interacting with the community through their discord channel, forums and weekly streams on twitch. The devs also run weekly challenges that will keep you engaged well beyond the standard play through.

The gameplay in Overload is amazing and whether you play on a gamepad, joystick or mouse you will find highly customizable settings that will allow you to find your perfect playstyle. This is especially true for mouse players, something D1/D2 did very poorly. So if you were a previous Descent player that used a Joystick, you might find you can easily play with a mouse and keyboard combo.

In the previous 6DOF freedom games you only had the ability to play either the single player mode of multiplayer modes, Overload introduces a new mode called Challenge Mode. In Challenge Mode you will be put against an ever increasingly difficult set of bots. The more bots you kill, the number of  bots increase and the harder they get. During the run, every so often super bots will spawn as your  number of kills increases. You will also be awarded weapon upgrades to ensure you can keep up with the ever increasing horde of bots You can play in either infinite mode, where you play until you die or timed mode, which challenges you to kill as many bots as possible in a set time limit. Challege mode also requires you to pay attention to your ammunition levels and make every shot count. If you don't you will be frantically flying around with no way to kill the bots. Leader boards are present for all levels and difficulties so you can let the world see just how good you are. Challange mode is also a great way to hone your flying skills in preparation for multiplayer madness.

Another new feature is the ability to customize your ship. Instead of being forced to find upgraded weapons, you can now select any weapon and missile setup, with the exception of the rare super weapons that spawn randomly during gameplay. You can also select ship perks that allow you to modify several aspects of your ship to further improve your flying style. While these customizations might make you think there is a perfect setup, I guarantee you they don't, The dev team really spent a lot of time balancing the weapon sets to ensure there is no one setup. This is especially fun for multiplayer where you can select two different ship setups that will ensure you have the right weapon types for the varied levels. Gone are the days of starting with a weak old pea shooter and frantically running around looking for a weapong upgrade. Instead, you are immediately a threat as soon as you spawn. This keeps the multiplayer games fun and furious.

Multiplayer offers three different modes. Anarchy, all against all. team mode and 1v1 . You can either queue for a game or setup a private passworded session so you can always team up with your friends. The private sessions are especially fun because it allows you to customize almost every features of the game. This includes changing the win conditions, levels, weapons and several other items. Multiplayer also supports optional setting for cross platform play. This provides a larger number of players to keep the action going. The level design are some of the best maps I have ever seen for this style of game. The will have you changing your ship loadouts to be effective in the session. Since you can pick two different loadouts, you will always have the right setup for the map type. You are also able to change from each setup during the gameplay so you will always be prepared. Overload also released a map editor which will ever increase the number of levels to play on. Revial Productions has published tutorials on how to use the tools so it is easy to get started.

Like most modern games Overload uses a queuing system to search for a session. While you can still ensure play with your friends using the private game setting, the regular queue requires you to wait for other players to join the queue. This means if no players are online, you will be stuck staring at a search screen until someone else joins in. There is no way to see how many people are currently online so you could be staring at the search screen for a long time. You can use the discord channel to try and find folks to play with, but this requires you to install another application to find a game and relies on other players to do the same. You are also unable to select the region you are playing in which can heavily impact your ping times. This dramatically changes your gameplay experience and can often leave you frustrated. Another area missing is the ability to join games currently in session, or immediately restart a session once the session timer expires forcing you to rejoin the queue. Since the queue has a session timer you may be stuck with only 1 other player. Ypu can host your own server, but this option is only available for local LAN play. This concerns me because this service requires Revival Productions to pay for the hosting, and without continual passive income, online play will go away. It is however important to note that the inital Kickstarter campaign did not include multiplayer as a feature. The dev team really pushed hard to get this feature in and shows just how much they love this game and their commitment to the community. The dev team is also actively engaged with the community to improve the online play so some of the issues may be resolved in the future.

To sum it up, I love this game and encourage you to try it. The graphics are amazing, the maps are varied and you can also play in VR mode giving you a whole new immersive experience. Former Descent players I promise you will feel right at home and be dog fighting in some of the best levels I have played. if you have never played a 6DOF game, I encourage you to the best game I have played in the 6DOF genre. With the release of the level editor, you are also ensured to have new caverns to explore that will keep the gameplay fresh. 

PDXGeek

author: {'steamid': '76561197972170220', 'num_games_owned': 559, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 526, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 371, 'last_played': 1619727135}

author: {'steamid': '76561198014685360', 'num_games_owned': 539, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 722, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 190, 'last_played': 1540148274}
review: Just like Descent but brought up to date with a pumping sound track, plus awesome crisp  graphics to.really hope they bring out overload 2 or first a paid dlc to add on to the single player story levels.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987739381', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2135, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 333, 'last_played': 1538596323}
review:
Have played only 90 min so far, but first impression is really good.

Pros:
[list]
[*]graphics are good (I personally like the "flashiness")
[*]it's very playable with only mouse and keyboard (after increasing the mouse sensibility a bit)
[*]weapons feel satisfying
[*]it has many elements of Descent 2 while still feeling unique
[*]classic gameplay where you have to collect power ups instead of automatic "health" regeneration
[*]many secrets that encourage exploration (notice unexpected "door opened" messages)
[*]attention to detail, e. g. enemies are kicked around by rocket explosions and then need a little time to "re-aim", some weapons have recoil
[*]great sound track
[*]less story to distract from gameplay
[/list]

Negs:
[*]none so far

author: {'steamid': '76561197972392543', 'num_games_owned': 1100, 'num_reviews': 123, 'playtime_forever': 2251, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1101, 'last_played': 1691423690}
review: An excellent and true successor to Descent, this shooter is very much in the mold of archaic shooters such as Descent and Doom while adhering to the pulse pounding and somewhat disorienting 6Degree of Freedom Model. The story itself is rather surprising because it touches on rather high end scientific concepts that rarely shows up in popular media, even if it is in service of an ultimately straightforward story. The story itself takes about 6 hours to complete, while challenge modes help flesh out your time to further than that. Not a bad price for that many hours of high intensity combat.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086092515', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 1215, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 727, 'last_played': 1645304255}
review: First level is a little slow, almost returned it. BUT! Now I can't stop playing, it's fast, frantic and fun. And omg particals everywhere! It's a true successor to the Descent series.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971759313', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 414, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 320, 'last_played': 1545877234}
review:
Worth every penny and a great VR "Descent" experience. The controls and flight is buttery smooth, I like the menus and gui and it is a polished gameplay experience.

I'd say a VR must have and can't wait to show my brother who was also a fan of old school flatscreen Descent.

author: {'steamid': '76561198298090230', 'num_games_owned': 206, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 78, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 61, 'last_played': 1637881132}
review:
It's a great game, just bought it. Just finished the 2nd level and already had a "made ya jump" moment and a few tense moments.

I'm not using the guidebot, atleast I'm planning on not using unless I just give up. Glad to have the option though.

Great graphics. Great performance.

Really tight controls, I mean the controls are just spot on perfect. Once you get used to the controls (shouldn't take long or more then a game or two) you just meld with you machince and just start to whiz around and try to get fancy and stuff.

Anyway enjoying the game hoping for more games like this still in the future.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983125554', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 191, 'playtime_forever': 64, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23, 'last_played': 1626219273}

author: {'steamid': '76561197972924033', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 2484, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1311, 'last_played': 1682726264}
review:
Crazy fans of Descent like me have been waiting 20+ years for this, and it does NOT DISAPPOINT!! 

Cutting to the chase:  It is a BEAUTIFUL love letter to its predecessors, and DELICIOUSLY old-school.  Key cards, enemy ambushes, secret doors, guide bot (who is easier to follow AND NO LONGER NAILS YOUR FACE WITH FLARES!!!), and the old staple of blowing up the reactor and flying your terrified butt to the exit ASAP.   

The original Descent developer team got together to make this, and boy is it a glorious love letter to those days.  If you're a fan of Descent, you'll LOVE this!

author: {'steamid': '76561197989815942', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 169, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 124, 'last_played': 1564533933}

author: {'steamid': '76561198009935176', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 817, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 351, 'last_played': 1674429050}

author: {'steamid': '76561198039666571', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 926, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 595, 'last_played': 1675993223}
review:
Descent was one of the first PC games I ever played, and though I wasn't very good at it because I was very young and didn't understand what "strafe" meant, I loved that it was truly 3D and offered six degrees of freedom. I dreamed of one day playing Descent in VR.

After watching a Summer Games Done Quick speedrun of Sublevel Zero, I found myself wistfully searching the internet for Descent-like games and... woah. I didn't expect this. 

This is Descent in everything but name. Many of the same designers, sound engineers, and writers. It looks like a modern Descent, feels like a modern Descent, sounds like a modern Descent... Naturally, it was EXACTLY what I was looking for, and holy crap it has a VR mode! YES, YES, YES, YES PLEASE!

Now that I have a consumer VR setup (and only 20 YEARS after getting a 5 minute taste of VR during a birthday visit to a nearby science center!), this is a dream come true.

I got just a little bit motion sick after playing it in VR mode the first time, but my brain got used to it much faster than I expected. By the second time I played in VR (the next day), I had no issues other than a little bit of eye strain because I played waaaay too long.

The game is amazing. Kudos to Revival Productions - You've definitely lived up to your name.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971231045', 'num_games_owned': 579, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1658, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 172, 'last_played': 1591635613}
review:
So, you are a millenial and received this fancy new VR set as a gift, from daddy and/or granddaddy, last christmas. 

You thought this is the brand new s..t and that they are amazed by this never seen VR  thing...well they fooled you! They disguised it as a gift but actually bought it for themselves, because they knew it was only a matter of time until this baby (Descent 4) would come into this world! 
They have been waiting for the last 20 years...and this VFX copycats where just crying out loud for Descent to come back!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198066590240', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2800, 'playtime_forever': 81, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 81, 'last_played': 1531886159}
review:
[h1] Experienced on the Oculus Rift with Xbox One Controller. VR Only Review. [/h1]

I tried the Demo and absolutely loved it. Finally decided to pull the trigger on buying the game with the 20% discount and wow this is probably the most exciting space shooter out there. If you don't know what Six Degrees of Freedom means, there's no reason to Google it, because I'll just tell you. It means on top of being able to move up, down, forward, & backward; you can also pitch, yaw, and roll. Okay, now Google pitch, yaw & roll ;)

After playing this game for a while, you won't know which way is up or down or left or right (although I cheat and look down at my hand ... my strong hand). I definitely recommend playing this game on normal. Just save often but not often as in when you're you have a warning sign that your shields are low. Often as is when you did good and your shields are good. So for a total noob like me, that means save after clearing every room. If you do bad, don't save. Die. Then do good, and save. Go to the next room. Rinse and repeat. Quicksave is your friend.

Lots of powerups to pickup. Weapons & Shields. Definitely need to find the shield potions or whatever they are. They are lifesavers. Enemies get progressively harder. You get used to what enemy ships do what. Some are fast, some take lots of damage, some throw like bullet landmines that you have to get out of the way or you will get rocked. Others shoot fast. You learn to know your surroundings. Nothing like backing yourself into a corner so your enemy can easily shoot you. Don't do that. At least don't do that more than a few times like I have done. In case you haven't figured it out, I have died a lot in this game. 

It's like close-quarters combat Doom in a space ship flying through clausterphobic corridors with secret doors with treasure (usually missiles/bombs) or enemies that will kill you fast all over the place! Anyways, this game is amazing in VR. One of the best. I just feel sorry for all people playing this game Non-VR, they don't know what they're missing. Then again, I guess that's good for them. Better to not know what you're missing out on if what you're missing out on is absolutely fantastic.

Rate 8/10. If you have VR this is a must buy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052259327', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 81795, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20460, 'last_played': 1710191358}
review:
It's been a long time since I palyed the original Descent games. I had all 3 main titles as well as both Freespace games.  It was a watershed game when released and to be honest has not been topped since it changed the gaming landscape back in the 90's.
I have been unknowingly waiting for this return ever since and was absolutley chuffed to learn about the original developers paying homage to the original with a new updated tribute called Oveload.  
Although it took a while to develop from "scratch" again (I paid into the early access channel) it was well worth the wait.  There's nothing like firing up a new game and instantly feeliong like a younger version of yourself again.  I would highly recommend this to anyone.  It's pure unadulterated arcade shoot'em up fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198216236347', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 92838, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 77, 'playtime_at_review': 4963, 'last_played': 1712268609}
review:
TLDR: If you enjoy 6DOF, you will love this game!

Overload is what you get if you took the good from the classic Descent 1/2 games but made in the modern day! They also have a level editor for you to make you own maps that can be shared with the community. I mean, you don‚Äôt have to share your creations but why would you hold out?

Single Player is awesome and brought back memories of playing Descent in my pre-teens.

Challenge mode is a fun Single player experience to see how long you can last against the bots and how high of a score you can get. There‚Äôs even leaderboards to see how you match up with others!

Multiplayer is also great if you like PVP and the mind games that comes from it! You have the option on playing in the public match making, whether that is a head to head/1v1, anarchy, or team anarchy. You can also create private matches where you can allow/disallow almost anything. There‚Äôs even a LAN option if you have people over to play!

author: {'steamid': '76561198000293962', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1525, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1144, 'last_played': 1574019853}
review:
I played all 6 dof games and always loved them. Loved Descent 3 and had great fun making levels to. Been waiting 10+ years for this. I love Overload, and they just relisead a level editor to :)

The game is not finished yet, still a pre reliease though, but I will give this 10/10 anyday. Perfect feel, great levels and weapons. I love this game....

author: {'steamid': '76561197990319404', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 992, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 358, 'last_played': 1620018081}
review:
Nostalgia probably makes me biased, but I'm only a few maps in and this game has already paid for itself. I don't normally pay full price for games, especially pseudo-reboots like this. But they didn't change anything about what made the original Descent great, and that makes it just perfect. AND Linux support!?

If you've never played the original Descent, then you've probably never played anything quite like this (certainly not done this well anyway), so I still highly recommend it. Gameplay is admittedly a bit manic-depressive...you go from frantic moments, then many moments of being lost and confused, because it's pretty easy to get turned around (the map helps a lot but not perfect). It's definitely a good excercise for your spatial memory....

Update: I just played in VR for the first time - mind blowing.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972244201', 'num_games_owned': 628, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 99, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 48, 'last_played': 1560369496}
review:
I played the loved the original Descent games, and have played many of the current reboots. Overload is the best spiritual successor I've played so far, it actually feels like the next installment of that series. 

Everything about it is amazing. The controls are well-configured on my XBox 360 controller and feel very tight. The graphics are top-notch. The holo-guide is a huge quality-of-life improvement for this sort of game, where disorientation is a real danger. 

Thumbs up from me! I only wish it had a co-op campaign mode. But maybe that can be added later.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965373099', 'num_games_owned': 1482, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 550, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 213, 'last_played': 1540998736}
review: This game is simply fantastic. It's just like you remember the good old Descent, with all the trappings of modern day games. Fantastic level design and effects, and the gameplay takes me back to my childhood! A++, would recommend!

author: {'steamid': '76561197965430177', 'num_games_owned': 432, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 4213, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4058, 'last_played': 1608626593}
review:
24 years later, Descent into the new era. Overload is the spiritual defacto scuccessor to the old classic games. and O.M.G, the feels, the bots, the sound of locked doors, the weapons, the (pyro?) ship: behave and sound the same but still have an upgraded feel to it, worthy of the modern era we live in.

The way the levels are made, sometimes - symmetric, sometimes chaotic - gives me exactly that feeling as if I'm playing an old descent game. And I meaan we go way back , to descent 1 and 2. It really feels like these games have gotten a modern update with this game, even if there's no general Dravis or material defender, it's another time in the fictional universe but it's a "sister game". There ARE referrences made to PTMC tho! 

When I play this game it is although I live in a suspension of time and had a modern computer in 1996. levels look like 2018 graphic technology, with a robust engine that allowed the devs to create a classic feeling of descent gameplay that "ticks" these old nostalgic glands as you spin out of control through the depth of the new mines, and ofcourse combat a newly created virus that make the bots go out of control and attack everyone in sight.

your lasers shoot and ricochet of everything, the guided missiles poor out of your ship and it's all mayhem and so familiar, yet upgraded for current gen. The gameplay experience is excellently updated as well. It's still Descent but somehow it is although you are playing it with a golden joystick. Smoothly interpolated and you can even design your own independent axis of control! 

You're dealing with waves of bots that act in a specific ways, either in your face bots, flanking bots and also cowardice bots. And after the hard work to get rid of waves of enemies, from moment to moment I stop to enjoy the current gen lighting too, still with my mind in 1996. When deep in a base I suddenly notice that a backlit grate or ventilation system casting an eerie shadow. If you have so much love for the old games it almost feels romantic to experience this, "wow, now we have a descent with great atmospheric shadows too!

What also helps me to get in that 1996 frame is the new techno/industrial soundtrack that was newly created for this game but has an all famliliar sound to it.

Good times... again!

author: {'steamid': '76561197974559349', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 97, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 97, 'last_played': 1527999430}
