author: {'steamid': '76561197967506510', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 997, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 997, 'last_played': 1529764666}
review: An awesome experience, requirings skill beyond your common FPS.  Story is simple but the action is worth it.  Plays smooth like the old Decent 1 and 2 games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071357475', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 393, 'playtime_forever': 1086, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 452, 'last_played': 1683912524}
review:
Brillante!!!!! jamas pense que en esta generacion veria un juego de Descent. Es un juego con la estetica clasica del Juego de 1995 pero es muy admirable en lo peronal que se halla podido adaptar a los nuevos tiempos. 

La jugabilidad es espectacular. Mantiene su escencia y todo con muchisima libertad de movimiento, combates hermosos cargado de los mejores efectos especiales, Y corre como la seda. Se le hecha en falta esas explosiones realistas de los primeros juegos. 

Los graficos son tambien hermosos nunca pense que el motor unity seria capaz de hacer grandes cosas. Con efectos de reflejo en los metales y todo.

El apartado artistico es de las cosas que mas me ha gustado con ese dise√±o original y personal de los robots realmente muy bien logrado.

Posee una historia muy uinteresante que se sigue con mucho interes. Hacerca de conflictos corporativos y algo mas misterioso.

Un juego espectacular. Una nueva entrega clasica de descent actualizada para a la next-gen. Totalmente recomendable a los fans de los shoters y una cita obligada para los fans de la saga descent.

No se lo pierdan!!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198003469036', 'num_games_owned': 3408, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 847, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 697, 'last_played': 1533425982}
review:
The whole six degrees of freedom genre never really took off, did it? There was the Descents, Forsaken, uh... more recently Retrovirus, and that's all I can remember. They're basically first person corridor shooters, but instead of walking down hallways and ducts, you zip around them in a small, agile ship. So besides running and turning around you need to worry about yawing and rolling. You can circle strafe around things vertically!
 Overload is a great addition to the genre, made by many of the same people who were involved in the original Descent games. Both when engaging in lightning-quick battles with a variety of enemies and when stumbling around and learning your way around large, complex, secret-filled maps, it feels modern while still providing the same tight, exhilarating experience I remember from the originals. 
 The nostalgia othe people feel for old nintendo games, I have for the niche PC games I played in my teens and early twenties. So this is my Shovel Knight, or every Mario or Zelda game ninty put out - A faithful but evolved throwback that manages to make it seem like the 6DoF genre never went anywhere. I love it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977848675', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 936, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 493, 'last_played': 1672835148}
review:
85/100

In so many ways, this is the perfect successor to Descent and is very inteligently designed; however simple and elegant.
  But I also cannot help but mention that a bigger overall opportunity was missed. Overload could be a Doom 2016-like revival of the concept. Overload takes Descent's concept so it could do what Doom did to Doom, to Descent. 
  Overload has a perfect story basis for a "Heart of Darkness-Apocalypse now in the future" type, basic story that won't get in the way too much. Mad men turns his armies on his own people. One guy has to go deep into his land and solve the problem. This could be Overload's answer to Doom's -evil or incompetent scientists open a portal to hell while doing research on Mars, one marine overcomes and becomes a mythical figure- could be that drama. Descent had some short but effective "mysterious dark dystopian corporation" cutscenes with depressing music that rocked. That style could be an inspiration.  More environmental hazards and puzzles like Descent 3 could be used -along with more environmental detail and variation obviously- and you have got a revial like Doom did. They probably just wouldn't be able to gather that kind of budget. All the best of luck for future games from their new company. I'm excited regardless.

author: {'steamid': '76561198322118912', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 33146, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 419, 'last_played': 1602922284}
review: This is an excellent game!  I loved Descent as a kid and had been craving another game like it, and I was so happy that Overload is out.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975636407', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1458, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 611, 'last_played': 1702434837}
review: I don't do reviews much, but I have such an attachment to this game I feel the need to. I saw someone say that this does for Descent was Doom 2016 did for Doom, and a more accurate statement cannot be said. Descent was life to me back in the day, and I'm glad to say this is a more than faithful successor. If you are not familiar with Descent and 6 degrees of freedom, watch the videos and judge for yourself. It's pretty much a zero G FPS. This game is a helluva lot of fun and I can't reccomend it enough.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992176324', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2806, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 551, 'last_played': 1695647078}
review: This game is worth every penny.  It's like hooking up with your old girlfriend at a high school reunion and she looks and feels better than she did 20 years ago.  If it had split screen for local multiplayer, my marriage would be in trouble.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990193933', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2548, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1476, 'last_played': 1705380826}
review: Super fun game (singleplayer at least - haven't tried multiplayer). Highly recommended if you ever played Parallax's Descent games. Even if you never played Descent, Overload is a very fun game. Combat is fun, visceral, and varied. The environments are interesting and heavily reward exploration. Upgrade/progression system is good. Story is intriguing. Gameplay overall is very smooth. I played with a controller and the gameplay felt nice and tight. I bought this game in early access for a slight discount, but after finishing it I'd definitely say it's worth the full price. Get it and enjoy. Cheers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021310427', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 139, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 106, 'last_played': 1629134963}
review:
A fantastic spiritual successor to the Descent series.

Sadly, I missed the Kickstarter campaign, so I'll just say thanks to everyone who contributed to help make this happen. The devs did a fantastic job, and it's evident how much care and attention went into the project.

There's not much I can add to the many other reviews, so I'll just mention a couple things that stood out for me.

The single-player level design is great, with interesting architecture and geometry and many large, complex, and nonlinear levels.

I also have to mention the sound design, which is top-notch. So many cool sounds - everything from the bot sounds, to the 'spang' of bouncing off a force field. (I'll admit I would occasionally run into things just for the sound effects...)

Great all around. Highly recommended for Descent fans, or anyone craving some 6DOF fun. I hope the team has enough success with this that they can do another project. If so, I'll be first in line.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963394659', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 709, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 281, 'last_played': 1663543678}
review:
Hi! Fancy a 6 Degrees of freedom FPS shooter?

- It's beautiful looking and sounding.
- Movement is silky smooth.
- The athmosphere draws you in.
- Soundtrack is great.
- The single player experience is engaging and eventful. ( I'm 4 hours in atm. )
- And then there's also Multiplayer.

- Plus, man these people are CRAZY!, they will also throw in a free Level editor!
It's like they don't want to make any money!!

Seriously though, Overload is a great game. If you like this type of shooter even remotely, buy it.

If you've played and enjoyed Descent, and are still reading this, go buy this game now.
You shouldn't even be looking down here anymore. Really, go up and click buy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017746934', 'num_games_owned': 1646, 'num_reviews': 487, 'playtime_forever': 1956, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1123, 'last_played': 1656596839}
review:
An excellent continuation of the original Descent games, 20-some years into the future.

The graphics are quite pretty and have a pleasant aesthetic, the movement feels very, very rewarding and has a great sense of speed and momentum when you boost down a hall, then duck into a side passage or down a shaft. Mouselook is very well implemented and has no real hard turning cap.

Combat feels great as all weapons and missiles have good audio and visual feedback. You can feel the force of impact and it just feels good.

The levels are spacious and well designed, you would sometimes get a little lost but it's nothing too horrible and you have a holo bot to guide you to your next objective, if you need it.

Multiplayer works surprisingly well. The community is tight but you can always count on the matchmaking finding you an opponent, even if it's just you two queueing, which is great. The multi maps are fun and varied in size and style.

Oh, I almost forgot. LEVEL EDITOR! This is basically half the reason I bought the game.

Overall, an easy, solid recommendation for anyone who likes first person combat and the freedom of movement that this sub-genre offers!

author: {'steamid': '76561197972493498', 'num_games_owned': 1188, 'num_reviews': 109, 'playtime_forever': 152, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 152, 'last_played': 1529154231}
review:
Nel 1995 lo studio statunitense Parallax Software esordisce con Descent, uno sparatutto per DOS dal gameplay divertentissimo e rivoluzionario, che ha dato vita a diversi seguiti e spin-off fino all‚Äôinizio degli anni duemila.

Gli stessi ragazzi di Parallax quindi decidono di lanciare una campagna crowdfunding nel 2016 proponendo un seguito spirituale della loro storica saga videoludica ed aprendo un nuovo studio sotto il nome di Revival Productions. Evidentemente il ricordo della prima volta in cui uno  sparatutto restituiva la totale libert√† di movimento era ancora vivo in chi ha vissuto l‚Äôepoca dei 386 e la campagna si √® chiusa con successo. Esce quindi il 31 Maggio Overload, un copia-incolla dichiarato di Descent e i suoi seguiti, ovviamente modernizzato dal punto di vista tecnico e con il supporto alla VR.

Come nel titolo originale, in Overload avremo la possibilit√† di affrontare una campagna dalla durata pi√π che discreta attraverso una serie di livelli labirintici che ci chiederanno di distruggere dei reattori, cercare delle chiavi colorate e ripulire le aree dai nemici. Ogni tanto spunter√† fuori qualche boss, ma il cuore dell‚Äôesperienza sar√† fondamentalmente quello di uno sparatutto doomlike. Ci√≤ che rende grande il gameplay di Overload √® per l‚Äôappunto la completa libert√† di movimento data al giocatore all‚Äôinterno della sua navicella. Attraverso il pad o con l‚Äôaccoppiata mouse e tastiera (i motion controller non sono supportati) potremo quindi muovere la navicella a destra e a sinistra, in alto e in basso, avanti e indietro e ruotarla a nostro piacimento. Il layout base del pad risulta in fin dei conti abbastanza intuitivo, nonostante il primo approccio possa spaventare a causa del numero elevato di tasti da utilizzare e le varie combinazioni. Nel giro di un‚Äôoretta staremo tuttavia sfrecciando a tutta velocit√† attraverso stretti corridoi pieni di nemici mentre spariamo all‚Äôimpazzata e ruotiamo costantemente in tutte le direzioni senza problemi di comprensione. L‚Äôesperienza, dal punto di vista del puro gameplay, √® davvero solida e divertente e non mancher√† di regalare momenti ricchi di adrenalina e tensione.

Guarda la [url=https://youtu.be/zwsLgUEPhLk] VIDEO RECENSIONE [/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561198121738358', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 36554, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7469, 'last_played': 1702095128}
review:
Overload is the answer for all who enjoyed the Descent series, and for those daring to understand what 6DoF means. The game play demands that you keep your head on a swivel. With enemies popping out of hidden areas or swarming you at an objective. I have met up with a few right around a corner, which takes from zero to fight immediately. 

The game offers single player modes where you can alter the difficulty while you adjust to flying. It has a brutal multiplayer experience with new and a few hardened Pilots from Descent. Although a veteran pilot, I still get my butt handed to me. You can use joysticks or keyboard + mouse.

My favorite part is the creative side where folks can create Challenge mode, missions, and soon multiplayer levels. This is all done through a seperate editor released by the Overload team. I am so happy to see the creative side again that I am in the process of resurrecting a retro styled version of my site www.GameEdit.Net that hosts game editing tutorials.    

The team at Revival Productions are still actively working on adding more to the game. I hope they do another Kickstarter campaign for what comes next, because we need to keep that team together! They are very involved with the community, which shows their commitment to their product and the fans. Although I am not a pro, I have interacted with a few studio teams in the past when hosting tutorials for their games, it was like pulling teeth with most of them. This team seems to love the game and appreciate their audience!  

Check out the conversations on Discord or to a lesser degree on their forums, and currently every Saturday on Twitch for an interactive chill session. They also have a youtube channel that posts content weekly. 

Nightmare - AKA- Gravid on Steam

author: {'steamid': '76561197961064752', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 17, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17, 'last_played': 1529763329}
review:
True to the roots, this is a spot on revival of the amazing Descent games.
The claustrophobic feeling from navigating through narrow corridoors and ending up in a panicly situation from surprising enemies appearing from the corner you missed, is still there as it should be!

This game is a good evidence of what developers of the old but gold era of gaming are still able to do, in this age of microtransactions/DLC/season pass bullshit.

Well done, Revival Productions, well done indeed.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998901926', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2926, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 703, 'last_played': 1589675124}
review:
if you're a fan of Descent, just get it. if you're new to 6DoF then this game is also good because the controls are so smooth for mouse & keyboard. just feels good to shoot and navigate around. there are tons (and i mean TONS) of secrets in the game so you definitely get a lot of game for the price.

 the only downside is it can get a little repetetive after a while but jumping online can break the monotony.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970410314', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 6440, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 595, 'last_played': 1665951330}
review: Just wanted to write a quick review, this is without question my favorite VR title so far.  I loved the original Descent games and this is an absolutely worthy successor.  VR makes it so much better!  You feel like you're right in the middle of the action!  Setting up the right control scheme with joystick/keyboard control took a little while, but once complete I'm gliding through the mines like I was born there.  Fantastic game!  Wish it would have been part of the summer sale but definitely worth it at full price.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985431904', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 136011, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 549, 'playtime_at_review': 25000, 'last_played': 1712370903}
review:
Overload is the game that I have wanted for 17 years, ever since Windows XP came along and killed Descent 2. I've been a lifelong fan of Descent and 6dof and to put it simply, Overload is the best 6dof game I have ever played.

The good parts: pretty much everything related to the gameplay itself.

- The flight is outstanding. I play with 2 joysticks (Microsoft Sidewinder 3D Pro) and the feel of moving around in the game is perfect. This is the most crucial part of any 6dof game for me and Overload nails it. Flight is fast and responsive (especially with tri-chording mode selected). Every little detail of inertia makes you feel like you are flying a spaceship!

- The visual design is striking. It might be minimalist but everything from the robots, to the weapons, to the world you fly in has personality. The lighting is incredible and the VFX fit perfectly into the experience to increase your immersion without making it hard to see what's going on.

- Overload's sound perfectly matches the game. The weapons sound powerful, the robots are terrifying, and the music is phenomenal! I highly recommend getting the soundtrack if you like Industrial/Electronic music.

- Enemy AI does a great job of both making the robots feel like characters and providing a serious challenge. There are 6 difficulty levels and the difference from one to the next is incredible. The increased difficulty is provided by smarter, faster enemies rather than simply giving the bots more hitpoints.

-Your arsenal of 16 weapons is very satisfying. Each of them has their own role in the game and provide very different ways of handling situations.

- The level design makes good use of those extra degrees of freedom. Levels include a lot of vertical elements and get pretty complex and fun to explore.

- The story of the game is interesting, and it's fun hunting down audio recordings left behind by survivors to hear more about the events that left the levels in their current sorry state.

- Challenge Mode is a fun diversion and may end up being where I spend most of my game time. This is a survival mode where you fight off bots in compact arenas until they overwhelm you. This mode features online leaderboards.

- Overload includes a level editor. I have only scratched the surface with it but I get the sense that it is very powerful. In fact it is the tool that the developers themselves created to build the game. There is a large community of people who made custom levels for Descent (100s over the years) and many of these people are already learning Overload's editor. With them on board I wouldn't be surprised to see a steady stream of custom content to play. At the moment the best place to find Custom levels is Overload's Discord Channel.

The less good parts:

-The story could be better supported by the level design and objectives. Overload's story is interesting and well written/acted but the campaign levels (the maps themselves) don't help to tell it. Each is good from a gameplay perspective but they feel like a series of semi-random labyrinths which were built for no particular reason. If not for the pre-mission briefings and the audio logs you find in the game there would be no way to tell what kind of facility you were exploring. Similarly, having things to accomplish in the levels other than "get to the end" could have made you feel more connected to the story.

-The Multiplayer is pretty limited and features no modes other than 3 variations of deathmatch. It also has a very small collection of maps. Finding other players can be challenging unless you go to Discord and ask people if they want to join you. This is likely to be improved however, and eventually the level editor will support multiplayer maps. More maps will add a lot to the experience, and being able to create your own arenas to play in should be really fun. Also, as with most games, more players will make the biggest difference.

- There is no co-op. This is something I miss since it would be really fun to play the levels with a teammate or devise team strategies for surviving longer in Challenge Mode.

Overall, Overload is probably my favorite game I have ever played. It has a few shortcomings but the gameplay is so good, the enemies so smart, the weapons so satisfying, as to make me want to spend countless hours flying through claustrophobic tunnels hunting down or running from the robots that lurk there!

author: {'steamid': '76561197978499328', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 499, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 469, 'last_played': 1530212842}
review:
For someone who never played a Descent game before this was a really fun arcadey FPS action game.
Great soundtrack, controls, gameplay and level design.

A bit confusing to navigate around at times, but for most of the game you have access to a hologram drone that will point you in the direction of your next objective.

Good luck managing to find all the secrets.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030980822', 'num_games_owned': 253, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 7307, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4047, 'last_played': 1705163589}
review:
I'm not exaggerating when I say I believe Overload is the best old-school FPS released in a decade. Stellar large non-linear secret-laden level design, weapon variety balance, incredibly intuitive and customizable controls, intelligent enemy behavior and enemy variety come together to form a pure and action-fueled experience with no bullshit or long boring corridors between each fight.

Overload is not 'just' a Descent clone, it is also a refinement in many ways that makes it the ultimate 6DoF game. It's way more fair in how health items are placed, hitscan enemies are used tastefully, the Thief-Bot, Class 1 Driller or Red Hulk is no more in Overload, the difficulty overall is more balanced, robot generators are destroyable, and reactor rooms can no longer be cheesed. Even on the higher difficulties you can just dogfight enemies in a fun way rather than having to hide behind corners and take potshots so you don't die. The new Smash Attack, where you ram into enemies directly with your ship, even recovers a bit of health so you can get more aggressive. 

It features an upgrade system, but unlike other games where you end up with every upgrade in the game towards the end, here you need to make a permanent decision between two upgrade branches for each weapon, each of which augments the weapon in a different way, but you can't have both. Kind of like augs in the original Deus Ex. This way you actually have to weigh your options and decide which one suits you the best, giving you more replay value for future playthroughs if you want to try something different, as opposed to providing you with an illusion of choice where you'll get everything eventually, and the only choice there is is what upgrade you want first. Upgrade points are mostly found through secrets, so you really want to explore as much as you can.

There is an actual story this time around, mostly told by intro briefings and finding audio logs scattered around the levels, but the logs themselves are very short so they don't get too intrusive, and the story never forces you through unskippable cutscenes or forced walking(/flying?) sections where you can't do anything. You can pretty much disable it all in the options menu.

It features a functional multiplayer mode which usually has about 10 or 20 people playing it as of writing, but don't really expect it to get really populated outside of finding matches on the Discord. Do expect that you will get your ass kicked by Descent veterans who have been playing its multiplayer for over 20 years. 

The passage of time has allowed Overload to improve its visuals over Descent in many ways. Bots explode in chunky debris and hellfire. Kill an enemy by ramming into him and his corpse is sent flying across the map. Dynamic lighting makes the dark cavern areas much more tense to fight in. Robot eyes flicker when they take damage, and they light up to indicate more strongly they're being damaged. The particle effects enemies like the Shredder give off makes them even more menacing. The only unfortunate part is that the texturing and the colors used for the levels themselves makes them stand out much less from eachother.

Even though this game runs on the Unity Engine, it is remarkably well optimized, and save for certain shaders I experienced next to no framedrops on a medium system.

If you call yourself an FPS fan and are also anticipating the full release of other old-school FPS throwbacks such as DUSK, Ion Maiden and Amid Evil, do yourself a favor and get Overload. If you completed the game once, you can try it again on New Game+ with revamped enemies where late-game enemies appear much earlier on to shake things up.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
+Classic non-linear exploration-heavy level design in the vein of games like Descent and Doom
+Controls are incredibly smooth and customizable, supports several flightstick setups
+Enemy AI is actually responsive, and some enemies have uniquely different behaviors (they can even respond to your headlights)
+The lighting, enemy designs and explosion effects look really good
+Tons of unique and properly balanced weapons to mess around
+No Thief-Bot
+Destroyable robot generators
+Non-intrusive story
+More fair this time around, but can be still very challenging on higher difficulties
+Upgrade system actually adds to the game and is also decently balanced
+New Game+ adds another playthrough worth of replay value
+Challenge Mode and Multiplayer for the competitively-oriented players
+released Level Editor means many more custom missions are to come
+Excellent soundtrack by former Descent musicians

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
-The game's too lenient with Driller ammo
-The boss fights are lame and can be powered through rather easily
-Ship upgrades could also feature branching upgrades
-Some newer 'stronger' enemy variants towards the end are paradoxically easier to fight
-Starting with loadouts for multiplayer is decline
-Having permanent Challenge Mode upgrades be locked away until you play the game itself long enough is cheap

[b]Total: 9/10[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561197991941945', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 41721, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 262, 'playtime_at_review': 7756, 'last_played': 1711855960}
review:
Overload features one of the best Singleplayer Campaigns of 2018  (complete with New Game Plus), a Challenge Mode with infinite replay value, a robust Level Editor, and a promising Multiplayer mode. This is without a doubt one of the greatest FPS reboots in gaming. Mix the intensity of a flight sim with the intensity of DOOM and you have Overload. 

Give this game a chance. You will not regret it.

Imagine if one of your favorite game franchises went into cryosleep for almost twenty years. Then one day the original creators return on Kickstarter with the spiritual successor you always wanted. Many of the original programmers, artists, map designers, and composers are back. The campaign barely reaches its goal in the final hours. 

After two years of frequent updates and playable builds the sequel you never thought would happen arrives...and it just delivers. This is that game for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968331541', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 127, 'playtime_forever': 5744, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2452, 'last_played': 1692591574}
review:
I finished the game TWICE and I loved it !!!

I enjoyed:

- The weapons !! My favourites -> Cyclone, Crusher, Thunderbolt, Nova, Hunters, Devastator and of course the beautiful <3 TIME BOMB  <3
- The level design: If you could add some even bigger maps like those on Descent 3 that would be perfection, but besides that.... nice ideas, specially the end levels.
- The AI... woow.... robots run away and sometimes to ambush you gathering others, avoided creepers, surprised me many times...amazing... I'm going for the NewGame+ to see what else I could find
- Bosses !! Probably I could ask even more but I enjoyed the ones that are here....
- The secrets sub game : This is related also to the level design.... I enjoyed it a lot. And I liked to see that is balanced, some are easier and some require to think other clues.
- upgrades: You nailed it!! One of the best features in the game, I absolutely loved it, please if you can add one more level for an expansion I'll buy it !!
- The robots: I loved the variety, the Ai, the weapons and auto op situations.
- VIRTUAL REALITY ---> You can do a perfect circular strafe while side looking. And I swear I was moving my head as a reaction avoiding shots, or looking quickly to the sides up and down when I'm about to enter a suspicious hall.  Incredible.. .. guys... is a gamer's dream.

My only complain is... I WANT MORE.

Thank you!!

What a shame that I cannot enjoy Multiplayer action, I have too much lag to play correctly against those servers (can you improve this to South America Players?)

I will play the Challenge Levels and the NewGame+ 

9/10

Level 2: https://youtu.be/Umg2Oa48D2Q
Tauros Boss battle: https://youtu.be/-9U2Elv_vn0


UPDATE: DLC is amazing too. Great level selection because they change the previous level design that was already great but this time the levels are very different ideas, first ones are shorter but have some nasty surprises, the others are some medium and very very large ones and you cannot use your holo guidebot on some so be prepared for a new level of challenge. 

Another hit, seriosuly good with new enemies that have some devilish AI.
8.5/10

This game is brilliant and must not be missed for VR joy.

Here is some gameplay video from the DLC:
https://youtu.be/ZixH9f8r5M4

author: {'steamid': '76561198051405462', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 562, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 536, 'last_played': 1623442223}
review:
Overload ist das Spiel, auf das Descent-Fans fast 20 Jahre lang gewartet haben...
...und als solches macht es seine Sache gut. Bereits in den ersten Spielminuten fallen zwei Aspekte als herausragend auf:
- Gameplay
- Sound
Overload spielt sich genauso fl√ºssig und dynamisch wie sein spiritueller Vorg√§nger. Es f√ºhlt sich einfach [i]richtig[/i] an und macht wahnsinnig viel Spa√ü. Unterst√ºtzt wird dieses Gef√ºhl von einem bombastischen Soundtrack und den wuchtigen Waffensounds, die ein gro√ües Plus zur Atmosph√§re sind. F√ºr jeden Descent-Fan ist das Spiel uneingeschr√§nkt zu empfehlen.

Trotzdem gibt es eine Schattenseite in Form eines lieblosen Designs. Das Spiel ist in etwa so fantasievoll gestaltet wie sein Logo: Es ist funktional, bietet aber auch nicht viel, woran das Auge h√§ngen bleiben kann. W√§hrend Descent 2 noch mit beeindruckenden Kavernen, Wasserf√§llen und Eisplaneten aufgewartet hat, sieht in Overload einfach ein Minenschacht aus wie der n√§chste. Das ist nicht nur √∂de, sondern erschwert auch die Orientierung ungemein. Bei den Anflugsequenzen, mit welchen neue Levels eingeleitet werden w√ºrde ich sogar soweit gehen zu sagen, dass es schlichtweg peinlich ist, was die Entwickler da abgeliefert haben. Ein kastenf√∂rmiges Schiff auf eine unf√∂rmige Weltraumkartoffel zufliegen zu lassen h√§tte man sich auch sparen k√∂nnen.

Trotzdem: Auch wenn es Abz√ºge in der B-Note gibt ist Overload ein ungemein spa√üiges Game und ich hoffe, dass die Einnahmen ausreichen, um bei einer eventuellen Fortsetzung mehr Augenmerk auf das Design zu legen.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985548864', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 880, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 580, 'last_played': 1652752650}
review:
Not just some soulless Descent nostalgia cashgrab, Overload is a very worthy sequel to the series. 
There are so many thoughtful design improvements over the original games that fans of Descent will welcome, such as the ability to destroy enemy spawners, and much thought given to the balance of the new weapon set. You'll quickly find ideal situations for weapons, and the upgrades will satisfy all your immediate thoughts of "This weapon would be so much more useful if..."

Newcomers who haven't played Descent may find the controls awkward at first, due to the uncommon nature of moving in all 3 dimensions and the fact that you are steering a ship rather than aiming a gun, but the game feels just as at home with a mouse as it does with a joystick, due to increased max turn speeds compared to Descent (yet the ability to limit it to feel more like it). So, the barrier for adjustment is not high.

Levels feel most like Descent 2, with more open rooms and not just cramped tunnels. Cool VR support is a nice bonus to the game, looking around the cockpit looks like a blast, though I do not have a VR headset myself to know...

The only real complaints I have are that the enemy AI feels much more simplistic compared to Descent, enemies tend to only move towards you and shoot, only sometimes dodging or retreating. However, the game is challenging enough regardless due to the level design and enemy placement that maybe it's a good thing that enemies aren't smarter. Additionally the explosion effects are a bit overdone for my tastes, a single enemy exploding will shower the room with sparks and smoke and completely obscure anything behind it (from more enemies to incoming rockets) for several seconds.

Whether you're a Descent fan or a new player looking for something fresh in the world of shooters, this is a quality video game in the year 2018 that you will smile at.

EDIT: Further into the game I am finding even my complaint about AI is unwarranted; later robots are much more keen on dodging attacks and retreating to find ambush positions. Clearly this was intended to help differentiate enemies by giving them different behaviors, and ramp up difficulty.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990816800', 'num_games_owned': 785, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 3401, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1345, 'last_played': 1582423161}
review:
It's no secret that first-person shooters have changed dramatically over the last two decades.¬† Whereas they once tossed players into labyrinthine levels and expected them to find the exit all by themselves, today they usually take a much more linear, cinematic approach in which exploration is discouraged and the story is force-fed.¬† Even the recent DOOM reboot, as fantastic as it was, had some awfully straight-forward levels (especially compared to the '93 original) and several unskippable cutscenes.

Well ladies and gentlemen, I'm happy to report that Overload never got the memo.

Made by the creators of Descent, Overload is everything a fan could possibly hope for from a spiritual successor.¬† It sports prettier graphics and a larger feature set while retaining everything that made the original game so special.¬† The levels are still as large and complex as ever, weapons and enemies still come in great varieties, and yes, you still have to destroy reactors and run like hell before the whole place explodes.

If you've never before played Descent or any other six-degree-of-freedom (6DoF) shooter, you're in for a trip.¬† The 6DoF movement system means you can fly in literally every direction and even roll your ship.¬† Although this can be quite disorienting and even nauseating (especially at first), it also gives you an unprecedented amount of control compared to traditional "grounded" first-person shooters.¬† It makes combat more exciting, too, since threats can come from any angle and you aren't just limited to strafing left and right in order to avoid incoming fire.

Overload's campaign is broken up into 15 levels, three of which feature boss battles.¬† Although that might not sound like a large number, the sheer size of these levels means you'll be spending up to half an hour or more on each one.¬† The levels are so complex, in fact, the developers not only included a full-fledged 3D automap but even implemented a "hologuide" that can be deployed at any time to lead you to the nearest powerup, security key, or even enemy.¬† Best of all, the levels all play out without any interruptions.¬† There aren't any cutscenes whatsoever--only collectible audio logs--and even the pre-mission briefings can be skipped in an instant.

Perhaps the biggest change coming from Descent is the addition of an upgrade system which allows you to improve and modify both your ship and weapons over the course of the campaign.¬† Some examples are the ability to make Missile Pods seek nearby enemies and a big boost to "smash" damage so that you can turn your ship into a powerful battering ram if the need ever arises.¬† It's worth noting, however, that upgrade points can only be acquired by finding and collecting them, therefore it's strongly encouraged that you explore to your heart's content if you wish to be at your very best going into each new level.

In addition to the campaign, there's also a challenge mode (Overload's take on horde mode) as well as local/online multiplayer.¬† As someone who's never been a huge fan of multiplayer in these types of games, challenge mode is my personal favorite.¬† The goal is simple: survive for as long as possible against killer robots that constantly spawn in all around you.¬† There are 12 arena-like stages to choose from and the more you play, the more XP you earn and the more persistent perks you unlock.¬† It's admittedly simple, but incredibly fun, highly replayable, and a great way to hone your combat skills.

Perhaps my favorite aspect of Overload aside from its oldschool nature (minimal cutscenes, maximum gameplay) is its vast array of weapons and enemies.¬† There are 16 different weapons--yes, you can have them all at once--and my favorites include the Crusher, a punishing shotgun that can be upgraded to become fully automatic, and the Devastator, a large missile that explodes into a bomb cluster to deal insane damage.¬† The enemy variety is even more impressive with over 20 different types of robots.¬† You'll encounter everything from Guardians, which pester you at long range with precision shots, to sawblade-armed Shredders that launch themselves at you arms-first with very bad intentions.

I also must bring attention to the game's excellent soundtrack.¬† The audio as a whole is great, from the weapons and explosions to the eerie, mechanical groans emitted by enemies themselves, but the soundtrack is what shines the brightest.¬† Composed by Dan Wentz,¬†Allister Brimble, and¬†Jerry Berlongieri--all of whom worked on the Descent games--Overload's soundtrack is a perfect revival of the same techno-like musical style that helped make those games so much fun to play and listen to.

Overload is one of those rare titles that, in the process of reviving a long-dead franchise, somehow manages to hit all the right notes.¬† Even the graphics are surprisingly good, with excellent lighting effects and awesome, over-the-top explosions.¬† The only complaint I can muster up is that I would've liked to have seen a greater variety of levels and locales, but I'm sure even that will be smoothed out in time thanks to the recently released level editor.¬† Suffice it to say, if you've been longing for a new Descent or just a new oldschool first-person shooter in general, Overload is like a wish come true and you'd be doing yourself a great disservice to pass it up.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969877452', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 3222, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2832, 'last_played': 1667000680}
review:
It's kind of funny how the best Descent doesn't even have the name. Sure it's new and looks great but I enjoyed this campaign as much or more than the original games, Overload is worth a purchase for that alone. 

 I always dreamed of something like Overload's challenge mode in my movement based 90's shooters like descent and doom/quake. Something competitive but in an arcade leaderboard sort of way. It's great, makes this game infinitely replayable for me. I even love the maps.  Overload is one of my favorite 90's shooters, it just looks a lot better.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970300140', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 6, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6, 'last_played': 1529443161}
review:
- Switch controls to an xbox controller. 
- Realize that it doesn't work. 
- Be surprised to have 3809402 settings to be configured manually on THE standard controller in 2018. 
- Quit the game. 
- Thank the developers for the greatest EXCITEMENT DESCENT in modern game history.
- Repeat.
developer_response:
Sorry for the problems with the controller Gekko.  If the controller isn't immediately recognized, you may have to restart the game.  Overload normally works great with an Xbox One controller.  In case you had a different controller plugged in first, you may have to do the following steps:

1) Go to Options -> Control Options -> Joystick/Gamepad Options.  Make sure the Primary Controller lists "XInput Gamepad 1" (may be different depending on your OS).

2) Go to Remap Controller from the same screen.  Normally the gamepad is mapped by default, but if not, just push the button Gamepad Default in the lower right side.

That should be it.  The default control settings work well with a gamepad.  If that doesn't work, please email feedback@revivalprod.com and we'll be happy to help figure out any issues.  I'd recommend playing the Training Simulator first (Play Mission -> Training Simulator from the main menu).

author: {'steamid': '76561197973072341', 'num_games_owned': 589, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 24, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 24, 'last_played': 1529439485}
review:
I bought this game specifically to play it in VR. I'm not an old fan of Descent although I remember playing "forsaken" back in the day, being amazed at how smooth it ran.

That's unfortunately the issue here. I tried all kinds of settings both in the game and in SteamVR, and somehow I'm getting so many missed frames the game runs effectively at 45fps instead of 90. I think with a GTX 1080, no supersampling and all quality settings set to low it should be possible to run a game like this at 90fps with hardly any missed frames at all.

On the discussion boards others reported similar problems. So I definitely can't recommend this to other VR users.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034083409', 'num_games_owned': 749, 'num_reviews': 98, 'playtime_forever': 409, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 305, 'last_played': 1630226092}
review: 20 years ago I was playing Descent 1 & 2 basically non-stop... This game is a true successor - it is done so well, runs so smooth and omg the music is epic! So that the only thing I'm missing is my old joystick... well mouse controls seem to be done perfectly, so I'll just go with mouse for now :D Kudos to the devs!

author: {'steamid': '76561198001284502', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1077, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1050, 'last_played': 1538521492}
review:
I've never been happier to pay full price for a game. It's the old Descent for modern systems, and somehow manages to look and feel more refined, while still maintaining that original 90s aesthetic. And OH MAN the soundtrack. I feel like 90% of "killer soundtrack!" games are only just "not terrible". But this... this is the only kind of music you should be listening to while slipping sideways around corners and blasting insane mining robots into zero-gravity shrapnel.

Only one tiny tiny disappointment: It's not like you to ever get to see it that much, but i miss the mean, "weapons-forward" x-wing type design of the earlier Descent ships. This one has a kind of... Star Trek shuttlecraft feel to it, which is incongrous to the deliciously powerful feel you get from the numerous weapons systems.

One tip for newcomers: don't get discouraged with the controls. I used to rock a keyboard-only setup on the original and CRUSH deathmatch. But apparently flying a 6DoF ship is NOT like riding a bike, and adding a multi-button gaming mouse to the mix... welp, you're going to hit a lot of walls and lava, and practically everything else at first, until you tweak your setup. A LOT. But that first time you zip around a corner, pitch left and strafe right, level out and destroy an operator with a Falcon, all that failure makes it totally worth it... and the headshot mechanic that is the holy grail of other shooters loses a whollllllle lot of sparkle.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961964059', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 4577, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 932, 'last_played': 1651031771}
review:
Great game, achieves exactly what it set out to do: create a modern version of Descent with a new game engine to bring it into the modern era of gaming, but retains what made it special while at the same time, making it better. The graphics are great, very sharp with good lighting, great exposions and partical effects. The weapons all feel unique and have a very good "kinetic" feel, similar to how the guns felt in the original F.E.A.R. The music is similarly as good and you can tell has flavors from the original Descent games.

The are plenty of difficulty levels, and quite a bit of content with the Challenge Mode and multiplayer. If you're a fan of Descent, it's easily worth the $30, probably worth $40-50 for fans of Descent, so $30 is very fair for what it is and the quality of the game.

When they release the level editor/tools, it'll be great to see what people do with it. Recreations of Descent 1 and 2 and their mission/expansion packs would be awesome. As is though, there's more than enough content to enjoy for the price.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970424978', 'num_games_owned': 969, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 769, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 769, 'last_played': 1529249719}
review:
Over twenty years later and the original creators of Descent manage to create a game that's as much of a breath of fresh air as Descent was back then.

Well optimized, top tier graphics with intense gameplay that requires your full concentration and your memory working together, coupled with a story that had me absolutely hooked. A huge variety of enemies and over a dozen weapons along with upgrades for said weapons and also your ship combined with secrets galore and some effort on the part of the devs in creating a New-Game+ mode means this title will not bore you (or me) any time soon.

Can't comment on the multiplayer as I haven't jumped into a game yet but the star of the show should be the single player campaign, well voiced and delivered in bite sized morsels that kept me hanging on what was going to happen next.

9/10 - I'm excited for more content or a sequel or spin off or whatever comes next from this studio.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970818678', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 2159, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2100, 'last_played': 1622868410}
review: Yup, it's Descent.  The only thing it's missing is a Thief Bot.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972581651', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2308, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 628, 'last_played': 1582690125}
review: True Descent successor. Feels like Descent, plays like Descent, and is a total blast to play. Aside from obviously improved graphics and all new levels and story-line, Overload also improves on Descent with upgrades and a holo-guide to aide you when you get totally disoriented.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972019990', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1156, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 887, 'last_played': 1541828166}
review: This game has great feel and excellent polish.  A few nitpicks, but most of those are personal preference and not really worth mentioning.  If you liked the Descent games then you will LOVE this game!

author: {'steamid': '76561197992616341', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 2846, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1691, 'last_played': 1584506055}
review:
Excellent heir to the Descent franchise.  Shooter mechanics are as good or better then the old games.  Level design is great, with many secrets and rewards for exploration.  Weapon variety, balance and mechanics easily surpass the old games.  Single player campaign only has 20 ish levels but they are large and easily an hour of play each.

Artwork is mediocre (many enemies look alike) but explosions are inpressive and gameplay feel is very satisfying.  Story is just interesting enough to keep your attention but the real star is the gameplay.

Controls are excellent, though it could use a few more hotkey bindings (Weapons are bound in pairs; I don't like havning to cycle them and want to direct key some of them).  Mouse and Joystick gameplay is both excellent - sadly, mouse is objectively superior with faster turn rates, which will affect you if you want to do multiplayer.  Joystick is way more fun though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045890996', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 670, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 154, 'last_played': 1537736181}
review: Bliss.  Descent was my favorite game during its time, and this recaptures it closer than anything thus far, including the all important ability to map the controls nearly identically to what my fingers remember from all those years ago.  Definitely recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960633257', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 987, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 987, 'last_played': 1529115301}
review: Just finished this game. Really enjoyed it, better than other recent 6DOF games. I really enjoyed Decent 1 & 2 back in the day and this did all the same things well. I still prefer the art of Decent 2, especiallly some of the enemies and weapons but this is a great game, feltt great with the joy stick. Music was great.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967807967', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 2777, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 467, 'last_played': 1596839074}
review:
This is the Descent successor Steam needed. If you are not familiar with the Descent series, at first this may look like your everyday space shooter. What it actually is is a fast paced FPS with 6 degree of freedom movement, meaning you are able to not only move forward and backward and side to side, but also up and down and all around. This makes for some amazing gameplay experiences. 

Just like it's predecessors, great care has come in the level design. Being able to spin all around can become disorienting; luckily the 3d map makes navigation much easier. In single player, as you increase difficulty levels, learning the maps and remembering enemy positions is key to surviving and doing well.

Multiplayer is excellent as well, however I feel like this game hasn't received the attention it deserves and as such, it may be difficult to find a full game of anarchy or team anarchy at times. Small games can be fun, but you may find yourself playing against the same players over and over again. That being said, buy this game and start playing it! Heck, buy two copies and give one to a friend so we get as many people as possible playing this masterpiece of a throwback to the 90's PC gaming glory days.

10/10... possibly GOTY

author: {'steamid': '76561198021304253', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 705, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 153, 'last_played': 1710087401}

author: {'steamid': '76561197970629472', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 570, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 570, 'last_played': 1529032517}
review:
No game that has tried to be a spiritual successor to Descent has ever gotten the "feeling" of Descent right.  The nuances of the movement - the right amount of acceleration, the right amount of drift - no one seemed to be able to crack it. Nor could they ever really get the level design, enemy design, or overall balance...until Overload.  Unsurprisingly, the original guys who made Descent were able to make a game that feels like Descent!

It's a fun throwback and I enjoyed my time with it.  However, I will say that it's faithful to Descent to the extent that it might as well just be a graphical overhaul of Descent II.  Key hunts, powerups, largely abstract level design, and enemies that feel perhaps a little too familiar.

I think the developer delivered exactly what they promised: a new Descent; but in retrospect, I'm not sure that's all I really wanted.  In truth, I'm not sure this is a style of game where there even is any room for meaningful gameplay evolution, but I would have liked to see them try.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973577439', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 627, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 594, 'last_played': 1532401083}
review: Fantastic revival of Descent/Descent II, really capturing the flow and feel of the original DOS games with a modern engine. It's an unassuming action game that focuses on the flow and doesn't get bogged down in the extras. Upgrade system and NG+ are nice without undermining the core game. Tons of secrets to uncover in the same vein as the classics. Levels feel sufficiently mine-like without trying to explore other environments that don't fit the theme (the way Descent 3 did). I'm just straight up happy with this game!

author: {'steamid': '76561197998892343', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1577, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 158, 'last_played': 1618197602}
review:
Last night, my wife came into my gaming den/our bedroom, and about died of laughter at my kludged two-stick setup. She found me zooming around blasting infected robots to bits in the challenge mode, yelling "Gotcha!" and "Take this, sucker!" so I joined in the laughter until i realized she was taking pictures. While my wife's family will likely never look past this new dweebishness, I have found inner awesomeness. This is Nerdvana.

11/10: Would alienate myself from in-laws again

For those wondering: my two-stick setup was with a 12-year-old Saitek ST290 for my left hand (with broken trigger and 5 button), and a new-ish Thrustmaster T16000m (that my wife was a whole lot less excited about when she saw what was inside). The game accepted input from both devices without a single complaint. The movement was engaging and thrilling, and the game simple enough that it didn't require every button within reach. It's beautifully simple, and it's endlessly fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007739760', 'num_games_owned': 524, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 597, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 411, 'last_played': 1530747042}
review:
I was afraid when I got my hopes up for this one, because my childhood game was Decent. Let me tell you though, the fear was completely unfounded. These devs still have the magic touch and I'm loving every minute of it. The bots are punishing, but beatable. Secrets are everywhere. Controls are fantastic. Story is light but rich.

There's really no reason not to get this one. They did their old titles justice!

author: {'steamid': '76561198152407009', 'num_games_owned': 67, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 34, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 34, 'last_played': 1528831582}
review: I couldn't even make it thru the first door of the training level.  This game is insanely hard, especially played with a joystick.  I hate puzzle games where the whole game is "LOL THERE'S A LOCKED DOOR YOU HAVE TO GO SEARCH THE WHOLE MAP TO FIND THE KEY LOL."  I'd get a refund but Steam never gives refunds.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978829443', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 845, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 816, 'last_played': 1694135776}
review:
Overload gets better every play.

See that "Overwhelmingly Positive"? Those are first impressions.

It starts strong and gets deeper.

Once you learn how to enable trichording in settings, you'll be zipping and flipping through room spaces at absurd angles in order to survive two seconds and loving it. When you have enough experience to take advantage of the continually interesting and varied robot AI, single player is a charm.

If you dare, multiplayer has an incredibly high skill ceiling as well. It's brutally fast paced and requires that essentially everything be muscle memory in maneuvering and firing.

To those wondering about controls, mouse + KB is best, and although dual joysticks is a possibility a throttle isn't.

I can't recommend Overload enough if you have any interest in what's essentially the only true 6DOF FPS.

author: {'steamid': '76561198305125338', 'num_games_owned': 76, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 17744, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5110, 'last_played': 1707365781}
review: There's not a lot I can add that other reviews didn't already cover, but I'll say this: Overload brought back the chilling fear of corners and doors from Descent, and for that I'll love it forever.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041661955', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1158, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 685, 'last_played': 1529730440}
review: Not sure what I can add to what other reviewers have already said. This is a great game and really nails the feel of the old Descent games! As a kid Descent scared the crap out of me, slinking through corridors and peeping around corners, terrified that a red Super Hulk might be lurking. I'm older now and the robots look different, but this game gives me the same addictive dread I had back then :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197988563057', 'num_games_owned': 903, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 243, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 189, 'last_played': 1557001855}

author: {'steamid': '76561198087503955', 'num_games_owned': 188, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 4847, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4749, 'last_played': 1529158524}
review:
Ay time for a review then.

Lets start with the [b]Multiplayer first[/b].
Finding a match usually goes quite fast, max time i had to wait so far where about 5 minutes, ofc. it really depends on the time, especially during the hours where EU peeps head to bed and US peeps get home from work the multiplayer can be quite dry untill they all ate their dinner and are rdy to match up (wich is, the way live works, so not really a negative point)

The multiplayer matches themself are quite fun, i love the 1v1's since it reminds me alot of quake, ofc. the item spawns are random, but the player who keeps map control and item control (as random as they may be, this ones actually important) has the upper hand, aswell as knowing where ur enemy can come from, so skilled prefiring works just fine to get the headstart in a dodgefight.

The Anarchy matches (in other words, free for all) deliver alot of action, aswell as planning ahead, either u are that type of guy that goes straight into the action or the one that sneaks up behind of all that mess to try and snack a few kills.
And this game does contain "assists", so there is no real "kill stealing" since those "assists" give u points aswell (ofc. not as much as a solid kill) - this especially kept my frustration low haha :D
Same for the Team Anacrhy (TDM) , it can be really fun to play this in a 3v3 or 4v4, sticking to your teammates or spreading out to flanck the enemys.
Sadly i couldn't find any TDM without asking/gathering people in beforehand.

Next thing are the servers, there arent many available and me as EU player, i often see myself "forced" into USA servers, the netcode isn't too bad, but u feel the lag at around 150ms and people with 30ms ping have a clear advantage on you.
Gladly u can setup private matches, with your own set of rules and invite people to it, wich is also tons of fun.
The game does contain a matchmaking and ranking system, but as you can guess, matchmaking only works well when there are enough people playing at the same time - so it can happen, especially at those "empty" times ([i]see above[/i]) that a plat player gets qued up with a bronze or silver.

Time to check out the [b]Campaign[/b].
The story itself consists of Radiologs and Text, since theres quite alot of stuff going on it can take 2 playthroughs to really understand the story, since listening to those radiologs WHILE fighting a hord of bots isn't really the easiest thing to do.
But they deliver every reason to do the campaign twice because after your first runthrough u unlock the "NewGame+" where u keep all your upgrades and weapons from your first run through in addition to more and harder enemys, delivering you a real challenge.
The campaign itself is actually quite easy for most experienced 6dof players, it really comes down when u play it on harder difficulties - wich sure is challenging, but can sometimes just be straight out frustrating.
Keeping the difficulty high tho makes up for the repetitive objective *blowing up reactors, all day long*
Every 5 Levels u get to fight a boss, wich... sadly i found underwhelming so thats a minus from me.
The maps themself contain the well known secrets, switches, locked doors, secret levels etc. wich reward u with upgrade points wich u can invest into your ship after each level.
Now it really depends on what kind of player you are, but if u enjoy hunting secrets etc. for a 100% playthrough then this can keep u on your toes for a while.

Time for the [b]Challenge mode[/b].
This is by FAR my favorite time killer in the game, it is so much fun!
U got several maps to choose from, several difficulties and u can choose between countdown and infinity.
So why do i find it the most fun? Becouse i love to top the scores of the other pilots, especially when u can show off in their Discord :D
Infinity literally means that u try to survive a hord of bots as long as u can, the difficultie increases the longer u last.
The most fun part is countdown tho, u get 5 minutes to destroy as many bots as u can, as fast as you can and since it is only 5 minutes u start to tell yourself "just one more run, just one more run".

Due to the amount of configurations the [b]Options[/b] become their own part in my review!
At first it is overwhelming and superb confusing, escpeially for people who have no idea what mouse limiting does, or what tri-chord,allwas and hybrid means.
If u have problems with setting up your controls then i STRONGLY ADVICE that u head into their discord and ask the people!
It really helps out, i had my configuration set up after a few minutes and it feels spot on for m/kb.
It gives so many things u can change/tweak/play around with that u can literally set it up for dual joysticks, hotas, gamepads, probably even a steeringwheel with pedals - it's truely amazing!
You just need to take that time to set it up tho - but its worth the effort.

So all in all, the Campaign could have been a bit more - especially the bosses, but i did enjoy the extra challenge with my second and third playthrough on higher difficulties.
Aswell as gathering the achievments and finding the secrets.
So this part gets a 4/5 from me

The Multiplayer gets a 3/5 from me - it could have been more love, like a serverlist for example.
On the other hand, if the playercount rises just a bit more then i give it a 4/5 - becouse then it is garanteed to get big TDM matches up'n'going without having to gather people in discord.

Just the fact that i spend 80% of the playtime in Challenge-mode makes me give it a 5/5, it is still not boring and beating the top scores is so satisfying.

The options get a 3/5 from me, because i had my difficulties with them at first, not knowing what they exactly do - wich forced me to ask in their discord for help and advice.

All in all a 4/5 game for me :)

Ay, i hope i didn't forget anything.

Cheers TX

author: {'steamid': '76561198064168291', 'num_games_owned': 163, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 449, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 105, 'last_played': 1617797254}

author: {'steamid': '76561198111668214', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 562, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 207, 'last_played': 1646079258}

author: {'steamid': '76561197961771823', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1183, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 374, 'last_played': 1693775412}
review: I played the old games witth a Joystick. Now many years later with a Mouse and Keyboard. Its alot of fun and worth the Money. There are alot of small things that I think really show that the developers thought about. First, you can auto-Upgrade, for me with out a lot of time to dig deep is was great to be equiped properly without having to study the upgrade stuff. I could dive into the action instantly. Another good thing is the GuideBot. I remember the old game also had a guidebot but here its almost ready any time. if you got lost or stuck you just press "Z" and the bot apears and leads you to the next key or entrance. Sometime its just the small things that make good games. One last notice: for me haven't playing alot in the last years. I find it a bit to frightening, you pick up something and around the corner there are some enemies and they are very close, so that you can get the frills very quite. but its also whats makes it fun. I fully recommend playing with mouse and keyboard and hope that there will be more multiplayer in the future.Thanks for this Game!

author: {'steamid': '76561197972680393', 'num_games_owned': 233, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 339, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 291, 'last_played': 1706243743}
review:
It's descent.

It's not an unfinished multiplayer being played by only the devs pretending to be it. It's not some false promise. It's not a remake 1 for 1. It is merely Descent as it was then and is awesome now. As someone that put money into another project, I'm frankly ashamed to miss the opprotunity to have my name in this wonderful true new Descent. To the devs of this game, fantastic job. You made my childhood with the originals, and to see it done so well once more makes me so happy. I'm ashamed to have not supported you when I had the chance.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993037355', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2360, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 855, 'last_played': 1671742511}

author: {'steamid': '76561197970376748', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 61, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31, 'last_played': 1529771460}
review:
*Diese Review basiert auf einem ersten Eindruck* (~30min Spielzeit)

Ich spiele es in VR (Windows Mixed Reality via SteamVR) und es f√ºhlt sich gro√üartig an.
Das wirft direkt in die Jahre zur√ºck, als man Descent1-3 mit vollem Elan gespielt hat und sich immer vorgestellt hat wie geil es doch w√§re, wenn man wirklich im Cockpit sitzen w√ºrde.

Im Moment verwende ich zur Steuerung ein Gamepad. Das funktioniert ansich ganz ordentlich, nur komme ich damit √ºberhaupt nicht klar. Ich werde wohl also bald meinen alten Joystick wieder auspacken.

Die Grafik ist nett gemacht, wenn auch keine absolute High-End Grafik. Die Effekte der Waffen und Explosionen sehen super aus und auch die dynamische Beleuchtung sieht gut aus (wenn man sie einschaltet.. sie Ist standartm√§√üig stark reduziert).
Die Spielphysik ist realistisch und auch das Trefferfeedback wird gut dargestellt.

Thema VR:
Hier muss wohl jeder seine eigenen Erfahrungen machen. Solange ich ruhig geflogen bin war es ein tolles Erlebnis. Als ich jedoch dann angefangen habe etwas k√ºnstlerische Flugman√∂ver zu fliegen wurde mir ganz leicht flau. Ich denke mal mehr als eine Stunde am St√ºck w√ºrde ich im Moment noch nicht durchhalten. Aber das m√ºsst ihr einfach selbst probieren.

Thema Technik:
Ich wei√ü nicht, ob es nur daran liegt, dass WMR offiziell nicht unterst√ºtzt wird oder ob andere VR-Systeme noch √§hnliche Probleme haben. Im Moment ben√∂tige ich immer 2-3 Versuche, bis das Spiel in SteamVR erkannt wird und in der VR-Brille angezeigt wird. Es ist jetzt nichts was total st√∂rt, aber andere VR-Spiele sind hierbei zuverl√§ssiger.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967115265', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 31014, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5514, 'last_played': 1685742817}
review:
I didn't know this game existed until the day I purchased it.  I was pleasantly surprised to find it in the store, since I really enjoyed Descent 1, 2 and 3.  

It's great fun and you almost get that Descent vibe while playing, but not 100%.  
I will say I'm a bit disappoined with the lack of more open spaces.  The levels almost seem the same but just layed out a bit different.  This gives the game sort of a vibe that you're on one HUGE level and never really see anything new and never seems to end.  Not that I want it to end, but would like to feel more like I am progressing than playing the same level over and over.

Still, this game is worth it if you loved any of the Descent games.  Plays awesome so far.  Ace difficulty is a bit challenging on some levels until you get a foothold and also get your playstyle  down.  After that it's just a matter of taking advantage of the spawns.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017838794', 'num_games_owned': 152, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 6261, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1790, 'last_played': 1708930147}
review:
Although perhaps not by name due to several reasons (as it's named Overload), this is the "Descent" title we needed and we deserved as fans of the saga.
Made by the original creators of the good old Descent titles from the 90's, this masterpiece (Overload) mixes all the best points and mechanics from the past games and blends it in such a masterful manner that it's a must play for every fan of the Descent games and the 6DOF genre in general.
Level design is superb, it has beautiful graphics, a not so complex but very interesting story (even if it has some clich√©s), and the action (specially on Hotshot difficulty and up) is constant and fast-paced and overall very fun to play!

-WARNING - THE REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS AHEAD (I'm focusing on the Single Player campaign)-

[spoiler]It plays mostly as Descent 1, specially during the first 12 levels of the campaign:
it has a VERY similar atmosphere, design and gameplay (robot placement and level flow) to that of Descent 1 campaign, with just a bit of extra elements from Descent 2 (switches to unlock doors or disable forcefields) and small details from Descent 3 like accelerator tubes and small mini-generators that you have to destroy to disable forcefields.
But each one of those elements just so well balanced and placed that I consider it like the Descent of my dreams (and it has the advantage that doesn't has the features that I didn't like from Descent 3 on its time)

Of course, I'm not saying that this game is just a copy-paste of the classics made to please the old fans (like me) that just want some fanservice, it has a good deal of new features to be considered a new and different title from those of the Descent saga.

Specially from level 13 and onwards, the atmosphere and mechanics changes enough to feel separated from the original Descent games, and I applaud the developers for those new gameplay elements that feel so great when you mix them with a Descent style gameplay. The latest levels really blew my mind.

The fact that there are a couple special weapons that you only find on those levels, how you need to activate special alien 'cores' to advance through (to open doors or forcefields), how you encounter a different set of enemies from the past levels and how it's aesthetically different from the rest of the game not only makes the story develop better, but also adds something that the original Descent titles lacked or didn't implement well enough (even if Descent 3 Mercenary was [i]very[/i] close): the feeling to be very far on real alien worlds, much like on Half-Life with planet Xen.

My only complain of the game is that I don't like the design of the last boss arena on level 15, it turned the fight against the boss enemy a bit frustrating and infuriating, I had to lower the difficulty just to advance that level, but it's not a big game breaking element, fortunately. [/spoiler]

Overall, I find Overload to be a complete masterpiece of the 6DOF genre, and I put it at the same pedestal along the big ones, Descent 1,2 & 3. :)

Kudos to the developers, long life to Revival Studios and its members! :D

review:

Wether you liked the predecessors (Descent series) or its later homages or are just up for a really strong, slightly more complex shooter experience, give this one a try. The demo is free and extensive and the price for the full game more than fair.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025048349', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 3891, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 681, 'last_played': 1675521851}
review: The game I didn't know I wanted in the genre I didn't know I missed. An absolutely amazing, fast, brutal, dazzling six degrees of freedom shooter that will truly test your aim, your movement, and your spatial sense. Handcrafted levels that get bigger and bigger, an array of varied and powerful weapons, nasty enemies trying every trick in the book and inventing some new ones too, excellent graphics and great music. One of the best games released this year, and certainly the best shooter.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964814744', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 19034, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1573, 'last_played': 1562960120}

author: {'steamid': '76561198199679878', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 3094, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2383, 'last_played': 1569881639}
review:
So I just recently beat this game on my first playthrough (Ace difficulty) and I gotta say this game is a blast from the past. The Descent games were my childhood in the 90s and now seeing a new title from the very people who pioneered and polished the 6DoF movement genre back with a whole new title was just amazing. The controls, the graphics, the music, the levels, the robots... it was all so gloriously fun. Working on my second playthrough now on Insane.

This is definitely a game worth getting. Tell your friends (heck, buy it for your friends!), family, anyone you know who would remotely be interested in this. We need this game to succeed and sell big for the sake of the genre, the game itself, and the future of gaming. Too many trash or rushed games litter the market, this game is a return to form of what could be when developers get together and let their passion run wild. I've already bought this game for two friends and will undoubtedly buy it for more.

Highly highly HIGHLY recommend this game to pretty much everyone.

P.S. While I am a Keyboard / Mouse user, this game IS compatible (barring the usual setup of each) for both a controller and even a Joystick/HOTAS setup. So pretty much anyone can play!
