author: {'steamid': '76561197970858682', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 113, 'playtime_forever': 4363, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1374, 'last_played': 1638712474}
review:
*Gnome Seal of Approval*
Finally another GOOD game in this genre. I have been waiting for a Descent clone/sequel for years, and Overload is IT!

Six degrees of freedom, lots of enemies firing a plethora of projectiles at you, powerups, upgrades, confusing mazes, secrets.

Now that Overload is out, I hope Revival will start evolving the underused genre further. Get creative and inject new concepts into Overload 2 (when it happens).

My only (minor) gripe so far with Overload is the upgrade points you gather through exploration and secrets. The game doesn't tell you how many upgrade points are hidden in each level until you complete it. If you miss one, you can't go back later to look for the missing one. Well, you CAN go and replay any previous level at any time, but even if you find all upgrade points this time, it won't affect your current save. They must be collected in a linear fashion.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968151952', 'num_games_owned': 1375, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 25, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25, 'last_played': 1528519601}
review: Descent in VR <3

author: {'steamid': '76561197996696153', 'num_games_owned': 831, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 77431, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 210, 'playtime_at_review': 11789, 'last_played': 1712034938}
review:
Overload is a Six Degrees of Freedom first person shooter with a single player story mode, replayable challenge modes with leaderboard, and online multiplayer.  If you enjoyed Descent, you will enjoy this.  But why?  What about this game is special?

1) The Nostalgia

The moment you teleport into Ymir Outpost and start moving around, you already begin to recall the feeling of the original series.  The first secret you discover.  The first robot that pops out of a secret room after you trigger it.  The first time a Scorpion surprises you.  The first cryotubes you rescue.  The first secret level you find.  You will remember everything you loved about the original game as you get introduced to some of the new concepts that Overload brings to the table.

2) The Music

Much of the music of this game comes from Descent music legends Dan Wentz and Allistar Brimble.  You'll hear styles from Descent 1 and 2 as you play through the game.  But can we talk about Descent 3's Jerry Berlongieri and his absolutely brilliant "Unmanned", the soundtrack to level 14?  If there's nothing that gets me, it's music that fits what's going on.  Kantor's descent into madness is captured perfectly by this soundtrack, which starts making you, the player, start questioning reality.

3) The Story

The story starts out with you investigating various accidents that happened.  As you learn more, you start to feel that things are wrong.  This culminates in the level 15 mission briefing, AKA the "Three Queens" story.  Everything is PERFECT about this.  Not only does this briefing explain everything up to that point, it invokes a level of terror that you'd expect from rounding the corner into a Scorpion.  The voice acting on this part is exceptional as well, sends chills up and down the spine.

4) Challenge Modes

And after the story campaign, you can keep playing more with the addictive challenge modes.  12 maps teeming with robots for you to destroy and set high scores on the leaderboards.  Try to play as long as you can with infinite, or see how fast you can kill things on countdown mode.  It's a simple idea that players love.

While I can't help but glow about the single player experience, the multiplayer experience isn't quite as good.  This is largely because multiplayer wasn't intended to be part of the 1.0 release.  However, the team at Revival pivoted and decided to add multiplayer to this mix late.  This really shows in the disparity between in polish between single player and multiplayer.  While it might be difficult to justify criticizing the game for including something that it wasn't planning on, it is no longer Early Access, and needs to be looked at as such.

There are a number of missing features with multiplayer: co-op campaign compatibility, server browsing, joining games in progress, hosting dedicated servers, Hoard CTF & Monsterball game modes that were popular in Descent 3, and a way to observe games in progress (my #1 feature request).  It really seems like multiplayer is something that either should have delayed the release of 1.0, or should have been part of a 2.0 release several months down the line.  It is not great that multiplayer was released half-or-less-finished.

For playing multiplayer itself, you're forced into playing client-server.  There are no peer to peer options, which means that a 50ms swing in ping can be the difference between winning 9-8 and losing 11-20 against the same pilot, just because you had different pings on different servers.  The lower your ping, the more what you see is accurate, which means you get a pretty big advantage over someone who is at a higher ping.

Anarchy has a strange points system that rewards 3 points for a kill and 1 point for an "assist", which requires you to do a certain amount of damage right before someone else gets the kill.  I very still much believe anarchy should just be based on kills, because now you get situations where games end because someone with 18 kills and 6 assists win over someone with 19 kills and 2 assists.

Don't let this get you totally down about multiplayer.  The actual multiplayer games can be quite fun, and as long as you can deal with these nitpicks, you'll still have a good time.  No other game outside of the Descent series has a multiplayer that can even be called comparable to that series, so Overload at least has that going for them.

The other thing that Overload has going for them is their exceptional and responsive dev team (edit: See below for update).  All those multiplayer nitpicks I discussed above?  They're *working* on resolving some of them, and are very good at listening to player feedback when determining what to tackle next.  I feel confident knowing that this game will continue to evolve, especially remembering where the closed beta of multiplayer was a month prior to release, and how far it has come since.  (Spoiler alert: It was *terrible* back then.)

So if you're looking for an authentic Six Degrees of Freedom single player experience that brings the genre into modern times, I can't recommend this game enough.  It even supports both Individual Level and full game speedrunning, has a new game+ mode where the levels change up to add even more difficulty, and has a ton of replayability.  Multiplayer feels unfinished, but give it a shot, and if you're not happy with what you see yet, don't be surprised if in an update down the road you see something added that you wanted in the game.

[edit]
I wanted to edit this review because eight months on from release, and not a whole lot has changed with multiplayer.  The main nitpicks are still there.  There've been some weapon balance passes, but no major change into how multiplayer works.

What's worse is the dev team has gone silent.  I have said in a number of places that this now seems like a 2019 indie company thinking like a 1995 corporate studio.  I don't know what happened between May and now, but this no longer feels like it's going to get any major updates, and the lack of communication from the dev team on this and other major issues (XBox is *still* unreleased) is frustrating a lot of players.

I still highly recommend the crap out of this game for single player, and the DLC has extended the life of the game for sure.  However, it's a shame that the best multiplayer 6DoF game is going on 24 years old this month, and no game in 20 years has managed to even exceed Descent 3's multiplayer.
[/edit]

[edit2]
Revival Studios is no more, so no more updates will be coming for the game.  They did make a v1.1 update to allow for online play without their own servers, but the experience kind of sucks because there were no changes to the net code.  So, if you really want to play Overload multiplayer, be sure to check out my Steam guide on olmod to learn how to play multiplayer in olmod.  olmod was conceived by Arne de Bruijn, and since has been modified by no less than a dozen other developers who love this game.  It has many improvements and quality of life features that have made multiplayer an awesome experience.
[/edit2]

author: {'steamid': '76561198019388720', 'num_games_owned': 670, 'num_reviews': 196, 'playtime_forever': 280, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 280, 'last_played': 1528521300}
review:
Overload is a fantastic descent style game made by some of the original creators of the descent series. It feels like jumping right back into descent except with nice modern graphics and amazing lighting and particle effects. I've been playing through on normal difficulty and just finished level 9. There are 15 or so levels in this and some are so large that they will take you a long time to get through, especially if you get lost or have trouble with some of the enemies.

As far as the map design goes they are very well done. There are many secrets to be found on every level and cool story bits that give you audio dialogue and reveal the story as you pick them up.

The control is nice and smoothe using keyboard and mouse. With 6DOF games I find a controller doesn't really work out as well but usually if you have a jotstick those seem to be alright. Keyboard and mouse though is by far the best with this title I would say. 

As far as other game modes than the campaign there are challenge mode and multiplayer. The multiplayer is alright, the levels I played seemed a little small for my tastes and I wasn't a huge fan of the level design of the multiplayer maps. They remind me of the typical arena style maps you see in FPS games a lot where every way you go has a back way and everything seems a bit too symmetrical. I prefer maps that are not the arena style, I like maps that are closer to the campaign style of maps where it's not symmetrical and there are dead ends, places to park and set traps etc. The multiplayer seems lacking on this one.

One other thing to note is that there is a level editor coming. This will add to the game with new maps being created and available by the players and that's always cool.

The music, sound effects and ambiance are fantastic and fit the levels very well. I really enjoyed the music in this.

The weapons on the ship are pretty cool and so too are the secondary weapons. Each are upgradable multiple times based on how you prefer to play and sometimes you can give them added effects too like turning dumb missles into homing or extending the life of homing mines, lots of cool stuff here. Your ship also has a headlight which slowly drains power but you also have flares that you can use and they are really cool with awesome lighting and the way the bump off the walls is so neat.

If you like 6DOF games, the old descent series or sci-fi in general this game is really good and you will probably enjoy it. A lot of work and effort went into this game and it shows, you feel it while playing. There are 4 or 5 difficulty modes, something perfect for everyone's skill level or to challenge yourself. I think the price for this is pretty fair as well. I can't wait to see what sort of maps people make when the editor releases. This is a cool game, check it out if you think you'll like it because you probably will.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001816322', 'num_games_owned': 845, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 7658, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 947, 'last_played': 1703363911}
review:
If you ever enjoyed a Descent game, do not miss this game! There have been a few similar games in the last few years but this one is significantly better than the rest, not surprising since its creators have the most experience designing this type of game.

If you've never played Descent but you enjoy classic Doom-style FPS games or perfectly controlling a cockpit in 3d space or hunting for secrets in memorable but complex truly three dimensional mazes, this is the game for you! Really great music and quality voice acting as well.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990378522', 'num_games_owned': 2334, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 584, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 264, 'last_played': 1552110830}

author: {'steamid': '76561198303943596', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1040, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 601, 'last_played': 1552146838}
review: Wow, thanks for this game! I loved Descent games - very happy there is a real good new game. Graphics, Gameplay, Sound .... everything is amazing!

author: {'steamid': '76561197964258610', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 43, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 43, 'last_played': 1528231074}
review:
This game was released on 5/31/20018.

It was made by the creators of the original Descent after a successful KickStarter Campaign and going through Steam Early Access.

It is amazing! Highly recommend it to all interested in 3D FPS and/or 6 DOF titles. It has both a SP campaign and Multiplayer. Graphics are legit, allows for VR either via either Occulus or Vive and both the music and sound effects are top notch. The title uses the Unity engine.

Without a doubt, this is the best "Descent" game since the original in the 1990's.

[This brief review may be followed by a more fleshed out version in the future.]

author: {'steamid': '76561197997335149', 'num_games_owned': 4891, 'num_reviews': 166, 'playtime_forever': 297, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 209, 'last_played': 1618622616}
review:
Did you like Descent? Do you love six-degrees-of-freedom shooters? Do you like sneaky bots hiding in amazingly-designed levels?

Then get this. Stop reading, just get it. It's soooo good.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994333970', 'num_games_owned': 163, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 1158, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 878, 'last_played': 1528648591}
review:
If walking simulators had controls this perfect Id probably played trough all of it. The maps so nice aswell. Where you move and how you move are awesome!
Only problem is, im afraid to move in this. The game design is really nice as it drags you in to the heat, puts the clock on you with spawners and lures you in the heat with buffs and stuffs. Game design spot on to lead the player the way it shoudl be, i felt the adrenalin rush in the chest, but I hate that feeling. I am aware that some ppl love that shit, but me, it is torture.

All thumbs up, but not for me. Thanks for making it tho good job.

Graphics amazing, performance pretty shit. Typical Unity game in that regard. Time and technology will fix it i guess.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016341179', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 5202, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2708, 'last_played': 1682532849}
review:
There is a playable demo if you want to try before you buy (look up Overload Playable Teaser)

VR is not required and I greatly enjoyed the game without it (not that I wouldn't try it if I had a headset).

With those two things out of the way, this game is amazing. The controls are easy to get used to even if you haven't played 6DOF before or if it's been 15-20 years since you touched one. A run of the campaign on Hotshot (medium difficulty) took me about 13 hours, and that was with a lot of secret hunting. While said secret hunting certainly helps, and some players will find a lot of fun in it, it's by no means required - you can play slowly and carefully, trying not to waste the many missiles and powerups you'll find, or you can blaze through the mines with your favorite weapons.

Overload has simple goals - "destroy robots, rescue survivors, blow up the reactor" - but the many difficulty modes, weapons, and even a New Game+ mode ensures that there are many ways to accomplish those goals. Everyone should give this game a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970757842', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 8620, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6575, 'last_played': 1560971373}
review:
Played the demo with 5 levels and really liked and plyed it so many times before the real game was ready.
The demo was a big plus for me and i buyed the game.

Now the full version i notice my opion has changed. 
I played it but it didnt had that wow factor i had before. The grapics are oke but not good, even crysis 2, 6 years old? are much better. The gameplay is more about hunting for hidden secrets if you want to have succes (upgrades to your ship). 
All the decks on the level are the same so in the end you have no idea where you have been and where not. There is a map but is so badly implemented that i didnt try to look at. Also later levels are so big bigger then descents that is not helping either when they look alike. 
I liked all the descent games and played them tot death. But this game not. I really dont care avout the last level, replaying the levels gets bored. Doom and Crysis 2/3, i played 50 times again and again. Because you make progress here it i   
The game is also now $30. $20 or even $15 would be more fair, because you can finish the game in a few days.

The game is still a good game if you can but it for 15 or 20, but to me its not decent. Yes Its from some of the makers i know but not decent4.
For $30 in the state it is now, its ok but not enough ok to say thumbs up. 
I am sure the full game will get less hours from me the 5 level demo.

edit: 17.06.2018
After playing for another 20 or 30 hours i cant say it isnt worth the money anymore :-)
Played some more now, i know the best weapons and best upgrade path that works for me. I used some cheats to get all weapons and with that i enjoyed the game much more. The frustration went away. More cheats are coming i heard. But i dont think i need them anymore, maybe for some fun ater aka more super upgradepoints.
Found some more secrets and upgradepoint so i can upgrade the weapons i wanted right away (1. TB and 2. Crusher)

Also finally understand how to use the map to help me i use markers and the pointer now to guide me also i check the map many times to see where i am. helps me to rememeber the map.
 
Arent there any negatives?
1. Yes they are. The grapics are still to simple the game would look much better with more colorfull HD textures. I hope in the future.
2. Secrets can be easier found now if you listen to a special sound they say. 
That true but even with max volume i only sometimes hear them most of the time not even when i am sitting next to it. Its broken somewhere. So no real help here and if you shoot your speakers explode because the volume was on 10+ in hope that you could hear the sound a a hidden upgrade point.
3. NG+ levels you get after completing the game. One problem you loose the guidebot to find the exit.  Another problem the difficulty is raised much more if you want to keep yur weapons.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960316818', 'num_games_owned': 159, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 7443, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3182, 'last_played': 1606660142}
review:
Did you love Descent? You'll love this. I do. It really is just Descent for modern hardware.

Want to fight Humans and Robots in a fast-paced True 3D environment? Give this a try!

Do you get motion sick easily? Are you easily lost in a true 3D environment? Do fast-paced shooters leave you confused? Maybe this game isn't for you.

Biggest Con: Not that many players for multiplayer. Don't expect that to totally turn around either as Descent is not for everyone.

Some kind of advanced Joystick or similar controls required for strong play. Keyboard + Mouse is possible but just won't cut it for being a strong player.

author: {'steamid': '76561198405795815', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 403, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 215, 'last_played': 1529267982}
review:
The single player story for this game in no way follows the old Descent games, but the vibe is within the gameplay itself. Robots have similar traits and characteristics, your ship is equipped with energy lasers as well as missiles, and there are reactors to blow up at the end of levels while you make your way to the exit hatch. The developers of Overload came from some of the original devs from the Descent series, so you will see a few Easter eggs throughout the game. The 6-DOF experience is a great one in Overload. There are not many shooters with this type of freedom, and it's a refreshing feeling in an engine that can give you upwards of 300 to 400 frames per second, with great quality textures.

I haven't finished the game, I'm writing under first impressions. As someone who played the Descent series a long time ago when I was under 10 years old, this game brings back the feeling Descent gave, with better graphics than even the D2X and D1X texture pack. Easily recommend if you enjoyed the old series.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971513943', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 27, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 27, 'last_played': 1527900636}
review: I purchased this and returned it.  I just couldn't get into it.  I was running a Vive Pro with a Warthog Hotas.  I meticulously bind my Hotas to give me maximum control but I just couldn't enjoy flying around with the way the controls responded.  I tried for 27 minutes to dial in perfect controls and play the game but I really felt like it was a dizzy motion sickness strafe backwards flier.  I have well over 970 hours into Elite Dangerous with every ship and all engineers so I have plenty of Space Time with VR and a Hotas.  Perhaps it would have played better with a keyboard and mouse with VR? or maybe with a xbox game pad?  I ended up returning it as the flying just wasn't for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073218504', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 4539, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1507, 'last_played': 1707639372}
review:
*Disclosure: I backed this game on Kickstarter*

If your into first person Shooters but want something a little different, definetly give this a look. 

Also highly reccomended for people who enjoyed 6dof games like Descent (same devs as this) and/or Sublevel Zero.

The gameplay is tight, smooth, and highly refined, story is also fairly engaging (especially if your into sci-fi). Has a surprisingly addictive challenge and multiplayer mode.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979967960', 'num_games_owned': 930, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 85, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 79, 'last_played': 1534921650}
review: It truely feels like Descent I & II with Descent 3 in an upgraded mode. I love this game. I love the classic Descent series. Absolutely beautiful environments also. Looking forward to later on in the game. I can give an upgraded review then.

author: {'steamid': '76561198141550626', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 62, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 62, 'last_played': 1528334349}
review:
Overload shares a lot with the original DOS-based Descent. So much so the controlling is amazingly similar.

However unlike the original DOS based Descent, multiplayer still leaves a lot to be desired. If you're like me, you bought it for co-op online multiplayer, but the developers couldn't be bothered to add it yet--and go so far to say it may be too complicated to implement at a later time (which is frankly not true). A basic system could be implemented that allows you to invite a friend over steam into the session.

The second problem is that if you relent and decide to do the multiplayer battles; the lobby system is a bit odd and there's no option to add any AI challengers in the mix.

All-in-all the game is great, but has so many drawbacks when it comes to multiplayer. They really should clarify that the multiplayer is crippled from the original counterparts. Once that's fixed I'd recommend the game to anyone...

author: {'steamid': '76561197994041959', 'num_games_owned': 279, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 2516, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1332, 'last_played': 1591895726}
review: The men who created the 6DoF Shooter genre prove they are still its masters.  This one gets it all right. The controls are sharp, the music, the graphics, good variety of enemies and weapons, lots of secrets to find. If you're a fan of the old descent games, you should own this already.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064387547', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 456, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 371, 'last_played': 1590795454}
review:
I've been playing this all day today using a Vive and keyboard (and monitor and keyboard too, because my cat kept freaking me out in VR) and I have to say this is a ridiculously fun and nostalgic reimagining of the experience of Descent.  Which makes sense considering it's the same guys, down to the soundtrack, which rocks.)  

To all the VR enthusiasts out there, there are several things I want to point out that will hopefully sway you to pick this one up.  

1)  It offers the option at launch to either play through the traditional PC arrangement of the monitor and whatever input device you like (HOTAS, kb/m, controller) or your preferred flavor of VR HMD.  This is fantastic because you don't have to set a launch argument, and instead can decide to play flat on a whim if you're just looking for a quick session or for whatever reason don't want to always play VR.

2) On my 1070 I can crank EVERYTHING up to max.  In addition it seems incredibly well optimized and should run fine on any rig that isn't 10 years old with a discrete GPU.  VR settings are just as forgiving, allowing me to leave them at max with no perceptible frame loss.

3) If you're not a fan of the VR cockpit (I am not) you can simply remove it.  I AM BLOWN AWAY by this option.  Allowing me to get a full view of the environment greatly enhances my immersion and allows me to not only see what's going on where normally I'd be occluded by cockpit, but it also works really well and you forget that it's not there after 30 seconds.

I cannot imagine not owning this for VR - do yourself a favor and grab it if the idea of flying a small craft in mazes and blowing up enemy robot craft all to a killer pumping soundtrack appeals to you.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963400152', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1698, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 701, 'last_played': 1607194432}

author: {'steamid': '76561197984543386', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 1705, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 480, 'last_played': 1696462382}
review:
This game is a GIFT to everyone who fondly remembers Descent/D2 years ago. Literally EVERY concept that made the originals so amazing is included AND improved upon! This is the paragon of a fantastic modern successor to an oldschool game. There really isn't any more to be said. Pay these awesome people and Prepare for Descent...

(And if you haven't played the original Descent games, this game is an amazing 3D FPS with awesome music, amazing effects, and hours of fun.)

Final note, I hope there's eventually a level creator with Steam Workshop!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561197965929510', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 6005, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 462, 'last_played': 1709774367}
review:
I've been playing Descent and Descent II for over 20 years, and I stumbled upon Overload while it was still in early access a few months ago.  When I saw that a handful of the original Descent develpers were creating a spiritial successor to a game that was so near and dear to me, I kept an eye on their progress up until the official release. 

After playing this game for about 8 hours, I can say that it certainly scratches the Descent itch I've had for all these years.  M+KB controls are excellent, and this game is exactly what I would hope for in a modern day spritual successor to Descent II (my personal favorite in the series).  I haven't finished the campaign yet, but it's clear so far that great care was taken into modernizing the Descent experience while keeping intact all that made the original games great.  Even the music has a distinct Descent vibe.

Great level design (don't forget to use the automap if you feel lost!), really cool weapons, and tons of interesting robots to shoot at.  Don't pass this one up.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966089212', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 202, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 162, 'last_played': 1678567452}

author: {'steamid': '76561198074408394', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 1175, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 735, 'last_played': 1638303588}
review:
Truely a revival of what made the original Descent games so fun:
Fast action skill based flight combat and masterfully designed spaces for all kinds of potential devious ambushes.
The same feeling of precise control but with a modern mix of visual effects and online options.
Now you dont even need to pay for Kali.net to get whooped by the pros!

author: {'steamid': '76561198004310953', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 15446, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4063, 'last_played': 1708736179}
review:
Well here it is; the game Descent fans have been waiting for.
And I'm gonna try and gear this review towards not those people.  Cause it looks like the majority of these reviews are already aimed at fans of Descent so what would be the point in that, eh?

Simply put this is the best zero gravity shooter in recent years, and possibly in forever. --yes more games like it exist, but not very many, and this is absolutely the one you want to buy first.  The extra dimension of movement adds an extremely simple sort of complexity to the game -- it's surprisingly easy to pick up but still needs you to put in the work to master it.  This is the sort of game that anyone who's dreamt of flying and woken up feeling wistful about it needs to play.

Overload is a joy to control -- every movement feels responsive and all of the weapons in the game have their place in the task of destroying your robotic foes.  I would encourage new players to spend some time in the training level getting a feel for strafing up and down and rolling left and right, flying on their back -- any other sort of movement or orientation they can dream up... this sort of excersize not only helps get yourself used to the controls but will also help you navigate some of the more complex levels.

And complex some of these levels are.  The game provides you with a holographic guide robot you can activate at almost any time and will lead you from wherever you are to your next objective so you don't need to worry about getting lost if you go exploring.  The game does get punishingly hard as you get farther into it so dark souls fans should be in love. :P  Although there is no checkpoint system you can also save at almost any time.

Finally, there is a simple yet surprisingly deep plot going on as you make your way across the moons of saturn and beyond... It's presented as a sort of murder mystery and hooked me in even though I didn't think I was playing the game for its story at all.  You can tell the writer is a fan of Ender's Game and Agatha Christie since the story comes across as something like a mix of the two.  Even if you don't manage to find all the audio logs and background information you never feel lost in it, and it's remarkably well-written as well as being engaging.

So, even though the mission objectives can sometimes feel repetitive and the three bosses might be a *titch* too easy once you've wrapped your head around flying instead of walking, I still wholeheartedly, unreservedly recommend this game to anyone, not just fans of the old Descent titles.  It's an exhilarating experience that, if you've ever dreamed of flying and woken up feeling wistful, will never get old.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Author's note: a level editor for the game is coming out some time in the next few days and, although I originally did want to spend some time with it before I wrote my review so I could include a review of it here, I decided to write the review early.   I do intend to add on to this once I've spent some hours in the editor so, if that's the sort of thing you like in a game, check back here in a week. ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561198143229012', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 5803, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3202, 'last_played': 1594511574}
review: This game is simply amazing! I know just about every other review on here mentions Descent somewhere, and yes, if you played and enjoyed any of the Descent series then stop reading right now and buy this! If you have no clue what Descent is then this game is definitely worth taking a look at. The graphics are well done, the lighting is phenomenal, the controls are extremely smooth and easy to learn, and its incredibly challenging! Playing on any difficulty over the easiest ones you will quickly discover that the game wants only one thing, to see you dead. The bot AI is extremely intelligent, sneaky, and they will come at you from every direction. The level design is quite complex, so you will probably get lost from time to time. There is a handy Holo Bot included to help find your way when needed. All in all the single player campaign is very enjoyable, with a great storyline to go along with it. The fun REALLY begins though when you try the multiplayer. It. Is. Intense! There are three modes to play in, 1v1, anarchy, and team anarchy. Playing with a full lobby of 8 players can be absolute insanity! especially on one of the smaller maps. On top of all this, it also has VR support! If you enjoy FPS gaming in general, then I highly recommend you give this one a go. You will be happy you did.

author: {'steamid': '76561198250544676', 'num_games_owned': 3672, 'num_reviews': 323, 'playtime_forever': 539, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 539, 'last_played': 1528236923}
review:
[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/7871885/]Follow our curator page:[b] OCG-Curations[/b] if you like and want to see more reviews like this one.[/url]

VERDICT: A tricky, and intense, successor to a classic first person shooter. 

This is a nice and easy review if you played Descent back in the day and loved it. The same developers, the same premise, and gameplay that's just as intense and frantic as you remember it. There's a few modest additions to the formula, which I'll cover in more depth later, but they enhance the game and I'm confident you can buy this without regret. If it has a flaw, it's that the difficulty can spike in a few places - namely the boss battles, and the area where the reactor is can be tricky to overcome. Otherwise it's pretty enjoyable, and scratches that nostalgia itch.

If you've never heard of Descent, or never got to play it way back in the 90's (?) - it's a straightforward enough game. It takes place in the future, at a time when corporations have set up mining facilities in outer space. The worker bots in these facilities have been infected with a virus that is causing them to attack people. You are the clean up crew sent in to destroy the bots, and blow up the reactor core. Once you do that you then have a limited amount of time to escape, before it all gets nuked to a crisp.

Because you are in a ship, movement is freer than 99% of FPS'. You have your strafe, but can also rotate the craft around, and move up and down as well. It might sound complicated, but it's not too tricky to get to grips with how much space you can cover, and it controls really well with a pad. I just find this control method (which obviously takes a lot of keys) to be most accommodating on a controller, and it's totally configurable too so you can do all that you want quite easily. With radial wheels for everything (two sets of weapons, and a third for a final ability), that are quickly accessed by holding the relevant button, it's really smooth to play.

Enemies can come from every angle, and due to how your weapons fire it can be advantageous to have rolled your ship around to accommodate this. Instead of strafing, which may leave one of your blasters hitting a wall as you're not far enough past it, you would want to alter the pitch of the ship and then use the vertical controls to "drop down" and have both weapons free to hit. It's a bit mindbending to do, but the controls are up to it, and your craft handles really well.

Whilst the level design can be a bit of a swine due to this freedom, most enemy types are actually fair in how they attack. You have fast shooting ones that do less damage, and slower ones that are more powerful, and they only really get to blast you quickly when you're gingerly creeping into an area. When you're moving faster they do take a little longer to respond. It's entirely possible to whizz in, flip the ship around, blast a few and then whizz back out. That's if you don't totally lose your cool, and your bearings, and fly smack bang into a wall....

Which, uh, I've done on more than one occasion. Then at other times I've been an exhiliratingly slick WHIRLWIND OF DEATH. It's not so much a case of when the game works, as it works very well 100% of the time, but it can be overwhelming  and the developers don't ever let you get comfortable. But that's why it's such an exciting game, as it's unpredictable - oh, and they do some stuff flike having enemies pop out of hidden panels.  Which will often cause a shock when you think you have the upper hand and one has appeared right behind you....

You have two different weapon systems: your primary is energy weapons, and the secondary is ammunition weapons. Primary weapons deplete from a pool of energy that is also shared by a third system - the light of your ship, and a probe that can guide you to ammo / energy reserves. This energy can be replenished through dropped items from enemies, and at a limited number of recharge stations. Ammunition weapons are based around supplies that are found in the environment.

There is no health recharge in this game - you only get it returned by destroying enemies, and having them drop replenishment. Combined with relatively scarce ammo it makes for satisfying risk / reward gameplay. You're low on health and ammo, but if you want more...well, you're going to have get stuck in. Them's the breaks! 

As exciting as all of this is though, it's really when you blow up the reactor that Overload (and Descent before it) gets just a  tad sweat inducing. When you've got an alarm blaring, and a timer ticking down...and you can't for the life of you remember where the exit is, and you're frantically haring toward somewhere, anywhere, in the hope of escape...and the devs have yet more bots popping out of hidden panels giving you a fright....

Make it out in time and there's a cool sequence of everything getting blown to bits behind you as your ship whizzes out. Big explosions!!! If all of that doesn't get your pulse racing then you're either dead, really boring, or harder than adamantium crossed with vibranium. 

There's a mild upgrade feature for your weapons in place, which means exploring for some hidden (and not-so-hidden) upgrade points is worth the time. It looks good, with some very funky particle effects and nice lighting. Crisp graphics, albeit not hugely detailed - at a guess I'd say this doesn't require a particularly hefty pc to run it at a very smooth framerate. Excellent music that gets you pumped for the action, great sound effects and voiceover work.

There's also a multiplayer, though I'm not really a mutliplayer kind of guy, so can't comment on the quality of that. But if it's been done with the polish of the single player, then it ought to be good. So far I've clocked up nine hours in the campaign, and according to the game blurb there's 15 levels, with my progress currently sitting at the sixth level. 

That's playing on the hotshot difficulty, which equates to medium. So, a rough guess would be that it takes about 20 hours to finish, and for the cost I'd be pretty chuffed with that. It's been bug free so far and mostly fun - with a few small exceptions that are holding back my progress (usually I'd prefer to finish a game before reviewing it). 

There are some difficulty spikes that can be annoying. I've already dropped the difficulty down one level (currently the third of five levels) and I'm still finding area's where things aren't quite right. They have a device that pumps out bots endlessly unless you can destroy it, but at times there can be too many enemies to deal with them and trying to stop more from coming. 

I just did a reactor where it had two of these devices which couldn't be destroyed as they were shielded, and ended up having to snipe the reactor from a position enemies wouldn't go to. As it was just too much to get any closer and deal with it without cheesing it. The one boss battle I've encountered so far was rather lame in design and to battle, and I ended up with no ammo just flying around in a circle shooting it (you get one energy back so you can still shoot, though it's slow to recharge).

It's a pity. It doesn't take away from the fact that 90% of the game is enjoyable, exciting, and challenging. It does mean that some of it can get a bit tedious. Most areas are quite tricky, but some are the wrong side of that. A small blemish, but it's there nonetheless.

For the price this is an almost perfect nostalgia trip if you were a fan of Descent, and a tricky and exciting game if you are new to it. It runs well, for the most part plays well, and has a decent amount of content. Add in the muliplayer, and that's great value in my book. Overload gets a thumbs up because it is fun, but there are a few bad elements bringing it down slightly. Coupled with the games intensity, and slightly bewildering scope, it may prove to be a game you finish in chunks, rather than a couple of sittings.

Der VR-Modus ist schon Krass, entweder man vertr√§gt das oder man hat pech...oder man spielt trotzdem wie ich und hofft das es besser wird mit der sickness...ja und bei mir wirds besser. Kann dank Overload nun auch VR Spiele mit free locomotion spielen, wo voher nur Teleport angesagt war.;D

author: {'steamid': '76561197992889261', 'num_games_owned': 473, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 15932, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7058, 'last_played': 1562050621}
review:
If you liked the original Descent 1 and 2 games, you'll like this too. It's basically the original games' formula, revived with shinier graphics. It's got everything the original had - reactors and emergency exits, miners to rescue, secrets (sometimes inside other secrets), a 3D automap, etc. It does bring some new stuff to the table though, including being able to find and spend upgrade points to improve your ship and weapons between levels, and a New Game+ mode. Even the music was written by the sound designers of the original games and provides the perfect soundtrack for blasting robots.

These are my biggest complaints about the game right now, but keep in mind they are very minor gripes in an otherwise fantastic game and didn't ruin the experience at all.

[list]
[*] There's a major bug where doors sometimes get stuck closed after loading previous saves (possibly involving secret levels) but I expect that to be fixed in the first patch.
[*] I'm 2/3 through the campaign and the emergency exit shafts are still located pretty close to the reactors, in contrast to the original where you often found the exit halfway through the level.
[*] The automap has a fixed vertical axis that you can't rotate more than about +/- 80 degrees around, meaning the levels always have a fixed vertical axis you can orient yourself with. The originals' automap could be freely rotated in any direction without limits so the levels felt much more disorienting.
[*] There's a quicksave keybind (which you'll be using a lot, since there are no autosaves), but there is no quickload keybind, meaning you'll be spending a lot of time waiting for death animations and navigating the "load game" menu if you're on a higher difficulty.
[/list]

author: {'steamid': '76561197993406990', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 37, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 37, 'last_played': 1528252960}

review:
Ein freundliches Hallo an alle Spieler, Zocker & Daddler,

Overload wird ja sehr unterschiedlich bewertet von der Spielepresse, von Gamestar 62 % bishin zu 4players 85 %, deshalb schreibe ich auch meine Meinung zu dem Spiel hier in diesem Review f√ºr Interessierte oder unschl√º√üige auf, allerdings bisher nur f√ºr den Singleplayer Teil des Spieles. Ich hoffe ich kann Euch bei Eurer Entscheidung helfen wenn Ihr unschl√ºssig seid ob Overload was f√ºr Euch ist (es gibt auch eine spielbare Demo, was nat√ºrlich noch besser ist ;-)  ).

Als ich die ersten paar Meter geflogen bin und dann auf den ersten ersten Gegner traf, hatte ich ein breites Grinsen im Gesicht... ich liebe Overcent ...√§h Descload... √§h Overload, es fliegt sich wie fr√ºher, und auch das Spielprinzp hat sich gl√ºcklicherweise nicht ge√§ndert, d.h., die Labyrinthm√§√üigen level zu durchqueren, dabei die Mission zu erf√ºllen, und so viel wie m√∂glich von den Versteckten Kammern/R√§ume/bis hin zu ganzen Arealen / Levelabschnitten zu entdecken. 

Dem jenigen dem die alten Descent Spiele gefallen haben, und auch nichts anderes erwartet, wird auch sehr wahrscheinlich mit Overload seinen Spa√ü haben.
Wer allerdings auf Inovation, oder auch eine Geschichte wie z.B. in Freelancer und Konsorten oder Open World wert legt, wird h√∂chstwahrscheinlich ent√§uscht sein und mit Overload nicht viel anfangen k√∂nnen. 

Ich finde ja das Overload ja √§hnlichkeiten mit Dark Souls hat ;-)  , wenn man bei beiden Titeln zielstrebig die Missionen  erledigt und nur dem Hauptpfad folgt, wird man einen gro√üen Teil des Levels/Spiels nicht zu Gesicht bekommen. Man mu√ü sich da schon ein wenig reinfuchsen (verbei√üen ;-)  ) wenn man alles entdecken m√∂chte.

Revival Productions LCC haben aber einiges getan um die Baker/Fans der alten Descent Spiele und neue Spieler zu erreichen, und es √ºr diese etwas leichter zu machen. So gibt es nicht nur 5 Schwierigkeitsgrade wo f√ºr jeden Skill was dabei sein sollte, sondern auch eine gut funktionierende automatische Karte (was bei 6-Achsen Spielen gar nicht so einfach ist) und als i T√ºpfelchen eine Drohne der mann ein Ziel vorgeben kann (vom n√§chsten Gegner/Munition/Energie/Reperaturgebiet/Ausgang bis hin zu den Missionszielen), und diese einem den Weg zeigt indem sie vorraus fliegt und man Ihr nur noch folgen mu√ü. Ich finde das so gut gel√∂st, die alten Hasen k√∂nnen z.B. die Drohne einfach ignorieren, und den neuen Piloten wird damit die Orientierung erleichtert.

√úber den Multiplayer kann ich allerdings noch nichts sagen, denn ich m√∂chte erst mal die Kampagne abschlie√üen.

Egal bei welchem Titel, ich w√ºnsche allen noch viel Spa√ü beim Spielen.

Gru√ü Kalumet

author: {'steamid': '76561198116552528', 'num_games_owned': 244, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 233, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 143, 'last_played': 1632663014}

author: {'steamid': '76561198034086516', 'num_games_owned': 1049, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 1172, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 405, 'last_played': 1679762736}
review: Plays just like the classic descent games.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997068522', 'num_games_owned': 335, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 2562, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 819, 'last_played': 1640461526}
review:
The Descent formula honed and polished to something approaching perfection.

* Works with basically any control scheme or peripheral I've thrown at it: Mouse & keyboard, 360 controller, dual joysticks, all great. 
* Runs stable and smooth
* Excellent range of difficulty options
* It's friggin Descent and it's beautiful and it's perfect

author: {'steamid': '76561197976399577', 'num_games_owned': 345, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 757, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 434, 'last_played': 1604703130}
review:
If you liked the Descent games from the 90s, this is basically more of that, and it's every bit as awesome. Flying around in 3D space with the maneuverability of DOOM is unlike anything else, and it works equally well if not better in VR, provided you're as immune to motion sickness as i am. But eithe way I think the cockpit overlay would mitigate most of that.
Like I said before it's like Doom or Quake or Unreal tournament except you have the whole space to fly around in, the levels are designed to be interesting given that vertical element, and everything is nostalgia + iterative improvement. An excellent game for my money

author: {'steamid': '76561198062725504', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 206, 'playtime_forever': 615, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 406, 'last_played': 1701468902}
review:
Ann√§hernd perfekt !
Was die Entwickler geleistet haben, darf gern als gutes Beispiel f√ºr andere Produktionen gelten.

Spiel ist ein neues/altes Decsent. Das sollte wirklich jedem bekannt sein, also gibt es dazu nicht mehr zu sagen.
Kult wird zur Legende.

Update: Technisch ist das Game hochoptimiert und l√§uft einer AMD RX 580 butterweich. Mit Freesync nochmals so gut. Klasse Arbeit von den Entwickern, schlie√ülich ist auch die technische Seite gerade in einem Shooter immens wichtig.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970967829', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1122, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 350, 'last_played': 1568084660}
review:
A true modern 'Descent'. The dark, claustrophobic mines, the twisting and turning feel of combat against a multitude of robotic enemies, the weapons, and even the soundtrack are exactly what you want if you ever played Descent from the mid 90's. The visuals are stunning, with excellent detail on enemy robots, great visual effects, and a UI that tells you everything you need to know without being confusing or obtrusive. The story is given in very short pre-mission briefings and in-mission audio, with no terrible cutscenes to wade through to get to the 'destroy all robots' part of the game. The soundtrack is very nice too.

9/10 in my book.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978980437', 'num_games_owned': 484, 'num_reviews': 120, 'playtime_forever': 3100, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 343, 'last_played': 1674425323}
review:
The more you play the more addicted you will become. If you haven't played Descent then the closest thing I can describe this as Asteroids in full 3D.   

The game gets pretty freaking hard as enemies start becoming more numerous and some even become elites, it is then when you enter full zen mode and you will just be effortlessly moving and dodging in full 3D, unleashing every manner of pew pew boom boom that that game has to offer... and HOLY SHIT ITS 3AM AND YOU JUST WANT TO DO ONE MORE LEVEL!

author: {'steamid': '76561197992708157', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1359, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1337, 'last_played': 1687047884}
review:
A spiritual successor to the Descent series that lives up to the pedigree. The level design just gets better and more intricate as the campaign goes on, culminating in some amazing levels that really show off what a 6dof game is capable of. The new addition to the formula here is the upgrade system which works really well. The upgrade points are the secret items throughout the levels, usually hidden somewhere or gained after completing a tough challenge. This makes you want to fully explore the levels because the upgrade points are so important to your survivability as you progress. It wouldn't be a good incentive if the upgrade system was lacking, but fortunately its very well done as you upgrade your ship and weapons in between missions. The great thing here is that it's not just boring stat upgrades, every upgrade has clear and unique benefits to that weapon that do change the way you use them, and later on you get some branching paths to make that campaign run a little more unique.

Another highlight is the soundtrack, which is a thumping synthy sound that is perfect for this type of game. Navigating the twists and turns of a level, blowing up enemy robots, all while jamming to these beats really made this game feel like the 90s again.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970009749', 'num_games_owned': 509, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 7154, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2979, 'last_played': 1681849763}
review: I will echo what most reviews, positive and negative have been saying. This is almost exactly like classic descent with way better graphics and animations. The levels get repetitive very quickly. The textures all look the same. The upgrade system is cool. I haven't touched anything but the campaign so far and I've only made it to the 3rd level. My ultimate impression is that this game may get boring quickly, but I loved descent and the way it plays and I bought this game looking for that. I wasn't expecting something revolutionary, but just an updated descent and this does that well. If you liked classic descent and can still stand to play it then this is for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979099756', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 110318, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 156, 'playtime_at_review': 4491, 'last_played': 1711916024}
review: This is the game!  Flying feels awesome and smooth.  The graphics and sound is awesome.  Multiplayer is also awesome, has a great community.  If you havn't played a 6dof game, this is THE one to get into.  It's the best once you take the time playing with the controls.  See you in the mines.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004865494', 'num_games_owned': 319, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 241, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 108, 'last_played': 1592695816}
review:
Back in my youth, I loved the Descent games. Is this game a worthy successor to it? Heck yes it is! If you enjoyed Descent and its sequels, this is easily worth your time. 

The controls are smooth, the combat is fun and engaging, the soundtrack is banger.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001914736', 'num_games_owned': 520, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1027, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 795, 'last_played': 1676498693}

author: {'steamid': '76561198022177566', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 117, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 102, 'last_played': 1596588097}
review: Great HOTAS support and VR support! This game is intense, and lets you set up your cockpit controls to become one with your ship!

author: {'steamid': '76561197987816557', 'num_games_owned': 382, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 877, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 385, 'last_played': 1541901157}
review: Looks ok, plays well, sounds satisfactory

author: {'steamid': '76561197997689387', 'num_games_owned': 490, 'num_reviews': 100, 'playtime_forever': 118, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 118, 'last_played': 1528056483}
review:
I don't have much to say, but I got it for the multiplayer. Jumped right in, and it took about 5 minutes of figuring things out but it was shockingly clear and simple to understand what was going on and how the gameplay works. I played for a couple hours, community was extremely friendly, didn't encounter bugs or issues. The game was beautiful, the sound was really well done, there was cool customization options for your ship.

Friendly, high-skill competition is something I look for in games and it's hard to find. This game does it so well. I go up against people who can quadruple my score without breaking a sweat, and they're the nicest guys in the world. Give this game a shot.

author: {'steamid': '76561197962803839', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 435, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 435, 'last_played': 1528492414}

author: {'steamid': '76561197971522977', 'num_games_owned': 318, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 938, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 499, 'last_played': 1655152531}
review:
I have yet to beat the game but at 6 hours I can say this game is pretty much to Descent as Doom (2016) is to Doom.  This game captures everything down from the weapons to the music to the enemies to the level design in perfect sync.  Its like if they made a modern Descent game this is it.  Blowing up the core and busting your ass to find the exit brings back memories.  I love the weapon/ship upgrades and the fact they tied it to hidden secrets in levels works out very well.

I grew up playing Descent & Descent 2 and this faithfully captures that same feeling.  Amazing game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198024310232', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 475, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 87, 'last_played': 1667891888}

author: {'steamid': '76561198414384267', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1118, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 995, 'last_played': 1528640537}
review:
Love the feeling, love the atmosphere and love the gameplay. The devs done a great job and I'm getting nostalgic legacy 6dof feelings again. Enjoying it so far and I've touched on multiplayer a little and with only 3 players already found it intense and exhilirating, so fast and chaotic but technical at the same time. Loving it :)

Also, the upgrades in this game are amazing and you can choose a variety of upgrade and sub-upgrade options which adds alot of fun and dynamic to the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009959708', 'num_games_owned': 4166, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2199, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 226, 'last_played': 1670341180}
review:
Like every other review, pure gold for Descent lovers.  What Descent Underground needs to be (instead of drama).  Worth the full price, and that's coming from a person who only buys at $15 or less.

PROS:
+Solid Descent-like Gameplay (6-axis awesome with solid controls)
+Intriguing story
+Outstanding soundtrack
+Clearly and extremely well designed by the original Descent team
+Borderline copyright infringment in all the best ways!
+Zero bugs encountered

CONS:
-None

Not a CON, just unexpected:
-Difficulty needs minor tweaking (Rookie too easy, but Hotshot is a kick in the nuts, and it's only the next level).

review: Que dire?? FABULEUX, super beau super fluide super fun, gameplay excellent (apr√®s avoir red√©fini quelques touches mais ca c'est perso). Un hommage √† "Descent". J'adore! c'est absolument excellent!! je ne peux rien dire de plus. Je ne recommande pas ce jeu je vous oblige √† l'acheter :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198409943649', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 373, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 344, 'last_played': 1591472992}
review:
This is a game I learned to hate. The single player campaign takes a sharp turn in the last third and  lots of poor game design decisions finally stack up. I didn't finish the game. Bot AI,  flying and dynamic lighting are the best parts of this game. 

[b]Botched control configuration[/b]
Let's start with the stuff that broke the game for me. Later on the game relies on armies of enemies with powerful hit scan weapons. It also forces you to use a weapon you hate. Before that you could use any weapon you like to get stuff done. You *could*  switch to your favorite weapon but bugs and dumb configuration options ruins it.

The selection wheel never matured into a usable tool because you either can't pick a diagonal item or your selection interferes with your movement. You can't assign your favorite weapon(s) either because they are paired. And finally, the slowest fall back method of previous/next selection is broken because it maps internally to ‚ÄúInvert Y‚Äù.

Edit: Clarification
This section sounds a bit silly but I fly with joystick and aim with mouse, so buttons are very limited. At this tough stage of the game I'm suddenly and needlessly forced to toggle between two select weapons very fast. Neither the games' options nor my button contingent/configuration allowed that and I never trained it. I could remap everything but at this stage I was already weary, so I decided to quit.

[b]Poor story progression[/b]
Story went from a nice start to lots of short, repetitive chatter to heavy handed crap. 

[b]Environment kills flying[/b]
The environment is heavily stylized with nice textures and a nice color palette. It's rather sterile and lifeless and there are only a few rooms that look truly exciting but I kind of liked it. But I didn't like the overall darkness.

Flying in this game is 50% of the fun. To increase the sense of orientation and movement/speed the environment needs to be visible and close by. Lots of dark areas and (later) black hole textures (the already feeble headlight becomes useless) don't make sense for this game.

[b]Explosions kill motivation[/b]
The explosions also got changed for the worse. 1. No more easily visible flashes indicating a robot death. 2. Heavily darkened debris trails leading to disconnected/confusing debris explosions. 3. Usage of cliche fire textures.

Killing robots became tame, less visually rewarding and less fun. For challenge mode it essentially removed the primary motivation (have fun playing the game) and promoted secondary motivation (play the game to be on the leader boards).

[b]Bright, ear-piercing sounds and annoying music[/b]
I actually tried to play the game without any sound, just to see if I can. It wasn't fun. I settled on -10 db treble, low effects volume and no game music. It's a pity, because I usually liked parts of each track (nice Dark Knight reference) and some sound effects but I couldn't stand the '70s bright whining lead guitars, bright mixes for '80s dull speakers and far too many noise-based, bright, digital, processed, distorted sounds.

FYI: Playing time is wrong, I played mostly without Steam.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961635953', 'num_games_owned': 1093, 'num_reviews': 230, 'playtime_forever': 466, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 466, 'last_played': 1528033590}
review:
[h1]An amazing Descent successor everyone should play![/h1]

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
    [*]Gorgeous visuals with great particle effects.
    [*]Amazing soundtrack by composers from the original Descent games.
    [*]Game is super challenging.
    [*]Lots of content with campaign, NG+ mode and the challenge maps.
    [*]Smooth, fluid controls.
    [*]It will make you throw up from how amazing it is.
    [*]VR support for the masochistic.
[/list]
[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
    [*]Some balancing issues with certain enemy types.
    [*]Game can be crushing to newcomers.
    [*]You've wasted time reading this review instead of buying the game.
[/list]
Full video review: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hSjxmiZpf7M

author: {'steamid': '76561198004442009', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2038, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 487, 'last_played': 1670993130}
review:
Within seconds of this game starting I was 15 years old again playing the original Descent. I grew up on Doom, Heretic, Wolfenstein, etc and Descent was a complete paradigm shift that blew my mind and pretty much the entire gaming world's as well. Overload captures that perfectly. Of course it's a lot of the same people involved but they have managed to capture what made it so cool and make it even better. Revamped weapons and significant graphical improvements. The engine is smooth as silk covered in buttery melted milk chocolate. The play is just as frenetic as I remember it being and the story has been fun. The addition of upgrades is a welcome one as is the employee journals much like in Doom 3.

Whether you played and lived the originals or are new to this type of game, I highly recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000443740', 'num_games_owned': 464, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 1875, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 495, 'last_played': 1602391548}
review:
I've never played any of the Descent games.

I've only played Overload's tutorial level so far.

I came a little bit.

Buy this. Now.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021149057', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 228, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 160, 'last_played': 1561775098}
review:
Wow, Overload is loads of fun! I was a big Descent 1-3 fan back in the '90's and logged many an hour playing head-to-head with my buds over our modems (14.4k bps baby!).
Playing this in VR with the Rift fully realizes the vision of the older games in my memory. It's almost like this is how I always remembered them. The HOTAS controls were like slipping on a comfortable old pair of gloves. 

Well done, Revival Productions. This old Material Defender is thrilled to be called back to duty!

author: {'steamid': '76561197998955872', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 158, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 158, 'last_played': 1528256339}
review: This feels like Descent and it is awesome!  If you want to hunt evil robots in a mine with 6 degrees of freedom, this is it.  Stop reading and go buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997310646', 'num_games_owned': 66, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 634, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 634, 'last_played': 1528503492}
review: Enjoyed single player. Multiplayer just needs more people. But it brought me back to the good old lan days of descent. Has a ton of potential.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964277337', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 269, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 263, 'last_played': 1530832726}
review:
Nostalgia can only take you so far... yes it feels like a new Descent but I would not give this a positive review.

Here are my issues:
-All the levels/textures look the exact same and enemies have little variety
-No variety in the missions - its the same mission every time to blow up reactor (yawn).
-No coop play
-The multiplayer stinks - its basically strafe around in a small map  and jam attacks against very few players

Going to refund this one.. needs more variety in the levels, missions, and enemies.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021614868', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1980, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 135, 'playtime_at_review': 1625, 'last_played': 1712001963}
review: Descent 2 was the first pc game that I ever purchased, and I loved every bit of it. Overload triumphantly carries the Descent torch into the future. Using a mouse and keyboard, the controls are fluid and precise. The graphics don't strive for realism, but are vivid and pleasing with dazzling explosions. The maps are twisty mazes, puzzles in themselves, and the inclusion of loads of secrets in each level encourage exploration. It's fantastic, arcadey fun!

author: {'steamid': '76561198000182984', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 85, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25, 'last_played': 1625813755}
review:
Back in high school I used to find any excuse to go over to my big brother's apartment to go play the original Decent on his pentium computer since our dad's 486 just couldn't cut it.  

This game literally made me feel deja vu upon playing it.  

11/10 for its near time traveling capability.

Oh did I mentioned this game kicks ass?  Hell yeah it does.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045393929', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 113, 'playtime_forever': 210, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 162, 'last_played': 1561900001}
review: It feels great and the handling is intuitive. The VR is very fast and immersive. I got sick, but not because of poor optimization. I got sick, because I used a new form of technology enabling a mobility that will probably be added to my dreams. If the afterlife has this type of locomotion, I will be ready.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024982599', 'num_games_owned': 363, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 1345, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 480, 'last_played': 1582400863}
review:
I grew up a Descent junkie, and after nearly 20 years... I finally get to play multiplayer Descent online for the first time.
And it is glorious. 
Everyone buy this game so we can blow each other up!

author: {'steamid': '76561197995317348', 'num_games_owned': 2875, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 803, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 534, 'last_played': 1665249398}
