author: {'steamid': '76561197975119427', 'num_games_owned': 129, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 6770, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5350, 'last_played': 1642351376}
review:
Do you all remember the scene in the film [i]Ratatouille[/i] when Anton Ego, the restaurant critic, took his first bite of the ratatouille which instantly triggered flashbacks to his childhood when he ate the same dish his mother cooked for him? This happened to me with [i]Overload[/i], and it will happen for many of you who have experienced the [i]Descent[/i] series as a kid (or as an adult too üòä).

I remember loading up [i]Overload[/i] for the first time, and it triggered the memory of my dad buying my first new computer when I was 9 years old: a Compaq Presario 9232. It had three games: [i]Hardball 4[/i], [i]Magic Carpet[/i] (RIP Bullfrog), and [i]Descent: Destination Saturn[/i]. I remember loading up [i]Descent[/i] for the first time and could not move at all. I was used to using the arrow keys for games. So I was just rotating my ship around, shooting the destructible signs, and thinking when are the bad guys going to come? Embarrassingly, it took me about a week (after finally reading the manual), that you move forward and backwards using A and Z. Once I held that A button and heard that first scream from the Class 1 Drone, I knew I was in for a real treat. My dad rarely bought me games because he was worried about game violence (e.g. [i]Doom[/i]), but he knew [i]Descent[/i] was more family-friendly. Over the years, he gave me [i]Descent: Anniversary Edition[/i] (which I didn‚Äôt realize until I got the game that the campaign had me going past Saturn), [i]Descent 2: Infinite Abyss[/i], and [i]Descent 3[/i]. Prior to [i]Descent 3[/i] coming out, I convinced my dad to get me a PC with a graphics card since [i]Descent 3[/i] required one. He agreed, and my new PC came equipped with an S3 Savage4 card. Although it was a budget card, I was able to experience the final chapter of the Material Defender.

Subsequently, I was following rumors and possible concept art for [i]Descent 4[/i], then hearing [i]Descent 4[/i] being cancelled, then reading that Interplay was bankrupt, and then Interplay sort of re-emerging which gave some hope that the series might revive again. Nearly 20 years later, the original creators of [i]Descent[/i] created its own company, [i]Revival Productions[/i], to develop the long-awaited spiritual successor of [i]Descent[/i].

I was bummed that I missed the Kickstarter for the game, but I cannot imagine the anxiety of the developers during those last 24 hours. I wish I knew about the game to help out at the time. So, thank you for all the Kickstarter backers for making this game happen! I know if the developers start another Kickstarter project (e.g. [i]Freespace 3[/i]‚Ä¶ fingers crossed!), then I will definitely contribute knowing how well [i]Overload[/i] was developed and produced. Thank you to the Revival team for allowing me to relive my childhood memories and congratulations for producing a fantastic game!

Many reviewers have already gone into the features of the game, but I would like to reiterate that there are many types of gameplay that fits everyone‚Äôs needs and extends the replayability and life of the game. It‚Äôs not just a [i]Descent[/i] game with modern graphics. There‚Äôs the single player campaign with a deeper storyline and voice acting. In addition, there is your arcade-like Challenge Mode that would likely bring hours and hours of gameplay to get to the top of the leaderboard. Then there is the multiplayer to challenge other pilots in anarchy and team anarchy with more multiplayer modes coming in the future. Lastly, there is the Level Editor that will be released shortly after [i]Overload‚Äôs[/i] release day that would bring on countless customization. 

Prepare for Overload!

author: {'steamid': '76561198055350283', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 7230, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6323, 'last_played': 1646154400}
review:
I put this review here for people who are true fans of descent...

Sadly because star citizens hack developers got the descent trademark long before the original descent team did their kickstarter.  The descent team did there own thing, the problem is they only got 300K during the kickstarter.

https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/revivalprod/overload-the-ultimate-six-degree-of-freedom-shoote

versus the hack devs here:

https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/descendentstudios/descent-underground

So overloads kickstarter had its thunder stolen from it and you can feel it in the end product.  Not only that, the original descent developers haven't worked on descent in almost 20 years.  The last time they worked on descent was roughly 18 years ago and you can feel it.  The problem with that and many of them largely being out of the game industry is that many of the things that made descent, descent were removed for overload.  

Descent team doesn't seem to grasp fully what made the earlier version of descent 2 great.  They had stumbled upon the right weapons, movement and weapon feel for a great party multiplayer game because the weapons were so bloody devious.  If you were not so good at the game you could spam smart mines around doors and in halways and rack up the kills, or you could go for the earthshaker and get a room full of people who were busy fighting one another and cackle maniacally.  To use an analoguef from another game - think about the blue shell in mario kart vs the earth shaker in descent 2.   It gave weaker players hilarious ways to get back at the 3D spaceship flying gods of descent.  That equalization between low skill vs high skill players has been removed and sadly overload is basically a high skill loaded game.

Overload as a game is a real mixed bag, they captured somewhat the feel of the descent games but the game overall feels very sterile because there has been almost 20 years of game evolution since Descent 2 in 1996.  Descent 2 being the best version from a game mechanic standpoint.

Overload is only inspired by descent and unfortunately you can feel it in the end result with the weapons.  Many of the weapons for overload weren't really thought out too much.  That and many of the quirks from descent 2's homing system were actually to descent 2's benefit in multiplayer.  Basically back when descent 2 was released early in 3D videocard history, there was a framerate bug that made homing bullets lock in on you better the higher your framerate on the 3dfx version of the game.  The great thing about that was though was it increased the challenge of the game, I remember roaming through the halls of minreva and having smart missle bullets and gold smart mine bullets everywhere.  When you turned down the fps, many of the homing bullets were trivial to dodge thereby making them useless.  This is one of those wonderful accidents of history that was missed, unlike what happened with quake and bunny hopping where the movement momentum bug in quake became integrated into the game.

The overload campaign is nothing to write home about and tragically the things that were actually good about descent's single player have been forgotten by the devs, like huge endbosses at the end of levels.  The things that were actually the high points of descent 2 single player.

The story in Overload is bizarre to say the least, they created a great feeling universe that is undone with the last acts of the game as the story writer is too obsessed with crazy nerd theories regarding collective superhuman AI consciousness.  So all the atmosphere they built up with the voice acting and the feel of the universe, comes undone in the last few acts.

Overload is not a bad game, but don't go in expecting a true "Descent 4".  Descent overload isn't, Overload is really a hybrid of all the worst aspects of D1 with all the worst aspects of modern progession based weapon design.

The thing that made descent what it was, was the battle for the powerups and the weapon/missle powerups that allowed low skill players to also have fun which is totally missing in overload tragically if you have any inkling to play its multiplayer.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961563809', 'num_games_owned': 98, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 2194, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1240, 'last_played': 1671079325}
review:
[h1]Welcome back 1998[/h1]

Ahh 6dof, how I've missed thee.  Since the days I was running Kali in Dos with a 14.4k modem, I've been playing descent online.  I took a long break, as did many others over the years.  Went to different games.  Got hooked on Overwatch for the last 2 years (600 hours on Reinhardt) but lately, it's been a struggle.  I was then hit with an epiphany, it's the game.

Multiplayer in Overload is a completely different vibe.  Overwatch gets frustrating, because usually when you lose it's your knucklehead team mates.  In Overdrive, [b]YOU ARE ONLY RESPONSIBLE FOR YOURSELF[/b].  When you lose or do poorly in Overdrive, you end up admiring your opponents skills and techniques.  There's nobody else to blame but you.  Everyone types "GG" after a game.  

[b] a primer on 6dof[/b]

6dof stands for "Six Degrees of Freedom".  In most shooters, you run along the ground, and point your gun at people.  6dof games offer something substantially different.  The ability to rise from the ground and move in any direction.   Probably the closest thing that can describe it would be First person drones, but in a zero-g environment.

[b] Gameplay[/b]

The pre-release game contains both single player campaigns, and if you ask nicely from various sources, a multiplayer component.  In 2 days of this review, it will be included in the release. In addition to these game modes, there's also a "Challenge Mode" where wave after wave of enemies with ever increasing difficulty come after you. 

You fly a small spaceship that's equipped with a variety of main weapons, that come in 2 flavors, energy and ballistic.  The ammo for either can be used on a fairly nice spectrum of guns.  You have plain lasers, a charge laser, shotgun, flak.   On the secondary side you have missiles or bombs.  Missile pods are small missiles with rudimentary tracking.  Hunters are full homing.  There's also a time bomb that in campaign or challenge mode creates bullet time, slowing down the gameplay giving you crucial time to lay some robots to waste.

[b]Controls[/b]

Developers did a fantastic job capturing the feel of the original descent.  This is probably the most important aspect of this game is the controls.  There's a lot of things you have to turn off to get the original trichord control style, but it's in there.  The controls menu offers a plethora of mappable controls, and even an analog axis recalibration tool.   Very very nice.  I can't talk this up enough.

[b]Multiplayer[/b]

This is really what it's all about, and will make or break any game these days.  Multiplayer will be harder for newcomers, because a lot of the people playing this game have been playing similar games since 98' (Wow, 20 years!)  but if you're up for a challenge, this game has already gotten the seal of approval from all these old 6dof "pilots" I'm no top tier, but even when I lose like I said above, nobody gets mad.  

There's a total of 3 modes for multiplayer.  Team vs Team, 1 VS 1, and deathmatch.  All of these modes are fairly self explanatory.  

I do find some critique with the multiplayer though.   The original gamebrowser in Descent 2 was great.  Joining games in progress that had no time limit was great too.  Not really a fan of the queuing system, but for all intents and purposes it works.

[b]Graphics[/b]

Very nice.  Sparks fly out of damaged robots, and when things die there's a giant explosion of sparks flying everywhere.  It's sort of like watching the death star blow up. Settings will allow you to do everything from run your graphics card cool, to cooking breakfast on it.

[b]Overall[/b]
5 out of 5.  A game like this hasn't been made in a while, and it's every bit the successor to the game that inspired it.¬† If you've never tried a 6dof game, start here.¬† If you're an old Descent Pilot looking for a new place to hang your helmet, hang it here.¬† Everyone from the old days are here.

[h3]Shouts[/h3]

Dev team, fantastic!
JediLuke
Pooterman
Birdseye
foxgguy2001
Lioness
TankGirl
Caffiene
Kiln

and all the other oldtimers I'll be running into :)

review: Amazing fun. Lots of options. Personally I can't stop playing the Challenge mode. It's great fun trying to get high scores on the leaderboards. The missions are not as complex as Descent 3 (the 3 that I've played so far) but they provide adequate fun as well. I'm not in the multiplayer beta but watching streames- can't wait to play it. Solid game, well worth the money. If this was any other studio they'd be charging at least $50 for this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020282818', 'num_games_owned': 667, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 983, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 818, 'last_played': 1667328193}
review:
This is the type of game that has been missing in the modern gamespace - a twitchy, full-freedom shooter that the best of the best (Descent is the daddy of all 6DOF games) pulled together from the ashes of Interplay/Parallax and reminded us all of a time when placement, velocity, direction and loadout all mattered intuitively.  

Overload is a game of sublime movement and shooting, quite bare-bones in the EA release but what is there is bunkers and reactors & other industrial-looking corridors that pour out occasionally into caves and lava flows, teeming with deadly bots that sometimes seem cunning, sometimes wildly erratic.  I have spent many quick 15 minute sessions with the challenge levels climbing the internet leaderboards, and have played the single player campaign maps all several times and can't wait for the full release.  In whatever mode, the game makes well for short bursts and long runs, and can be quite addictive if you wish to be tops.

The biggest promise this game has is its' as-of-yet fully detailed or released level editor (probably not out at launch either) and the robustness of the campaign.  For the price i would say it is a fair risk even if the level editor ends up being a year away, what is in the Early Access at this point is well enough to recommend for those that loved the 6DOF games of yesteryear, this truly feels like the best tribute and extension that could be.  For those that require an open, moddable level editor may want to wait to see how that pans out.  Multiplayer should allow for plenty of replay value and play well beyond what the campaign alone and challenge maps will bring while we wait.

It's a blast and one of the most sorely missed types of games imo, and it is so great to see it back and represented so well.  For FPS gamers of all types, especially those willing to add another dimension to their thinking, this is it.  Get Overload!

author: {'steamid': '76561197993314533', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2348, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1196, 'last_played': 1619492824}
review:
6dof action in a modern engine, significantly more polished than similar titles still in development. Move in any direction, stop on a dime, fly around obstacles, and try to take down foes who can do the same, in claustrophic environments full of hazards. The ceiling is lava.

It's a different sort of frantic first-person shooter where eveyone can fly, with a single-player mode focused on exploration. You may find yourself upside down with no idea where you are. Bring Dramamine.

Pros:

It feels great, controls great. Every pro of Descent I and II slots in here alongside much-improved mouse support (to be expected after 20 years). Robust single-player, now with a plot beyond a text blurb prologue, ranked online multiplayer, and a Challenge Mode score attack against AI on the multiplayer maps.

You kill robots (Autonomous Operators, or "Auto-Ops"), pick up energy and shields (*cough* armor) in the form of yellow and blue orbs, and expand your arsenal across single-player levels. Two varieties of upgrade points, often found in secret areas and awarded for rescuing hostages, add minor RPG elements in the form of weapon and ship upgrades that persist between levels.

Cons:

This is a revival of Descent II more or less as it existed, with minor modern touches. If you're looking for an evolution of the format in terms of setting and objectives, Outrage Games released the somewhat-different Descent 3 in 1999. This game doesn't push the envelope so much as it dusts it off.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971530952', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1180, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 438, 'last_played': 1554696668}

author: {'steamid': '76561197972939374', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 94496, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15325, 'last_played': 1704206559}
review:
I once had a dream about a modern Descent game. That dream is now a reality. 

This is the game the Descent fans have been waiting for and even though it doesn't have the Descent name, it does have its developers and that is what matters. The game doesn't only feel good, it feels better than Descent. The weapons feel impactful and strong, the robots are menacing and provide quite a challenge. Overload has 5 main difficulty levels with one extra "secret" difficulty. The different difficulties make sure that a wide variety of players with different skill levels can have a fun and fairly challenging time. 

The single player campaign levels we've had a chance to play in early access have been very promising. In addition to the classic Descent style mine clearing and secret hunting, there is now an upgrade system, so your playthroughs can actually vary a fair bit depending on which types of weapon and ship upgrades you choose to specialise in.

The visuals in this game are great. The modern game engine allows for some very impressive visual effects which truly bring the game alive and make it very atmospheric. The lighting in particular is great. Firing a flare down a dark cave system or seeing a robot's headlight coming around a corner in a dark tunnel is truly something special.

Overload also comes with two "challenge modes". "Infinite" is essentially a last stand survival mode. Robots keep spawning and you have to survive for as long as possible while destroying as many robots as possible. "Countdown" has a 5 minute timer, destroy as many bots as you can and try to survive until the end. Once the 5 minutes runs out, your ship blows up and it's game over. Both modes have online leaderboards, so there is definitely a competetive aspect to it. The modes do have some luck-based elements such as powerup spawns. If you get a bunch of invulnerability powerups, you're most likely going to score higher. Such elements can be quite frustrating for the really competitive players. Overall the challenge mode is a very fun experience where you can really push your limits.

Finally there's the Multiplayer. Currently there are two game modes Anarchy and Team-anarchy, essentially deathmatch and team-deathmatch. Weapons are altered from their single player counter-parts for balance reasons.

Multiplayer beta plays really quite well as long as you have low ping. Currently the multiplayer uses official matchmaking servers that are in different parts of the world. The servers seem to be good quality and connected to the German server I got ping ranging from 30-50 while connecting from Estonia with a 100/100 Mbps connection. To the North American East Coast server my ping was 120-140 and West Coast was 180-200.

Overall this game is definite recommend for me. If you liked the Descent games, I'm sure you'll have a blast with this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023468645', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2072, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 574, 'last_played': 1572828635}
review: Despite having only a few minutes of playtime recorded so far, I'm filled with such excitement to sit down for a full gaming session with this bad-boi. I was hit with a flush of glorious nostalgia and joy within the first few moments of flying around, but lo and behold, my Logitech Pro Joystick took a big ol' crap on my fun and now I'm waiting for a new joystick of a different type and manufacturer in the mail. If it's any indication of how fun this game feels, it influenced me to spend $60 on peripherals with just 10 minutes of playing. It's not of the same complexity and depth of a game like Star Citizen or anything like that, but more like a high quality arcade-style game where you can sit down, get your game on, feel great, and look forward to coming back and getting into the game and not worrying about things like you would in some game of a grander scale. For the price as it is right now, I'd recommend anyone who likes flying a ship around to jump on this, but I feel it's worth mentioning that I don't play these sort of games without a joystick/flightstick. Good stuff!

author: {'steamid': '76561197963861761', 'num_games_owned': 412, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 820, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 158, 'playtime_at_review': 63, 'last_played': 1711371848}
review:
If you liked Descent, stop reading now and buy it.

This game is a fantastic spiritual successor to Descent 1 and 2. You have the full six degrees of freedom to move your ship around, and it has full VR support. I was giddy with glee after playing just one level.

Be warned, this game will scare you at times; bots have been known to sneak up and surprise me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198297338531', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 177, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 66, 'last_played': 1600336602}
review:
This game is superb. its not to complex, yet not to simple. it maintains all the aspects of the Descent games to which it suceddes, adds some usefull new features (like the map), simple, blocky graphics that still look beautiful; an art style that triggers nostalgia in me as a big fan of Freespace. the gameplay is smooth and fluid, controls are mostly intuitive; and customisable if you dont feel they are. for an early acces game im quite impressed so far.

overall a solid 8/10. graphics didnt exactly blow me away, but the gameplay is excelent and the nostalgia is real. A true successer to Descent. 

I wish the developers the best of luck and hope they rake in enough cash to buy the freespace IP back... becasue the ammount of $$$ i would drop on freespace 3 if they made it....

author: {'steamid': '76561198013020097', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 174, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 94, 'last_played': 1706136573}
review: 22 years ago, when you played Descent with your SimulEyes shutter glasses you just caught a glimpse on what Descent looks like. Today playing Overload in VR (with the Vive, mouse and keyboard) is how (the spirit of) Descent really looks like and it is amazing! 6DOF with full 3D vision of the environment at 90FPS simply puts you inside the space craft and the world of Descent. This is where you always wanted to be and finally you can be part of this world!

author: {'steamid': '76561197981772565', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 8202, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1694, 'last_played': 1710790479}
review:
If you're reading this then you're probably a 6DoF fan. Let's see... what games have we had to enjoy lately?

‚óè [i]Miner Wars 2081[/i] could've been interesting but was actually a horrible, unpolished (and arguably unfinished) mess.
‚óè [i]Sublevel Zero[/i] added procedural levels, gear crafting, and unlockables into the equation to become a pleasant enough distraction, but never a real contender.
‚óè [i]Elite: Dangerous - CQC[/i] is a polished multiplayer 6DoF experience but is also a totally different beast from Descent.
‚óè [i]Everspace[/i] is fun, but with more Roguelike elements and open space instead of claustrophobic tunnels, the vibe is once again very different.
‚óè Hmm, and I guess there's [i]Descent: Underground[/i]. Let's just not go there.

For anyone who savours the simple joy of turning evil robots into smoking piles of scrap in twisty underground mines, It's been a withering drought of nearly 19 years since Descent 3 released in June 1999. After so long we'd probably be happy for [i]any[/i] half-decent spiritual successor - fortunately for us, though, Revival didn't simply set their sights on half-decent.

I'll just say what any sane person can obviously see. [b]In all but name, Overload is the Descent 4 we've been waiting so long for.[/b] The ship handling is incredibly responsive with masses of options to customise everything to your liking, whether you're using keyboard only, M+KB, or joystick, or some combination of those. The visual design is sparse but consistent, with gorgeous lighting and explosion effects that make destroying stuff a delight. Weapons are varied and all have their uses without being overly situational. Audio is brilliantly immersive and well-balanced.

Overall, the game just *feels* right. Don't believe me? Play the PT! Don't trust the videos alone because the encoding doesn't do it justice.

The drought is over. There's materials that need defending. Are you prepared to descend?

author: {'steamid': '76561197975744174', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 876, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1, 'playtime_at_review': 195, 'last_played': 1711649731}

author: {'steamid': '76561197980315993', 'num_games_owned': 593, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 337, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 272, 'last_played': 1605371397}

author: {'steamid': '76561197969661553', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2488, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 78, 'last_played': 1557807699}
review:
Forget the rest, this is the Descent successor you need to get.  Descent I and Descent II were easily my most played games of all time.  Hundreds and hundreds of teenage hours poured in to those 6 degrees of freedom.  I wouldn't hesitate for a second to say the Descent series were my all-time favorite games.  Even in recent years I would dig out my old CDs and boot up a engine replacement and blast some bots.  The Descent II soundtrack has a permanent place on my iPhone MP3 list and I listen to it all the time.  Back in the day I used to spend HOURS in Polyedit and HAMM and Yahoma and Descent Manager trying to make my own mission pack.  I was on the Descent Editors mail list, and even contributed voice work to a fan-made mission pack that was on the Silent Threat add-on for Descent: Freespace.  That's how much of a Descent fan I am.

Other Descent-alikes have come and go, some were fun, some were okayish.  The new Descent that was Kickstarted a couple years ago was a good attempt but still doesn't feel "right" to me.

This.  This game feels RIGHT.  The bots, the maps, the weapons, the sounds, the music, the fluidity of the controls.  It's all Descent.  This game could be Descent IV and you'd never even question it for a second, heck, it'd probably be considered better than Descent III.  The first map just blew me away.  It was like I was teleported back to 1995 being 13 and playing Descent I for the first time.

CanNOT wait for more!

author: {'steamid': '76561197980938572', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1936, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 245, 'last_played': 1680797457}
review: Oh emm gee.  I'm in love.  Like Descent of the early days, but better.  Flashier levels, cooler enemies.  Multiple levels of difficulty.  Still short because they're in early access.  "No log messages during early access."  But I'm looking forward to the release.

English translation:
Well, yes, my friends! We're going to wait 20 years, but finally it was born! This is REAL DESCENT! The feeling, the sight, the mood, the music, the effects are all the same as in the original, first Descent - but in absolute contemporary quality.
The game is flawless (ok, some tiny things need to improve, but it's under development), thoughtful, clever, heart-souled professional work. Beautiful spectacle, fearful enemies with excellent AI, simple but challenging gameplay, a clear menu system, full customization, and excellent hardware support.
ABSOLUTE RECOMMENDED! For Descent-fans REQUIRED !! Although its name is different, it has been the best Descent ever - including similar attempts.

Many thanks for the developer team!

author: {'steamid': '76561197983020667', 'num_games_owned': 96, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 10125, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2612, 'last_played': 1660264567}
review:
This game is a blast. It's still in Early Access, which means you can still get a deal on it. Given the developer's track record (They wrote Descent and Descent II) I think it's safe to say that it will release on time (which right now is forecast for May). I am very much looking forward to when they release multiplayer. 

The game looks great, feels great, is great. The bot AIs are very well done, they look great, and are a real challenge as you scale up the difficulty. If you're a fan of the old Descent games, you'll love this game. A solid 9.5/10 in my estimation.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060601878', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 117, 'playtime_forever': 8017, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1422, 'playtime_at_review': 568, 'last_played': 1712420987}
review:
The general feeling, the level design, even the music, they are all so familiar. 
It has modern graphics but it feels like it didn't lose anything from it's core. I feel like crying now, this is so nostalgic.

This IS the Descent I know from my childhood.

Not just that, it has even improved upon the classic's formula with new features like being able to upgrade your ship.


Edit: There is a campaign mod that remade the Descent 1 levels in Overload, with Overload's robots, weapons and upgrade system.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025210074', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1755, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 646, 'last_played': 1688581703}

PS... You had to include those damn scorpions, didn't you... ;-)

author: {'steamid': '76561197992673878', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 1179, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 209, 'last_played': 1640476735}
review:
Descent 4 in all but name. Loses the more open concept levels from Descent 3, but that's not necessarily a bad thing as this returns to Descent 1's roots. 

Seriously, if you liked Descent at all back in the day or tried them recently and liked them, GET THIS. It truly is the spiritual successor we've all been waiting for.

author: {'steamid': '76561198259452697', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2270, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2236, 'last_played': 1590989521}
review: Within about 2 seconds of starting, my fingers remembered how to map my keys the way I had them setup for Descent in 1995. I'm so glad that the devs absolutely nailed this, and didn't mess with anything that made the original so great. Outstanding. Runs like butter on my Mac.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018759231', 'num_games_owned': 3828, 'num_reviews': 512, 'playtime_forever': 10462, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1061, 'last_played': 1624212793}
review:
I was not ready for such awesomeness...
I'm literally speechless about how good this is.

I'm having a blast like it's the late nineties again.
It's been years since i had so much enjoyment playing a videogame and i played many...

The gameplay is great, it's smooth, the weapons are pretty good you feel very empowered using them, killing the ennemy ships /robots is rewarding, the level design is fantastic.
Overall flying with the ship is like a fusional relationship. 

I'm playing on both regular monitor & in vr, this game is a masterpiece.
It's simply the best six degrees of freedom game since Descent 3.

These developers put their heart and soul into this game and you can feel it the second you start playing it.
The only thing I dislike in Overload is that we cannot set FOV above 90¬∞.
If only there was options for 100-110 FOV it would have been perfect.

Probably my new 2018 best game !
Rating 9.5/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970789401', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 256, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 164, 'last_played': 1550170494}
review:
I...

What!? How? Really? Is it back?

No other "remake" or "re-imagining" can hold a candle to this. I wish I could shave 20 years off of my age and be at the same store I bought the originals. Oh, the awe, the anticipation to return home holding the brand new box and on to install it on my 486 precious rig.

It is finally back, and it's better than ever. Not just the feeling, but the gameplay as well.

[11-3-18]: As I get deeper into the game, I'd attach this post I made in the forum:

[i]It's a shame...

...that this game isn't widely marketed to the public.

Not only does it satisfy the "nostalgia crave", not only is this a perfect emulation of the Descent of yore (no wonder with the guys -legends- at the helm), it's a lesson in contemporary games design. It encompasses multiple genres (FPS, flightsim, stealth and tactics) and distills them into a unified, solid experience. Like we were used to in an era long gone by. :)

What Doom '16 did, this one does better. Spread the word!

I have had the game lingering in my wishlist for several months, among the usual "roguelite /pixel art/ metroidvania/ 'remake' and 'enhanced edition' shovel. Little do I know of picking actual, real gems.[/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561197995852977', 'num_games_owned': 1690, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 199, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 56, 'last_played': 1627514115}
review: Great game, very simple fun. A joystick helps but even with mk/b it's just such pure entertainment flying around and blasting robots with flashy lasers. It *is* just a Decent clone, but Decent is a damn good game, so that works fine. I do mean clone though, it's a straight recreation like I've never seen before, to the point where it's so damn faithful that it's just neat rather than feeling cheap. Game is hard as balls though without cheesing everything super hard, be prepared to knock down the difficulty to the the third option out of five even if you're used to playing everything on the hardest difficulty.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012101852', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 3914, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 596, 'last_played': 1609078030}

author: {'steamid': '76561198027911565', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 601, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 341, 'last_played': 1697999056}
review:
So, that might sound a bit silly, since this game is a successor of Descent 1+2, no question here, but I think that this is also the closest you can get to something like DOOM 2 or Quake or the Duke. In a way, it is that kind of oldschool, and they made so many correct descisions in development where almost all other developers fell through or missed the mark by a few centimeters.

The whole thing starts with the startup. You are looking at no logos, no unskippable animations, no advertisement. Nothing. A load screen you are in the main menu. As simple as that may sound, this is pure delight.
This continues within the game in an unapologetic way. It feels as the developers implemented a "No-nonsense" doctrine. Items, powerups, weapons, level design. Especially the latter: If this may be too much of 3D at the start, as it was for me, go out of your way and try to adapt. Even though I played the games of old, my brain forgot how challenging this was. That is 20 years of dumbed down FPS.

Gameplay is fast and balanced as it used to be, but not without challenge. Sometimes, the learning curve is steep, but, as you reading this, chances that this is something new to you are slim. I read the following somewhere in another corner of this site: "Rapid unscheduled disassembly". That is an accurate description. Everything considered, the developers mastered that part.

The level aesthetics, however, could use a bit more variation. Some single levels do indeed look more varied, which shows that it is fundamentally possible, so there is hope that more of this this will translate over to the final campaign. As the levels are now, this is my only real criticism on the game. There are wow-effects however, when suddenly the crowded space opens up and gives room to a - vastly - bigger interior. More of that large scale contrast would be nice.

Overall, graphics are excellent. They deliver exactly what they should, whit added emphasis on beautiful explosion. Soundtrack is lovely and the sound effects are colorful, too. While writing this, it strikes me that
I cannot remember the last game which had a soundtrack. From the not too distant past, just can remember games with ambient tracks or sequenced samples, so this came as a nice surprise.

Controls are awesome. I know that there are several people out there who think that a HOTAS setup is the way to go, and it indeed might be for them, but this comes from a convinced mouse+keyboard user. I think it just works, it does not get in the way and after an enormous short amount of time, thinking about it disappears, which is the greatest compliment I can offer for gaming controls.

This is the only early access title I own, which is telling. I played the demo and that was it. It feels like a finished game - with just the full content missing. If this was 1994, the early access title would be equivalent of a shareware release and, consequently, the mail order game is what this will hopefully be at Version 1.0.

Highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198148974553', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 98, 'playtime_forever': 1577, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 728, 'last_played': 1682356060}
review:
This review is for the VR version.......

AMAZING AND ADDICTIVE are 2 words that spring to mind instantly.  Man i love this game!! (even in early access) 
I thought i would play this on ACE diffeculty setting which is 1 setting harder than default so i could make the game last longer coz of its early access status and boy oh boy it gets hard real quick and i love it. 

Graphics are nice and runs very well....

Music is spot on, really gets u in the zone, sound and ambiance also spot on.....

There is just 1 thing i would like to see in the full release.....

LIke when u blow an enemy up the debris would float straight through u,  would be a whole lot better if it bounces off your ship( oh and you do have cockpit now unlike the pics ) but thats really a minor.

These types of games ( 6dof ) are perfect for VR i hope to see alot more of them in the future,  anyways great job to Revival Productions keep up the good work,  cant wait till full release but highly playable and fun as is.

Only an hour and a half into the game so far, but am absolutely loving it! Can't wait for the final release --- and, of course, the multiplayer ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561197996739663', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 121, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 105, 'last_played': 1657998916}
review: I'm putting a stake in the ground: Overload is without question the best 'Descent' game since Descent 2 was released all the way back in 1996. Forget about Descent: Underground, Overload is the rightful heir to the Descent legacy. This game is exactly what a modern revival of the 6DOF genre should be. The controls are great. The feel of movement is great. The graphics are phenomenal, and I can't say enough about just how well optimized this game is. It runs butter smooth. Even the soundtack is excellent. I really don't have a single complaint. It's fantastic!

author: {'steamid': '76561198036868895', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1366, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 67, 'last_played': 1710559030}
review: I'm an original Descent gamer from 1995 and still play the original.  I have been waiting for this forever and didn't find it until today.  This is an epic continuation of the tradition and excitement.  Can't wait for multiplayer and deathmatch!

author: {'steamid': '76561198037461114', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 6364, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 179, 'last_played': 1662118295}
review:
You have no idea how happy I was to see this existed.

And it's made by the guys who originally made Descent!
What you see is what you get.

If Descent 1 & 2 were done in this day and age, this would be it.
The moment I saw Rift support, I was extatic. While the Rift doesn't enhance the experience greatly, it is still something I appreciate seeing greatly.

Considering that this is a price point at which I would've definitely bought the original 2 Descent games when they came out, this is definitely a fair price for what you get.

Keep in mind, I am two levels in, just got to my second reactor.


Pros: 
-It's Descent, but new again
-Rift support
-Great soundtrack, not that this is exactly surprising from this franchise
-More weapons than I've ever seen in a Descent game. Keep in mind, I have not played Descent 3.
-Graphics very close to the original, if it were fully rendered with ambient occlusion, screen space reflections, bloom, a proper lighting system, bumpmaps/normalmaps. Most of the mining robots have kept familiar shapes, but they look infinitely better.

Cons:
-High probability that mouse acceleration is being used. Still a step up from previous games when it comes to mouse support though.
-Does not like ASW one bit, though I would attribute that to ASW being ASW more than anything else.
-Framerates can vary greatly. I've found turning off AO and anistropic filtering didn't yeld terrible results graphically, and improved framerates greatly.
-Bloom cannot be fully disabled from in-game menus.
-You don't have a physical body. You are an empty, haunted ship.
(To the developpers of the game, I'm just mentioning this because it's fairly jarring to look down to an empty seat in VR)

.. That's about all there is to it. It's everything I expected so far, and I'm very happy with it.

Note to VR users: 
If you're complaining about experiencing great motion sickness in this game..
It shouldn't even be a surprise at this point. Game was already confusing in 2D at first.

Would probably be one of those people who would bash a game about being an astronaut because it made them sick.

News flash: Astronauts are trained to handle these things. 
That means you can be too, and should expect your endurance to be tested in zero grav scenarios.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980644667', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 795, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 514, 'last_played': 1604074207}
review:
I'm normally not publishing any evaluation prior to release, but the game is already awesome and a complete successor to Descent 1, 2 & 3. I'll probably update this one once released and I have completed the campaign.

Very smooth movement, some nice default controls (upper mouse wheel to manage primary weapon, lower mouse wheel to manage secondary, really good idea !), cool maps, oppressive atmosphere and *totally* awesome sound tracks !

Also, extremelly agressive robots.

It really seems to be Descent, next generation.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046447302', 'num_games_owned': 392, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 725, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 249, 'last_played': 1584625130}

author: {'steamid': '76561198053666158', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 274, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 170, 'last_played': 1706404795}
review:
Man I wish I knew about this game a year ago, I've been waiting nearly 20 years for a proper Descent sequel. It looks good (both graphically speaking and stylistically speaking) and more importantly it feels good. The movement mechanics feel great and there are tons of options to help tweak the control and flight system to your preference. 

I haven't sunk too much time into the game yet but I have noticed both the weapon sets and enemies bear some resemblance to those in the original Descent games while still being fresh and interesting. One enemy bot type will charge at you with a buzzsaw type weapon (similar to but more aggressive than the classic claw-drill enemies).

Long story short, this game looks like it'll be everything a modern Descent game should strive to be.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999145607', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 16782, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 159, 'last_played': 1687196242}
review:
Still a bit early to tell, and the physics might not be exactly Descent 1 (which I am sure some people will be turned off by); But the game is shaping up to be the best spiritual successor to the Descent franchise and 6DOF games as a whole. With Multiplayer and the level editor coming soon, this game might actually take hold of players longer then most of the other games that have came out in this 6DOF renaissance that has occured over the last 5 years (albeit a lot of the 6DOF games that have come out are all solid in their own rights). This might be the game that actually attracts a younger newer audience like the original game did back in 1994.

Currently it is only single player with 4 or 5 single player missions done, and a huge selection of survival maps with interesting waves of enemies, bosses, upgrades, and a variety of online difficulty score boards for each map. Even with this, you get a feel for the guns, the AI, the flying machanics, and some level layouts that show off their new cube system for maps. I'd say, wait for release if you can (because thats when the multiplayer should start rolling out), or get it now and enjoy some nice score board competition with friends.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007595394', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 248, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28, 'last_played': 1587227222}

author: {'steamid': '76561197969500864', 'num_games_owned': 392, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 3623, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 393, 'last_played': 1602208112}
review:
In short: 

This game is literally Descent. You may make your own mind up as to whether or not that's a recommendation.

To go into more detail:

Were you born in the late 80s or early 90s? Did play flight-sim/shoot-'em-up hybrids like Hellbender and Descent religiously? Do you enjoy the thought of guiltlessly murdering a variety of hovering robots with a colourful selection of guns and missiles? Do you like flying around in extremely constrained spaces?

Congratulations - you will love this game!

When I write reviews on Steam, I try to shy away from the whole "if you liked X, then you'll love this game" clich√©, but in this case I think it's appropriate. If you liked Descent or any of its direct sequels, you will very likely love this game, because it's literally just Descent but with better graphics. All the guns and missiles are more or less straight ports of weapons from the old games with new names. The robots are different to some degree, but even there I could see some obvious design similarities. Everything is more or less the same.

This also includes the claustrophobic, labyrinthine level design, the dozens of genuinely secret secret areas in each level, the fast-paced, nerve-racking gameplay and a pretty period-accurate soundtrack. The controls need a little bit of work here and there, but they're generally as tight and responsive as I remember then being back when I was 9 and only very slightly worse at video games than I am at 29.

Beyond a fairly simple upgrade system, this game makes no real attempt to innovate on the Descent formula. The slight changes it makes to core systems from the old games feel like additions that should always have been there. And for fans of Descent 3, I should say that aside from the general look and feel of the game, this game cribs far more heavily from Descent 1 and Descent 2 than the third installment. You shouldn't expect any wide-open outdoor spaces, mission control updates or gigantic set-piece boss fights in this game.

I had genuine fun playing the four missions currently available for this game, and it's one of the few Early Access titles I felt was genuinely worth my money. I can't say for sure whether you'll feel the same. This game is decidedly a nostalgia trip, and if you were never a fan of Descent or you want something that takes the genre some place new, this game will not satisfy you.

But I loved it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045318350', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 134, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69, 'last_played': 1622808341}
review: Pretty much Forsken.   Forsaken was a 360 flyer released in the mid 90's   same basic concept, but way more advanced graphicly than anything else out there at the time.  Descent 2 wasn't even close to the graphics & speed of Forsaken.  I would even venture to put a VR Forsaken (if it got made) up against this.  I havent delved into any of the multiplayer stuff as of yet, but if it's anything like Forsaken was I will be enjoying many hours of gameplay. I'll give this a solid 8/10.  I'd rate it higher, but quite a few situations are entirely too dark, and the flight control options are limited and wonky.  Play in seated position and be able to map to a flight stick... that would rock.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058234808', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 51, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 51, 'last_played': 1514947278}
review:
[h1]Joystick dran, Belegung konfiguriert und es ist wie fr√ºher mit Descent![/h1]

Habe total viel Spa√ü und f√ºhle mich viele Jahre zur√ºck versetzt als ich sehr viel Descent (I + II) gespielt habe. Da wird auch gerade was entwickelt (Descent: Underground), aber leider gibt es da noch keine Solo-Kampange.

In VR leidet die Performance leider ein wenig. Es gibt bei mir einen Input-Lag mit dem Joystick, so dass ich es derzeit nicht in VR Spiele. (Oculus Rift mit Saitek X52 + Tastatur)

Das Leveldesign gef√§llt mir (bin zwar aktuell noch in den ersten, aber ich erkenne die Elemente von fr√ºher). Gegner sind auch mal hinter eine S√§ule oder in einem Verschlag. Manchmal √∂ffnen sich T√ºren hinter einem, und ein weitere Gegner taucht auf. Sch√∂ne Momente, wie fr√ºher eben!

Von mir eine klare Empfehlung f√ºr alle, die Descent geliebt und gespielt haben und f√ºr alle, die mal einen Shooter mit richtiger Bewegungsfreiheit spielen wollen.

Ich hoffe, die Entwickler bleiben am Ball und erhalten das gute Descent Feeling und schaffen eine gute VR-Performance. Ist ja im Early Access!

author: {'steamid': '76561197997628741', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 178, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18, 'last_played': 1542739064}
review:
I loved Descent as an adolescent, and Overload ticks all the right boxes. It's got incredible looking maps, a nice variety of weapons that pack a punch while also being fairly balanced, colorful enemies with different tactics to dissuade a single form of gameplay, and more. If you were a fan of Descent, you'll feel right at home.

If you never played Descent, be aware of some of its challenges. It's very easy to get lost on the maps, especially as you're trying to make your escape. Some areas have cues to help, but they're a bit inconsistent on that front. Harder difficulty levels mean a LOT of dodging, and the lack of an NPC paradigm of consequence means that if you're not playing multiplayer, you're going to feel a bit lonely.

All in all, an excellent game that's well worth its cost, and props for the developers for keeping the core tenets of such a great game in what is more than simply a reskin or a nostalgia grab, but a great game in its own right.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072997539', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 129, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 92, 'last_played': 1577561623}
review:
I haven't got the brainpower at the moment to write a full review, but I can say without a doubt the game has a solid foundation as far as gameplay is concerned.

If I had to say what I liked least, I'd have to say the levels. They feel characterless and confined. In descent 3, the levels were big, important chapters of the game, each feeling distinct. Switzers lab, the city, mars, the battleship, the prooving grounds--all of them had their own feel and shape. And they all took a good amount of time to get through too, but whether or not that's a good thing is up to debate.

The enemies feel less important too. I could barely tell what I was fighting let alone pay the distinction any mind. The most I could tell was that one of them attacked via ramming.

Once again, to compare to descent 3: The little blue police-looking robots which told you to freeze, The big screeching brutes, the ones with the claws, the soldiers, the flying squid things, the gunslingers. All of these had character. 

In Overload they've been downgraded to making simple noises and all looking relativly the same.

Now, I know reading this you might think I don't like it: I've only been playing for 30 minuets max. This opinion could be garbage. However, I wanted to mention these things and add a "+1 reccomended" to the counter. (and lets face it, I couldn't do that without writing a barebones review, lest someone tell me off for "Not contributing anything.")

author: {'steamid': '76561198361774256', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 125, 'playtime_forever': 1220, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1159, 'last_played': 1586636020}

author: {'steamid': '76561198049171274', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 120, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 120, 'last_played': 1514265592}
review:
Descent was my all time favorite game in the early '90s and this game definitely bears all the hallmarks of the original - even the sounds and music are familiar! I only played the training mission and one level and I can already say with conviction that Overload is a worthy succesor to the Descent trilogy.

Several games have tried to emulate the things that made Descent great with varying degrees of success (Sublevel Zero, Strike Vecor, Miner Wars) but nothing beats the origninal developers. 

I can't wait to see this game when it is finished! Material Defender flies again, maybe this time he'll actually collect his pay?

author: {'steamid': '76561198015783511', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 785, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 140, 'last_played': 1531256827}
review:
Unlike Underground this feels like a real Descent game.

Work perfrect in VR, Vive + Steam Controller.

Minor nitpicks: energy is yellow and armor is blue - I wish it was vice-versa; I wish there was an option for a lighter, minimal cockpit (as it is, you can have the cockpit either on or completely off - I play with off, because in VR cockpit covers too much for my liking).

author: {'steamid': '76561198022577535', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 52, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 51, 'last_played': 1531765873}
review:
This Review is only from VR aspects, since the developer gives official VR support.

cons:
-The Cockpit is really boring, no appliances or displays.
-Really BAD Cockpit texture, yes 1 cheap texture for the whole ship... OMG even descent1/2 got a better cockpit -.- (It feels like a placeholder, not immersive in VR at all...)
-Hud is only a overlay, no displays in your ship.
-own Weaponshoots went straight into your cockpit when you strafe your ship.
-no resolution adjustment (Pixel Density/SS) for VR.
-Mission Briefing is only a text file with radiovoice
-no Brightness adjustment for the stupid HUD, Godrays incoming... 
The brightness in graphic settings only adjust the whole game.

pros:
-good weapon sounds
-nice environment sounds
-nice particel effects
-good performance
-good AI

If the developers decide to improve the game, i will update and change my Review.
But at the moment i cant really recommend to buy it, if you looking for a game in VR.

Update1:
-The developer response to my feedback, and announced improvement for HUD and
weaponfire that moving into the cockpit and the missing Pixel Density feature.

Update2:
-Last Patch released few days ago and still no improvements for VR.
Devs told me to wait and promised they working on it after console build is ready.

Anyways i lost faith in Overload, if they not releasing a really great VR improvement update, i just wasted my money, there is no reason for me to play it in this state. :(

Update3:
5 days till release and no VR Updates at all in sight, really sad... dont buy it if you looking for a good polished VR game.

Update4 Release version 1.0:
Final Release Version is out today, No VR improvements at all!
It was all a simple lie, the developer dont put any work to improve this game in early access.
I wish i never backed this game, big disappointment.



There is a fresh updated demo, you can try this out... dont buy this game blind, if you still intrested!

I was a fan from descent1 and 2 and also from forsaken.
Im expected a really good VR game, but the quality isnt there yet and potentialy never gets improved. I hope im wrong here, because i like the genre :(

Dont get fooled by some fanboys, most steamreviews are a joke anyways... 95% positive reviews and im sure that 70% write positive, even about this game in VR but 1 week later all of them playing another game and never come back.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969357482', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 14343, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 759, 'last_played': 1707003593}
review: Very good game, especially for early access. Looks great on my ultra-wide monitor. Feels like Descent.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970731419', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 2051, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1376, 'last_played': 1689785178}
review:
Finally, a true sequel to Descent 3, made by the original Descent team. This absolutely oozes quality, unlike the steaming pile of poo Descent Underground. This looks and feels exactly like Descent but runs like a freakin' racehorse with new technology behind it. Beautiful effects and sound, amazing bot AI, stunning.
Bravo, and thankyou to the team for making it. If you were a fan of the originals just buy it, you won't be dissapointed.

**UPDATE AFTER OFFICIAL RELEASE**

The game is amazing, so polished it shines. Now that I can progress further into it I have encountered incredibly clever new bots, awesome weapons and upgrades. 

The Bot AI particularly impresses. They flank, quietly sneak around behind you, retreat and sucker you into ambushes. And have a creepy ability to navigate even complex cave systems, and use the environment to their advantage. I have jumped out of my seat occasionally like I'm playing Doom when one of them has sneakily surprised me. Spooky!

It's rare to find an early access game so polished. Sure it doesn't have fancy hollywood cut scenes and a story written by Joss Whedon. But most of us just usually skip that stuff anyway. What it does have is distilled to perfection game mechanics, graphics and sound.
Throw in some mind bending navigation puzzles, a long campaign and multiplayer, and it's all you will ever need.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987729486', 'num_games_owned': 655, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 221, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 114, 'last_played': 1542836095}

author: {'steamid': '76561198059395681', 'num_games_owned': 322, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 472, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 106, 'last_played': 1681212939}
review:
EXCELLENT Game !

author: {'steamid': '76561198262819127', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 445285, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 150, 'last_played': 1711096529}
review:
Read other reviews for specifics. Only one thing worth mentioning to add to this wonderful D4 game -> It's fast.

Other kinda-like-games out now, and even D3 when it was released, was slow (not only in gameplay, but also in getting from start-to-game). Overload is quick in gameplay AND in starting up and playing. SO glad for that. I can get in and out without wasting time. And the play is fluid. All games should be so clean. Since I'm a Descent/Freespace fan, I'm glad this one is.

author: {'steamid': '76561198369865541', 'num_games_owned': 13, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 211055, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 736, 'playtime_at_review': 23122, 'last_played': 1712437048}
review: I played the D1 downloadable Demo in '95, ran out and bought it in a store the moment it was available, bought D2 through Paralax when it was first offered, pre-release, and did D3 the same way.  I have backed this since I learned who was developing it.  I have also played several of the "other" wannabe 6DOF fps shooters that are in development, and THIS GAME IS THE BEST OF THE LOT OF THEM!  Ship handling is par excellence!  Controlller support is the best you can find.  The artwork is STUNNING!  The music is off the chain!  The AI is crafty, and sneaky and just awesome.  The random robot spawns and power-up drops make every run through this compelling, riveting.  If you only buy one game this year, this should be it.   Overload is the ONLY physical and spiritual successor to the Descent series.  Feels like the 'team' is putting another one in the endzone.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999136028', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 157, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 156, 'last_played': 1549100000}
review:
OMG! YES! DESCENT FTW!
This is it.
This is the one you want.
This... has been... waited for for a LONG TIME.
This is even actually coded by the actual coders of the original game.
This has a different name than it did originally due to legal issues.
A rose by any other name would smell as sweet.
And this is certainly one you want to have.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076702384', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 3318, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1589, 'last_played': 1695869480}
review: Nominated for the Steam Awards 2017 for "Even better than I expected"! When I play this game I truly feel transported back to the time when I played the original Descent. This game takes that awesome game concept and improves it 1000x! And the dev team keeps adding up new stuff regularly, listening to the community, which makes it even better! :D

author: {'steamid': '76561198045610304', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 12574, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 707, 'last_played': 1639184616}
review:
At last a good Descent successor.

This IS what a game based on Descent SHOULD BE. Overload is a sweet nostalgic trip, it behaves and feels like as the old Descent was, with the plus of amazing visuals and great graphic definition. As a Descent II and Descent 3 veteran, Overload gets my whole positive approval. If you are an experienced Descent pilot, this game will fit your skills, and satisfy your taste for a good 6dof game.

I hope the developers keep up the really good work and take this project to the next step to turn it into a full release.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980096403', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 281, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69, 'last_played': 1608437105}
review: Old gamers that remember Decent will instantly recognize the origins of Overload. The only thing missing is a compelling backstory, but that's not even necessary anymore, is it?

author: {'steamid': '76561197985843700', 'num_games_owned': 766, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 860, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 43, 'last_played': 1693162229}
review:
Was soll ich sagen...

Descent war eines meiner liebsten Spiele als ich klein war. Ich habe jahrelang ein Spiel gesucht das mich so fesselt wie die Alten Descent Teile doch leider vergebens... Descent Underground war meine gr√∂√üte Hoffnung gewesen dieses Feeling wieder aufleben zu lassen aber auch hier Fehlanzeige. Umso eher war ich √ºberrascht als ich Overload gesehen habe. Dieses Spiel hat mich vom ersten Moment an direkt gefesselt, mit genau demselben Flair wie Descent. Musik, Leveldesign das Design der Gegner alles genauso klasse umgesetzt wie im Original und das ganze noch in sch√∂ner Grafik. Overload tr√§gt zwar nicht den Namen den es haben sollte aber es ist meiner Meinung nach der einzig wahre Nachfolger der Descent Reihe. Wer Descent gern gespielt hat dem rate ich zu Overload und selbst im Early Access ist dieses Spiel ein Absolutes muss f√ºr Fans der Spiele Reihe!

author: {'steamid': '76561198420013074', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 624, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 70, 'last_played': 1668134663}
review:
Playing this with a Oculus Rift and Xbox Controller.
The ability to customize the controller to your liking is fantastic and most welcome (I come from primarliy a console background, where this feature was not largely available until PS4 and XboxOne).
Given the amount of praise this game has already received for being the spiritual successor to Descent, I have very little to add to that which alreeady has been said.
Playing this in VR has been a real treat for how well it puts me in the game.  Something that would add to the immersion (for me) would be the addition of windows on the floor and rear. This request was made after experiencing what Eve Valkyrie brings to the table with regards to situational awareness (and there is something to be said to seeing the world pass beneath your feet.
I am anxiously awaiting for when this game will be completed.
Thank you for making a game that not only harkens back to the days of old (yes, I am an 'old fart'), but shows adaptability to the tachnology of today (yes, VR, I'm looking at you)

author: {'steamid': '76561197971256909', 'num_games_owned': 1182, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 372, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22, 'last_played': 1664247399}
review: This game is exactly what I wanted when I heard they were doing an updated Descent like game. The feel of this is just like the original Descent games but with modernized graphics and controls. The nostalga level is just right, the game does enough new to make it feel fresh while keeping enough of the old feel to keep that link to the original. It is as close to Descent 4 as we will ever get without the rights to the Descent name.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049062537', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 499, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 56, 'playtime_at_review': 127, 'last_played': 1712392335}
review:
Overload is a true successor to the classic Decent games and it is wonderful.

Already extremely enjoyable and more so with each early access update, this game nails the 6DOF gameplay/feel and looks great while doing so. Runs excellent on my old i7 2600k and (less old) gtx970.

Highly recomended whether you are a fan of the game's lineage or not.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002773286', 'num_games_owned': 284, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 10188, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1236, 'last_played': 1679780814}
review:
Fluid controls - check
Satisfying kills - check
Crisp graphics - check
Smart & fun AI - check
Sprawling levels - check
Monster closets - check
Lots of secrets - check
Scary trap rooms - check
Level design that actually matters - check

Yeah they nailed it. If you in any way shape or form enjoy classic fps games where the point is to blast your way through a dungeon-like level while you look for the powerups you need (ala doom/quake/descent) then Overload will give you a really good time. It just works, impressively so. This is not a "modernisation". But this is not "stuck in the past" either. This is simply a classic dungeon fps and it works. And it feels relevant.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987010285', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 7274, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 44, 'playtime_at_review': 1600, 'last_played': 1711513757}
review:
For a Game that has yet to be released it sure is getting attention!
I AM a backer!  I was hesitant, yes, but I saw the teaser they released when their Kickstarter success looked grim.  I JUMPED at the chance!   The teaser turned it around and they got what they needed.  
And THESE GUYS CREATED the original Descent and Descent 2!!  AND one of the best level creators back in the day is working with them to make really great places to combat rogue mining robots!
Their TEASER Looked more polished and played SO WELL, better than other attempts at Descent-Type play, it grabbed attention and has held it very well.  For new players and old Descent players alike it is thrilling nearly everyone.
EXCELLENT 3D, VR support, Multi-Platform (PC, Xbox One, PS4, LINUX!), and the game is now FAR MORE polished, better, and feels SO MUCH like playing Descent 2 with awesome graphics.  Ability to upgrade your ship in many areas, not just weapons.  When you destroy a robot ship it is VERY satisfying with parts scattering everywhere, smoke trailing many of those parts, great particle physics with sparks and flames and destruction!  You only have ONE life, but you have the ability to save early and often!  If one strategy doesn't work, reload and try again.  Many difficulty levels, many options for  YOUR preference of Keyboard, Mouse, Joystick or Console-type controller. and completely configurable keys and buttons.
The SOUNDS are fantastic, atmospheric graphics and sound really suck you into the scenes, good music, surround lets you know quickly something just came up behind you, and overall this has been done very very well.
There have been public demo releases, but the beta versions for Backers have been a joy to play.  They hit ANOTHER ONE outta the park!  
GET IT!  Back it!  Play it NOW.  Every update to the beta versions have introduced really nice changes and they are listening to the beta players finding bugs and requesting features.
It is all Single Player at this time.  But there are several modes, from Training, to Story mode, to Challenge Mode that has you fighting wave after wave of bots as long as you can stay alive in one of many different and really cool levels that cover many types of environments to play in.  One is mostly ICE!
When you go to www.playoverload.com you see the game played on the background... not just a little window, but the WHOLE browser background is actual game play.  (many scenes, not one session)  And you see exactly how it will look when you load it up!
This one is great for all Descent fans old and new.  There is little I can really complain about so far, except that I think the rock in tunnels dug by bots are a bit plain, but hey, it's just rock!  VERY minor.  They still might change that.
It's obvious I'm loving this game.  Loved Descent 1 & 2.... Descent 3 was Okay, but just okay, though it was fun too.
Overload takes the whole experience NOT to the Next level... but SEVERAL levels above!
(Multiplayer to be added as a FREE Update later in the year after the release.)
You will find This has a lot to offer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052162417', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 121054, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 159, 'playtime_at_review': 344, 'last_played': 1712113287}
review: As soon as I saw the intro into the level on how you enter the level, I immediately felt and flashed back to the days of Descent and Descent 2. As I played the game, I was feeling how I felt about Descent back in the 90s. I play Descent and Descent 2 still to this day using the port Dxx-Rebirth (D1x-Rebirth, D2x-Rebirth). Overload is everything Descent was and still is. To the creators of the original game and this game.... GLAD TO HAVE YOU BACK!

author: {'steamid': '76561198012423422', 'num_games_owned': 728, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 3601, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2455, 'last_played': 1607039770}
review: This is the Descent sequel I've been waiting for for decades, no holds barred. From the second I jumped into the first demo to the latest EA release I've had a grin on my face. The heft of the weapons, the satisfying rumble of robot explosions, the punch of the weapons, so many seemingly minor aesthetic details that make blasting baddies feel so fantastic. Easily one of my favorite Kickstarter projects, having more than gotten my money's worth from just what's available in the EA releases. Absolutely cannot wait for the proper final release and the level editor and multiplayer extras.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076677763', 'num_games_owned': 558, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 834, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 754, 'last_played': 1531717407}
review:
This game is absolutely amazing for the fact that it really feels like I'm back in Descent, but with cutting edge VR technology and current day graphics.

It's simply incredile. Smooth controls, lots of input options, well polished UI's for VR, an immersive feel, good enemy AI and a far more "complete" feel to the single player experience.
I holding fingers that this project continues, because I do look forward to playing a long, grueling solo campaign through as many levels as you can toss at me. Titan enemies (bosses) in large arenas could also be a plus to the current level-end "destroy the core" type mechanic.

A nice selection of weapons and missiles closely resembled to their original Descent counterparts.
Same goes for power-ups and game mechanics: flares, the way doors open, flight control, etc; everything is just plain Descent but with more modern and polished graphics.
I love the Play Challenges, especially the Countdown mode. Everyone who liked descent, thats the game for you.

Overall the game is great for VR and for non VR.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997420838', 'num_games_owned': 487, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 396, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 301, 'last_played': 1650173580}
review:
***EDIT: POST RELEASE UPDATE*** They knocked it out of the park! This game is great, and is a must play. Even more so if you have a VR headset. Everything I wrote below was refined and distilled into a great experience the 6DOF genre hasn't seen in a very, very long time. If I could thumbs it up more I would.

So I'm giving this a recommend, but under the pretense that you add this to your wishlist and keep an eye out for it when it comes out of early access. Everything about this game feels promising, from a gameplay and even development standpoint, but in it's current state it is a glorified, albiet very polished demo of sorts.

Everything from the music, to the graphics, to the ship handling, to ther weapons feels phenominal. 

Weapons have a certain "weight" to them and varies depending on which one you're using. They all feel like they have thier place and are balanced well against the enemy types.

The music is this mid 90's "Goldeneye-esque" sound that meshes well with the games atmosphere, especially considering it's a love letter to that era and the height of 6DOF games. 

The graphics are great, and are exactly what they need to be. Sort of inbetween old and new. Blocky enough to harken back to the old style, but with enough polish and pop to fit in with newer titles. Like the ships themselves look very much like that chunky classic design, but the lighting effects of the weapons and levels really stand out and look great,

Control-wise, even as a flightstick/gamepad player everything is responsive and smooth. All buttons and axes can be bound and rebound to whatever your heart desires. Your ship feels great to control and manouvering around obsticals and enemies is effortless once you get the hang of it, which isn't long. The control scheme and handling make it easy, especially if your used to flight/space sims or even FPS games.

Gameplay feels great, making use of the stay moving or die philosphy of old shooters. A lot of the challange comes from keeping tabs on your surroundings, your weapons, your energy and your enemies at the same time. Balancing booming and zooming, full on assaults, or retreating to replenish health/energy/weapons. All in all, the core of it is very satisfying to get a hang of and clearing out a horde of enemy ships all trained on you is very satisfying.

Again, as this is an early access "beta", there's not a lot in the way of game modes, and while maps and game types are still being added, what you have are some broken up story maps and survival modes. But if Revival stays the course and completes what they set out, what we'll have is one of the best 6DOF games in a long, long time.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982783917', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 5687, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3723, 'last_played': 1599647223}

author: {'steamid': '76561198115333904', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 1718, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 629, 'last_played': 1632821236}
review:
If you search for a true Descent sequel, this is it.
It¬¥s got the feel, looks and sound of the beloved old titles, built with current technology.

The +/- 

+ Very good level design
(As an early access backer i played some of the singleplayer missions in advance and was very pleased)
+ Nice and moody visuals/graphics
+ Sounddesign
+ Music
+ Controls
(a few easy to undestand adjustments in the options made my optimal control feel [m+k], idk about joysticks though)
+ AI of robots
(On harder difficulty they hide behind doors/corridors or hunt you down from different angles when in groups)
+ Adequate game pace/speed leads to entertaining action
+ New fun to use weapons in additions to many old ones

o Upgrade system is useful, but doesn¬¥t feel spectacular to me atm (Alpha 0.7)
o Multiplayer gets added a few months after official release (not before)
o Hostages are now rescue pods :/

- No editor yet
(I hope this is still planed/in the works. Player made levels and campaigns could keep this game alive for a long time)

update 27.11.2017:
It seems the editor is still in the plans, but some time after launch.

update 02.06.2018
An Editor program is confirmed. Aprox.2 months
Multiplayer is already available and a lot of fun.  ++
