author: {'steamid': '76561197999231543', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 36971, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 404, 'last_played': 1706291614}
review:
An outstanding 6-DOF festival, even in early access. As it stands, it is an excellent successor of Descent.

The game plays just like the original: Navigate 3D environments in a space ship, collect items and weapons to progress, blast robots to bits, and then blast the reactor to bits... oh, and escape, or you'll also be blown to bits.

The individual robots are very smart, especially in the challenge mode. They'll go and cut you off while you are running through a tight corridor, hunt you in packs, approach you from behind and grab you... The fights are really tense, especially on higher difficulties.

The graphics and the overall design is a win as well. The environments are detailed enough to be attractive, but simple enough to be navigated. The levels look distinct from each other, but a little bit of "same" feeling *may* be there, perhaps after a quite while of play time. I connect this issue to the state of the game right now, as there are not much levels yet... and these levels are very well played, I never felt bored in repeated playthroughs. In fact, their pace is so frantic, especially on higher difficulty challenge levels, that one doesn't think about graphics that much.

The individual robots can be recognized at a glance, and the damage system is ok (maybe you can dismember the bots, without destroying them? Imagine a bot, which has one arm destroyed and is also on fire, doing a kamikaze...). They feel quite different from each other: the little pesky ones, the big bad rocket platforms, the maniacal Shredder with its charge attack and distinct scream (which will be in my nightmares, along with a certain bot from the first Descent. You know which &%+ Wheeezer I'm talking about.). Excellent work.

The weapons are designed well so far, and they are very fun to use. They have distinct strengths and weaknesses, making them situational weapons: There is the starting laser, dealing low/moderate damage with moderate firing rate, a few shotgun-like guns using matter or energy for close quarters, a charging weapon that deals high damage with low refire, dumbfire missiles, homing missiles, missile pods that fire tons of missiles very rapidly, mines that are excellent for shooting around that corner, and that big one going with an extra-large kaboom. And there is yet to come (I'm sure they will be great and tested well, without being TOO annoying, right? RIGHT?? I'm looking at YOU, designer of those !&% HOMING FLASH MISSILES!!! My EYES man, HAVE MERCY! - Good programming, by the way). You can try each of them in challenge mode, where you are dealt with different weapons each time you start a new game...

Speaking of weapons, you can also "Bump" into the robots, like a melee attack. You can finish off weakly arnored bots like this. You can also use this to gain an additional boost as you are boosting. One thing, however, this bumping "locks" into the nearby enemies, which isn't good if you are trying to dodge them - you get smashed right into them instead, sometimes with additional bots surrounding you. I'd like an option at the very least, to turn this locking feature off, we can smash our way without it.

One thing I noticed that the environment doesn't get damaged...  Granted, we're in early access, so this aspect might be added later. Still, I looked for destroyable screens everywhere...

The interface is great, you can tell your ship's status at a glance. Only a minor alteration I'd suggest, maybe a bit larger fonts, especially for the central armor counter near the reticle... It is somewhat hard to read :)

EDIT, 20.03.2017: Re-reading this, I realize I forgot a major part out: The sound and the music, and both are over the top. The sound design is fantastic: the weapons sound deadly, and the robots sound even deadlier. The only nuisance was the automap on/off effect, it sounded a little too close to an actual robot hunting you...

But the most shining thing in this game is the music, with the one in the 4th challenge map (Centrifuge) being my favorite. In fact, I played that challenge map over and over, just to keep listening it :).

Overall, the minds behind the game are putting up an excellent job. It is expected, since it is a team of veterans, the creators of the original game(s), as well as great mission sets for those games. I'm confident that they will keep up the good work, and I cannot wait for the rest of this game's development... especially THAT level editor!

I recommend this game with confidence in this team. Godspeed, Revival productions!

author: {'steamid': '76561198015705329', 'num_games_owned': 1671, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 218, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 36, 'last_played': 1604570638}
review:
Ich habe das Spiel gebacked und war hin und her gerissen. Potential f√ºr ein tolles Spiel, aber beim Backen kann immer was schief gehen und wie viele vielversprechende Spiele wurden eingestellt, oder verbugged und supportlos auf die Spielerwelt losgelassen.

Nun in diesem Fall hat es sich gelohnt! Als Descent Fan der ersten Stunde - ja ich bin so alt ;) -  muss ich sagen: sehr, sehr geil!

Die Stimmung kommt sofort wieder auf, enge G√§nge, verwinkelte Maps und Horden von Gegnern. 

Grafik: gef√§llt! L√§uft maximiert sehr fl√ºssig in WQHD unabh√§ngig von Gegnerhorden und Strahlengewitter (i7 3770K @ 4,3 GHz, GTX 1070). Die Optik gef√§llt und passt zum Setting.  Licht- und Partikeleffekte passen auch.

Steuerung:
mit Maus und Tastatur ist recht pr√§zise mit dem Abstrich, dass das Wechseln der Ausrichtung und das Wechseln der Bewaffnung/Raketen nat√ºrlich nicht ganz so intuitiv ist. Aber das Ausrichten der eigenen Position und Optik ist definitiv einfacher als in den alten Teilen.
Mit XBOX 360 Controller funktioniert das Spiel fabelhaft. Die Steuerung ist absolut intuitiv! Links- und Rechtsrolle, Steigen und Sinken, Weapon Slot und Raketen durchschalten bzw. beides einsetzen. Super!

Mir gef√§llt sehr gut, dass wenn man ann√§hernd parallel zum Untergrund ist, sich das Schiff selbst ausrichtet, das macht den Verwirr-Faktor wesentlich geringer und erleichtert die Navigation durch die Level

Soundeffekte und Musik: Sounds passen, Musik war auch da :D Die Hintergrundbeschallung ist mir im Kampf-Stress weder positiv noch negativ aufgefallen unn das reicht. :)

Spielmodi: 
Kampagne: Das erste der Level der Kampagne ist noch √ºberschaubar von der Gr√∂√üe, anfangs √ºbersichtlich und dann ziemlich verwinkelt. Wenn man glaub, man hat es ges√§ubert, kommt doch noch von irgendwo ein versteckter Gegner vor. Macht absolut Spa√ü.
Challenge: Endlosgegnerdeathmatch in verschiedenen Maps mit Leaderboard. Mir gef√§llts, eignet sich auch gut um den Kampf gegen √úberzahl zu trainieren und verschiedene Waffen zu testen.

Zuerst hatte ich die freie Demo angespielt, da schwante mir schon √úbles. Diese Early Access Version hat bereits alle meine Zweifel weggewischt! F√ºr Fans der Descentserie oder schneller, verwirrender Shooter absolut empfehlenswert! Bis das Spiel mit Kampagne ver√∂ffentlicht wird, werde ich mir die Zeit im Challengemode vertreiben. Man sieht sich auf der Rangliste... ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561198020391437', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 1600, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 739, 'last_played': 1694587152}
review:
This game is absolutely great so far. Made by the original creators of the Descent games of the 90's, you get exactly what you would expect from these stalwart developers. Well designed, tight, beautiful environments. Engaging and robust AI. Interesting and varied enemy types with a spectacular design that is both classic and modern. Great audio and sound design, and stunning new graphics that ensnare and captivate the auditory and visual senses. All that and their classic, pristine Six Degrees-of-Freedom movement system that made their previous games some of the best games of the 90's. Combat is as challenging as ever with more enemy types than the playable teaser and demos. Giving you an invigorating experience as you attempt to fly through superbly designed, tightly packed caverns and beautifully simplistic star base styled rooms. All while trying to dominate a wide variety intense robotic enemies that have a very challenging and sinister AI at higher levels of difficulty.

The UI is smooth and clean. Power-ups and weapons have simple yet nicely designed meshes and textures, that fit the world space and overall game design very well. The controls are fantastic and fit in with all their previous classics; They are quick and easy to learn and will have you flying through the "Labyrinth" of level design with precision in no time.

The only problem that I even have with the game is that it did not get its full release this month. However that being said I am truly grateful they decided to release it as an early access game for the time being, giving everyone a chance to experience the wonderment this game has to offer. Plus I would much rather have a game months from now that is complete and well thought out than get a game that released too early with game breaking day one bugs and the feeling of incompleteness that plagues so many of the modern games released currently.

This game will not immediately seem engaging to everyone. It is not an open world game like so many of the other games of the modern  day. It won't have huge numbers of side quests(which is good in my opinion as so many modern side quests are useless fetch quests.) It is a classic arena styled game with simple objectives. In comparison to all other contenders of 6 DOF this one in my opinion shines out among the many for its precise controls, engaging game play, and well thought out design. I would recommend this to anyone looking for a good arena flight game as it definitely rings out among the rest. Give it a try and stick with it for an hour to get comfortable with the controls and I guarantee you will be having a blast for hours to come.

Pros:
‚Ä¢	Smooth Classic Controls
‚Ä¢	Engaging Compact Level Design
‚Ä¢	Superb AI
‚Ä¢	Great Sound Design and Visuals
‚Ä¢	Menacing Robot Design
‚Ä¢	The Classic 6 DOF Shooter
‚Ä¢	I Was Given Early Access Free as a Backer(Subjective as it only applies to me)

Cons:
‚Ä¢	It isn't a full release
‚Ä¢	Splash Damage feels like it needs an increase for some weapons and with some enemy types
‚Ä¢	Damage from some enemies feels like it needs more balancing on higher difficulties
‚Ä¢	Some super robots feel far less menacing than the heavily armored robots, ie they don't feel quite as super as I expected

I will continue to update this review as the game progresses through early access, on it's full release and have a final update with the release of multiplayer. Hope you enjoy the game as much as I do and thanks for reading my review!

EDIT: I was going to continue to update this review but I have pretty summed it up here. The only thing I can say is it continues to get better with every update. The Challenge Mode continues to get new invigorating levels and the bots feel far more balanced than in the early release and updates. The story missions released are engaging and fun, with the classic style of Descent gameplay taken to a whole new level of visual prowess. This definitely is a "Revival" of Descent that's been "Overload"ed with tighter controls, more challenge, better graphical fidelity, and the best small team Indie Developement can hope for powering it to the new generation. This is Early Access done right. Can't wait for the full release and see the full potential this game has to offer. All hail the "Revival!"

author: {'steamid': '76561198372223797', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 50, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9, 'last_played': 1491052733}

Gerne haben wir auch im lokalen Multiplayer eine Karte gespielt an welche ich mich leider namentlich nicht mehr 100%ig erinnere, ich meine aber sie hie√ü "Heavy Artillery" oder √§hnlich. Dort haben wir uns so manche Stunden aufgehalten.

Ansonsten ist alles dabei was dabei sein muss: Gute Musik, Spielspa√ü, die "Taschenlampe", Geheimg√§nge, und und und.

author: {'steamid': '76561198137345097', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 4832, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 47, 'last_played': 1549314081}
review:
5/5

OVERLOAD represents a return to form for REVIVAL Productions, composed of those who created a series of games that served as Overloads' spiritual predecessor - The DESCENT series of games. Overload taps into the best of each Descent title, and the team more than manages to create a new experience (the rights to the Descent name and content are, shall we say - messy) that is fully their own (notwithstanding their publishing deal with EA).

Games such as the new DOOM combine conteporary trimmings with oft-overlooked aspects that made games of yesteryear historical gems. Overload does this in spades in honoring Descent, with fast-paced gameplay, winding levels, and a plethora of weapons and enemies that are uniquely distinct and NOT generic. Wyverns are elusive critters, while bladed 'Shredders' charge at you with alarming regularity. Most bots go down easily, though in Challenge mode you'll encounter rarer 'Super' versions of these robots - an RPG convention that fits in well with Overload's action to keep you on your toes. Well, your WINGS - you're flying after all!

The levels are beautifully crafted, and even the few environments we've seen thus far feature much in the way of variety, while tying the game together as a whole thematically. I can't wait to see what other locales we'll visit - acid, ice, and even overgrown batthegrounds are all ripe for possibility. In traiditonal single-player sense, you're required to find a reactor, destory and thus 'overload' it and the mine, and escape with your life out of the exit. A tried and true callback to the original Descent games that never gets old since each reactor encounter has different, alternate and increasingly tough challenges and puzzles per map to ensure things remain changed up.

If you're a fan of FPS, flight sims, and even RPG's, you'll wanna check out Overload. And you're going to enjoy the ride.

author: {'steamid': '76561198094912019', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 74748, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20, 'last_played': 1617507365}
review:
As if the teaser weren't enough already, now the dev's have given us thias beauty of Overload in EA, and I could not be more pleased. Gameplay is fluid and dynamic, simple and yet challenging. It's everything we've been wanting from 6DOF games, and now it is closer than ever to coming to fruition. 

If you yearn for the haydays of 6DOF, this game is for you.
If you played Descent 1, 2, or 3, and loved it (it MADE my childhood), this game is for you. 
If you like space shooters, this game is likely for you. 
If you appreciate Dev's that actually care about their customers/fans, this game is for you. 

I cannot think of one single complaint about the game. My only hope is that somehow the orginal Descent 1 & 2 engines could be run through Overload.....

....oh, a boy can dream.....

10/10 game (esp. for EA). 

Congrats is in order to the dev team and the testers/backers who made this possible. Us old descenters owe you all a great deal of thanks :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197998648266', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1754, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 274, 'last_played': 1569897665}
review:
Being in early access, the full content of the game is not available at the moment. Right now there is training, a demo level, and a few challenges. If you buy now challenges is what you will be spending most of your time doing. 

For the challenges there are 2 modes, countdown and infinite. They are fairly similar, the one big difference being you die at the end of 5 minutes on countdown if you haven't blown up yet. There are 4 maps, each have some slightly different enemy sets I think. The maps are just about the right size- not so big that you will get lost, but large enough you feel like you have somewhere you can run too. There are also 4 difficulty levels and an additional level (Insane) that can be unlocked. Each of the challenge modes gets more difficult as time goes on - so with time even the lowest difficulty rookie mode becomes tough. You will see your score up on the global leader boards at the end of the challenge, as well as a summary of the enemies you killed, etc.

While there isn't many levels to play everything else feels like a finished game rather than something in early access. The levels, enemies, and attacks all look and sound great. It could use some changes to the default XBOX controller layout (the fire gun and missile buttons are right bumper and right trigger so you can only fire one at a time), but you can change them to your liking. You will most likely have to change the sensitivity of your mouse, but the mouse and keyboard default setup feels natural otherwise.

Overall the game doesn't have a ton of content at the moment, but it has the polish of a finished game. Releasing the challenge mode first though was a excellent idea, since they have great replayability for a small amount of content. Overload at the moment isn't worth the full price quite yet (unless you are a fan of Descent or similar games), but the full game seems like it will be easily worth $25 once completed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198214083392', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 25949, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 587, 'last_played': 1583663780}
review:
Overload is a game in the "6 degree of freedom" (6dof) genre. If you are not familiar with these types of games, this is a perfect introduction. Made by the creators of the most famous 6dof game of all time (Descent) but updating for modern hardware.

If you are a descent fan looking for a real 6dof experience, look no further!
If you are not familiar with 6dof games, prepare yourself for a truly unique experience and give this a try! There is also a free "playable teaser" you can download if you want to experience the game before deciding on early access.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971251537', 'num_games_owned': 993, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 4008, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 107, 'last_played': 1616591263}
review:
This game is essentially Descent 4, written by the same core team that did the first two games in the series. Therefore it plays and feels exactly like Descent brought up to date; great feeling, insane dogfights in mines against smart AI robots. It's not called Descent because someone else has the license now, but you wouldn't know it.

Although it feels highly polished and bug free, it's basically limited in content right now. There's a full single player campaign coming, but there's only a single example level available right now. The rest is single-player challenge mode: four maps against waves of bots, with leaderboards. It's all enormous fun and feels "complete", but it's only a taste of the final game. There's even a free Playable Teaser available which contains quite a bit of this initial Early Access release, so if you're on the fence perhaps try that first, but the devs are working on this now with content drops planned each month, so the difference will soon become highly apparent.

Buying Early Access can be risky. Will they deliver? Well, these are veteran devs with decades of industry experience (and the brains behind some of my favourite games). They clearly know how to manage a project, and so far they're on track albeit slightly behind the original schedule. I have complete faith. Oh, and this is very much single player only, although multiplayer is coming after the final full release. If you buy this now you're getting the very playable, solid foundations of the next great "Descent" game, but its full value is yet to come.

I'll update this review as the updates come in.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969898245', 'num_games_owned': 586, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 360, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 360, 'last_played': 1528169967}
review:
A polished, pitch-perfect recreation of everything I loved about Descent.

The term "spiritual successor" can be pretty loosely defined, but let's get one thing straight: This is Descent 4 in all but name. Even better, it goes back to the template laid out by the first two Descent games, and captures the dense, labyrinthine level design packed with secrets, as well as the floaty, cramped zero-g combat. Even the visual design and sountrack are instantly recognizable throwbacks despite the added sheen. 

But this controls better than old-school Descent ever did, and the move to a modern control pad feels great. There are some added story elements, as well as an upgrade system, and some polish to the overall feel, but all of it feels like it fits with the old school, level-based formula, which hasn't been altered. 

On a negative note, the VR implementation seems to suffer from performance issues that force it to run in a reduced framerate with reprojection. I find it unusable. Don't buy this for VR, at least not right now.

Despite that, this game gets an enthusiastic reservation from me. It's old-school 6DOF fun, and probably the best game I've played in the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979888518', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 650, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 174, 'last_played': 1617676790}
review:
3/13/2017  Early review: if you liked Descent 1/2, then definitely get this, the game is coming along great! I haven't said a game was AWESOME in a really long time until today.  It's early access, so content is still light.   Vive/Oculus support is still in early stages.  

GRAPHICS:  Clean and immersive, the shadows/lighting are especially great and a big part of the game!

SOUND: Music is fitting and enhances the atmosphere, sound effects are very good so far!  Wear headphones!

PERFORMANCE:  On my laptop GTX 970m i7-6700hq it runs great with settings turned down but still really looks great!  Might have difficulty running on anything older than a GTX 760?

GAMEPLAY:  Action, suspense, and explosions!  AI is fun to play against (it better it's only singleplayer for now)

CONTROLS: If you have never played a game like this it might taking some getting used to, it feels great when you get the hang of it though!  

TLDR: Game is looking awesome and developers seem to be doing the series justice, support them!

author: {'steamid': '76561197962745040', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 272, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 66, 'last_played': 1566540260}

author: {'steamid': '76561197993654912', 'num_games_owned': 334, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1860, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 216, 'last_played': 1689077431}
review:
It's Descent. If you played Descent when you were younger, it's back, proper.
Designers for the original Descents have made a proper spiritual continuation, it looks and plays exactly as it should; you smash panels and parts off repurposed mining robots until they go fireworks, while they try to extract the meaty bit from your ships metal shell using various methods.

The controls are intuitive, the momentum physics behave as you would expect, the weapons have a solid feel to them (even the frickin laser beams) and each connecting hit gives a physics reaction and a pretty light show as reward.
The sound is great, the baddies sound suitably demonically possessed, the lighting is a real treat, accurate realtime shadows (something of a rarity these days for some reason) are on full display and it all sits together in a surprisingly atmospheric package.

You still get as disorientated as the original Descents and the screen fills with carnage quickly, but that's a positive in this reviewer's book. It may be early access, but these developers have actual pedigree and an impressive work ethic, if you genuinely enjoy a 6DOFFPS, you won't regret the purchase.

[i]Mostly copy-and-pasted from the earlier playable teaser review, all points still stand. Reposted again because of a misunderstanding of the concept of 'free' and its relation to Kickstarter.[/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561198262061260', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 11510, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 784, 'last_played': 1622905234}
review:
In case anybody thinks it's relevant, I backed this game on Kickstarter. In any event, Overload is shaping up to be a fantastic spiritual successor to the Descent series. I play with mouse and keyboard, and the flight feels exactly right once I turn off mouse smoothing, turn mouse limiting to strong, and enable full trichording by pushing F8 in-game.

Right now there's a training mission, a campaign-style mission (blow up the reactor and get out!), two challenge modes across four extremely well-designed maps, and several highly-varied weapons and bots. They've also introduced a new physical smash attack, and there's no more badass feeling than smashing a superbot to scrap metal. There are five difficulty levels, with separate leaderboards for each, and the most difficult must be unlocked for each map; this challenge is sure to keep you coming back if you're the competitive type.

It's worth highlighting the variety of even just the four maps and weapons -- one map is bright with relatively open spaces, another is arranged in a geometric pattern of tunnels and medium-sized rooms, and the other two are full of dark, foreboding tunnels. Because of the different spaces and lighting, each map encourages the use of different weapons and tactics -- the Reflex Cannon probably won't be your first choice on open Syrinx, but it bounces around in deadly fashion in the narrow tunnels of Labyrinth and Caverns.

The development team is also using dynamic lighting throughout each map. This choice gives the darker maps an exquisitely creepy atmosphere, as you can see the bots' headlights growing more intense on the wall around a corner as they draw near.

The bots themselves are diverse and interactive. They have a variety of behaviors, from swarming and chasing to running to (as far as I can tell!) predicting your escape and trying to cut you off. They're extremely satisfying to hit and blow up, as they get knocked back, lose pieces of debris, and exhibit a variety of explosions. Above all, they're *tough*! 

To top it all off, they're supporting Linux natively, and the game runs fantastically on my Arch Linux machine with an I5 processor and GTX 750 Ti GPU with proprietary drivers.

I've experienced one downside to playing: after a while, my eyes start to water because this game is so intense that I just. don't. blink. Play this game now, and thank Revival later.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993204205', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 969, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 36, 'last_played': 1544933266}
review: This game is a dream come true for an old Descent addict. If you ever loved Descent, you're going to love this. It's exactly what you want it to be.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972340172', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 100946, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14385, 'last_played': 1703477045}
review:
I'll preface this review as I usually do - with an acknowledgement of the effort's rarity.  I almost never write reviews, and the few that do exist are in response to the creation of games that reach the highest pinnacle of worth.

I could expound without end upon the quality of work they've produced, here.  Anyone remotely familiar with the concept of 6DoF shooters knows what they're in for.  And if you already played any of the Descent games in your younger years, then... well, let's face it - that's most likely why you're here in the first place.  No need to read any more of my words.  Go get your fix.

For those new to the genre, the game concept is simple.  It hearkens back to the original Doom/Quake model (and Descent model) where you need keys to open doors to progress to the next area of the level, with occasional boss mobs or hard-to-find treasures mixed in.  Where the real challenge comes in is in the controls and the lack of gravity or an up/down.  At this stage, the videos included with the game can portray it a lot better than I can.  Just know that, as the devs who made this are the same who brought us Descent, you're in very good hands.  Very.  Good.  Hands.

The result of Revival's efforts, a fast-paced zero-G first-person shooter worthy of the genre, has delivered all that you could ever hope for in a spiritual successor to Descent and more.  The only feature missing that some may lament the loss of is co-op play.  Everything else from the originals is here, along with the addition of Challenge Mode, an extra gameplay mechanic that quite a few Overload players have embraced and enjoyed.  Graphics, sound, music, gameplay, controls support, VR support, and developer support are all top-notch.  The price is reasonable, and the resultant product is a significant value.  A free level editor is on the way, there's already talk of recreating favorite multiplayer content, and there's even been experiments with porting some of the original content from Descent 1 and 2 into the Overload engine.  See the 12-hour launch day live stream on Twitch for examples of this in action.

If you enjoyed any of the Descent games, there is no question that you will enjoy this.  If you enjoy games that require a higher than normal degree of skill to master, this will do nicely.  And if you enjoy a mulitplayer experience with a lot more head games, prediction, chaos, and memorable moments, look no further.

review:
So, first things first I am a Kickstarter backer so got my EA key from there. 

That out the road, Overload so far is a heck of a lot of fun. Feels very strongly like Descent of old, be it playing with joystick with a hat or using just keyboard and mouse. Its slick and fluid.

The challenge mode is incredinly intense, zipping around trying to find energy and shields as your being swarmed more and more by bots. (As more and more come along firing, plus your own shots the frame rate does occasionally take a bit of a hit - though I do have ligh shafts on).

I backed for 35$ to get the game and the soundtrack, and so far, its been worth every penny. (Although if your like me remember to turn off auto-level and invert the Y axis :) )

author: {'steamid': '76561197974957459', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 1919, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1535, 'last_played': 1709364117}
review:
Overload is the closest I've seen to something that really feels like a Descent successor. While it's not a perfect game, and the multiplayer component in particular is disappointing compared to the best that Descent 2 offered (mainly thanks to the enormous variety of community-made maps it received), the single player and challenge modes are all incredibly fun. It's also one of the best seated VR games I've played; it's up there with Elite Dangerous and Thumper.

Revival Productions went above and beyond with their development efforts on this game and I really hope it paid off for them. Throughout the Kickstarter alpha period and Early Access they were quick to respond to feedback and even made the effort to port the game not only to Mac but also Linux. They also included custom support for many niche input devices as well as VR, something few developers put in the effort for.

Don't be scared off by that Unity logo. Unity gets a bad reputation because it's free and and it's easy for first-timers to work with, which results in a lot of very amateurish products being made with it. In the hands of a talented developer it's capable of amazing things, and Overload is a showcase of Unity at its best. It's a beautiful game that performs well on a wide variety of hardware, though Unity's famous engine inefficiency does keep it from performing as well as I'd like with the highest settings. It's a challenge to keep a steady 120+ FPS even on a 1080 Ti and overclocked i7-4790K. My ageing CPU is probably the limiting factor there. Unreal or a custom in-house engine might've alleviated this, but would've likely also added unrealistic cost and time to what I imagine was already a lean development cycle considering the game barely met its minimum Kickstarter funding goal.

I highly recommend Overload to anyone looking for a quality game in the nearly abandoned 6DOF shooter genre.

(my key came from backing the game's Kickstarter campaign)

author: {'steamid': '76561197971966779', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 5650, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2685, 'last_played': 1706803430}
review:
Kickstarter games often don't live up to their promise. If there is ever a grand list of exceptions - this should be on it. 

The original Descent games transformed my perception of what an action game could be. They expertly avoided pitfalls of modern games - the pacing was dramatic, the tension was visceral and the atmosphere sublimly chilly. Overload, in everything but the name, is a Descent game made by the original developers to be a modern interpretation of the Descent franchise. Everything that made the original games great is here, and in a time where stagnation is prevalent, the laser focused design of this game makes for a very refreshing experience. 

Most surprisingly, to me, is that after all these years of playing a Descent game with a joystick I never thought I would be say this but here it is: 

This title has such good mouse control that you don't need to bother with anything else. 

This is a stellar achievement by the development team. The joystick was one the reasons the originals didn't become quite as ubiquitous as the likes of Doom/Quake. This is no longer the case!

Strongly recommend that you support these developers early on. As a backer I can verify that they have met every milestone and contiually updated the community - they have been very professional and have provided realistic timelines for deliverables - which gives me great confidence that the final product will be delivered in its entirety by the end of 2017. 

Here's to Revival Productions and their excellent work!

author: {'steamid': '76561197976812284', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 206, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 105, 'last_played': 1569137625}
review:
I accidently found out about this game yesterday when I clicked accidently on the Descent news on Steam.

So........I played this for 20 mins. Thats all I needed. Actually going through the training level is all I needed. This game is EXACTLY what I wanted in a Descent game. Such a simple formula, which I've never seen perfectly replicated by any other publisher. After nearly 20 years of waiting.......... all I can say is it felt like I went straight back in time to 1996. Descent 2 was one of the first PC games I ever played, I loved it then and still love it now. I hoped that Descent Underground would be able to bring back that feeling of nostalgia but they have failed. When I saw that the original creators were involed in this.....what seems as a spiritual successor to the Descent series, well all I can say is that I've been sitting in front of my PC waiting for this to unlock early access. I don't regret waiting. First time ever I haven't regretted paying for early access to a game, even though it is just one demo level. You can tell straight away that this game has the original creators fingerprints all over it. 

Pros:
The fluidity of movement (if you're Descent fanboy like me you muscle memory will kick in split seconds), 
the electronic soundtrack (which you think wouldn't be an influence but for me its a big deal), 
gameplay itself hasn't change from the originals which makes it so good. 
Visuals are pristine, 
AI, holy sh*t! first time I actually felt like I was being hunted. Very few games I've played where I  actually had to flee for my life.

Cons: (there are some which are minor, really not worth mentioning
Is there a guidebot?

Thats it, if you've read this far my question to you is, why are you still reading and not purchased? And this is coming from someone who is firmly opposed against purchasing early access, DLC, season pass which are blatant cash grabs.

To the creators, you made a mid 30's gamer feel like a teenager again. I'm home! Thank you very much! :)

P.S. I come back from time to time to see if there is any updates which there has been. So I played the second or third level. Yep, did nearly jump out of my seat when I pretty much flew straight into a trap. And another addition to the game which brought a smaile to my face: When exiting it has a little cutscene like the original Descent of you flying out of an exploding tunnel. HAHAHA nice work boys. I'd laugh if your character is called defender of material. THIS IS DESCENT 4

author: {'steamid': '76561197969308510', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 61, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 38, 'last_played': 1501311134}
review:
A faithful recreation of Descent with VR to boot.

I'd played the demo a while back and was eagerly awaiting this to launch on early access. Now that it has I'm quite happy with what I see so far. As with anything you jump on board with this early it's lacking content but the game itself seems quite polished.

So what's the bad? Mouse sensitivity was way too extreme for me, I had to set it all the way down to get anything remotely playable. Was glad to see my expected keyboard/mouse binds were all in the familiar places though.

What's the good? Holy hell was the the intense VR experience that 10 year old me dreamed of when he heard the original Descent had VR back in the 90s. Explosions in your face, rockets and lazers flying everywhere. It's epic! I was afraid I would get mad motion sickness from it but I pulled up reasonably well. Not for those susceptable to VR sickness though.

Overall this is one I'll be watching closely throughout it's early access period waiting for a full campaign to land.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974247760', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 12902, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1064, 'last_played': 1541111589}
review: Prepare for Overload! The original creators of Descent are back, and ready to send you into another pulse pounding experience where your senses are in, well, overload! This spiritual successor brings that classic gameplay into the modern age and is the only 6DOF to truly give you the same feeling as Descent. The bots are menacing looking and sounding, are ruthless, their AI a true modern evolution for the 6DOF genre. The weapons are varied and gives a nice feedback for use. You'll see some old favorites with a modern edge and some all new concepts. The lighting is excellent and the music is phenominal. If you've played the free playable teaser for Overload before, then consider that just a "sample" of what's in this. Everything about the game contributes to your immersion and to the fun you'll have. The Early Access is starting and it's already blowing it out of the park. The completed game will have a full single player campaign by the writer of Freespace 2, and a multiplayer expansion will be coming about 6-8 months after that. The game already has a sample mission, as well as Challenge Mode, a veritable gauntlet of merciless bots coming after you wave after wave. Do you have what it takes to survive? Well strap in and hold on tight, this is gonna be a wild ride and you're going to love it every step of the way.
